Title: An Angel at My¬†Table
Text:
Based on the autobiographical work of New Zealand writer Janet Frame, this production depicts the author at various stage of her life. Afflicted with mental and emotional issues, Frame grows up in an impoverished family and experiences numerous tragedies while still in her youth, including the deaths of two of her siblings. Portrayed as an adult by Kerry Fox, Frame finds acclaim for her writing while still in a mental institution, and her success helps her move on with her¬†life. √ó
["I think I have decided that the times when suspension of disbelief makes a fool of me are amazing. This happens every so often, and fortunately, it only happens in my head (up until now, I haven't really admitted this to anyone, though perhaps some have guessed at my thoughts). Sometimes, when I am watching a movie (or a television show, or reading a book, etc.), I get so caught up in it that a thought will cross my mind that I will later realize was utterly idiotic, usually in some sort of in between place between being wrapped up in the film and knowing that it is a film.

Title: Dopesick
Text:
The story of how one company triggered the worst drug epidemic in American history. Look into the epicenter of America‚Äôs struggle with opioid addiction, from a distressed Virginia mining community, to the hallways of the DEA, and to the opulence of ‚Äúone percenter‚Äù Big Pharma¬†Manhattan.
['All it\'s missing is a scene with Mark Ruffalo angrily slamming down papers and yelling, "They knew!"', 'Will Poulter and Michael Keaton sharing scenes makes for great drama as two of the greatest eyebrow actors of their respective generations.', "It speaks volumes about an actor's talent that he can impact an audience by playing two characters that couldn't be more different. On the one hand you have Stuhlbarg as one of the best fathers in film history, and on the other you have him playing a male/probable father version of Elizabeth Holmes. Sometimes I wasn't sure if Sackler was actually speaking that way or if it was all satire, but either way I just had a ball.\nWhat is not funny but is quite informative is the overall series, which provides us a glimpse inside the opioid crisis, which was largely sparked by Oxycontin, a drug that has become more infamous in recent years because of such shows as‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: Multiple¬†Maniacs
Text:

["Imagine seeing this only a few months after Watson and company were arrested for the Tate-LaBianca murders. If you want, replace that with more recent murders to get a sense of how scandalous, how tasteless, how tacky this was. Add to that the idea of John Waters doing anything depicting Jesus Christ (with Edith Massey as the Virgin Mary) intercut with Divine being fucked with a rosary. Include bicycle seat-sniffing, vomit-eating, and a brazen mockery of 1970s values and views on homosexuality and normalcy. Film it with little regard to convention, a mixture of awkward and inventive camera angles, and performances that drip with histrionics. And then, there's a lobster.\nI've written before about how Waters' films tend show more‚Ä¶ \nmore", '"And then, to my horror and amazement, the Infant of Prague appeared before me! Title: Hoop¬†Dreams
Text:
Every school day, African-American teenagers William Gates and Arthur Agee travel 90 minutes each way from inner-city Chicago to St. Joseph High School in Westchester, Illinois, a predominately white suburban school well-known for the excellence of its basketball program. Gates and Agee dream of NBA stardom, and with the support of their close-knit families, they battle the social and physical obstacles that stand in their way. This acclaimed documentary was shot over the course of five¬†years. √ó
['"If I don't make it, don't you forget about me."
At once a class-conscious procedural of the American dream (its genuine allure vs. the abuse of young bodies needed to sustain it) and a richly detailed portrait of the emotional lives of human beings that would otherwise be treated like statistics. One of the most intimate studies of the economic realities of this system and the people most preyed upon/left behind by it. Every shot of Curtis watching his little brother fuck up a play is heartbreaking, nobody is more aware of the personal stakes of William not making it than he is. Shoutout to Spike Lee who shows up for 30 seconds in the middle of the film to‚Ä¶ 
more', "the great lies of the american dream: that we all are born at the same starting line in the race to the top, that it's possible for one to achieve success without the help of encouraging adults working at thankless jobs, that you don't have to sell a part of your soul to get it. victory and happiness are so, so fragile.", 'Impressively, this did not feel like a 3 hour movie. Though its initial intended medium of television is somewhat evident in the look of it, that really adds a journalistic air to it that is fitting. It still looks good; it just also looks like public television sometimes.
What struck me most while watching this was the implication that the best way these kids saw for improving their lives was to escape the places they were from. While I share almost nothing with these kids in terms of where I come from or how I grew up, I did share that need to find a way out of where I was from. Though I had a decent family, small town‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Viridiana
Text:
Viridiana is preparing to start her life as a nun when she is sent, somewhat unwillingly, to visit her aging uncle, Don Jaime. He supports her; but the two have met only once. Jaime thinks Viridiana resembles his dead wife. Viridiana has secretly despised this man all her life and finds her worst fears proven when Jaime grows determined to seduce his pure niece. Viridiana becomes undone as her uncle upends the plans she had made to join the¬†convent.
['Viridiana isn't a good person. She's barely a person. She may seem virtuous and humble but at the core there's a self-righteousness that's prideful and disgusting. Bunuel was a known Anti-Catholic. It's not in the subtext but in the overtures. At the surface, Viridiana is about a nun falling from the grace of God, but it's the characters around her who are pure. While Viridiana is busy isolating her thoughts, human animals are living in God's image. Unnecessary Shame compels her to divorce from the calling she once held sacred. Her "charity" is the beginning of her own undoing.
The beggars are heart of this film. They aren't good, they aren't bad, they just are. Humans doing as humans do.‚Ä¶ 
more', "i think he don't really like the rich and religion i'm not sure", 'Catching Up with Bu√±uel
"I went through a great shock, I am only trying to recover."
Such a deeply cynical film that you can feel Bu√±uel's hatred for the fascist Franco dictatorship in the very texture of every frame. The world itself is a test of Viridiana's faith, continually confronting her with the darkest depths of humanity's sinful depravity, rewarding her conviction with nothing but more hardship, asking at every turn, "What about now? Do you still believe?" How is anyone supposed to have faith in such a corrupt and twisted world? The infamous dinner party scene becomes a microcosm of Spain's political environs: the bourgeois fascist state is a juvenile food fight where the guests have no respect for the house, where they trash the place, stuff their faces, and fuck in the corner, destroying everything in their irreverent bacchanalia. 
"I was so happy‚Ä¶ You ruined everything."
Luis Bu√±uel']

Title: Homework
Text:
Young male students at a local Iranian school are asked about their feelings on¬†homework.
['each of these kids are quick to associate abuse with the word punishment, but when they hear the word encouragement, their eyes are blank. and yet, the ending tells us that encouragement is passed between them. even though in most cases adults are not expressing encouragement or support, they have found it with each other. it doesn‚Äôt need to be taught. the act exists without knowing the definition. it‚Äôs something that is present underneath so much of kiarostami‚Äôs work ‚Äì a silent trust.
homework
 proposed a slightly new definition of encouragement: allowing your fear to subside when in the presence of someone that sees you. the strength you gain from just being in the same room as someone that protects and loves you.', 'Somebody be the Molaei to my Majid, please.', 'HOMEWORK is a hurricane of devastation from my man Abbas. This thing is pretty heavy and uncomfortable and explicitly sad. For 86min we listen to interview after interview of children describing the burden of homework, the abuse they face at home and school, and the lack of positive reinforcement that would otherwise buttress their academic confidence.\xa0
Behind their words a deeper story is being told. A story about a problematic national mentality, one that normalizes abuse and grooms a future generation for letdown and punishment.\xa0
The most interesting thing about the doc is how transparent the camera and film crew are in probing the parent-child/teacher-student relationship. The presence of the camera does something to the way these kids respond, almost‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The History of¬†Sound
Text:

['decent as a (very) muted romance, much louder and more effective as an argument for physical archival media.', 'Not perfect, but just depressing enough to ruin my week', 'this is a sign to stop summoning the same six white dudes to do these sad gay romance movies once a year like it‚Äôs jury duty']

Title: The Chronicles of¬†Riddick
Text:
After years of outrunning ruthless bounty hunters, escaped convict Riddick suddenly finds himself caught between opposing forces in a fight for the future of the human race. Now, waging incredible battles on fantastic and deadly worlds, this lone, reluctant hero will emerge as humanity‚Äôs champion - and the last hope for a universe on the edge of¬†annihilation.
['"Look at you. All back of the bus and shit."
One of the dorkiest, most conceptually tin-eared things ever, sort of a bro'd out Edgar Rice Burroughs. But hell if it isn't committed, and at least it has the good sense to be both relentlessly happening at you and bafflingly stupid, not to mention the killer final moments. Burns through plot like a gas explosion, and absolutely bursts with esoteric design and outlandish characters; there's a massive, occasionally downright gorgeous and deeply silly universe crammed into every little corner here. You can easily imagine Twohy and Vin Diesel hanging out after a long day of D&D, their faces plastered with the beaming smiles of proud fathers as they watch their personal, unreleased 4 1/2 hour cut of this. To call it kind of awesome is probably an overstatement, but it's definitely 
a kind
 of awesome.', "it's like fritz lang directed a mountain dew commercial", "vin diesel's self-image as the last great auteur actor, carefully cultivating an esoteric brand of genre dorkiness that both endears and alienates contemporary audiences & critics. 
the chronicles of riddick
 is perhaps the apex of diesel's twin desires to both make big-budget mass entertainment and to indulge in an illustration of his offbeat scifi/fantasy obsessions gleamed via tabletop RPG campaigns, anime and videogames. while dominic toretto is diesel's most famous archetype, one could easily claim that riddick is the role that truly codifies diesel's strengths as a performer: his burly physique, the growled baritones, the dreadfully sincere yet still playful tone, the literal animistic magnetism, and especially the pouty rugged distance that makes him not always a strict audience surrogate, but‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Attack on Titan: Crimson Bow and¬†Arrow
Text:
When man-eating Titans first appeared 100 years ago, humans found safety behind massive walls that stopped the giants in their tracks. ['levi singlehandedly turning me into a weeb', "i'll just say this; mikasa... queen shit!", 'Revisiting this almost ten years later (?!?) has been incredibly fun‚Äî both because of the knowledge I have now but also because of the strength of its bite. A show that sinks it‚Äôs teeth into you from episode 1 and rarely lets go. It balances such a rare combination of fascination and fear that few shows can juggle, let alone achieve.\xa0
And to think, this was only the beginning.\xa0

Title: Lifeboat
Text:
During World War II, a small group of survivors is stranded in a lifeboat together after the ship they were traveling on is destroyed by a German¬†U-boat.
['This is simply some of the most watchable shit. I‚Äôm so completely fascinated by this movie that I can‚Äôt even put its wack, sexy energy into words. People DIE on this boat. People discuss RACISM and ANTI-SEMITISM on this boat. People FALL IN LOVE on this boat. People BETRAY EACH OTHER on this boat. Twenty minutes in everybody starts to look really rugged and wind-swept and attractive. Also the energy between Connie and Kovac? Nuts. He‚Äôs a communist sailor who‚Äôs shirtless the entire movie, has tattoos all over his chest, and bears a striking resemblance to Billy Zane. She‚Äôs Tallulah Fucking Bankhead, playing essentially herself or maybe Dorothy Parker. At one point she draws her initials on his bare chest with her lipstick. It‚Äôs amazing. Inglourious Basterds WHO I only know the lifeboat gang.', 'There has never been an actor so confidently, outrageously and iconically out of place as Tallulah Bankhead in ‚ÄúLifeboat.‚Äù\xa0
The actress, as a society writer cast out to sea, has such a pull over ‚ÄúLifeboat‚Äôs‚Äù rudder that she transforms the film around her essence. And what an essence it is.\xa0
‚ÄúLifeboat‚Äù is something of a seabound chamber play. An ensemble of American survivors from a u boot bombing attempt to carry on (without quite keeping calm) until they reach rescue.\xa0
Alfred Hitchcock, working from a script initially penned by John Steinbeck, executes a shrewd cleverness over who or what is the villain of the piece. The narrative and characters are compelling enough even if they are working only against the‚Ä¶ 
more', "LIFEBOAT is a masterfully composed wartime thriller, often under-discussed in Hitchcock's filmography. Set entirely on‚Ä¶ a lifeboat carrying the survivors of a sinking ship‚Äì from both sides of the war with Tullulah Bankhead heading solid ensemble cast. Another great example of how brilliantly Hitchock uses of claustrophobic spaces."]

Title: I,¬†Frankenstein
Text:
200 years after his shocking creation, Dr. Frankenstein‚Äôs creature, Adam, still walks the earth. But when he finds himself in the middle of a war over the fate of humanity, Adam discovers he holds the key that could destroy¬†humankind.
['In 2014 the guy who wrote Michael Mann's 
Collateral
 had an idea so good the mainstream media had to hide it from you: what if Frankenstein was a sexy superhero who fought CGI gargoyles with fingerless leather gloves and abs and dressed like an H&M mannequin... For nearly a decade now I've been able to amuse people who never watched this movie by informing them that it, 
 I kid you not
, cuts to credits on Aaron Eckhart turning towards the camera and saying "I, Frankenstein."', 'If you see only one movie this year about Frankenstein's monster caught in a war between demons and angels who are also gargoyles... then you are totally fucked, because this movie is horrible.
It spends its first 20 minutes carefully explaining one of the silliest mythologies ever, then spends the next hour completely ignoring all of the rules it just laid out. In one scene, the angel-gargoyle people have captured and imprisoned Frankenstein because he dared to fight a demon in view of a human being. "Ours is a war that must be fought in secret!" one yells at him in a haughty British accent (in this movie, all angels and demons hail from England). Literally one scene later, demons‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I, I, I really regret watching this movie.']

Title: The¬†Tribe
Text:
Deaf-mute Sergey enters a specialized boarding school for the deaf. In navigating through the school‚Äôs hierarchy, he encounters a corrupt underbelly of criminality, known as The Tribe. By participating in several robberies, he gets propelled higher into the organization, when he meets one of the Chief‚Äôs concubines Anya, and unwittingly breaks all the unwritten rules of the¬†group.‚Äù
['things that are fucked up:\n-this\n-me after watching this', "I've never been so glad not to be fluent in Ukrainian sign language. a fascinating reconfiguring of silent cinema modes, THE TRIBE does remarkable things with deep focus, however indebted to the Romanian New Wave those techniques might be. not entirely sure that the film had to be *that* brutal (at times it feels like an affect), but it certainly lubricates this bracingly unique portrait of sub-worlds and the price of escaping from them.", "Impressively staged (each scene is a single unbroken take), and in case you hadn't, uh, heard, entirely in untranslated sign language. Too bad that's in service of a crushingly banal and generically bleak drama that utterly fails to explore the experience and stigma of being unable to hear or that condition's attendant problems of communication. Putting us in a similar headspace about the confusion over details that a deaf person might experience in the hearing world only works if there's some narrative or structural ambiguity, but there's none here (admittedly a testament to the clarity of the single takes and performances). Also the only female characters are sexual tokens. I'm only not calling this bullshit because of the formal rigor."]

Title: The¬†Sacrifice
Text:
Alexander, a journalist, philosopher and retired actor, celebrates a birthday with friends and family when it is announced that nuclear war has¬†begun.
['"I see it as my duty to stimulate reflection on what is essentially human and eternal in each individual soul, and which all too often a person will pass by, even though his fate lies in his hands. He is too busy chasing after phantoms and bowing down to idols. 
In the end everything can be reduced to the one simple element which is all a person can count upon in his existence: 
The Capacity to Love. 
That element can grow within the soul to become the supreme factor which determines the meaning of a person's life. 
My function is to make whoever sees my films 
aware of his need to love and to give his love, 
and aware that‚Ä¶ 
more', "Like John Huston's 
The Dead
, Tarkovsky's final film addresses regret. Having spent his days crafting ideas, speaking his mind, and ultimately sacrificing his life for art, Tarkovsky bows out with a film that, among other things, demands to know why no one takes action. At the same time, it feels like an apologia of his leaving behind his family and pursuing his filmmaking in Italy and Sweden, and it is an expression of deep, profound faith. It staggers me to see so much put into a film, so ably made. 
What stands out is the use of mirrors. Tarkovsky at this point seemed to be devoted to the long take, the sacred tool of filmmakers seeking to maintain continuity, suspension‚Ä¶ 
more", '‚ÄúIn the beginning was the 
Word. Why is that, Papa?"']

Title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal¬†Skull
Text:
Set during the Cold War, the Soviets‚Äîled by sword-wielding Irina Spalko‚Äîare in search of a crystal skull which has supernatural powers related to a mystical Lost City of Gold. Indy is coerced to head to Peru at the behest of a young man whose friend‚Äîand Indy‚Äôs colleague‚ÄîProfessor Oxley has been captured for his knowledge of the skull‚Äôs¬†whereabouts.
["Fuck yes. 
I love it. All of it. From the classical opening giving way to a rollicking rock 'n' roll tune, 
Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
 is something different than fan-service for disgruntled internet complainers. It is a luscious tribute to 50s B-movies and the pulpy comics that inspired them, embracing every glorious quip and every moment of flowering insanity in order to liven the Indiana Jones universe into an old-fashioned burst of blockbuster entertainment. 
Crystal Skull
 reminds me of a time when summer popcorn extravaganzas were 
directed
, focusing on the story at hand rather than worrying about the studio's five-year plan of world domination. Steven Spielberg revels in every silly and goofy quirk in George‚Ä¶ 
more", 'A pretty good movie if you turn it off once they get to Peru', "Gripping drama about a dementing geriatric Archeologist who thinks he's having an adventure while in reality he's being spoon fed porridge."]

Title: Floating¬†Weeds
Text:
When a theater troupe‚Äôs master visits his old flame, he unintentionally sets off a chain of unexpected events with devastating¬†consequences.
['No Nonsense November #6
1959 was such a bizarre and wonderful year for Ozu. Having fulfilled his Shochiku contract with for the year 
Good Morning
, he went on to make 
Floating Weeds
 for Daiei. This saw him partially separating from his usual crew, resulting in a temporary collaboration with, amongst others, Kazuo Miyagawa! The photography is stunning. But it is a departure in other ways. We temporarily step away from the middle class concerns of the marriage films to focus on a troupe of poor kabuki actors. We move away from Tokyo to a seaside town on the inland sea.
I love the village by the sea. And I love the shots of boats. I love 
that joyful, wistful theme
.‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Sometimes I get the wrong idea that Ozu makes wholesome movies because my first few were 
An Autumn Afternoon
\xa0and 
Good Morning
, this was depressing as hell. A compelling portrait of being unable to escape our worst tendencies, doomed to repeat ourselves and forced to accept the consequences of our actions. The central character is such a jackass, every step of the way you want to shout at him to chill the fuck out, but he‚Äôs in too deep. Movies like this feel like cautionary tales, be honest with the ones you love and be honest with yourself or else! Sometimes it‚Äôs nice to see someone else truly ruin their life to remind you that you‚Äôre doing a pretty good job at the whole living thing.', 'It is such a privilege to view the films of Ozu. He has invented a filmmaking style entirely unique to his films.\xa0It takes a few minutes to adjust to the visual style, as the head-on conversations can be jarring, yet once absorbed it tends to be quite meditative. While his characters can be stiff at times, they reveal great depth of emotion.
This was the most intense of his films I‚Äôve seen. Autumn Afternoon and Tokyo Story are much more reflective, whereas Floating Weeds has a lot of anger and resentment boiling up between the cracks. The intergenerational relationships are something Ozu captures especially well, often showing characters\xa0trying to connect but failing to give what the other wants. The setting‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Cosmopolis
Text:
Riding across Manhattan in a stretch limo during a riot in order to get a haircut, a 28-year-old billionaire asset manager‚Äôs life begins to¬†crumble.
['Turned this off after 45 minutes to do something more enjoyable, like sit in a bathtub full of hard boiled shit.', "Gosh, where do I begin.... Cosmopolis is a mess. A big, beautiful and very intelligent mess. It is a very difficult film to come to terms with, especially because Cronenberg seems intent on the viewer not liking it at all. Title: Nickel¬†Boys
Text:
Chronicles the powerful friendship between two young Black teenagers navigating the harrowing trials of reform school together in¬†Florida.
["I have not sobbed as hard and as consistently at a movie as I did at the last ten minutes of this. I thought it wouldn't get me because I predicted the ending about halfway through, but it fucking shook me. And now I'm sitting on the couch, thinking about it, and crying more. 
Small detail that kind of fucked me up was how often the camera would turn away from something, not horizontally, but by turning to the floor. Keeping its gaze downward. Staying out of trouble. A survival instinct black boys know well. I don't really know how to sit with any of this without crying even more.", 'You can freeze this movie at any moment of its 139 minutes and see an image that tells a story. Danger on a dark street. A magnet sliding down a fridge. An open seat in a car. A ceiling fan. A cane poking a bare chest. A wooden cross tied to a truck scraping the pavement. The cover of a book. A grandmother‚Äôs face. Space. A Google search. A bar patron you haven‚Äôt seen in years. Sidney Poitier. 
It‚Äôs a movie that doesn‚Äôt force you to look at everything because it sees everything for you, from the hell on earth to whatever is beyond it. It constrains our view the same way we do. The same is true if you‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Occasionally difficult to emotionally connect with due to the first person perspective, but equally difficult to deny how bold its storytelling style truly is. How the hell was this not in the conversation for Best Director, Editing, and Sound?!']

Title: Innerspace
Text:
Test pilot Tuck Pendleton volunteers to test a special vessel for a miniaturization experiment. Accidentally injected into a neurotic hypochondriac, Jack Putter, Tuck must convince Jack to find his ex-girlfriend, Lydia Maxwell, to help him extract Tuck and his ship and re-enlarge them before his oxygen runs¬†out.
['Martin Short has one pitch, but it‚Äôs a cutter.\nReally wish we could get more coked-out studio execs greenlighting shit like this, BEETLEJUICE and WHO FRAMED ROGER RABBIT. A golden age for extremely weird nerds with good ideas for movies. All hail Joe Dante.', 'The Marvel Entertainment Group is currently flooding the marketplace with big scifi blockbusters that have quips, goofs, and maybe even some shenanigans, but most of the time no real comedy, no jokes, no gags (Shane Black excepted, naturally). Here we have plenty of all of the above, and with enough weird science-fiction concepts to power dozens of lesser entertainments. And yet I think the thing that will stick with me the longest is Meg Ryan smiling at Martin Short with two parts affection and one part apology at the end.', "There's a hero inside you."]

Title: Carnage
Text:
Two pairs of parents hold a cordial meeting after their sons are involved in a fight, though as their time together progresses, increasingly childish behavior throws the discussion into¬†chaos.
['i wish i was married to christoph waltz', 'I\xa0AM GLAD OUR SON KICKED THE\xa0SHIT OUT\xa0OF\xa0YOUR SON\xa0AND I\xa0WIPE MY ASS\xa0WITH\xa0YOUR HUMAN RIGHTS', "Language. It can be used to create and to destroy. For me that's what this film was all about. 
We see four people who slowly strip away social conventions and eventually show their true selves, all because of the incessant need to talk, justify oneself and outwit others.
You cannot get around the fact that this is a play. One location, four actors and an insane amount of dialogue. For a film like this to work the acting has to be perfect. And it is. All four of them are absolutely fantastic, they portray the slow descent into social and moral ambiguity in such a way that, although the characters are somewhat stereotypical, you always get the feeling you're watching‚Ä¶

When √Üon Flux, the top operative in the underground ‚ÄòMonican‚Äô rebellion, is sent on a mission to kill a government leader, she uncovers a world of¬†secrets.
["This is like a film that would be played, on mute, in the background during a party at your weird friend's house while he plays Ministry on a CD-R and some guy named Trevor talks about how he hates his job at Best Buy.", 'way way way too odd to hate. I am currently on drugs', "Does a great job of replicating the pervy bio-organic weirdness of the cartoon, with vaguely vaginal poison dart-shooting security fruit, spies passing sensitive stolen technologies with their tongues, or Sophie Okonedo's hand-feet. But it was probably a mistake to try to manufacture a decipherable plot out of what was always an intentionally narratively baffling feat of imaginative futurist design and impossible animated acrobatics. There's just too much talking and explaining, and what should be carried off with alluring silence instead seems like intentional camp. That's not necessarily bad, but unfortunately Kusama's action has been sliced to ribbons for a PG-13, and in the occasional instance when it's not, you get bland stuff like Charlize spinning in place with a machine gun, and so most of what was lithe and visceral in the source material ends up a generic blur here."]

Title: The Last House on the¬†Left
Text:
On the eve of her 17th birthday, Mari and friend Phyllis set off from her family home to attend a rock concert in the city. Attempting to score some drugs on the way, the pair run afoul of a group of vicious crooks, headed up by the sadistic¬†Krug.
["Not as great as The First House on the Right but it's still really good.", 'play less pretty acoustic guitar over rape scenes!', '‚ÄúHot damn, I wish I was something else sometimes.‚Äù
History has an interesting way of codifying certain untruths as true. Whether by way of shortcut or faulty memory or utilitarian spin by the powers that be, things that didn‚Äôt happen‚Äîor, perhaps more often, didn‚Äôt 
exactly
 happen 
quite
 like that‚Äîworm their way into the official record and thus become established fact, the archaeological effort needed to contradict them either underfunded or underreported (or both). As but one minor example, take President Jimmy Carter‚Äôs famous ‚Äúmalaise‚Äù speech. Delivered in 1979, Carter‚Äôs speech about the energy crisis and the need for a ‚Äúwindfall profits‚Äù tax on the oil industry referred to a ‚Äúcrisis of confidence‚Äù among the American people but never used the‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Suncoast
Text:
While caring for her brother along with her audacious mother, a teenager strikes up an unlikely friendship with an eccentric activist who is protesting one of the most landmark medical cases of all¬†time.
['This movie is infinitely better if:
- Woody Harrleson was not in it. A character who spends time stifling any of the momentum and development between Parker and the rest of the cast. A nothingburger role, a role solely so people scrolling on Hulu will stop and say "Is that Woody Harrelson?"
- wasn't afraid to actually dive deeper into the politics of life, death, and religion. 
Every moment between Parker and her friends or Parker and Linney, it was like watching an entirely different movie. There's an impressive level of authenticity in Chinn's portrayal of 2000s youth and the raw emotion between Parker and Linney is enough to fuel the entire movie, but instead we have to take a break to hang out with Woody.
Too afraid to be confrontational, so it settles on being cliche.', 'father figure woody harrelson is my favorite genre', '"when this is over, i'll... i'll learn how to be fun again"']

Title: Mahjong
Text:
Amid a rapidly changing cityscape, the lives of a disparate group of swindlers, hustlers, gangsters, and expats collide, with a naive French teenager and a sensitive young local who tries to protect her caught dangerously in the¬†middle.
["Yang's second remake of Rebel Without A Cause, and probably his angriest film; every relationship is a transaction, the only world these kids know is making money and how they will make it. A group of charming young thugs befriend a lost girl from France because of the possibility to prostitute her. Another thug refuses to get intimately involved with another, for fear of overwhelming heartbreak. He nevertheless falls in love, and is proven right. The french girl even tentatively agrees to prostitution, only because she thinks it will make the man she used to love suffer. Yet for every character in this movie, no matter how cynical they may be, there is a fundamental humanity to each of them‚Ä¶ \nmore", '"You thought the 19th century was the glorious age of Imperialism? Wait until you see the 21st century."\nMaybe the best movie of the 90s?', 'Money means nothing in the face of death.']

Title: Barren¬†Lives
Text:
In vivid images, the documentary-like story of a drover and his family in the northern badlands of Brazil during the drought. A family in the search of new hope and¬†destiny.
['Depois do √∫ltimo di√°logo, em cima da imagem final, Nelson Pereira dos Santos nos oferece a √∫ltima informa√ß√£o de "Vidas Secas": o letreiro confirma que o ano daquela hist√≥ria √© o de 1942, ano de uma das secas mais severas da hist√≥ria do Nordeste brasileiro. O n√∫mero redimensiona a trag√©dia de Fabiano, Sinh√° Vit√≥ria, do menino mais velho, do menino mais novo e da cachorra Baleia. Escapa √† literatura.

A hist√≥ria da mis√©ria brasileira contada sob a c√¢mera realista aos moldes nacionais. √â evidente que toda essa documenta√ß√£o fotogr√°fica aparente finca suas bases de influ√™ncia no cinema Italiano. N√£o tendo direito ao c√©u, resta o inferno de luminosidade estourada. O inferno que √© seguido pela c√¢mera que exp√µe a mis√©ria em sua total apatia, n√£o h√° como se defender, essa √© sua condi√ß√£o. Bicho. Como baleia. Plano e contraplano, a personagem s√≠mbolo e os ratos que marcam a mem√≥ria de outro momento. Pesad√≠ssimo.', '"Vidas Secas" √© um dos filmes mais dolorosos j√° feitos no Brasil. Mas n√£o se trata de uma dor grandiosa ou exagerada. √â uma tristeza seca, contida, marcada pela dureza da vida no sert√£o. √â uma tristeza que pertence ao Brasil, principalmente ao Nordeste, onde a seca e a pobreza moldam gera√ß√µes inteiras. O filme mergulha fundo na realidade de fam√≠lias que n√£o t√™m quase nada, que lutam todos os dias apenas para sobreviver. N√£o se trata de grandes sonhos ou conquistas heroicas, mas de desejos simples: um prato de comida, um pouco de √°gua limpa, uma sombra para descansar, um colch√£o que n√£o seja o ch√£o. Title: Sleepaway Camp II: Unhappy¬†Campers
Text:
Angela Baker escapes from a mental hospital and surfaces at a summer camp as a counselor who lectures her teenage charges on proper moral behavior. Those teens who break her strict rules ‚Äì from the camp chatterbox or a sex-obsessed girl to the boys who are peeping Toms ‚Äì are murdered by the impostor in various gruesome ways. As more campers go missing, intrepid counselor Molly begins to piece together the¬†truth.
['Bad camper: *exists*
Angela: you what', '"ain't no skin off my tits" is a good phrase', "Angela is really too enthusiastic about her job, determined to give the kids of Camp Rolling Hills the camping experience she herself was not able to have at Camp Arawak which was full of mean kids and corrupt staff. The campers and counselors of Camp Rolling Hills are not mean or corrupt, but they cannot meet Angela's impossible standards of camp conduct which have nothing to do with how people actually behave at summer camp. This, I am sorry to say, ends in tragedy. Sleepaway Camp II makes me so very happy and wistfully sad all at the same time. It refuses to judge any of its characters too harshly, even when they do messed-up things because it understands that‚Ä¶ 
more", 'she really killing these people for breathing', 'I love this stupid bullshit.', 'pamela springsteen decapitates the transphobic son of a cop. five stars', 'More or less a revamp of the first film with a little more black humor thrown in, picking up with Pamela Springsteen really nailing her role as Angela‚Äîhappy go lucky kumbaya one minute to shoving someone in an outhouse hole and drowning them in piss n shit‚Äîfrom making a can of peas to pouring acid out of a car battery and into a mug before tossing it in someones face. She really takes her counselor job seriously, all misbeahavers must be punished!
There‚Äôs plenty to dig here‚ÄîLots of sex crazed teens, mess hall hijinx, a leetle bit of satire, and\xa0solid kills always delivered with a smirk... but the highlight for me is that creepy slow motion fever dream sequence that‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Trashy camp slasher like the first part, who knows how to entertain.
Thanks to a completely insane Angela, who manages to impress with humor and the different variations of kills in this flick.\xa0
Fun fact: Pamela Springsteen, who plays the killer here, is the sister of Bruce Springsteen and final girl Ren√©e Estevez is the sister of Charlie Sheen.', 'I know they‚Äôll never make another Angela Baker film because it‚Äôs outdated or whatever but I just want to say I love my trans horror icon diva. Need Pamela Springsteen to dust off the Angela Baker wig and get back into making another one of these. I love her. She served CAMP at camp.', '"Party Hats at 2 o'clock!"
Set five years after the first movie Angela is now working at Camp Rolling Hills as a strict prudish camp councilor and if you offend her upright morals principals then she's gonna send you home ...
... in a body bag! 
"Nice girls don't have to show it off!"
A camps worth of mullets n sluts 
(Angela's opinion, not mine)
 with great ingenious camp based death's 
(with the outdoor toilet death scene being a family favorite!)
 which go to make this a pretty decent sequel although the ending does not hold up the first movie - but then again not many endings do!
Still I'm a Happy Camper!!', 'Now Angela is a villain with morals we can root for. Even though there was still plenty of short shorts, this was offensively less homoerotic than the first.', "There's no hiding who the killer is this campy sequel to Sleepaway Camp. We know two minutes into the movie. Gone are the red herrings, and POV kills from the original. This isn't bad, because the kills are insanely hilarious, and done in a way that would make any money shot kill lover smile with pure joy. Among the weapons of destruction are: a knife, cordless drill, fire, acid, the toilet, Leatherface's chainsaw and choke wire. Almost every kill counted, and I must give mad props to special effects artist Dick Cross, who would later do the effects for Speed 2. Well done, Mr. Dick! My favorite kill scene involves bootleg versions of Freddy, Jason, and Leatherface. It's a great‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Phineas and Ferb the Movie: Candace Against the¬†Universe
Text:
Phineas and Ferb travel across the galaxy to rescue their older sister Candace, who has been abducted by aliens and taken to a utopia in a far-off planet, free of her pesky little¬†brothers.
["Can't believe this movie finally gave Jeremy a personality trait", 'Movies have been around since the late 19th century, but only now ‚Äî after more than 100 years of failure ‚Äî has someone finally made one that hinges on the invention of a ray gun that replaces anyone it shoots with the nearest available chicken. The device is called ‚ÄúThe Chicken Replace-inator,‚Äù and it‚Äôs the latest weapon created by the mad scientist Dr. Doofenshmirtz (of Doofenshmirtz Evil Incorporated fame) in his never-ending quest to kill the fedora-wearing secret agent who always foils his plans and also happens to be a platypus ‚Äî Perry the platypus.
The cackling lovechild of Abe Vigoda and the Wicked Witch of the West, Doofenshmirtz has come up with all sorts of cockamamie schemes to destroy‚Ä¶ 
more', "I've never met a single person who doesn't like Phineas and Ferb.
And if you happen to not like Phineas and Ferb, keep it to your fucking self."]

Title: The¬†Trial
Text:
The surreal tale of an unassuming man who is accused of a never-specified crime and shambles through bizarre encounters to escape this¬†nightmare.
['where has this been all my life', "Absurd. Surreal. Oppressive. All fine words to describe Orson Welles' The Trial, but I think the term that best describes how I felt while watching is 'hysterical': not in the sense that The Trial is a comedy - to describe it as a black comedy stretches the very definition to the breaking point - but that I found myself laughing to ward off the physical and mental unease it forced upon me (especially during the absolutely insane last 20 minutes). That a film can cause laughter as a defense mechanism is a testament to Welles, Kafka, and Perkins.\nThe dialogue flies by so fast that you become inured to the fact that the words spoken are so bizarre, the sentences‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'This film stressed me on an absurd level, I felt physically ill after finishing']

Title: The Chronology of¬†Water
Text:
Growing up in an environment torn apart by violence and alcohol, a young woman struggles to find her path. She manages to escape her family and enters university, where she finds refuge in literature. Gradually, words offer her an unexpected¬†freedom‚Ä¶
['When famous actors decide to try their hand at filmmaking, the results can be ‚Äî and often are ‚Äî unremarkable by design. Timid and safe with a network TV aesthetic that screams ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a lot more afraid behind the camera than I am in front of it.‚Äù Not so of Kristen Stewart‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Chronology of Water.‚Äù Not in the slightest. Some movies are shot. This one was directed. 
Which isn‚Äôt to suggest this aggressively fragmented adaptation of Lidia Yuknavitch‚Äôs memoir should be graded on a curve because its famous auteur dared to film on 16mm, or even because she had the skill required to adapt her source material with the same febrile porousness that made it such a striking piece‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I really do live for movies made entirely by people who have torn their hearts out. You can tell, there‚Äôs so 
much
\xa0in this (inevitable with such a life). Kept thinking about Jennette McCurdy‚Äôs memoir as well tbh. Truly believe every single shot has a hell of a lot to say, there are a lot of them and I could honestly watch them as a photo book with fewer words, but I was moved quite a few times.', 'THE CHRONOLOGY OF WATER floored me from start to finish with its fragmented but precise editing, uncompromising vision, and the raw, fearless performance of Imogen Poots, delivering her finest work yet. This is a pure art house biopic that scratches, pierces, and digs under the skin, confronting the viewer with a blistering emotional intensity that some may find too much to bear. To that end, Kristen Stewart‚Äôs directorial debut is unflinching & abrasive, a grueling exploration of pain that‚Äôs as likely to move you as it is to leave you shaken.']

Title: Gertrud
Text:
Hopeless romantic Gertrud inhabits a turn-of-the-century milieu of artists and musicians, where she pursues an idealized notion of love that will always elude her. She abandons her distinguished husband and embraces an affair with a young concert pianist, who falls short of her desire for lasting affection. When an old lover returns to her life, fresh disappointments follow, and Gertrud must try to come to terms with¬†reality.
['The realization that reality is prismatic, acceptance of reality, and then retaliation against it. Maybe this is the only profound film.', 'Advanced studies for Dreyer‚Äîrigorous in ways one doesn't even know how to particularly articulate. Dreyer's choices of when to edit and when to pan or move the camera at first seem defiantly baffling, until it all starts to form a logic with the narrative. The film has both a simplicity (woman's idealized version of love will always fail her), and yet an intense complexity that it's hard to know where to begin. Paintings are key here‚Äîreflections of narrative, all mainly Renaissance "representational" art, save for that final one of the grotesque woman (her 
Dorian Gray
?). Compositions have a intense stillness to them that registers almost beyond comprehension‚ÄîDan Sallitt pondered after the screening that only Dreyer would pull back the camera‚Ä¶ 
more', '"This is so often the way with life. You spend so much time waiting for something ‚Äì a person, a feeling, a piece of information ‚Äì that you can‚Äôt quite absorb it when it is in front of you. The hole is so used to being a hole it doesn‚Äôt know how to close itself."
 
- Matt Haig']

Title: Prince of¬†Broadway
Text:
A New York street hustler specializing in name-brand knock-offs finds his highly profitable game suddenly complicated when his ex-girlfriend shows up toting the son he never knew he¬†had.
['Between this and \nTake Out\n, I feel like no one was conveying life in NYC as authentically as Sean Baker in the 2000s. The scrappiness here is so beautiful, and perhaps feels sorely lost in Baker‚Äôs latest work. Nowadays Baker maintains similar editing and shooting styles, but feels to be forcing what was once his only option. When you have no crew, it‚Äôs going to be messy and that‚Äôs beautiful. When you instruct a big crew to be messy, the authenticity falters and perhaps some of the intrinsic heart is lost. Nonetheless I haven‚Äôt seen a Sean Baker film that I haven‚Äôt enjoyed, his early work just feels doubly special to me.', 'This felt like I was watching someone‚Äôs real life', 'Little man‚Äôs going to grow up to be the finest hustler in all of NY.']

Title: Let the Sunshine¬†In
Text:
Isabelle, Parisian artist, divorced mother, is looking for love, true love, at¬†last.
['i dont ask for a lot. if claire denis wants to capture the essence of a depressed, terminally horny juliette binoche, who are we to say no.', '1) "at last" jazz version softly plays in the background -- juliette binoche's married lover tells her she's charming but that his wife is 'extraordinary'
2) etta james painting hangs above binoche as she's curled up on the couch, devastated
3) "at last" by etta james plays in the club (IN THE CLUB!!) when she first meets and dances with sylvain
claire denis! fuck!
NYFF 2017.', 'I really don‚Äôt quite now how to review it. At first I thought about just not write anything, so not to embarrass myself, but I‚Äôm a fool so here it goes. I‚Äôm fascinated by how the film can feel warm and close, so especific yet at same time keep itself out of reach. Giving a look at writing here and outside these scale seem to be a recurring theme, the film is either perceptive or distant according to how one feels about it, my impression is that Denis achieved something very hard remaining warm but clinical. In this and only on this, the film does suggest the Barthes book that supposedly was the starting point for the project. It is‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The Salt of the¬†Earth
Text:
During the last forty years, the photographer Sebasti√£o Salgado has been travelling through the continents, in the footsteps of an ever-changing humanity. He has witnessed the major events of our recent history: international conflicts, starvations and exodus‚Ä¶ He is now embarking on the discovery of pristine territories, of the wild fauna and flora, of grandiose landscapes: a huge photographic project which is a tribute to the planet‚Äôs beauty. Salgado‚Äôs life and work are revealed to us by his son, Juliano, who went with him during his last journeys, and by Wim Wenders, a photographer¬†himself. √ó
["A nice reminder for a cinema fan that pictures don't have to move to be utterly affecting", "Such a deeply moving manifest, visual ode and unique hommage to the power of photography and it's meaning in the modern world. We humans truly are such cruel and vicious animals. My heroes no longer are the kings of wars, but the things of peace. Title: Lucky Number¬†Slevin
Text:
Slevin is mistakenly put in the middle of a personal war between the city‚Äôs biggest criminal bosses. Under constant watch, Slevin must try not to get killed by an infamous assassin and come up with an idea of how to get out of his current¬†dilemma.
["Drop all the crime stuff, make it a romantic comedy with Josh Hartnett and Lucy Liu, and you've got an okay movie", "Lucky Number Slevin is a Tarantino and Guy Ritchie wannabe film. It isn‚Äôt as clever or smart as it thinks, you can predict the twist half way through it‚Äôs story telling. BUT, but it's a slick, entertaining movie. 
It got solid cast including Bruce Willis, Morgan Freeman, Ben Kingsley and Stanley Tucci. And Josh Hartnett makes a surprisingly great lead, loved his chemistry with Lucy Liu.", 'Well, the rumors were true‚Ä¶. This was somewhat convoluted‚Ä¶
That being said, the performances in here are all around great and you can‚Äôt help but loose yourself in the great style of the picture that in many ways reminded me to a hybrid of Guy Ritchie and Matthew Vaughn. 
Its quick editing and snappy dialogue makes for a good time as we try to unravel the mystery that surrounds our protagonist played by the beloved Josh Hartnett, who sells the charm and the quirky nature of his character. He and everyone is given some great dialogues and scenes that make up for some very entertaining moments from the whole flashback narrations, the cheating scene and its reaction, its just a‚Ä¶

When an unexpected enemy emerges and threatens global safety and security, Nick Fury, director of the international peacekeeping agency known as S.H.I.E.L.D., finds himself in need of a team to pull the world back from the brink of disaster. Spanning the globe, a daring recruitment effort¬†begins!

Title: Female Prisoner Scorpion:¬†#701
Text:
After being cruelly set up and deceived by Sugimi, a detective in cohorts with the mob with whom she was whole-heartedly in love, Matsushima‚Äôs desire for revenge knows no¬†bounds.
['Some kind of violent kaleidoscopic pop-art gore soaked nightmare. Compact revenge jam with the fiercest eyes, I‚Äôd kill to see this on a big screen.', '"What is it like to be a Woman?" 
Genre cinema frequently asks this question of viewers. In genre it is used as an empathizing technique to ask audiences to identify with a victim and her eventual conflict. By getting viewers to see themselves as the women of these movies filmmakers create a funnel that cycles into tension, horror, action and eventual catharsis through resolution, but what of female audience members? Women already know what it's like to be a woman. We know the feeling of being followed down a side walk for an uncomfortable amount of time. We understand the jeers of men who make comments about our bodies, because this isn't something we go to the cinema to feel,‚Ä¶ 
more', '‚ÄúNone of you seem to understand. I‚Äôm not locked in here with you. You‚Äôre locked in here with me!‚Äù
\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 - Rorschach
\xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 \xa0 - Matsushima
\xa0
Fuck yeah. Unbridled female rage. Women-in-prison exploitation. Rape revenge fantasy. Psychosexual dreamlike nightmares. Soul-piercing demon eyes. A sensory overload onslaught of vertigo, anxiety, and violent chaos. Vibrant, cold, colorful, and bleak all at once. A human Terminator anchored by the will to survive and driven by the sole purpose of eliminating her one target: the embodiment of male sexual abuse, the man who ripped her innocence, her humanity, and her soul from her chest, betraying her love & trust and leaving only an unrelenting fire to rage inside‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Psycho¬†II
Text:
Norman Bates is declared sane and released from the facility in which he was being held, despite the complaints of Lila Loomis, sister of his most famous victim. Is he really cured, or will he kill¬†again?
['it is absolutely imperative that this rehabilitated patient be immediately sent right back to the place where his trauma came from', 'Honestly, of all the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù movies, I think this might be the most unexpectedly awesome sequel that none of us knew we needed and half of folks forget/refuse to remember exists because ‚Äúsacred cow‚Äù syndrome.
Anyways, 
Psycho II
\xa0rules‚ÄîEasily one of my favorite sequels and favorite 80‚Äôs slashers. Also, I‚Äôve \xa0experimented with watching this in Black and White and it that‚Äôs a big mood‚Äîit looks wonderful... especially right after watching 
Psycho
! Definitely a fun experiment but either way you can‚Äôt go wrong with this movie‚Äîit‚Äôs great!', '"I'm becoming confused again, aren't I?"
I'd always heard that this was a surprisingly good sequel but not how downright devastating it is; Holland writes it with deep empathy for Norman's battle with both his own psyche and members of the community that would maybe prefer he doesn't get better, which Franklin and Cundey then visually realize with an effective combination of Hitchcock's classical form and these bursts of more updated 80s slasher elements. What especially works about this is the way it deliberately weaponizes the iconography of the original film and audience bloodlust as Perkins (who is unreal good in this; as broken, confused and sweaty a performance as I've ever seen) actively tries to resist every single image‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: La¬†Llorona
Text:
Accused of the genocide of Mayan people, retired general Enrique is trapped in his mansion by massive protests. Abandoned by his staff, the indignant old man and his family must face the devastating truth of his actions and the growing sense that a wrathful supernatural force is targeting them for his¬†crimes.
['This movie might be from Guatemala but speaks volumes about the history of corrupt politicians in Latin America. A folk tale with social conscience.', 'Reviews of Jayro Bustamante‚Äôs ‚ÄúLa Llorona‚Äù (‚ÄúThe Weeping Woman‚Äù) are obligated to mention that this quiet and trembling phantasmagoria about the ghosts of the Guatemalan Civil War has virtually nothing to do with Michael Chaves‚Äô ‚ÄúThe Curse of La Llorona,‚Äù the schlocky jump-scare machine that Warner Bros. released last spring. Aside from their shared roots in the same piece of Latin American folklore, these two films couldn‚Äôt have less in common; one is a slow-burn s√©ance for the victims of a recent genocide, and the other is a PG-13 studio programmer that was only produced because of its ridiculous margins ($122 million in ticket sales against a $9 million budget is a job well done).
And yet, maybe it wouldn‚Äôt‚Ä¶ 
more', "I hesitate at calling this a horror. It's more a political thriller with a horror folklore as an element. Whatever it is, it's pretty fascinating.
Wait til you hear the sound design. The chants of the protesters almost becomes a rhythmic tone to the film"]

Title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood¬†Orchid
Text:
A scientific expedition sets out for Borneo to seek a flower called the Blood Orchid, which could grant extended life. Meanwhile, they run afoul of snakes and each¬†other.
["I watch this once a year with my dad. We don't know why, or what it is about this film that keeps us coming back‚Äîbut we return. Every. Single. Year. And I don't think a single one of them saw us awake through it all. \nBlood Orchid is a terrible film. It features a terrible cast. The script is stupid. The CG is 90s grade. And at ninety-seven minutes, it's too long.\nCan't wait to do it again, dad.", 'This sequel was a lot of fun. The anacondas were scary. Johnny Messner was ripped and I loved KaDee Strickland with that southern accent. I was also really invested in that monkey.', 'I guess the real Blood Orchid was the friends we made along the way.']

Title: Embrace of the¬†Serpent
Text:
The epic story of the first contact, encounter, approach, betrayal and, eventually, life-transcending friendship, between Karamakate, an Amazonian shaman, last survivor of his people, and two scientists that, over the course of 40 years, travel through the Amazon in search of a sacred plant that can heal them. Inspired by the journals of the first explorers of the Colombian Amazon, Theodor Koch-Grunberg and Richard Evans¬†Schultes.
['Any movie with a tapir in it gets at least 4 stars', 'Not to be dramatic but I had forgotten cinema could be this beautiful and hypnotic.', "From Francis Ford Coppola to Werner Herzog, maverick filmmakers have always been entranced by the madness of the jungle. Colombian director Ciro Guerra's Embrace of the Serpent doesn't shy away from the violence of Apocalypse Now or the delirium of Fitzcarraldo, but his trippy dive into the dark heart of his homeland is ultimately like nothing you've seen before.\nIn 1909, sick and scraggly Dutch explorer Theodor von Martius (Borgman star Jan Bijvoet) travels up the Amazon river in search of the rare yakruna leaf that can supposedly cure his illness. Although he's aided by a native companion who paddles him downstream, Von Martius knows that only one man can help him find what he's after: Karamakate (Nilbio Torres), a‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: My¬†Son

Title: The¬†Mummy
Text:
One by one the archaeologists who discover the 4,000-year-old tomb of Princess Ananka are brutally murdered. Kharis, high priest in Egypt 40 centuries ago, has been brought to life by the power of the ancient gods and his sole purpose is to destroy those responsible for the desecration of the sacred tomb. But Isobel, wife of one of the explorers, resembles the beautiful princess, forcing the speechless and tormented monster to defy commands and abduct Isobel to an unknown¬†fate. √ó
['RESE√ëA EN ESPA√ëOL
SPOOKTOBER VI: THE HAMMER OF HORROR
Another solid Fisher/Cushing/Lee joint; this time the team brings us their own rendition of the classic Mummy film. I honestly haven‚Äôt seen the Universal classic, so I can‚Äôt compare the two directly. The first‚Äîand until today only‚Äîiteration I‚Äôd seen was the Fraser version, which I still prefer over this one; then again, that feels unfair.
This film leans more into a slow burn and spooky atmosphere, with Lee playing a zombie-like mummy who mostly shuffles and looms until the moment he needs to attack or break something, then my dude suddenly begins to slam and punch with some crazy force. The kills were a little goofy and it was obvious the‚Ä¶ 
more', "Hammer's production of The Mummy rests everything on the lavish set design. It retains the camp synonymous with the brand, but they really pushed the boat out with the style and atmosphere - so many sets bathed in beautiful lighting. The Mummy's tomb and a swamp in the UK moorland being particular highlights. The story, which focuses on a group of archaeologists who ignore warnings and proceed to desecrate an Egyptian tomb, brings with it an interesting debate on the morality of doing such a thing. The film is essentially a collision between the ancient world's archaic beliefs, and the misunderstanding of the modern world, seeing everything as ripe for the taking. Peter Cushing doesn't really get his teeth into‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Who is killing the English graverobbers of Egypt?!
Colorful tosh. \xa0You‚Äôll root for the mummy. \xa0And the way to destroy the undead is‚Ä¶blast him with shotguns? \xa0We don‚Äôt even need to recite an incantation or some shit?
Gorgeous Second Sight blu-ray.\xa0
The boy gives it ‚Äúone hundred thousand stars.‚Äù']

Title: I Spit on Your¬†Grave
Text:
A young, beautiful career woman rents a backwoods cabin to write her first novel. Attacked by a group of local lowlifes and left for dead, she devises a horrific plan to inflict¬†revenge.
["I feel like the scariest thing about this movie is that even now, men still try to justify their terrible, awful actions with the same sort of 'she was asking for it' bullshit that all of the men in this film try to pull.
Surprised that people find this one to be sleazy/exploitative, because even though there's a lot of nudity - mainly during the 30 (!) minutes of rape scenes - it's never in a way I could ever think of as being eroticized. It's not a fun movie by any means, but I think it's one that, along with 
Ms. 45
, 
Thriller
, and the 
Female Prisoner Scorpion 
films, is still important and that still resonates as clearly today as it did when it was made, as depressing and sad as that is.", 'needed more castration scenes imo', "Hoop-Tober, Film 21 of 31:
*SPOILERS, I GUESS... EVEN THOUGH PRETTY MUCH EVERYONE ALREADY KNOWS WHAT HAPPENS IN THIS MOVIE*
The first half of this film is not very good. It's almost as if they make the sexual assault sequence just long enough to stretch the film over ninety minutes, and in order to stretch the film over ninety minutes, they had to make the sequence incredibly drawn out and gratuitous. It might be realistic - I'm sure there have been terrible cases where women have actually had to endure that sort of torture for such a prolonged period of time... but from a purely filmic standpoint, it doesn't work in my opinion. Why? Because it exhausts and repulses the‚Ä¶ 
more", "In a good revenge film, we are forced into the perspective of the victim. We empathize with them because we experience their pain firsthand. The way this film is shot, we are forced into the perspective of the attackers. The camera (like the poster) lingers on the victim's body. She is mostly shot from behind or from a low angle. The camera, like her attackers, treats her as an object of desire. 
Now, there are great movies that put us in the mind of a rapist (
Henry Portrait of a Serial Killer
), but I expect a film called 
Day of the Woman
 to tell the victim's story and to do that effectively, she needs to be the point-of-view character.
When‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Gotta say, 
Day of the Woman
, not a great title for this motion picture.', 'Cringe Movie Bucket List
(Halloween Movie Fest 2020)
It is so messed up that Rape revenge is a horror subgenre, and I Spit on Your Grave may just be the most notorious one.
"AW, JESUS! JUST TAKE A LOOK OF WHAT YOU'VE DONE TO ME! OH, GOD!"
Uggh, so I finally sat down to see just how depraved this was, and it absolutely lives up to its reputation. The first two rapes are of course awful to witness, but it was the third one that happens so suddenly when you think she is about to call the police, which was truly gut-wrenching.
I fully expected this to feel like an exploitation flick, but that was not the vibe it had‚Ä¶ 
more', 'WTF? No.', 'Not sure why this gets such low ratings, I thought it was pretty good. Somebody wrote: 
"Most of the film is completely boring and lacking any emotion or entertainment -- like the rape scene."
 Oh I forgot, rape is supposed to be fun and entertaining, silly me! Views like that are exactly the reason why violence should be shown like this -- lacking emotion and thrill. 
I thought it was visually particularly beautiful, other than that pretty ugly, as it should be. A lot of religious imagery, too -- the garden of Eden, a red apple, the crucifixaction of Christ, images of angels and depictions of hell, the devil himself in the eyes and groans of the men during the‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Spookyween 2023: Video Nasty Month
Day 2
"Suck it, bitch!"
Viewed on effedupmovies.com with my phone at the back of the bus on my way to work, which is probably more than this film deserves. Maybe playing it on a Nintendo DS on the rough carpeted floor of a crack den would have been more appropriate.
It probably doesn't deserve 2 and a half stars either, but I have to admire how effective it still is after almost four decades. Its cold, clinical approach to the vile subject matter of the first half is chilling to say the least. There's no music, there are a lot of wide open shots which make you feel really helpless and paranoid. A lot‚Ä¶ 
more', '*
Part of 
HOOPTüéÉBER 5.0: ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt believe in the Boogeyman? You should.‚Äù
 challenge.
5/33
--------------------------------------------------------------
"I Spit on Your Grave" is a shocking and frustrating experience. 
The first half does everything right. It portrays its villains as ordinary people (which makes it all the more scary) and shocks the audience with a brutal sequence of rapes and physical assaults that seem to have no end, all done in the most realistic and natural way possible. 
The scenes with Jennifer Hills (Camille Keaton in the performance of her life) walking in shock through the forest, covered with mud and blood, completely naked, is a haunting sight to never forget.
One of the most shocking aspects is the naturalness with which these‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Great vengeance and furious anger, leveled against any and all men. Rightfully reviled, but mostly because it‚Äôs so fucking gifted at placing you in a victim‚Äôs shoes, making you feel every thrust and blow, before reveling in the quiet resilience that brutality generates inside a near silent avenger. One of the finest exploitation films in history.', '‚ÄúI could have given you a summer to remember.‚Äù
I don‚Äôt like it. But I respect it. I respect Meir Zarchi‚Äôs hustle (‚Äú
Halloween
 had money. I had nothing‚Äù), and I think his heart was in the right place in its creation, inspired by his real life incident of running into a dirty, naked woman in a Jamaica Hills neighborhood park. And the subsequent poor treatment she received when they took her to the police station to report her rape. Understanding that, and divorcing the film from its provocative, Jerry Gross rerelease title‚Äîrecontextualizing it from its Video Nasty rep to its original 
Day of the Woman
 (failed) marketing‚Äîsoftens my feelings a bit. 
Zarchi was just a young emigrant from Israel, inspired‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Both Sides of the¬†Blade
Text:
Jean and Sara have been living together for 10 years. When they first met, Sara was living with Fran√ßois, Jean‚Äôs best friend and an admirer from back when he played rugby. Jean and Sara love each other. One day, Sara sees Fran√ßois in the street. He does not notice her, but she is overtaken by the sensation that her life could suddenly change. Fran√ßois gets back in touch with Jean. For the first time in years. He suggests they start working together again. From here on, things spiral out of¬†control. √ó
['Being French is simply no way to live a life', 'A white woman living in a post-colonial African country refuses to abandon her family‚Äôs coffee plantation even as civil war brews around her. A derelict spaceship full of criminals sails across the stars towards a black hole, adrift between their histories on Earth and the oblivion that awaits them in the cosmos. A former officer in the French Foreign Legion remembers his time stationed in Djibouti, where his men lost themselves in the desert (and each other) while preparing for a fight that never came.
The people in Claire Denis movies are seldom in a hurry, but they‚Äôre often out of time. They‚Äôre drawn and quartered between the soft flesh of memory and the acrid metal of waking life ‚Äî‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Euphoria High but they are middle aged and French. Sorry.', 'It somehow made me think of Trouble Every Day more than any of Denis more grounded movies. It pretty much is about how camera negotiates space between two tense bodies and Denis usual formal excellence, editing and camera, are great at it. Both Sides of the Blade also suggest Denis stab at making a more balanced Pialat movie. Some great work from Binoche and Lindon even more so because so much of it is about how their bodies are positioned inside the frame.', 'Relationships are hard.', 'The first great movie about how the Covid pandemic turned everybody into a volatile, horny maniac', "Torn between Vincent Lindon and Gr√©goire Colin is probably a woman's luckiest dilemma. In Both Sides of the Blade, Claire Denis' newest messy romantic drama, Juliette Binoche tries to balance her affections towards two men, and it backfires in the most explosive manner possible. 
Not Denis' career best by any stretch, this still reeks of her trademarks of sentimentality, feminine identity and black experience, which eventually counterbalance all the flaws. Despite a lukewarm first half of slow-burn buildup, the story picks up pace in the second, amping up emotions, tensions and dramatic scenes to repay the long wait. Lindon and Binoche are great enough veterans to pull off the equal parts sensual and turbulent dynamics with ease, while Colin still has the look and charms to disturb the couple's perfect existence. Despite an unsatisfying closure, Both Sides of the Blade still serves its purpose beautifully as an engrossing arthouse drama. Recommended.", 'I was the only person at my screening with any colour in their hair', 'BERLINALE FILM 4
Personally, this ranks below titane as it doesn‚Äôt have enough ass shots of Vincent lindon', '‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my Rue d‚ÄôAmsterdam wife.‚Äù
I would have liked flashbacks to explain Sara‚Äôs (Juliette Binoche) former relationship and why she was drawn to Fran√ßois (Gr√©goire Colin). Sara interviews people on the radio and it reminded me of the movie 
C‚Äômon C‚Äômon
. Scenes when Sara and Jean (Vincent London) were fighting seemed like C√©sar bait much in the same way that 
Revolutionary Road 
felt like Oscar bait. It also channeled 
Marriage Story 
but there was no wall-punching and the scenes were blocked better.\xa0
Also watch for director Claire Denis‚Äô cameo in the party scene.', 'Commuterland Paris, a casual domestic geography in familiar handheld, but the seasons are changing, skies are gray; everything is liminal, especially the world of sports, a zone in which established hierarchies of race and class become mutable (that‚Äôs why Denis stages a FaceTime call in which a member of France‚Äôs 1998 World Cup-winning squad explains Frantz Fanon).
Some of the funniest, harshest and most accurate domestic arguments ever‚Äîthe way Binoche leverages Lindon‚Äôs insecurity to turn offense into defense; the way the subject of the argument is invariably subsumed into a meta-argument about communication styles; ‚Äúeach sentence is a breath.‚Äù\xa0
Need to sit with this one but it strikes me as one of Denis‚Äôs major films, a complex synthesis of familiar themes like female erotic abandon, postcolonialism, nostalgia and spiritual unrest, mixed families, and the up-to-the-minute tactility of French life (the way Marcus‚Äôs mask outlines his lips‚Ä¶).', 'I never thought I‚Äôd see a Denis film that would elicit in me little more than a tired ‚Äúokay, boomer,‚Äù but here we are. Considering the world needs another film about tortured infidelity the way it needs another pandemic airborne illness, the film‚Äôs inherent uselessness can never quite save three moody, mercurial performances from feeling like they‚Äôre wasted on such tired material. One mid-film sequence stands out as the ghost of some more intense, special, strange film that might have been; Binoche struggling to balance the irrationality of her intensely corporeal responsiveness to even the sound of Colin‚Äôs voice with her very real emotional ties to Lindon, all of which Denis shoots like the stuff of some shadowy political thriller‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Batman and Harley¬†Quinn
Text:
Batman and Nightwing are forced to team with the Joker‚Äôs sometimes-girlfriend Harley Quinn to stop a global threat brought about by Poison Ivy and Jason Woodrue, the Floronic¬†Man.
["A letter to Bruce Timm
Dear Mr Timm,
First off I am a fan of your work and I get it, we all have things we fantasize about. Even creators. That being said... STOP trying to fulfill your superhero sex fantasies in DC animated movies. If you want to see Nightwing banging Harley Quinn i'm sure you could find some nice adult films online. Stop compromising your story.This movie is so tonally inconsistent I don't know what you were thinking. I get it you love Harley but it's clear only Dini knows how to write her. Please make more movies like Gods and Monsters and less whatever this is.
Sincerely,
Everyone", "Finally, the Batman movie I've always wanted - the one where Harley Quinn farts in the Batmobile and Batman says it smells like discipline. 
Yes.", 'Arguably the worst installment in the DC Animated Universe by far, Batman and Harley Quinn is an absolutely stunning misfire that feels more like poorly-thought out fan fiction than it does a real film featuring these characters, with an incredibly weak plot and painfully unfunny humor (including cheap bottom-of-the-barrel fart jokes and an implied sexual assault played for laughs).']

Title: A Bad Moms¬†Christmas
Text:
Amy, Kiki and Carla ‚Äì three under-appreciated and over-burdened women ‚Äì rebel against the challenges and expectations of the Super Bowl for mothers: Christmas. And if creating a more perfect holiday for their families wasn‚Äôt hard enough, they have to do all of that while hosting and entertaining their own¬†mothers.
["there's a beloved, decades-old theater minutes from my campus. it closed its doors forever tonight, and 
A Bad Moms Christmas
 was the last film they ever screened. my roommates and i had to go. this was our theater - we weren't going to miss its last film, even if it was this. 
the theater was packed with wine moms passing bottles around, screaming at every joke in the movie. for ninety minutes, i was a wine mom, and for ninety minutes, this was the greatest movie ever", 'i am in christmas milf heaven', "my mom couldn't stop laughing the entire movie, thus, this movie is valid, because when moms are happy, i be happy"]

Title: Dance, Girl,¬†Dance
Text:
Judy O‚ÄôBrien is an aspiring ballerina in a dance troupe. Also in the company is Bubbles, a brash mantrap who leaves the struggling troupe for a career in burlesque. When the company disbands, Bubbles gives Judy a thankless job as her stooge. The two eventually clash when both fall for the same¬†man.
['you know a movie is directed by a woman when the fight scene between the two female leads features one of them dragging the other off a stage by their hair.', "Judge: The complaint states that you slapped her.
Maureen: Oh no, Your Honor. I punched her and then I jumped on her and tried to strangle her.
Judge: You mean, you happened to catch your arms around your opponent's neck in an act of self defence?

Title: Finding¬†Forrester
Text:
Gus Van Sant tells the story of a young African American man named Jamal who confronts his talents while living on the streets of the Bronx. He accidentally runs into an old writer named Forrester who discovers his passion for writing. With help from his new mentor Jamal receives a scholarship to a private¬†school.
["You're the man now, dog.", "There are directors who always seek to adapt to the genre or style of the film they are directing, and there are directors like Gus Van Sant who are always adapting the films to their own style.
Even though a lot of the story turns out to be predictable and the music is typical of such social melodramas of the era, yet what makes the movie feel so unique is Van Sant's unique approach. You see, even when it falls into some stereotypes, this is a film that is clearly trying to challenge our expectations. There is also the fact that for the most part everything plays in such a soothing and calm manner, that it also does its best‚Ä¶

the crowd boos, i begin to walk away in shame. then suddenly a voice speaks ‚Äúshe‚Äôs right!‚Äù

Title: Woman in¬†Gold
Text:
Maria Altmann, an octogenarian Jewish refugee, takes on the Austrian government to recover a world famous painting of her aunt plundered by the Nazis during World War II, she believes rightfully belongs to her family. She did so not just to regain what was rightfully hers, but also to obtain some measure of justice for the death, destruction, and massive art theft perpetrated by the¬†Nazis.
['Daniel Bruhl is decidedly NOT a Nazi in this', 'Not necessarily an amazing movie, but a movie that everyone should watch', "‚ÄúIf life is a race, you beat me to the finish. But if life is a boxing match, I'm the last one standing.‚Äù\nBased on true events, Woman in Gold is one of those films that ended up being far less interesting than the actual story it was trying to tell. If The Monuments Men failed to appeal to a wide audience I wonder what the producers of this film were thinking. It too centers on stolen artwork during the Second World War, but it takes us through the litigation process that Maria Altmann went through to try to regain what rightfully belonged to her family. At least The Monuments Men focused on a group of men trying to save‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

['do you think hobbs and shaw ever explored eachothers bodies', 'The USA and Canada get to enjoy a new Tarantino film meanwhile the UK has this meme of a movie to dominate the weekend. :D
This Dwayne Johnson circlejerk needs to end, his dialogue at this point is literally just him bragging about how big his winky is. No exaggeration. He‚Äôs a rubbish leading man I‚Äôm afraid.

Uh, super soldier cyborgs as well I guess. Whatever, this franchise jumped the shark ages ago so you‚Äôre either with it or your not at this point. I hope you enjoy franetic camerawork too because the camera never stops moving to emphasise how truly ‚Äúawesome‚Äù everything is.

Watched atCineplex Odeon Park & Tilford Cinemas, Vancouver.']

Title: Finding¬†Neverland
Text:
During a writing slump, playwright J.M. Barrie meets a widow and her four children, all young boys‚Äîwho soon become an important part of Barrie‚Äôs life and the inspiration that lead him to create his masterpiece. Peter¬†Pan.
['i just love looking at kate winslet‚Äôs face and i just love hearing kate winslet talk and yknow i just love kate winslet', 'I couldn‚Äôt even see what happened in the end cause I was crying so much that my eyes hurt now. I do believe ‚ú®', '"Young boys should never be sent to bed. They always wake up a day older."\n ~ Sir James Barrie\nWhat a delightful, charming and sensitive tale, based on Allan Knee\'s 1998 off-Broadway play "The Man Who Was Peter Pan." Johnny Depp was perfectly cast as the turn-of-the-century playwright Sir James Barrie. He\'s right at home acting like a child, never quite growing up and well aware that his "work" is to create a "play." He befriends the widow Sylvia Llewelyn Davies (Kate Winslett), whose four sons provide the inspiration for his greatest stage production, "Peter Pan." Dustin Hoffman, Julie Christie and Radha Mitchell also star, and this bittersweet saga received seven Academy Award nominations, including the Oscar-winning Best Score composed by Jan A.P. Kaczmarek.']

Title: Thumbelina

Title: The Killing¬†Fields
Text:
New York Times reporter Sydney Schanberg is on assignment covering the Cambodian Civil War, with the help of local interpreter Dith Pran and American photojournalist Al Rockoff. When the U.S. Army pulls out amid escalating violence, Schanberg makes exit arrangements for Pran and his family. Pran, however, tells Schanberg he intends to stay in Cambodia to help cover the unfolding story ‚Äî a decision he may regret as the Khmer Rouge rebels move¬†in.
['For me cinema should be more than entertainment. Cinema should help us grapple with and understand our history. 
The Killing Fields 
is valuable because it captures the Cambodian Genocide, which is something the world has not reconciled with. The film is unfortunately not from the Cambodian perspective, but still, I am glad 
The Killing Fields
 exists.
Forgive me for not discussing the film straightaway. I feel the need to re-iterate history before writing more, because 
The Killing Fields
 is incomplete and should be placed in context. The Cambodian Genocide is a haunting and almost inexplicable event. It was perpetrated by the Khmer Rouge who ruled Cambodia in the late 1970s. In 4 years, at least 1.5 million people were killed,‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Mostly solid, but you have got to be fucking kidding me with that ‚ÄúImagine‚Äù needle drop.', "A Law & Order journalist makes a life-long friend in war-torn CamfuckinBodia. A cafe goes boom. John Malkovich being John fuckin Malkovich. A Warlock with a camera. Coach, the Marine asshole. Getting your family the fuck outta Dodge. Random executions. Coca-Cola saving your ass from certain death. Hanging out with the French. The ultimate-fuckin darkroom. A bootleg passport. A gut-wrenching goodbye. Never giving up hope. Being trapped in the fuckin Killing Fields. A paddy field chain gang. A river of bones. Attempting the great escape. Fuckin landmines. The best phone call you will ever receive. I couldn't imagine a better fuckin ending. The realism in this film is fuckin insane. It didn't feel like I was watching a movie, it felt‚Ä¶ 
more"]
