Title: Sicario: Day of the¬†Soldado
Text:
Agent Matt Graver teams up with operative Alejandro Gillick to prevent Mexican drug cartels from smuggling terrorists across the United States¬†border.
['The first time I watched Sicario I said "if Denis Villenueve hadn\'t made this movie, it wouldn\'t be good" and now I know that I was right', 'all of these characters getting abducted and yet none of them, not even ONE, remembered to keep a money clip with $50 on them to throw in case of emergency', '‚ÄúSicario: Day of the Soldado‚Äù is a mean fucking movie. That‚Äôs sort of its thing. Much like the previous installment of this unlikely franchise, the film drapes itself in darkness so that it can focus our attention on any stray specks of light; one early shot, in which the white halo of a helicopter spotlight tracks a brown man as he sprints towards the Texas border during the dead of night, provides a convenient visual metaphor.\nIt‚Äôs also a hard movie, in the way that Josh Brolin‚Äôs jawline is hard, or that Hemingway is hard, or that trying to carve a coherent narrative out of the Escher-like power struggle of the Mexican Drug War is hard. Like ‚ÄúSicario,‚Äù ‚ÄúWind River,‚Äù‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: The House with Laughing¬†Windows
Text:
A young restorer is commissioned to save a fresco representing the suffering of St. Sebastiano, which was painted on the wall of a local church by a mysterious, long-dead¬†artist.
['Opting for the rural backdrop rather than cosmopolitan, 
The House with Laughing Windows
 lives deliciously within confines of the folk horror milieu, lacking the well documented motifs so commonly attributed to the giallo in favor of menacingly unstoppable atmosfear.
Establishing an eeriness from the get go with a disturbing opening (among the genre‚Äôs best) before throwing us into the fray with morbid paintings, deranged townsfolk and the local diabolical underbelly, the sinister looking (laughing) windows, and a seething/unforgettable final twist of pure bedlam.\xa0A full fledged genre masterpiece with great performances and tight\xa0direction that shouldn‚Äôt be slept on‚Äîbut in some weird way I think 
The House with Laughing Windows
 enjoys its often left alone place within the genre, it‚Äôs eye catching‚Ä¶ 
more', "Spooktober IV: Morte all'italiana
The movie in which they promise windows that laugh, but you instead have them screeching. 
A film in which the filthy, yellowish cinematography, which appears to some (Callie) to be vomit, really helps much of the terror become more effective. The mystery at hand didn‚Äôt engross me very much, but I really loved the little horror stuff we got with some good kills. There is very little blood and gore, as I was expecting, as it leans more into the sinister and psychological with one of the most WTF endings, like whoever told you they saw it coming is full of s**t. Capolicchio is a fantastic main character; he's someone you can readily root for, and‚Ä¶ 
more", '#
Giallo
What a return to my newfound favorite genre. 
The House of the Laughing Windows
 is my favorite kind of giallo: a slow-burn psychological mindcreeper set in an isolated village that is real but also the manifestation of your mind. The definiton of that kind of giallo? It hooks its talons into your forehead and rips and rips until your mind itself comes apart. Delectable. 
The patiently dripping terror is palpable in how the film goes about its plot of mystery. All the killings happen off-screen, but the killer is as real and human as the inhabitants of the village. This giallo is no police procedural at all; there is no police, only the village-dwellers who are all potentially crazy‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Star Trek: The Motion¬†Picture
Text:
When an unidentified alien destroys three powerful Klingon cruisers, Captain James T. Kirk returns to the newly transformed U.S.S. Enterprise to take¬†command.
["Avoided this for years because people said it was boring. And, like, sure. It's less exciting than a DS9 two parter. But most likely so are you. And I seriously doubt you ever gave the world a freaky proto-Borg villain who speaks like her voice is coming out of a wii-mote or DeForest Kelley dressed like the inventor of cocaine. So maybe shut the fuck up and have some respect.", "When you get down to brass tacks, this still has about 40 minutes smack in the middle that are just a bunch of people in awful, awful beige jumpsuits watching a big television. Even in 1979 you'd have to wonder who thought this would make for an exciting adventure, but certainly by today's standards it's so anomalously slow and pensive and thoughtful (not to mention the incredible miniature effects), and I just can't help but kind of love it. The spacedock flyby of the refitted Enterprise lasts almost 
six minutes
! Unheard of now, and in fact I can't safely say that if such a thing were to occur in a modern studio event feature like this that I wouldn't be bitching about it being excruciatingly boring. But there you have it. Add it to the list of largely disliked movies I really have a soft spot for just because they are weird.", 'Never saw more than a few minutes of this because of its reputation for being boring, but having now finally watched the whole thing... I'm sorry, we're all thinking of the same "Star Trek," right? Is this not basically an episode of the show you all like, but with cool 
2001: A Space Odyssey
-style special effects? Yeah, it's talky and maybe a little slow. Of course it is. You can't take a Star Trek that's talky and a little slow? The theatre marked "Star Wars" is just down the hall, you animals, you savages. Go have fun with that, you absolute children.']

Title: Le¬†Corbeau
Text:
Remy Germain is a doctor in a French town who becomes the focus of a vicious smear campaign, as letters accusing him of having an affair and performing unlawful abortions are mailed to village leaders. The mysterious writer, who signs each letter as ‚ÄúLe Corbeau‚Äù (The Raven) soon targets the whole town, exposing everyone‚Äôs dark¬†secrets.
['Croaa croa croooaaa üê¶‍‚¨õ croooooa CROA CROA CROAAAA üê¶‍‚¨õüê¶‍‚¨õüê¶‍‚¨õ croaaa‚Ä¶. üê¶‍‚¨õ(bient√¥t 38ans)', 'Pretty bitterly grim fable of an anonymous poison pen writer undoing a small provincial French town at the seams by simply shining a light on some of its own shocking, hypocritical behavior. Unfortunately, due to being made during the Nazi occupation of France (and funded by a German production company) it was largely interpreted on release as a depiction of a corrupt French people rather than the dark, anti-informant allegory that it reads as decades later. Clouzot has an exceptional feel for the palpably tense, misanthropic atmosphere he generates and uses just about every visual tool he can (especially lighting and architecture) to show the poisonous and paranoid effect of becoming overly fearful, insular, and cruel in the face of a force of surveillance and threat.
Full discussion on ep 251 of my podcast SLEAZOIDS
.', 'A particularly unsparing look at humanity and our ability to turn on each other, Le Corbeau has been dirtied by history from the day it exited the womb. Made by the German funded Continental Films, Henri-Georges Clouzot was banned from making films until 1947 (lifted from its initial lifelong stamp). It was seen as Anti-French at the time it was made, it is now seen in a more Anti-Nazi light and more broadly an Anti-People light. The misanthropy is locked and loaded even though room is made for people to find each other and for the guilty to go punished.
Le Corbeau addresses the power, cowardice and impact of omnipresent anonymity in a small town that collapses like a house‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: A Woman Under the¬†Influence
Text:
Mabel Longhetti, desperate and lonely, is married to a Los Angeles municipal construction worker, Nick. Increasingly unstable, especially in the company of others, she craves happiness, but her extremely volatile behavior convinces Nick that she poses a danger to their family and decides to commit her to an institution for six months. Alone with a trio of kids to raise on his own, he awaits her return, which holds more than a few¬†surprises.
["there's a scene towards the end, where peter falk takes gena rowlands hand and puts it under the cold faucet water. it's bleeding and hurt and a little inflamed. he's not particularly gentle with her, ignoring as she winces in pain. he grabs a bandaid and slaps it on. he cannot tell her that he loves her.
he's not particularly concerned with her feelings or well-being. that she just had a break-down mere moments before. he's hoping that if he covers it up enough, she'll stop inconveniencing him and he won't have to call her crazy again. she'll go back to taking care of the children and they can have parties with their friends. maybe, he won't even have to yell anymore.
she needs help that her loved ones and family can't provide. that's immaterial. maybe, if she keeps her voice down enough and her emotions under check, she'll be okay. until the next time.", "Man, I really don't know. Similar to 'Faces', this shit is just so hard to get through. Took 4 breaks just to do something else for a few minutes. I really really hate saying things like this but I appreciate films like this more than I enjoy watching them. This thing is oozing with talent. Some of the best acting I've ever seen coupled with amazing direction and don't even get me started on the cinematography. I'm a fool for thinking I can get through his 5 films (the Criterion stuff) in a month. Works like this are meant to be thought about with time until I'm ready to dive back into something that raw. I really did love this movie but I can't emphasize how happy I was when it was over.", "A breathtaking whirlwind of raw middle-aged, blue-collar domestic emotion in intense close-up. Cassavetes camera unflinching laying bare two deeply incompatible, mentally unstable people so completely in love with one another and each other's eccentricities and faults that, no matter how awkward or painful, they are going to keep trying to make it work anyway. This has two of the most intimate, heart-breaking performances ever committed to film so there are obviously so many incredible micro-moments of sadness and comedy but there's none more crushing than Peter Falk‚Äôs Nick, finally realizing that his wife's odd social norm breaking quirks were her honest expressions of her thoughts and feelings and who she is (and how much he misses them and her), shouting‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Paranormal Activity: The Marked¬†Ones
Text:
Seventeen-year-old Jesse has been hearing terrifying sounds coming from his neighbor‚Äôs apartment, but when he turns on his camera and sets out to uncover their source, he encounters an ancient evil that won‚Äôt rest until it‚Äôs claimed his very¬†soul.
['Alright, let me get this straight.
This is...
1) The only film in the series with an actual plot.
2) The only film in the series with an actual structure.
3) The only film in the series with proactive characters instead of merely reactive ones.
4) The only film in the series where characters actually spend a decent amount of time outside.
5) The only film in the series where the characters are all fairly intelligent and immediately take the paranormal threat seriously instead of just all calling each other liars.
6) The only film in the series that actually takes advantage of continuity.
...And 
this
\xa0is the one that Letterboxd hates and thinks didn‚Äôt do anything different?
Wow, words escape‚Ä¶ 
more', "What was good:

-Actually likeable characters
-A cholo shooting witches with a shotgun.
-Comedic moments that are actually chuckle-worthy.
-A FUCKING CHOLO SHOOTING WITCHES WITH A GODDAMN SHOTGUN.

-really crowbarred connections to the previous movies in the series(the tapes from PA3, certain cameos, etc.)
It's probably the most watchable of the series next to the first, but that ain't sayin much.", "Record ghosts witches repeat.
Record ghosts witches repeat.
Record ghosts witches repeat.
Record ghosts witches repeat.
Record ghosts witches repeat.
This franchise in a nutshell.
The only scary thing is that they managed to make it even more boring than the previous one.

Title: Keep an Eye¬†Out
Text:
Louis just found the corpse of a man in front of his apartment building. Taken in for custody by Captain Buron, he finds himself on the wrong end of a surreal interrogation. But how can you prove you are innocent when the cops are¬†crazy?
["c'est pour √ßa", "ACTION! - THREE AUTEURS: MR. OIZO'S META DREAMS
Dupieux‚Äôs first film shot in France and absolutely the first to actually look like a movie, at least with a lot of cinematic flair and some real stunning cinematography and minimalist yet stylistic locations, namely the police department office in which most of the action takes place, has this simple though also futuristic look that‚Äôs eye-appealing. Dupieux also abandons the music board and lets his peer Tahiti Boy score the whole film, which results in these upbeat, sometimes classy, jazzy melodies that never call attention to themselves and help set the mood really well. The writing is great; there‚Äôs much of that surrealism you would expect from Quentin, but it‚Äôs all more‚Ä¶ 
more", "It's been a few years since 
Wrong Cops
, and it seems Quentin Dupieux has learned a few tricks since that transgressive outing, that's why. 
Keep An Eye Out
 is not only a much better satire and criticism of the modern police force and punishment system, but it feels a lot more fully formed and substantial, that's why. 
Working through his career forwards chronologically (from a point, anyway) has been fascinating, as I've been able to watch Dupieux get a grasp on the type of things that really fascinate him, that's why. 
Rubber
 was a hypodermic needle of meta right to the brain, and while the surrealist prankster deviated from the auteur/audience dynamic exploration on a few separate occasions, it slowly‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: How Green Was My¬†Valley
Text:
A man in his fifties reminisces about his childhood growing up in a Welsh mining village at the turn of the 20th¬†century.
['the movie was black and white so I unfortunately couldn‚Äôt see how green his valley was :/', "No greater film was made under the classical Hollywood production model - it's always been easy to talk about Ford's compositions but what of his montage? We know that well until Ford had Argosy Productions in 1947 that he would cut his sequences within the camera - for example if, in the middle of a master shot Ford knew he would need a close-up, he would place his hand in front of the lens until the specific reading was complete, removing it again once he knew he would cut back: this was to prevent studio editors from meddling with the footage as directors often were not let into the cutting room, either because of studio regulations or because that director‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'A wonderfully told narrative about working-class perseverance, yes but I was absolutely floored by the images. Just gobsmackingly beautiful compositions of men populating the 80-acre Welsh town set with their bodies (songs, lives), gorgeous mountain landscapes and sky as frequently admired by the camera as infected by the black smoke of the mine, richly-lit interiors where the harsh realities of work and familial duty push and pull at the characters until memory and flesh, the emotional and material are one and the same. Unbelievable.']

Title: Horror in the High¬†Desert
Text:
In July 2017, an experienced outdoor enthusiast vanished in Northern Nevada while on an outdoor excursion. After an extensive search, he was never located. On the three-year anniversary of his disappearance, friends and loved ones recall the events leading up to his vanishing, and for the first time, speak about the horrifying conclusion of his¬†fate.
['Here's a little story:
For a while now 
(not as often anymore)
 - I had a hyperfocus on watching videos on yt about unsolved mysteries. Specifically those that had sinister theories behind: sightings of possible UFOs, Bigfoot, giant monsters in the sea and things like that. And also, people disappearing. And one of the videos that struck me the most due to a small peculiarity, was the video of an adventurer, who claimed to have entered a cave with the shape of an 
"M"
. A cave that after he entered, he said that his whole body vibrated and a strange sensation permeated him the whole time he was there. After posting the story, many asked him to go there and‚Ä¶
 
more', 'Woah this was crazy‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.
crazy good!
Saw lots of good reviews for this ‚Äúmade during the pandemic‚Äù movie, but I hadn‚Äôt hadn‚Äôt heard or read about it anywhere else so I wasn‚Äôt convinced it was really going to live up to the LB hype, but I was terribly terribly WRONG there. I really don‚Äôt want to give a lot away because I agree with everyone else that going in blind is absolutely the best way to experience this and I think that holds true for most found footage horror. Speaking of, I love how I keep telling myself that I‚Äôm tired of the whole sub-genre and it‚Äôs getting played out and yet I still keep watching it and discovering total bangers‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Where 
Horror in the High Desert 
falls well short of the excellent\xa0
Savageland 
is its inability to make the mockumentary portion feel like anything more than stage-setting for the found-footage finale. To an extent, the interview segments wind up hurting the flow because there‚Äôs so much redundancy ‚Äî you‚Äôll sometimes get two or three interviewees sharing the same basic information in sequence, leaving the story to spin its wheels and stretching the runtime without adding anything of consequence. All the while, there‚Äôs plenty of wide open space to explore, lots of untapped potential to leverage the interviews and ratchet up intrigue or add layers to the story. There‚Äôs a real missed opportunity to dig more into the pathos of Gary Hinge,‚Ä¶ 
more']

was the perfect way to follow up Hitchcock‚Äôs

... updating the mystery element with an 80‚Äôs slasher whodunnit vibe with\xa0a reformed Norman being such a great angle for intrigue‚Äîit‚Äôs a movie no one asked for but ended up being one of my favorite sequels ever. The perfect mood for a follow up if you ask me.

III...\xa0
where Perkins‚Äô fornicates

What a fascinating franchise.', "c'mon norman not while they're on the toilet man", 'It‚Äôs hard to believe that I didn‚Äôt remember a lot of this film because it‚Äôs honestly pretty damn great! Perkins does a respectable job in the directors chair and I love all the neon trash lighting and general sleazy aesthetic with just the right amount of 80‚Äôs slasher influence.
Hitchcock‚Äôs original is the ultimate B movie, but the sequel tried to take it in a different direction and class it up a bit and add a heavy mystery element. This one gets right back to its roots with Norman doing his thing and the kills are absolutely superb.
This is a tough series to rate because I love all of the films for different reasons. This one is like the slutty sister of the family and let‚Äôs face it, she always has the best time!']

Text:

I am not a big fan of Hollywood's need to revamp all these classic fairytales. Most of them are excellent and grim stories to begin with, so why change that?
Take the fairytale of Hansel and Gretel for example. It's a story about child abuse, cannibalism and horrific murder. That in itself is more than enough, right? But no, riding on Snow White's coattails we now have the story of Hansel and Gretel post traumatic candy cottage experience.
This shouldn't work and plot wise it doesn't. It is somewhat uninspired and therefore doesn't really hold any surprises. It also has a couple of bizarre ideas that aren't really fleshed out enough (Hansel's‚Ä¶

Fun movie with a ton of practical effects gore that mostly nails the straight faced tone the comedy necessitates. Title: Enys¬†Men
Text:

That is not to say that I did not receive a takeaway, however. Enys Men assaulted me with a feeling, an evocation of a specific space and time and emotion. I can tell you I related to this film, and yet I can‚Äôt tell you why and how. It‚Äôs not logic, it‚Äôs gut. The editing, the sound, the texture, all that of gut instinct. Title: Murmur of the¬†Heart
Text:
This loosely plotted coming-of-age tale follows the life of 15-year-old Laurent Chevalier as he stumbles his way over the burgeoning swell of adolescence in 1950s France. After having his first sexual experience with a prostitute and dodging the lips of a priest, Chevalier contracts a case of scarlet fever. When the fever leaves him with a heart murmur, Chevalier is placed in a sanatorium, along with his over-attentive and adulterous¬†mother.
["To quote Slovenian philosopher Slavoj ≈Ωi≈æek,
It's one of those nice, gentle French movies where you have incest.", "Laurent, you motherfucker!
Fascinating exploration of sexual maturation and the life of a teenager who is simultaneously very emotionally mature and unsure how to act on his feelings.
Louis Malle has a broad range of work, but his sensitivity towards childhood and love for jazz always shines through. I am so glad I've discovered his work this last year. It is occasionally challenging but always immersive.", '"To think someone might do that in Dijon."
From the director who would later issue a tender account of Dixieland child prostitution comes Oedipus-
haute bourgeois
-style in the form of 
Murmur of the Heart 
(
Le souffle au c≈ìur
),\xa0in which a haughty teen does some advanced bonding with his highly liberated mother while convalescing at an Alsatian spa. Despite its notorious incest theme, a cultural backdrop of parochial stuffiness, and recurrent allusions to the calamitous siege of Dien Bien Phu (betokening the first round of death throes for French colonialism‚Äîwhich would be further diminished by the onset of the Algerian War of Independence half a year later), Louis Malle's concupiscent coming of age tale nonetheless sets an extraordinary standard for chaotic buoyancy‚Ä¶

Title: Satyricon
Text:
After his young lover, Gitone, leaves him for another man, Encolpio decides to kill himself, but a sudden earthquake destroys his home before he has a chance to do so. Now wandering around Rome in the time of Nero, Encolpio encounters one bizarre and surreal scene after¬†another.
["Afterthoughts:
 Fellini‚Äôs orgiastic odyssey through Ancient Rome is a sheer, debauched delight.
Gliding seamlessly from one erotic and extravagant episode to the next, Fellini takes us on a richly symbolic journey of sex and violence that beams with colourful sights and sounds, critiquing the consumerist hedonism of capitalist modernity, whilst offering an eccentric look at one of history's most interesting civilisations.
Similarly to the films of Alejandro Jodorowsky, it is a great joy to see Fellini granted all the necessary resources to realise his audacious and ambitious surrealist masterpiece on the large scale it clearly required.
The average ratings for this film are criminally low! Worthy of higher and wider praise for certain.", 'Might fuck around and buy myself a slave twink.', "If an experiment was conducted consisting in submitting a modest cinema connoisseur to this beautiful and decadently disastrous orgy of anarchic cultural aspects of Rome, perhaps the first name that would pop up to his head was Pasolini. Surprisingly, it isn't. More surprisingly, this rebellious piece of art entered the business before Pasolini's Trilogy of Life. Truth is, Satyricon is the turning point for the legend that Fellini already was before autobiographical memoirs and nostalgia invaded his mind with controversial youth moments added here and there for spicing up his love letters to the city that gave him life and an identity forever.
99/100"]

David, a struggling comedy writer fresh off from breaking up with his boyfriend, moves from New York City to Sacramento to help his sick mother. Living with his conservative father and much-younger sisters for the first time in ten years, he feels like a stranger in his childhood home. As his mother‚Äôs health declines, David frantically tries to extract meaning from this horrible experience and convince everyone (including himself) that he‚Äôs ‚Äúdoing¬†okay.‚Äù
['lucas hedges in lady bird grew up to be jesse plemons in other people', 'As a gay man who moved from a small town to a bigger city, I can attest to the painful accuracy of so many details found in "Other People." 
I groaned out loud when all his relatives kept calling him a "big city boy," was in hysterics when they were eating at Applebee's (already so accurate) and the dad said "bet they don't have fries this good in the big city," and don't get me started on "Drops of Jupiter."
All these little details already elevated this movie for me, but then you add a poignantly average depiction of gay life (complete with embarrassingly realistic sex scene), a sweetly affecting performance by Jesse Plemons, and a heartbreaking turn from Molly‚Ä¶ 
more', 'a 30-year-old writer named David goes home to care for a parent who's dying of cancer before Christmas. I couldn't relate. 
not necessarily a great movie (it's a bit sketchy in key places, and Bradley Whitford has a doozy of a line about "debating" his son's sexuality), but trust me when i say that it captures its subject with rare accuracy and nuance. eerie how the process is so indivisibly personal, and yet threaded with so many commonalities. uncanny, really. and while i didn't think the performances were necessarily anything special... other then how Jesse Plemons nails how it feels to say "it's fine. i mean, it's not fine. but it's fine" for 9 months... i don't know what to say to anyone who thinks they were overblown.']

Title: Lethal¬†Weapon
Text:
A veteran cop and an unstable detective become partners who must put their differences aside in order to bring down a heroin-smuggling ring run by ex-Special¬†Forces.
["A few quick things on a movie I have been overthinking for 3+ decades.
I love that it's largely Murtaugh's story. He's the main character; Riggs is inflicted on him. Roger's never a mystery to us and Riggs is entirely unpredictable, not just the titular lethal weapon, duh, but truly an unstable danger. It's hard to remember that this collection of what would become laughable tropes was itself a response to same. It's like if someone with a DSM-IV and a shitty attitude got a look at Paul Kersey. Throw in Roger & Martin's (vaguely implied) shared but vastly different experiences of Vietnam and you got yourself a stew.
Speaking of Vietnam, the villains are also notably not street punk dope‚Ä¶ 
more", "78
Two forces, diametrically opposed, stumbling through their own baggage while trying not to fuck shit up, whether that be personally or professionally. Full of classic action set-pieces and iconic dialogue - it's nonetheless the details that reinforce the dramatic strength of the modern buddy-cop template. Maybe I'm just nostalgic around the holidays but the ending had me tearing up.", '"God hates me, that's what it is."
"Hate him back. It works for me."']

Title: The Ninth¬†Gate
Text:
A rare book dealer finds himself at the heart of a string of paranormal events when he is hired to find the last two copies of a text, The Nine Gates of the Kingdom of Shadows, capable of summoning the¬†Devil.
['Depp is the worst rare book seller ever. His treatment of the priceless 400 year old book included:
- handling it without gloves
- walking with it rain\xa0
- blowing cigarette smoke into it
- ashing cigarette in it\xa0
- drinking coffee while reading\xa0
- tossing book to colleague', '1999
Stanley Kubrick: Our ruling class are a cult of perverted Satanists who consecrate their bonds with ritualized sadism and debauchery.
Roman Polanski: lol yeah it owns.', 'Manifesting Satan through ritual is a simple matter of clipping the right comic strips from 15th century.
Johnny Depp plays a rare books expert who spends the entire film smoking cigarettes and drinking red wine directly over the priceless tomes he shoves in and out of a messenger bag. Essentially the fun and goofy version of Eyes Wide Shut. Polanski has a knack for imbuing beautifully appointed interiors with a subtle menace, probably has some experience in this regard.']

Title: Pavements
Text:

['A guy in the Venice press screening tonight took his phone out to google the band Pavement', 'My experience watching this movie was that I walked out halfway through and Stephen malkmus was standing directly outside. He asked me if I didn‚Äôt like his movie. I told him it was fine but my neck was hurting. He said fair, and then I left.', 'After watching this I am not convinced this band actually exists']

Title: The Boy in the Striped¬†Pyjamas
Text:
When his family moves from their home in Berlin to a strange new house in Poland, young Bruno befriends Shmuel, a boy who lives on the other side of the fence where everyone seems to be wearing striped pajamas. Unaware of Shmuel‚Äôs fate as a Jewish prisoner or the role his own Nazi father plays in his imprisonment, Bruno embarks on a dangerous journey inside the camp‚Äôs¬†walls.
['This was a complete and utter embarrassment to Holocaust historicism.\xa0
Predictable, cliched, and contrived.\xa0I don‚Äôt even know what message this movie was trying to send. Friendship knows no boundaries among the innocent? To show that the German boy‚Äôs father is still capable of love despite his monstrousness?? 
It‚Äòs pretty distasteful that the tragedy is not the senseless murder of millions of Jews but the unfortunate murder of one German boy who didn‚Äôt belong in the camps and didn‚Äôt\xa0
deserve
\xa0to die.', 'Oh hey, it‚Äôs a pretty lighthearted film that‚Äôs kinda sweet 
Hey where are they headed off to
OH
oh
oh
Oh no no no
oh', "I found this so extremely tasteless. It exploits the holocaust for a cheap movie, but even worse is how the entire plot just leads up to a German kid dying which we're meant to find as the saddest part of the movie. Why do so many movies dealing with tragedies focus on people who weren't affected by it or sometimes even the ones committing it? It's insulting."]

Title: Let It¬†Snow
Text:
In a small town on Christmas Eve, a snowstorm brings together a group of young people. They soon find their friendships and love lives colliding, and come Christmas morning, nothing will be the¬†same.
['must a movie be ‚Äúgood‚Äù? is it not enough to evoke warm feelings of christmas spirit AND have holiday lesbians?', 'this took one actor from every coming of age universe in recent years and threw them all together... wild', 'when that joan cusack voiceover said ‚Äúso even if it gets you stranded or stuck in a snow bank you just gotta let it snow‚Äù that was some powerful stuff wow i felt that!!!!!!']

Title: Jackie¬†Brown
Text:
Jackie Brown is a flight attendant who gets caught in the middle of smuggling cash into the country for her gunrunner boss. When the cops try to use Jackie to get to her boss, she hatches a plan ‚Äî with help from a bail bondsman ‚Äî to keep the money for¬†herself.
['I like how imperfect these people are. Max Cherry isn‚Äôt a badass gangster in a black and white suit; he‚Äôs a schlub with thinning hair. Jackie Brown isn‚Äôt a master criminal; before her big confrontation with a gun runner she practices her tough guy quick draw. Louis Gara forgets where he parked his car at the mall in the middle of a robbery. They‚Äôre just people! I think some of Tarantino‚Äôs later movies, great as they are, could use a little more of that humanness.
I remember some people were disappointed that 
Jackie Brown

Pulp Fiction
 when it came out, but even if Tarantino‚Äôs choices aren‚Äôt quite as flashy here, they‚Äôre absolutely perfect.‚Ä¶

Title: Submarine
Text:
15-year-old deep-thinking Welsh schoolboy Oliver Tate struggles to initiate and maintain a relationship with Jordana, his devilish, dark-haired classmate at their Swansea high school. As his parents‚Äô marriage begins to fall apart, similar problems arise in his relationship with¬†Jordana.
['i put off watching this movie for a whole goddamn year because i thought it was a beatles biopic omfg', 'four stars out of five for alex turner', "‚ÄúDear Jordana,
Thank you for letting me explore your perfect body. I could drink your blood. in 10th grade i lent this book to my boyfriend at the time, hoping he‚Äôd read it and write me a love letter even just a fraction as beautiful this one. five months later, he dumped me over the phone and returned my copy with a bittersweet break-up note tucked in the pages. it‚Äôs still‚Ä¶

Title: Broken¬†Arrow
Text:
When rogue stealth-fighter pilot Vic Deakins deliberately drops off the radar while on maneuvers, the Air Force ends up with two stolen nuclear warheads ‚Äì and Deakins‚Äôs co-pilot, Riley Hale, is the military‚Äôs only hope for getting them back. Traversing the deserted canyons of Utah, Hale teams with park ranger Terry Carmichael to put Deakins back in his¬†box.
["Totally slept on. Woo spent a lot of his American career being chastised for not being constant crazy-go-nuts, as if he was duty-bound by US studio budgets to present us with a feature-length version of the last 15 minutes of THE KILLER, as if the majors would ever allow him such a thing. 
So then, stung by the production and ratings difficulties on HARD TARGET, he deliberately set out to westernize with this one, trading gunfights and cities for wide-open Utah desert (totally a poor man's Monument Valley here) and all the helicopters he cared to detonate. Inexplicably rejected to this day as a misstep, this is absolutely Woo's film, if not in particular strain of mayhem then certainly in‚Ä¶ 
more", '"Would you mind not shooting at the thermonuclear weapons?"
Probably the greatest film ever made.', '"I say god-damn what a rush."
Broken Arrow was a dumb, fun distraction. Low-tier 
Woo but he 
still stages some really cool over-the-top action sequences, John Travolta is nuts & having fun and everything in between was just OK. This movie would be so much better if Nic Cage was in it instead of Christian Slater.']

Title: Tomorrowland
Text:
Bound by a shared destiny, a bright, optimistic teen bursting with scientific curiosity and a former boy-genius inventor jaded by disillusionment embark on a danger-filled mission to unearth the secrets of an enigmatic place somewhere in time and space that exists in their collective memory as¬†‚ÄúTomorrowland.‚Äù
["So close to being good at every turn. It's just slightly off. It's like a Disney Channel movie with an unlimited budget. Beautifully optimistic but nonsensical.", 'A 2.7 average rating. 
Am I missing something? Am I dumb? Am I out of touch? Am I ahead of the times? Am I behind the times? Am I a part of any time at all?
An achingly sincere, optimistic, passionate, ambitious, and lovingly-made ode to the resilience and creativity of the human spirit told through an adventurous, campy, retro sci-fi lens??
GIVE ME MORE OF THIS PLEASE!!!', "Are you a dreamer, or a non-believer? Do you have hope, or do you live in despair? Are you an optimist, or a pessimist? Is the glass half full, or half empty? Do you like Coke, or Pepsi? What if you could travel to a world that was full of endless possibilities? Would you seize the moment? Would you make a difference? For Casey Newton, a teenage girl with a rebellious streak, nothing is impossible. She still sees the good, and doesn't focus on the bad. After getting arrested for some criminal mischief; Casey finds in her possession a magic wings pin, that if touched by her, takes her to a place called Tomorrowland. It's a Disney movie, directed by‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Margin¬†Call
Text:
A thriller that revolves around the key people at an investment bank over a 24-hour period during the early stages of the financial¬†crisis.
['It‚Äôs just money; it‚Äôs made up. Pieces of paper with pictures on it so we don‚Äôt have to kill each other to get something to eat
Star studded thriller about the eve of the financial crash of 2008. This film is so captivating with all sorts of characters, from morally bankrupt to good hearted people, but in the end they‚Äôre all in it for the same reason. If it wasn‚Äôt for 
The Big Short,
\xa0this would be the definitive movie of the financial crisis.', "‚ÄúPlease, speak as you might to a young child. Or a golden retriever. It wasn't brains that brought me here.‚Äù
Ever since this 
GameStop
 malarkey I haven‚Äôt been able to get Stanley Tucci‚Äôs character out of my mind.
There‚Äôs a scene where Tucci and Paul Bettany are sitting on the stoop of an immaculate Brooklyn Brownstone contemplating the major theme of the movie: nothingness.
Tucci recounts the most meaningful piece of occupation he was ever involved in, the building of a bridge that significantly benefits commuters. It acts as an allegory for how one mans actions can have tangible benefits to others, and stands in contrast to the absurdity of moving ‚Äúnothing‚Äù around from one account to another.
Tucci is‚Ä¶ 
more", "You won't believe how many ways men in suits can mournfully stare out skyscraper windows."]

Title: Pillow¬†Talk

Playboy songwriter Brad Allen‚Äôs succession of romances annoys his neighbor, interior designer Jan Morrow, who shares a telephone party line with him and hears all his breezy routines. After Jan unsuccessfully lodges a complaint against him, Brad sets about to seduce her in¬†the guise of a sincere and upstanding Texas rancher. When mutual friend Jonathan discovers that his best friend is moving in on the girl he desires, however, sparks¬†fly.

also me: rock hudson can break me in half üò©
tbh despite some very outdated elements, this is so charming, u can‚Äôt make me *not* fall for a movie in which rock hudson (pretending to be a texan in new york) tells doris day, ‚Äúyou done did a terrible thing to me...you made me glad i ain‚Äôt in texas.‚Äù reminds me of another texan boy in new york!! ü§†‚ù§Ô∏è
35mm. Metrograph.']

Title: Outland
Text:
On the sunless moon Io, Marshall William T. O‚ÄôNiel goes toe-to-toe with the corrupt manager of a mining colony and his gang of roughnecks while investigating a rash of worker¬†suicides.
['I love that somebody made an Alien knockoff that borrows only the least commercially appealing aspects of that film: Strong anti-capital subtext, gorgeously detailed used future sets and miniatures, long, mute dialogue scenes with text-based computer interfaces, you know, all the stuff that made Alien such a huge smash. This rules.', "Blends the dirty, industrial blue collar sci-fi detail of 
Alien
 and a conspiracy noir/morality play western with Sean Connery essentially acting as the lonely space sheriff investigating the brutal exploitation of mining workers at the hands of a corrupt corporation that drugs and kills them (via 
vivid exploding heads
) for profit efficiency. Showing that despite all our astonishing technological advancements, the same capitalist greed of the Old West is still very much our guiding force and even in space sometimes the solution is still a principled, shotgun-wielding cowboy. A fun idea that Hyams stages with incredible genre-bending craft; filthy sets, goopy squibs, and gorgeous miniature/analog FX worthy of Kubrick (that presumably got him the 
2010
 gig) as the dexterous camera moves through the cramped, tensely pressurized space rig replicating the thrilling chases and brawls/gunfights you'd expect to see tracked on horseback or in a grimy city street.
Full discussion on ep 320 of my podcast SLEAZOIDS
.", "Pings two of my biggest fetishes in that A) it's not just HIGH NOON in space but one that replaces the fear of rabid anti-communism with its own anti-capitalist streak; and B) it's loaded with analog effects tech (specifically Introvision, an in-camera front-projection compositing process). I know it's weird but I get a genuine kick out of Connery storming through a set of burnished fiberglass saloon-style swinging doors."]

Title: Godard Mon¬†Amour
Text:
In 1967, during the making of ‚ÄúLa Chinoise,‚Äù film director Jean-Luc Godard falls in love with 19-year-old actress Anne Wiazemsky and marries¬†her.
['The funniest part of all of this is that the guy sitting next to me in the theater was googling Anna Karina pics while watching the film', 'Extremely different from what I imagined. I was expecting something like 
The Artist
 ‚Äî a sincere homage, obviously stylized and charming ‚Äî a tribute that despite its limitations, understands the importance of what it intends to revere. But guys‚Ä¶ Everything here feels more like mockery. A mockery disguised as love for cinema. There‚Äôs no affection on screen, but a (
bad
) caricature tone, as if the director is saying, ‚Äú
Look how ridiculous all of this was.
‚Äù
I understand, of course, that the caricatured tone is intentional. It really reminded me of an almost Woody Allen-esque comedy, 
Annie Hall
 style, with fourth wall breaks, self-aware dialogues, and affectedly neurotic characters. But this caricature goes beyond what‚Äôs acceptable ‚Äî it shifts from eccentric‚Ä¶
 
more', 'Basic Godard who fucks...
That the great French New Wave director Jean-Luc Godard hasn‚Äôt always been a very kind man isn‚Äôt news to anyone. His rebelliousness is in fact the very reason why he was such an important and controversial figure at a time when French ‚Äìand European- cinema was in a state of limbo in the late 1950s and the 1960s. With Redoubtable, French director Michel Hazanavicius (The Artist) decides to tackle not only this public persona of the director, but even more so his private life at a tumultuous time. Why focus on the personal aspects when the public dimension of Godard‚Äôs life, especially in the late 1960s, was already so evidently interesting, from badly received films to‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The Golem: How He Came Into the¬†World
Text:
In 16th-century Prague, a rabbi creates the Golem - a giant creature made of clay. Using sorcery, he brings the creature to life in order to protect the Jews of Prague from¬†persecution.
['jewish folklore made into an astrological, expressionist monster movie about power and creation. the fx and compositions are pretty stunning and help merge some of its implicit ideas about magic and storytelling. happy hanukkah!', 'Whether it be clay figures or cadavers, the idea of imbuing inanimate objects with life has long been a staple of the horror story. From European folk tales and gothic literature, to pulpy American potboilers, horror has long been marked by stories of human beings granting life to things that have no business living. "The Golem: How He Came into the World" is such a tale. Based on Jewish folklore, the film is an expressionistic and engrossing look at humankind's desire to play God.
When the Jewish population of Prague is ousted by the emperor, a Rabbi takes it upon himself to protect his people by creating a Golem, a hulking clay figure come to life. Paul Wegener and Carl‚Ä¶ 
more', '#30 of 31 - HOOPTOBER 5.0 : We Don‚Äôt Need A Stretcher In There We Need A Mop 
Many believe this is the forefather of Frankenstein! A remarkable Silent film that lives up to its reputation! One of the unexpected joys to be had was the romance blooming between the two lovebirds Knight Florian and Jewish maiden Miriam! Extremely well done with actors that were exceptionally expressive! I could feel their hearts beating as one all the way from here! For a 1920s film it ventured a little bit too close to risque territory I imagine!
A Rabbi creates a monster from clay, the very idea of creating such a creature that would do his bidding was no doubt intoxicating‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The Magnificent¬†Seven
Text:
An oppressed Mexican peasant village hires seven gunfighters to help defend their¬†homes.
["We deal in lead, friend.
-Vin
I think most people can't log 
The Magnificent Seven
 without mentioning 
Akira Kurosawa
 and 
Seven Samurai
 because they know if they don't, someone from the 
Letterboxd Cinephile Police
 will mention in the comments how it pales in comparison to 
Samurai
, which is a masterpiece, and how the western apparently owes everything to 
Kurosawa
.
What most self-proclaimed cinephiles fail to mention is that one of 
Kurosawa
's biggest influences is 
John Ford
 and Hollywood westerns. It's not because their ignorant of the fact or dispute it, it's something that was said by 
Kurosawa
 himself. It's because since they don't view 
Ford
 as an auteur like 
Kurosawa
, they really don't want to mention him. They only want‚Ä¶ 
more", "Qualitative comparisons to 
The Seven Samurai
 are fruitless. Apples & Oranges. However, here are seven magnificent things about 
The Magnificent Seven
:
(1) Steve McQueen riding shotgun on a hearse.
(2) Idiots who mistake James Coburn‚Äôs apathy for cowardice. 
(3) Yul Brynner‚Äôs regal gate. Did he walk like that around the house?
(4) Eli Wallach‚Äôs menacing practicability and red ruffled tux shirt. 
(5) The lonesome arithmetic of the hired gun, and the burden of a gun being less than the responsibility of a father. 
(6) The setting of the peasant‚Äôs village in a gorgeous crook in sawtooth mountains, a valley worth fighting for. Elmer Bernstein's rip roaring theme.
(7) Glorious widescreen color.", '"You think I am brave because I carry a gun? Well, your fathers are much braver because they carry responsibility, for you, your brothers, your sisters, and your mothers. And this responsibility is like a big rock that weighs a ton. It bends and it twists them until finally it buries them under the ground. And there's nobody says they have to do this. They do it because they love you, and because they want to. I have never had this kind of courage. Running a farm, working like a mule every day with no guarantee anything will ever come of it. This is bravery. That's why I never even started anything like that... that's why I never will."
Cried during this scene. The only reason I'm not giving this 5 stars is because Horst Buchholz kind of annoyed me.']

Title: On Swift¬†Horses
Text:
In the 1950s, a seemingly sensible newlywed and her wayward brother-in-law undertake parallel journeys of risk, romance, and¬†self-discovery.
['what if you were LEE and EVERYONE around you was GAY', 'when your circle small but yall gay af üòÇ', 'This film asks a very important question\xa0\n‚ÄúGay brother? Or gay wife?‚Äù']

Title: Away We¬†Go
Text:
Verona and Burt have moved to Colorado to be close to Burt‚Äôs parents but, with Verona expecting their first child, Burt‚Äôs parents inexplicably decide to move to Belgium, now leaving them in a place they hate and without a support structure in place. They set off on a whirlwind tour of of disparate locations where they have friends or relatives, sampling not only different cities and climates but also different families. Along the way they realize that the journey is less about discovering where they want to live and more about figuring out what type of parents they want to¬†be. √ó
["Continuing to catch up on the Sam Mendes films that I haven't seen. Was loving it for the first 30 minutes when things seem to get broad. But the scenes that shine, really shine. Absolutely love Allison Janney. 
Due to lack of time, I can't add much to these logs for now. :( 
Maybe in the future.
Watched on Blu-ray rented from Netflix", 'John Krasinski and Maya Rudolph share a beautiful chemistry and play a key role in holding your attention. When life turns unexpectedly tragic and unfair, it‚Äôs all about finding the silver lining and moving ahead positively especially for the sake of one another. It is hilariously quirky, lighthearted and at the same time moving, making this feel good road movie engaging enough and worthwhile.', "Nightmare couple zigzags across North America to visit other even more nightmarish couples before settling down somewhere to be nightmare parents. Gets better down the stretch, when they hang out with more down-to-earth people, but even then you get the weird spectacle of Melanie Lynskey doing the world's saddest amateur-night pole dance mere days after her fifth miscarriage. And good god every second of that Maggie Gyllenhaal segment is so excruciatingly over-cranked. This feels like something you might get in a public-radio pledge drive. 
Note: This was another Mendes film, like 
American Beauty
 I reviewed positively on first viewing. It really is rare for me to about-face on films this completely and I've done it twice with him. I'll have to puzzle over what they means, other than Mendes' talent for making a good surface impression."]

Title: Dragon Ball Z: Fusion¬†Reborn
Text:
Not paying attention to his job, a young demon allows the evil cleansing machine to overflow and explode, turning the young demon into the infamous monster Janemba. Goku and Vegeta make solo attempts to defeat the monster, but realize their only option is¬†fusion.
['This film is fucking weird.
There is an entire subplot in this film in which Adolf Fucking Hitler returns to life, commands hundreds of tanks that fire giant crayons and are manned by skeleton zombies, and tries to take over the world. As Goten and Trunks transform into super saiyans to take him down, he considers recruiting them due to their blond hair, blue eyes and super strength. I am not making this shit up.
Meanwhile, Goku battles a giant demonic baby that was created when a teenage intern played his rock music too loud causing him to become distracted from his job changing barrels on a device that syphons off evil energy from souls - which promptly exploded, doused‚Ä¶ 
more', 'GOTENKS CONFIRMED ANTIFA', 'We did it, Trunks! We stopped the Holocaust!', 'Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba! Janemba!', "Trunks and Goten would've stopped World War 2 in an instant", 'Came for Gogeta vs Janemba, stayed for Gotenks vs Hitler', 'Holy shit, I had zero recollection of actual, in-canon Dragonball Hitler.', 'would you believe me if I told you Hitler comes back to life in this one and when he sees a Super Saiyan he says ‚ÄúBlonde hair? Blue eyes? Super strength? I should be recruiting them.‚Äù', "And we're back to the good stuff! After the two letdowns of the Broly sequels, it feels good to be back on track again. 
Other than Super Saiyan 2 Gohan, I would have to say Gogeta is my next favorite transformation/character. We only ever see him in GT, which is hated by most fans. I can't help but love his design and his absurd capability to wreck shop with the power he holds. 
Keeping on the topic of transformation, Janemba (the evolved form) remains iconic and falls in line with those intimidating villains who don't speak a word. A truly bad motherfunker. 
It's not all serious however, as most DBZ films go, working in lots of jokes. I'm surprised we‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Dragon Ball Z: Fusion Reborn (1995)
The Best of the Best (In Plain Sight)
Because re-watch it‚Äôs an experience too
Dragon Ball Movies Ranked (Turning blonde is the new power up)
Wow! Ok this is my new favorite Dragon Ball movie! It‚Äôs amazing how this could be so good but short at once, the story take time after the 
Majin Boo Saga 
and this animation style will be always my favorite.
This is the first movie that introduce 
Gogeta
 
in the franchise and I‚Äôve to say is probably the best transformation/fusion! His design and how they mix both voices was great. And I‚Äôm glad that now this design in canon in the DB Universe (Introduced in 
Dragon Ball Super
)
Good movies!
Recommended.', 'Vegeta: I would rather be dead than fuse with you!!
Goku: Vegeta, you are dead and you have no choice.
Although they are not canonical in the series, Dragon Ball movies always have the particularity of being memorable with an overdose of energy for a guaranteed fusion.', 'I don‚Äôt know how to justify giving this a perfect rating, so I won‚Äôt. I just fucking love this movie.\xa0
I‚Äôve been sick all week, and I really hate my new job, so I was in a pretty shit mood, and the only thing I could think to cheer myself up with was this glorious piece of work. I didn‚Äôt get into Dragon Ball until Kai came out when I was a freshmen in high school, but ever since then I‚Äôve been completely obsessed. I used to watch this movie on infinite repeat. It‚Äôs got everything I want out of an anime movie. Lightning-fast action sequences, gorgeous 90‚Äôs animation, a bombastic color palette, and all the comedy you‚Äôd expect. The‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Corpus¬†Christi
Text:
A pious 20-year-old juvenile delinquent is sent to work at a sawmill in a small town; on arrival, he dresses up as a priest and accidentally takes over the local parish. The arrival of this young, charismatic preacher is an opportunity for the local community to begin the healing process after a tragedy that happened a year¬†prior.
['listen... after 
ethan hawke
 in 
first reformed
 and 
andrew scott
 in 
fleabag
, priest movies and shows are just not the same anymore man', 'Great film. Totally engaging, funny and brutal. The ending is quite a doozy. And Bartosz Bielenia - wow! Star in the making. This guy will be a Bond villain guaranteed. 
One could call it high concept. It's essentially a "convict hiding in plain sight" movie - I kept thinking of We're No Angels ('89). And I'm sure Hollywood is already developing a remake. 
Definitely going to check out director Jan Komasa's earlier works, Warsaw '44 and Suicide Room. I hear they are great.
Watched Academy Screener link', 'Seeing a great film that is masterfully made is like falling in love, you just need to tell everyone about it.
So, here I am telling you to see Corpus Christi. It is a wonderfully crafted film that transports you to a place and time and guides you to fall in love with the character.
Thank you for everyone on Twitter who recommended this film to me, it has officially changed my life for the better.
Let‚Äôs all strive for the perfection that is this incredible filmmaking.
I am here, confessing that I am a sinner. I will make films better in this films image.
I feel born again to the gods of cinema.
Join me, on the criterion channel.']

Title: Mysterious¬†Skin
Text:
A teenage hustler and a young man obsessed with alien abductions cross paths, together discovering a horrible, liberating¬†truth.
['This movie is beautiful, captivating, fascinating, moving, powerful and an absolute masterpiece.\nAnd I will never watch it again.', '‚ÄúI wished with all my heart that we could just leave this world behind, rise like two angels in the night and magically disappear.‚Äù', "So violent and so innocent. I honestly can‚Äôt remember if Araki had this many shots of characters looking directly into the camera in his other work but that choice is working stronger than ever here. What I really appreciate about this is how he‚Äôs capturing the manipulation in all forms of abuse. His use of shoegaze also does so much as far as romanticizing not these specific events but adolescence. I just felt very close to Neil by the end, as though I was one of those little moons orbiting around him. I'll never forget about this movie."]

Title: The¬†Grinch

It could be his head wasn‚Äôt screwed on just right. It could be, perhaps, the midterm polls were too tight. Title: Margot at the¬†Wedding
Text:
Margot Zeller is a short story writer with a sharp wit and an even sharper tongue. On the eve of her estranged sister Pauline‚Äôs wedding to unemployed musician/artist/depressive Malcolm at the family seaside home, Margot shows up unexpectedly to rekindle the sisterly bond and offer her own brand of support. What ensues is a nakedly honest and subversively funny look at family¬†dynamics.
['only Noah would use his blank check to make the most unpleasant film of all time', 'Like if a bunch of Wes Anderson characters had to go through the looking glass and live real lives. So upsetting and so funny.', '"I haven\'t had that thing yet, where you realize that you\'re not the most important person in the world."\nI have to give to to Noah Baumbach; he\'s an extremely talented writer, and that was one of the darkest, most fascinating comedies(?) I\'ve seen in quite some time... so dark, in fact, that some might argue it\'s not a comedy at all - quite similar in tone to his previous film, The Squid and the Whale, which is unquestionably one of my favorite black comedies of all-time. All of the performances are realized, especially Kidman\'s and Leigh\'s, and provide a realistic look into the lives of an extremely dysfunctional family, a microcosm of the selfishness that dwells in America\'s capitalist/consumerist/materialist‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Pulse
Text:
In the immense city of Tokyo, the darkness of the afterlife lures some of its inhabitants who are desperately trying to escape the sadness and isolation of the modern¬†world.
["Imagine if the internet wasn't actually a tool for establishing meaningful connections with one another that we all obviously know and agree that it is but was just another, newer, digital form of the terrifying existential isolation and mortality we've felt from the very beginning........ haha........ unless? 
Think I'm gonna need to come back to this one because it's a very good depiction of ghosts as a lonely invading force of inescapable depression but it didn't quite get under my skin the same way 
Cure
 did even though it definitely borrows much of the same trancelike atmosphere, stillness and sense of societal decay/sickness infecting those around you, and as demonstrated by the ending is intending a very different feeling I‚Ä¶ 
more", '"...once the system's complete, it'll function on its own and become permanent." 
Unbelievable. I need to watch it again, but certainty one of the seminal films of the 21st Century. Indeed a very digital ghost story, one which encourages us to reflect on the new spaces which have been created or transformed since 2000. People interact with computer screens, televisions...but rarely ever phones. Perhaps because there is no screen (or wasn't really in 2001) for a telephone? It's very interesting and telling that the movie's near-climax (only because the movie takes a sudden, very unexpected shift following which I'm still struggling to make sense out of) is in an abandoned factory, an analogue space, and one where ghosts exist in.‚Ä¶ 
more', 'a techno-ghost story that suggests the hollow detachment of the internet is a symptom that is both highly contagious and inescapable üòÅ
Pulse
 presciently predicted in 2001 that widespread internet use would lead to chronic loneliness, isolation, and misery; states of mind that are represented here as shadowy black stains and paranoid red tape. the dreary and dread-filled atmosphere supersedes its thin plot, crafting something trepidatious and ambiguous, eliciting scares from the ethereal and the existential rather than the visceral. had to see it on 35mm with a crowd so the internet ghosts that feed off of solitude couldn‚Äôt get me']

Title: The¬†Outsider
Text:
When an insidious supernatural force edges its way into a seemingly straightforward investigation into the gruesome murder of a young boy, it leads a seasoned cop and an unorthodox investigator to question everything they believe¬†in.
['Inside every ten-episode miniseries is a two-hour movie struggling to get out.', 'Sets up a very compelling, disorienting mystery with a really impressive, portentous mood in the first few episodes that it then kinda struggles to justify for the remaining like... seven hours.', 'This is a fascinating and irresistible concoction. Its tone is a mix of Stephen King's uneasy acceptance of the supernatural coupled with the harsh look at the American justice system that Richard Price loves to bring to his work (see: The Wire, The Night Of).
Combine that with an exceptional cast firing on all cylinders and you have an engrossing 10-hour procedural that asks what would happen if our notion of reality was disrupted beyond what we can typically accept. 
But...
That finale did not quite stick the landing for me. Between the mindless action theatrics, some really confusing moments ("Who's Terry?") and that maddening final shot, I thought it was only somewhat satisfying. 
Still, up until that last bit, it's aces.']

Title: Attack of the Killer¬†Tomatoes!

Title: Lava
Text:
Inspired by the isolated beauty of tropical islands and the explosive allure of ocean volcanoes, Lava is a musical love story that takes place over millions of¬†years.
['Watched this on an iPhone while inhaling two rubbery 75¬¢ hot dogs without condiments in an Ikea parking lot.', 'Those two volcanoes banged and gave birth to Te Fiti. This was all a prequel to Moana', 'I bet Ringo Starr loves the shit out of this. He probably sat there watching the movie and nudging his friends in the side with the biggest grin on his face. "Ahhh, they LAVA each other", he says at the close of the short film. 
When he arrives home later that night he begins to compose a rock opera on the love of Volcanoes because he is so touched by the great act of love between these two mountains. 
Paul McCartney gets a phone call at 1 AM from an exceedingly excited Ringo Starr, and he sits there politely listening to his friend recount the story of the movie he just saw and offers to listen to the first few ideas for songs he has for his album of Lava love songs. 
Hours later, Paul and Ringo end their conversation. Paul flicks off his bedside lamp and utters into the darkness one phrase. 
"Jesus fucking christ"']

Title: Master
Text:
At an elite New England university built on the site of a Salem-era gallows hill, two black women strive to find their place. Navigating politics and privilege, they encounter increasingly terrifying manifestations of the school‚Äôs haunted past‚Ä¶ and¬†present.
['"It‚Äôs not ghosts. It‚Äôs not supernatural. it‚Äôs America."
What's scarier than being the only black person on the dance floor surrounded by white people singing along to the n-word in rap songs? Master is resourceful in its decision to focus its horror story on the awkward, uncomfortable, and inescapable black experience, rather than your typical horror tropes of ghosts, witches, and curses, and the end result is simply a significant, skin-crawling, yet at times far too on-the-nose social commentary/horror hybrid.
Detailing the experiences of three black women at a predominately white college with a dark history, Master definitely shows excellence with its atmospheric, microscopic storytelling, where the lines between paranoia and destiny are intentionally blurred to create a disorienting world‚Ä¶ 
more', 'A twisting tale that combines elements of ‚ÄúCandyman,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Shining‚Äù and ‚ÄúGet Out,‚Äù Mariama Diallo‚Äôs ‚ÄúMaster‚Äù isn‚Äôt the kind of traumatic horror film that interrogates racism solely as a fright in itself. Diallo is too smart for that. This mesmerizing freak out, a psychologically brutal witch and ghost story, pulls in viewers with smart writing, and even more brilliant performances. It explicates colorism, racial passing, micro-aggressions, and the crushing pressures of Black Excellence not as history-teaching, example-making cudgels, but as illnesses that live and breathe beneath and above the surface of America. [full review via 
Indiewire
]', 'I enjoyed it for what it was. Feels more made to comment on race in College rather than to scare or anything but it was nice. In the end it just feels a little more simplistic than the buildup would make you believe. Still, solid movie. Regina Hall is actually so excellent.']

Title: The Exorcist¬†III
Text:
On the fifteenth anniversary of the exorcism that claimed Father Damien Karras‚Äô life, Police Lieutenant Kinderman‚Äôs world is once again shattered when a boy is found decapitated and savagely¬†crucified.
['This movie is like "how to direct a good horror movie 101", and that it is only the second movie directed by a guy who was a novelist for most of his career makes his confidence and skill even more impressive and worthy of study. Blatty is of course a lunatic who takes all that Catholic shit super seriously, which is why this movie is so frightening. The hospital hallway scene, if you've seen it, you know the one I'm talking about, should be studied in film school. It's a S tier scare, but most of the movie just builds an unbearable sense of dread and tension just with dialogue and spooky atmosphere. So when Blatty really opens up the‚Ä¶ 
more', "Revisited this with Kate last night. I gotta say, I've always dug this movie. It has some absolutely fantastic ideas, a great central performance from George C. Scott, and some gorgeously executed set pieces (that nurse in the hallway sequence remains one of the greatest of all time). The conversation sequences between Kinderman and the Gemini are exquisitely written and performed. 
I think I can feel the studio interference kick in for the last act - I haven't seen the director's cut, but will remedy that soon. Overall, I think this movie is a worthy sequel to Friedkin's classic, and deserves more appreciation than it typically receives.", "100
The man in cell 11. 
First re-watch in ten years or so. I first caught it after I fell in love with William Friedkin's 1973 classic, and I just don't think my 13 year old mind could handle such a cold, clinical departure from the ambiguous ruminations of faith that the original film offered. Whereas 
The Exorcist
 explored the fruitlessness of institutions when dealing with demonic possessions and the mysteries of faith, 
The Exorcist III
 argues that, with or without demons, the structures of the institutions around us are perpetually on the verge of collapse. George C. Scott's performance is molded out of frustration, often crumbling into fits of rage and tears as he thrashes against a seemingly unstoppable‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: A Matter of Life and¬†Death
Text:
A British wartime aviator who cheats death must argue for his life before a celestial court, hoping to prolong his fledgling romance with an American¬†girl.
['"Tell me, do you believe in the survival of human personality after death?"
"I don't know, I'd never thought about it, do you?"
"I don't know, I've thought about it too much."', 'The decision to make all of the fantasy sequences black and white while the "real life" sequences are technicolor speaks so much to the unorthodox philosophy of this movie. The afterlife may not be such a bad place, but there's something more appealing, more romantic about the fleeting, the evanescent, the malleable. Eternity is static (everyone dead is wearing the uniform in which they died, clinging to the beliefs with which they died), while on earth there is love, sadness, hope, grief, learning, growing, drama, etc. The afterlife isn't necessarily heaven. Heaven is love, so choose life.
There's no way to approach this movie that doesn't find it an unmitigated success. It's wonderfully romantic. It's hilarious and entertaining. It's a fantasy spectacle with jaw dropping analog effects. It's a post-war curative that inspires patriotism and a spirit of cooperation. This is one of the best movies.', 'One of the greatest moments in all of cinema is when Marius Goring looks at the camera and says ‚Äúone is starved for technicolor up there.‚Äù']

Title: Captive¬†State
Text:

["A solid bit of low-budget high-concept suspense work, with an exceptional lack of sentiment. Wants very badly to be a sci-fi BATTLE OF ALGIERS, which is a great idea, but that just means it gets to forego any of that film's ambivalence about its characters' terrorism because here it's against faceless alien monsters (about whom we strangely learn materially nothing) instead of other people.", 'What a waste of an excellent setting and concept!

cheesy 90s thrillers are my absolute favorite and my mum has always recommended this one to me, so there's no surprise that I loved it :-) I wish they still made films like this!", "‪the biggest twist of this movie??? finding out there's a pro when it comes to having a husband.... apparently if you get convicted for killing him, most guys find that unattractive & will leave you alone‬"]

Title: Wayne‚Äôs¬†World
Text:
The adventures of two amiably aimless metal-head friends, Wayne and Garth. From Wayne‚Äôs basement, the pair broadcast a talk-show called ‚ÄúWayne‚Äôs World‚Äù on local public access television. The show comes to the attention of a sleazy network executive who wants to produce a big-budget version of ‚ÄúWayne‚Äôs World‚Äù‚Äîand he also wants Wayne‚Äôs girlfriend, a rock singer named Cassandra. Wayne and Garth have to battle the executive not only to save their show, but also¬†Cassandra. √ó
["Garth lowkey builds a robot in this movie and we don't talk about that enough", "If the people who don't like this movie were an ice cream flavour, they'd be pralines and dick.", "Why is it that if a man kills another man in battle, it's called heroic, yet if he kills a man in the heat of passion, it's called murder?"]

Title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the¬†World
Text:
Eight years after the third film, the OSS has become the world‚Äôs top spy agency, while the Spy Kids department has since become defunct. Retired spy Marissa is called back into action, and to bond with her new stepchildren Rebecca and Cecil, she invites them along to stop the evil Timekeeper from taking over the¬†world.
['Just want everyone to know that when I saw this in theaters in 2011, the ‚Äú4D‚Äù aspect of this movie was a scratch n sniff card that you got. And randomly throughout the movie numbers would pop up on the screen so you knew which section of the card to smell to experience the smell of the movie with the characters. All of the numbers smelled like farts.', 'A masterpiece of an exercise in genre filmmaking. Rodriguez takes a worn-out premise and turns it on its head, inverting every trope and setting up a series of reversals that surprise and delight the viewer. It pays off every setup of the first three films, resulting in a fantastic set-piece worthy of the greatest Kurosawa.', '"You have to live life moving forwards, not back."
Not only did Harvey Weinstein force Rodriguez to make this - via a signed contract from the previous films - 
and thus should rot in hell for another eternity
, but they even cut out all of Antonio Banderas's scenes. Treacherous. 100% the film crew was on drugs.']

Title: Sisters
Text:
Inquisitive journalist Grace Collier is horrified when she witnesses her neighbor, fashion model Danielle Breton, violently murder a man. Panicking, she calls the police. But when the detective arrives at the scene and finds nothing amiss, Grace is forced to take matters into her own hands. Her first move is to recruit private investigator Joseph Larch, who helps her to uncover a secret about Danielle‚Äôs past that has them both seeing¬†double.
['unexpected but welcome addition to ACAB canon ‚Äî cogent narrative choice for the cops to refuse to help the plucky gal reporter because she wrote articles denouncing police brutality. horror films often fall into the trap of relying on police to save the main characters‚Äô lives, so it‚Äôs refreshing to see that subverted in a realistic and meaningful way.\xa0
also love how she explicitly called them out for not caring about the case because the violent perpetrator was a white woman and the victim was a Black man ‚Äî demonstrates screenwriter Louisa Rose‚Äôs understanding of the insidious history of systemic racism, which i think is imperative for anyone writing any piece of media featuring cop characters.\xa0easily my fav non-
Carrie
 De Palma!
(watched after reading about it in chapter 2 of 
House of Psychotic Women 
by Kier-la Janisse, a book i highly recommend for fans of horror/exploitation films!)', "Little bit of Hitchcock, giallo, 
Rosemary's Baby
, slashers and what would eventually become the psychosexual science-fiction of Cronenberg going on here. Creates a very strong formal tension between De Palma's classical Hollywood thriller style and the shocking violence/bizarre, sensationalist modern detail that he populates it with. The climax of the film that combines three different psyches battling it out in extreme close-ups, real memories, implanted flashbacks, POV/split screen images, and fake archival footage which are also dreams (??) before exploding into sex and violence is nothing short of insane. That no one really solves the central case feels quite appropriate with how this movie is designed to make you feel.", 'Revisited this film after approx. 30 years on the Arrow Films Blu-ray. 
I forgot how giallo influenced this film seems to be. And the split screen sequences are awe-inspiring. Masterful.
Extras and booklet included with the Blu-ray are nice. 
RIP Margot Kidder']

Title: Se7en
Text:
Two homicide detectives are on a desperate hunt for a serial killer whose crimes are based on the ‚Äúseven deadly sins‚Äù in this dark and haunting film that takes viewers from the tortured remains of one victim to the next. The seasoned Det. Somerset researches each sin in an effort to get inside the killer‚Äôs mind, while his novice partner, Mills, scoffs at his efforts to unravel the¬†case.
['KEVIN SPACEY GIVES BRAD PITT HEAD !!! \n*NO CLICKBAIT*', "se7en's ending scene is by far my favorite unboxing video on youtube", 'I recently watched a mini-doc on David Fincher\'s film techniques. One of the scenes that\'s mentioned is the famous "box" scene. When he filmed Brad Pitt and Morgan Freeman, he used a handheld camera as "shakycam" to represent the two losing control of the situation. When he filmed Kevin Spacey, he used a tripod so it would be shot in place to represent him having all the power.\nI had never noticed this before, that genius bastard.']

Title: Rolling¬†Thunder
Text:
A Vietnam veteran, Charles Rane, returns home after years in a POW camp and is treated as a hero. He has a hard time adjusting, and things go badly. A movie about the walking dead, before that meant just flesh-eating¬†zombies.
['Many Paul Schrader movies, including this one, follow a simple, but winning formula: a sexually and emotionally crippled man is driven to an act of violent, suicidal vainglory by a very young blonde woman. First Reformed, Taxi Driver, Hardcore... a slight variation in Mishima, as the guy is doing it for the emperor of Japan instead of a woman.
Most of the movie is a fairly quiet and sad examination of a man struggling to deal with the brutal trauma of being a POW and losing everything he thought he was coming home to. William Devane and Tommy Lee Jones do go beastmode at the end and kill like a dozen lowlifes in a Juarez whorehouse at the end though.', '‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like my eyes are open and I‚Äôm looking at you, but I‚Äôm dead.‚Äù
Psssh and people say we‚Äôve never gotten a good Punisher movie.
A rough-around-the-edges 70s revenge flick starring William Devane as a Vietnam POW who returns home to no longer recognize the world around him ‚Äî or maybe it‚Äôs the world who no longer recognizes him. Made numb by war and his years of torture, Maj. Charles Rane is a detached father and husband, but longs to reclaim the life and humanity that he left behind. However, in standard 70s grimehouse fashion, darkness soon rears its ugly head and tragedy befalls the Rane family. Unfortunately for the perpetrators of the atrocities, Charlie never really left the war‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I plopped on my couch expecting a meat and potatoes '70s exploitation action picture about a 'Nam vet with a hook hand, but did not brace myself for 
Rolling Thunder
 to go Paul Schrader dark. What an icky sweat soaked screaming surprise! This plays like a bleak and gritty character driven modern western with some stunning photography and chilling performances. The shadowy torture/interrogation scene left me shook! And the way Tommy Lee Jones says, "I'll get my gear" with that blank stare. Brrrr! 
A portrait of a man slipping off the edge in typical Schrader scripted fashion, 
Rolling Thunder
 feels like a countryfied genre slathered shell shocked cousin to 
Taxi Driver
. 2017 is off to a stellar cinestart!']

Title: Six Men Getting¬†Sick
Text:
Lynch‚Äôs first film project consists of a loop of six people vomiting projected on to a special sculptured screen featuring twisted three-dimensional¬†faces.
["My approach to avant garde cinema has always been not to let it bug me if I don't get it; the visual experience is more important than the theme in some ways. That's counter to my approach to pretty much everything else, but when something is oblique or abstract, it becomes like God. I can't prove she exists, I can't prove he doesn't. Why worry? So I watch and see what happens. If nothing happens, then at least I have the imagery to hold onto. This is all to say that David Lynch's animated short left me with some striking, disturbing images to hold onto.", 'The first time I tried to spot out the faces. I spotted out 5, and then they vomited.
The second time I was disturbed by the red color, and kept thinking about why it highlights only the faces at the left. I got interrupted by the time they all vomited.
The third time my mind subliminally perceived the word "SICK" two times, but couldn't read the word clearly. I got mad, so I decided to spot the 6th face. It was formed by the 4th and 6th face, so it was really the 5th. The red shot assaulted me again, and then I saw how their organs were filled with blood before they all vomited.
The fourth time I tried‚Ä¶ 
more', 'The title is not misleading.']

Title: Funny¬†People
Text:
Famous and wealthy funnyman George Simmons doesn‚Äôt give much thought to how he treats people until a doctor delivers stunning health news, forcing George to reevaluate his priorities with a little help from aspiring stand-up comic¬†Ira.
['Fuck you, Adam Sandler. Fuck you for knowing you can act and knowing you can be in better movies. You fucking cunt.', 'The audacity of that fucking runtime.', 'I‚Äôve watched ‚ÄúFunny People‚Äù more times than I care to count (fun fact: Judd Apatow movies comprise roughly 40% of all cable television programming), but it never occurred to me that Apatow‚Äôs raw, shaggy, desperate masterpiece of a third feature was inspired by ‚ÄúThe Great Gatsby.‚Äù For some reason, I didn‚Äôt automatically make the connection between The Great American Novel and a studio comedy in which Adam Sandler has sex with a stranger while pretending to be a Merman. But someone recently pointed out the parallel, and ‚Äî like a Magic Eye stereogram or that bump on Jean-Claude Van Damme‚Äôs forehead ‚Äî it‚Äôs the kind of thing that you can‚Äôt un-see. \nIra Wright (Seth Rogen) is our new Nick Carraway,‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no¬†Yaiba
Text:

To make matters worse, his younger sister Nezuko, the sole survivor, has been transformed into a demon herself. Though devastated by this grim reality, Tanjiro resolves to become a ‚Äúdemon slayer‚Äù so that he can turn his sister back into a human, and kill the demon that massacred his¬†family.
