Title: Murder, My¬†Sweet
Text:
After being hired to find an ex-con‚Äôs former girlfriend, Philip Marlowe is drawn into a deeply complex web of mystery and¬†deceit.
["Film noir
 is generally seen as a post-war innovation, mirroring the more jaded, cynical outlook that the world possessed after the cataclysmic conflict. Mr Raymond Chandler would have every right to disagree. In 1944, not only did he co-script what for me is one of the finest (and noirest) films ever made, 
Double Indemnity
, but he also provided the source material (the novel 
Farewell, My Lovely
) for this marvellous movie from the perennially underrated Edward Dmytryk.
Dick Powell transformed his frothy image in one fell swoop by personifying private detective Philip Marlowe so well and delivering Chandler's hard-boiled lines (via John Paxton's sharp script) as though born to them. We are introduced to him blindfold and under interrogation for multiple‚Ä¶ 
more", "Moose is a wonderful character. Almost comical, but wholly tragic, a man of few words, but a lot of muscles. I have mentioned my feelings on the femme fatale trope before, The fact that this big dumb lug is played by a woman falls into so many awful stereotypes, but there's just something likable about the hulking murderer. He, like certain goons from 
Blazing Saddles
, is a mere pawn, and maybe that's why I have sympathy for him.
This is a great Philip Marlowe story. A twisty plot that's not too twisted. A lot of quippy dialogue that doesn't feel forced or out-of-character for anyone. And a seediness to it that isn't quite as seedy as it should be, unfortunately,‚Ä¶ 
more", "Didn't understand what the hell was going on half the time, but I loved it."]

Title: Dead¬†Calm
Text:
An Australian couple takes a sailing trip in the Pacific to get over the recent loss of their son. While on the open sea, they come across a sinking ship with one survivor who is not at all what he¬†seems.
['Not the last time Billy Zane would torment a redhead on a boat.', 'They didn‚Äôt have to show us the toddler going slow motion through the window in the first five minutes, but they did. The dog is just a work of art.', "Insanely tight home invasion thriller that in typical Australian genre movie fashion takes place almost entirely during the day on a sail boat. Was not surprised to see George Miller and his 
Road Warrior
 cinematographer Dean Semler were very involved with this. Not much going on underneath the hood of this grieving couple forced into choosing to keep living via lean suspense mechanic setpieces but they're so well-constructed you don't really care. It's all eerie atmosphere filled with claustrophobic anticipation followed by eventual explosions of very sudden and gross action; did not expect to see a kid flying through a windshield or a face melted by a flare in extreme gruesome detail when I cued this up. Particularly love how‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Persuasion
Text:
Living with her snobby family on the brink of bankruptcy, Anne Elliot is an unconforming woman with modern sensibilities. When Frederick Wentworth - the dashing one she once sent away - crashes back into her life, Anne must choose between putting the past behind her or listening to her heart when it comes to second¬†chances.

When terrorists try to seize control of a Berlin-Paris flight, a soft-spoken young American co-pilot struggles to save the lives of the passengers and crew while forging a surprising connection with one of the¬†hijackers.
['being stuck in a cockpit with joseph gordon levitt for 92 minutes is literally my dream', '‚ÄùEuropean 162, what‚Äôs your emergency?‚Äù
‚ÄúWe have a 7500‚Äù
Patrick Vollrath‚Äôs
 debut film is a fantastic example of how to create a super engaging movie with little more than a single set, a great script, and some fantastic actors. 
The end result is an incredibly intense drama, and his use of limited visuals, and off camera sounds all come together to create a dramatically heightened effect. 
Joseph Gordon-Levitt
 carries this movie on his shoulders and delivers the pitch perfect performance this movie needs to remain airborne and engaging.
Sign me up for whatever Mr Vollrath wants to do next, and please, please, please, give him a budget that‚Äôs big enough to show us all just how high he can fly. 
‚ÄùIt‚Äôs vital that we continue talking to each other‚Ä¶‚Äù
Cinematic Time Capsule - 2019 Ranked', 'Pretty good in terms of acting and building tension, but do we really need another depiction of Muslims as terrorists?']

Title: The Night¬†Of
Text:

['this series is worth watching for the john turturro eczema sub plot alone (real)', 'I hope John Stone is hydrated and his eczema is cured and he is living happily with his cat', 'Student: Would you defend Hitler?

Title: The Golden¬†Child
Text:
After a Tibetan boy, the mystical Golden Child, is kidnapped by the evil Sardo Numspa, humankind‚Äôs fate hangs in the balance. On the other side of the world in Los Angeles, the priestess Kee Nang seeks the Chosen One, who will save the boy from death. When Nang sees social worker Chandler Jarrell on television discussing his ability to find missing children, she solicits his expertise, despite his skepticism over being¬†‚Äúchosen.‚Äù
['Fantasy comedy adventure with a crazy winged hell demon creature, Eddie Murphy as a social worker, and Charles Dance as an evil villain named Sardo Numspa could only be made in 1986. 
This\xa0was a major blind spot for me and I wish I could‚Äôve seen this when I was younger, it‚Äôs one of 
those
\xa0movies‚Ä¶ ridiculous well paced fun thats deceivingly creative despite its familiar journey‚ÄîI loved the effects, the wild dream sequence (that was the turning point of the movie where I knew I loved it), how Charles Dance owns every evil role he‚Äôs in, the reluctant hero moron/idiot chosen one storyline, the winged demon finale, and the appearances of Victor Wong and James Hong.\xa0
Carpenter vibed fun and undervalued Murphy if you ask me, plus those dark touches of demons and hell visits were very welcomed, lol at the henchmen in this.
Big Trouble in Little‚Ä¶ Tibet????????', '53
Honestly, not even sure how much I enjoyed this wacky horror-action-comedy starring Eddie Murphy (at the peak of his superstardom), but you have to admire the audacity of everyone involved. 
My co-host and good pal Corey talk about his pick of the week on our podcast, give it a listen: 
anchor.fm/willandcorey/episodes/The-Golden-Child-e1upt6b', "Recently, I have been paying more attention to this film than ever before, mostly because many people here have been reviewing it for the last month or so. My interest was piqued further by comparisons to films such as 
Big Trouble In Little China
.
Well, Murphy may not be Kurt Russell but he's definitely the reason this movie is worth watching. Throughout every moment, his personality, comedic timing, and style makes everything feel fresh, funny, and somehow interesting. Although the film is mainly fantasy and whimsical in tone, there is probably a fairly cool training scene that was almost thrilling.
I enjoy Carpenter‚Äôs film the most, mainly because of its scope. The effects and general ambience of The Big Trouble‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Unbelievable
Text:
A teenager is charged with lying about her rape allegation, but two determined investigative female detectives discover a far more sinister¬†truth.
['The rare show in this genre that cares about the victims more than it cares about the perpetrators. There is a distinctly different perspective behind the material that plays out in every single interaction and conversation. It‚Äôs angry about injustices, especially within law enforcement and the justice system, but it‚Äôs also deeply compassionate towards the people who are thrown into that system. It‚Äôs the little things that really add up here - it takes care to show moments of comfort, of validation, of even just one person telling the other what resources she has to offer. It lingers, but in a respectful way. One of the better shows of the year, strong recommend. 
Also: All three performances are stellar. Dever‚Äôs‚Ä¶

, 
and i cannot stress this enough
,

Title: The Devil Rides¬†Out
Text:
The powers of good are pitted against the forces of evil as the Duc de Richelieu wrestles with the charming but deadly Satanist, Mocata, for the soul of his friend. Mocata has the knowledge and the power to summon the forces of darkness and, as the Duc de Richelieu and his friends remain within the protected pentacle, they are subjected to ever-increasing horror until thundering hooves herald the arrival of the Angel of¬†Death.
['Poor Hammer, releasing this the same year of 
Night of the Living Dead 
and 
Rosemarys Baby
\xa0must‚Äôve hurt a bit. Still, I found it plenty fun and I always enjoy looking at Christopher Lee ü§ß', "Other than the usual Hammer horror aptitude for gothic visuals and cheap-but-great effects (that lightning!), this film has several great things going for it:
1. There's a moment early on where someone gets punched to the ground, and the camera inexplicably and unexpectedly shakes. I don't think it happens again, and it's so delightfully shocking that it makes it seem like that punch broke the world. 
2. The sequence with the circle of protection is just plain tense. It pulls out all the stops, with cheezy effects used well, simple tricks (a knock at the door) used well, and ultimately, some misdirection that makes the Angel of Death an intimidating presence on the screen. The ultimate reveal could be seen‚Ä¶ 
more", 'A mesmerizing satanic panicked feast! 
The Devil Rides Out
\xa0is packed to the gills with the kind of imagery, colors, and set pieces I go nuts for. Absolutely my favorite Hammer jam‚ÄîI adore this moving hell picture show!']

Title: Repulsion
Text:
Beautiful young manicurist Carole suffers from androphobia (the pathological fear of interaction with men). When her sister and roommate, Helen, leaves their London flat to go on an Italian holiday with her married boyfriend, Carole withdraws into her apartment. She begins to experience frightful hallucinations, her fear gradually mutating into¬†madness.
['Repulsion is what I feel towards this director', 'This is an effective movie because who else but a predator could capture on film the sheer terror a woman feels when she‚Äôs abused.', 'Throw out that fucking rabbit jesus christ']

Title: Beauty¬†Shop
Text:
Far from Chicago, hairdresser Gina Norris has relocated to Atlanta with her daughter and has quickly established herself as a rare talent in her profession. But after repeatedly butting heads with her shady, over-the-top boss, Jorge, Norris sets out to create her own salon ‚Äì even snagging a few of Jorge‚Äôs employees and clients. Now, Jorge will do anything to shut her¬†down.
['if loving this movie means that i'm not accepted into the "cinephile club", then so be it', 'why isn‚Äôt ‚Äúi don‚Äôt eat donuts with boys who exploit women‚Äù sold on t-shirts worldwide??? i don‚Äôt understand', "People forget how big of a deal Queen Latifah is. Oscar nominee Queen Latifah. She can act. But she doesn't have to act. She can just be, like in 
Beauty Shop
 and just be a magnet of charisma and likeability and positive energy. And 
Beauty Shop
 is this shimmering snow-globe of a bygone era. The pre-social media barbershop. Flip-phones out the ying-yang. You've got Kevin Bacon after just watching 
Napoleon Dynamite
 for the first time. You've got Djimon Hounsou going full-on Adonis. You've got Alicia Silverstone going full-on white trash. You've got little girl piano recitals. But always Queen Latifah pulling things to the center; the clear shining star that this zany shop orbits around."]

Title: Snow White and the¬†Huntsman
Text:
After the Evil Queen marries the King, she performs a violent coup in which the King is murdered and his daughter, Snow White, is taken captive. Almost a decade later, a grown Snow White is still in the clutches of the Queen. In order to obtain immortality, The Evil Queen needs the heart of Snow White. After Snow escapes the castle, the Queen sends the Huntsman to find her in the Dark¬†Forest.

Title: Lone¬†Star
Text:
When the skeleton of his murdered predecessor is found, Sheriff Sam Deeds unearths many other long-buried secrets in his Texas border¬†town.
["The screenplay for this is a marvel of engineering, with almost every single line baldly advancing the story's narrative and emotional beats or blatantly foregrounding its political themes while leaving so many pauses and gaps as to never come across as didactic. The performances enhance those dead spaces, as each actor leaves crucial things unsaid even when laying things out on the line, and little push-ins or insert shots of facial expressions subtly registering implications say just as much as the most scathing monologues.
There's so much going on here, but boiled down to its essence, this is a film about how the only way to feel proud of the story of America and its states is to consciously and‚Ä¶ 
more", "The twisty and often shocking plot could have so easily turned into a frantic melodrama, and I'm overjoyed that it didn't. Everything plays out so smoothly, with such wonderful transitions from past to present. Unfolds like a classic epic, spanning generations of love and pain and giving insight into so many perspectives of Texas life and history. The kind of film that makes me frustrated that I'm not a better and more experienced writer, more able to put my thoughts into the right words. Powerful, powerful stuff.", 'Back in the early 70s, a reporter from a national magazine asked the governor of our Lone Star state, ‚ÄúGovernor, what‚Äôs your ideal of what a real Texan oughta be?‚Äù Governor said, ‚ÄúSon, that‚Äôs easy. Just go down to Rio County and get a look at Sheriff Buddy Deeds.‚Äù
Texas, Texas, Texas. A cultural melting pot of a town in a cultural melting pot of state in a cultural melting pot of a country. Fathers & sons. Brothers & sisters. Myths & legends.
In a small desert border town, ancient secrets and grudges are buried deep within the sand‚Äîbut where there‚Äôs smoke, there‚Äôs fire, and once one skeleton is discovered, soon an entire graveyard‚Äôs worth of old town mysteries is unearthed.
I‚Äôve never‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Band of¬†Outsiders
Text:
Cinephile slackers Franz and Arthur spend their days mimicking the antiheroes of Hollywood noirs and Westerns while pursuing the lovely Odile. The misfit trio upends convention at every turn, be it through choreographed dances in caf√©s or frolicsome romps through the Louvre. Eventually, their romantic view of outlaws pushes them to plan their own heist, but their inexperience may send them out in a blaze of glory ‚Äì which could be just what they¬†want.
['Quentin Tarantino wishes his films were this cool.', 'the dance scene!!!! the louvre scene!!!!!!! ah that‚Äôs cinema', 'when your circle small but yall crazy']

Title: Watchmen: Chapter¬†I
Text:
In 1985, the murder of a government-sponsored superhero draws his outlawed colleagues out of retirement and into a mystery that threatens to upend their personal lives and the world¬†itself.
['Heard joke once.
Man goes to doctor, says he's depressed. Life seems harsh and cruel, says he feels all alone in a threatening world.
Doctor says, "Treatment is simple. Great Clown Pagliacci is in town. Go see him. That will pick you up."
Man bursts into tears. Says, "But doctor...I am Pagliacci."
Hmm...Good joke.
Too good, nailed in every aspect; can't wait for Part II.', "Even though I'm still not a huge fan of this kind of animation style, It's Watchmen, so it's still very good storywise. It has its problems though.
The execution could be better; everything feels rushed like there are no pauses and some of the line delivery isn't great. A lot of moments lack the impact they had in the comic or even in the Zack Snyder version.
But I like this story and love the graphic novel, so seeing it adapted for the screen is always fun for me, even if it almost always loses something in the process (which is why the best adaptation is still the Motion Comic, which is basically just the pages from the graphic novel animated).", "I really wonder what inspired this film considering it lacks any creativity whatsoever
it's basically just a frame-for-frame remake of the novel, with some slightly dodgy, Telltale style animation, and not great voice acting (which I expect will be a little better in the second part, since Troy Baker will be in it a lot more) 
not only does it add nothing to the original source material, it skips a bit of the narrative building and pacing of the novel, and doesn't manage to recreate the gritty, dystopian tone at all
it feels like if Watchmen was made into a cartoon show on some midday TV channel that nobody watches - despite having an obviously brilliant story, it's told with‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Borderline
Text:
After escaping from a mental hospital, a violent sociopath named Paul begins a dangerous rampage targeting Sofia, a world-famous pop star. Obsessed with her, he takes Sofia hostage in her own home, acting under the delusional belief that they are getting married. Paul is desperate to prove his devotion, leading to a tense and unpredictable¬†situation.
['A fine addition to the Samara Weaving marrying a hot guy with a mental illness cinematic universe', 'your honor, i fear my girlie samara weaving is guilty of serving an insane amount of gaggery and cuntiness once again', 'samara weaving as a fictional 90s pop star.. yeah I‚Äôm never shutting up about this‚Ä¶ sofia and skye riley were best friends in a alternate universe I‚Äôm calling it now.\xa0
hilarious, dark & surprisingly brutal. I do wish we had gotten some original music for the film but at least we got a cover of a celine dion classic from miss samara to make up for it. 
It‚Äôs like a fucked up romcom minus the romance.. samara & ray nicholson have incredible chemistry, I loved whenever they were on screen together. I‚Äôm not mad about ray being type cast because he‚Äôs just so damn good at playing a sociopath. I was just so \xa0locked in from the moment I pressed play. stunning cinematography witty dialogue a little gory & a thrilling unhinged third act.\xa0
‚ÄúI killed someone‚Äù ü§ó \xa0*claps*']

Title: The Danish¬†Girl
Text:
When Gerda Wegener asks her husband Einar to fill in as a portrait model, Einar discovers the person she‚Äôs meant to be and begins living her life as Lili Elbe. Having realized her true self and with Gerda‚Äôs love and support, Lili embarks on a groundbreaking journey as a transgender¬†pioneer.
['To my cisgender friends, I ask that, even if you would not normally do so, you please read this. This film was made for cisgender people, so I feel it important that I write this for cisgender people. I would not normally watch this movie, but it has been a subject of some discussion on this site in a way that has compelled me to watch it in order to discuss it credibly. I do not imagine what I have to say will be definitive or particularly more substantial than what other trans folks have said, but I have a voice here that some listen to, even if only briefly. I might as well take advantage of that. I know‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I once worked with a man who walked around the office with an anti-gay marriage petition, asking everyone to sign it. Many did. I refused. At the time, my daughter was less than a year old and the man with a clipboard decided to try to convince me to sign my name on the dotted line by bringing her into the conversation.
"What would you say to your daughter if she saw two men kissing?" he asked.
Talk to her. Explain to her how beautiful love is. Hope she is lucky enough to find it. Remind her that regardless of who she chooses to spend her life with, I will always love her back. Teach her to open her eyes‚Ä¶ 
more', "Not only primitive, but void
in its political observations.
If you're going to try to 
make something progressive,
make something progressive
(like 
Tangerine,
 for instance, 
though the two films can't be compared).
Ignorant, close-minded, 
borderline-delusional filmmaking
or, in other words, 
this year's 
American Sniper.
1.5 stars for Vikander and Vikander only."]

Some very smart people are missing the boat on this one, which surprises me because Layton's magnificent final shot couldn't be more pointed. There is no ambiguity, no mystery, no unanswered question (apart from what happened to the real Nicholas Barclay, which is no doubt a sad but thoroughly commonplace story that we'll never hear). And while there's a twist at the end, it's not the one cited in most of the reviews I've read. 
The Imposter
 is many things‚Äîan incredible true story, a queasy black comedy, a formally audacious doc/fiction hybrid, an uninflected portrait of a sociopath‚Äîbut first and foremost, it's a creative essay about confirmation bias, an "affliction" that, as we see here, spares nobody. Whether through‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Church
Text:
In a Gothic cathedral built on the mass grave of a Teutonic purge, an ancient discovery by the new librarian will release an unholy maelstrom of madness, violence, and demonic¬†vengeance.
["The first of two films produced by Dario Argento and Directed by the wonderful Michele Soavi, 
La
 
Chiesa
 has always been a movie I've never fully appreciated... until a few years ago.
Now it‚Äôs one of my favorites‚Äîperfectly encapsulating my love for escalating chaotic madness:\xa0a tower of contorted/distorted bodies covered in disgusting sludge, crazy traps everywhere, a librarian being willed to rip his heart out, crazy jackhammer impalement, beheaded priests, Satan goat man shows up, and a lady gets pancake flattened by a train... everything I could ever ask for in a movie.
Slow pacing be damned, this movie is delightfully bonkers and if you ask me, how it all unfolds is part of the magic. I adore this movie‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Oh, Dario Argento "presented" this, did he? Well Michele Soavi directed it and he opened it with a sequence where horses kick a decapitated head like a soccer ball and somebody disguised themselves as a basket until an evil goose rats them out. So let's keep that in mind next time we're deciding whose name is front and center on the poster. I tell ya.', 'I was in one of those moods where I wanted to watch a ‚Äúcomfort food‚Äù Italian horror movie and I was looking for 
New York Ripper
\xa0when I came across this and it‚Äôs not the first time I‚Äôvd been looking for a different Italian horror movie and came across this one and went with it instead. I‚Äôve\xa0seen this so many times and it‚Äôs just as amazing on every single watch.\xa0
Excellent direction from Michele Soavi who is an underrated genius. Superb cinematography. Beautiful set pieces. Terrific score that will be stuck in my head for at least a couple of days. Barbara Cupisti is gorgeous and it‚Äôs easy to see why Soavi loves her. Asia Argento was an adorable kid. Crazy‚Ä¶ 
more']

Text:
A divorced writer from the Midwest returns to her hometown to reconnect with an old flame, who‚Äôs now married with a¬†family.

A New Jersey guy dedicated to his family, friends, and church, develops unrealistic expectations from watching porn and works to find happiness and intimacy with his potential true¬†love.

Title: Goosebumps
Text:
After moving to a small town, Zach Cooper finds a silver lining when he meets next door neighbor Hannah, the daughter of bestselling Goosebumps series author R.L. Stine. When Zach unintentionally unleashes real monsters from their manuscripts and they begin to terrorize the town, it‚Äôs suddenly up to Stine, Zach and Hannah to get all of them back in the books where they¬†belong.
['Actually kinda fun ngl', 'why does dylan minnette only play Sad Boys that fall in love with girls named hannah', "a magic movie about the magic of books that speaks directly to kids without being condescending or too emotionally heavy. it never panders to adults (ok maybe save for that truly excellent stephen king joke) and that's exactly why it will work for any open-minded adult - it is so full of the joy of weirdness and adventure that there's no time to waste winking at the 30-somethings who dragged their kids in for a nostalgia trip. it's sappy and silly, sure, but you don't need to understand it because they will. aside from too much shakey cam this is visually a marvel, so alive that you don't need to see it in 3D for it to jump out at‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: Heart of¬†Stone
Text:
An intelligence operative for a shadowy global peacekeeping agency races to stop a hacker from stealing its most valuable ‚Äî and dangerous ‚Äî¬†weapon.
['Netflix would rather pour millions of dollars into hollow and pitiful movies like\xa0
Heart of Stone
\xa0
in lieu of paying\xa0fair residuals to their writers and actors. Yikes.', 'Answers the age-old question, ‚ÄúWhat if Mission Impossible movies were ass?‚Äù', 'Buried in here somewhere is a fun idea: A double agent in a team of spies who have no idea their ‚Äúrookie‚Äù computer expert is actually James Bond. When her colleagues aren‚Äôt looking, she kicks ass. When they are, she stumbles around and pretends she‚Äôs scared out of her mind.
That‚Äôs a perfect premise for a high concept action comedy. But in order to exploit it, you need a comic actor who reads like a nebbish, so that when they suddenly transform into Ethan Hunt, it catches us off guard ‚Äî\xa0and when they‚Äôre in awkward mode, they can do some actual physical comedy. 
So, of course, the filmmakers cast Wonder Woman in that part.
I‚Äôve got nothing against Gal Gadot‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Drunken¬†Angel
Text:
Doctor Sanada treats gangster Matsunaga after he is wounded in a gunfight, and discovers that he is suffering from tuberculosis. Sanada tries to convince Matsunaga to stay for treatment, which would drastically change his lifestyle. They form an uneasy friendship until Matsunaga‚Äôs old boss Okada returns from¬†prison.
["One man waits at the edge of the swamp knowing that one day he'll be pulled under like everything else.", '#madlad Mifune
About halfway into 
Drunken Angel
, a white flower is thrown in the swampy lake stretching out like some eerie omen in the middle of the neighborhood. The rotten water opens its mouth and yawns in the mud-brown stillness ‚Äì but the flower stays on the surface. After all, your life is no deeper than a puddle. How can you possibly drown when there is nothing to drown in?
Although it shows that 
Drunken Angel
 is an early Kurosawa picture ‚Äì his pans are not as dynamic, his zoom-outs not as poignant ‚Äì on a general scale, it is still a top-tier achievement. Its structure is flawless: there are recurring pieces of guitar music which fortify the melancholic inertia‚Ä¶ 
more', "I spoke yesterday of tigers. I read after my review that Toshiro Mifune was considered for the title role in 
Dersu Uzala
, but watching him here, in his ragged youth, I think he would have been better as the tiger anyway. He is certainly a predator, nearly as unhinged here (from booze, in part, and from sickness) as he was later in 
Sword of Doom
. He makes Val Kilmer's surprisingly charismatic turn as a consumptive look sedate, and yet what he really does is encapsulate rage and frustration that has nothing to do with booze or disease. 
I have read elsewhere that this film contains some subtle criticisms of America and the American occupation, and some not-so-subtle ones (the cesspool‚Ä¶

Title: Angels with Dirty¬†Faces
Text:
Childhood chums Rocky Sullivan and Jerry Connelly grow up on opposite sides of the fence: Rocky matures into a prominent gangster, while Jerry becomes a priest, tending to the needs of his old tenement¬†neighborhood.
["It's like I've said for years now: GOODFELLAS would be way better if there was a scene with a 10 minute-long youth league basketball game right in the middle.", 'In this movie, a major newspaper runs a front-page story that is entirely devoted to mocking a man for weeping\xa0on his way to the electric chair.', "James Cagney possesses an on-screen power in this Michael Curtiz directed movie which discerns itself in intriguing ways alongside his performances in 
The Public Enemy
 and particularly 
White Heat
, mainly as a result of the soft cushioned core which is spotlighted beautifully by the John Wexley and Warren Duff screenplay. Based on the story by Rowland Brown and additionally featuring Humphrey Bogart, Ann Sheridan and Pat O'Brien,\xa0
Angels With Dirty Faces
 is undoubtedly emotionally manipulative, but there's no denying this persists in being a pinnacle achievement of the classic Hollywood gangster era."]

Title: Goon
Text:
Doug Glatt, a slacker who discovers he has a talent for brawling is approached by a minor league hockey coach and invited to join the team as the ‚Äúmuscle.‚Äù Despite the fact that Glatt can‚Äôt skate his best friend, Pat, convinces him to give it a shot, and Glatt becomes a hero to the team and their fans, until the league‚Äôs reigning goon becomes threatened by Glatt‚Äôs success and decides to even the¬†score.
['69', 'A few weeks ago I tossed this film a shoutout in a review for another movie, and it made me realize it‚Äôs been a while since I last threw it on. Back in the day I‚Äôd watch this puppy at least a few times a year and it was almost always my go-to recommendation when someone was looking for a comedy they‚Äôd likely never seen.
Aside from being insanely quotable and featuring a cavalcade of phenomenal characters, this movie has a few things that people tend to criminally overlook: heart, grit, exciting sports drama, and one of the most compelling fictional sports movie protagonists of all time (yeah, I know it‚Äôs kind of based on a real guy, but like,‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Wow. I mean, shit. Coming from someone who's not a big fan of hockey, this really surprised the hell out of me. Thrilling and sweet. Exciting and beautiful. Funny and heartwrenching. Great acting, great direction, and great writing. Pulse pounding and touching. Shocking and brilliant. I went in hoping for at least a decent film. I came out loving it. It's already a strong contender for "Best of 2012" in my books.
Also, I never thought I would ever say this, but Seann William Scott gives an excellent performance. Who knew the guy had one in him?']

Text:

The two tyrants wage war for dominance, and Furiosa must survive many trials as she puts together the means to find her way¬†home.

Title: Dead¬†Presidents
Text:
On the streets they call cash dead presidents. And that‚Äôs just what a Vietnam veteran is after when he returns home from the war only to find himself drawn into a life of crime. With the aid of his fellow vets he plans the ultimate heist ‚Äì a daring robbery of an armored car filled with unmarked U.S.¬†currency!
['A story of three prisons for Black men.', 'this should be considered a classic.', '‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not your fault you‚Äôve been brainwashed by America‚Äù -Delilah, 
America. 
There is a weird corny live play quality to the performances and production of Dead Presidents that bothered me for about 5 minutes before I realized how brilliant and wonderful it was and how well it suited the tone and content. The whole film feels like a bit of a dream, or nightmare depending on the moment, and by the time it‚Äôs done you feel like you have gone through an experience as opposed to just watching a movie. Dead Presidents is a politically charged film, primarily focused on issues of masculinity, that uses it‚Äôs protagonist as a conduit to so many instances of inequality and dreams being deferred. The film effortlessly weaves personal and structural narratives in a way that is engaging and entertaining. 
I absolutely loved it and am confused as to why it isn‚Äôt rated higher. 
P.S. Keith David Academy Award when?']

Title: The¬†Holdovers
Text:
A curmudgeonly instructor at a New England prep school is forced to remain on campus during Christmas break to babysit the handful of students with nowhere to go. Eventually, he forms an unlikely bond with one of them ‚Äî a damaged, brainy troublemaker ‚Äî and with the school‚Äôs head cook, who has just lost a son in¬†Vietnam.
["There's a handshake in this that feels more overwhelmingly warm and emotional than most hugs I've seen in movies", 'paul giamatti ran that twink academy like its the navy', 'men were remembering the roman empire daily in the 1970s']

Title: A Little¬†Princess
Text:
When her father enlists to fight for the British in WWI, young Sara Crewe goes to New York to attend the same boarding school her late mother attended. She soon clashes with the severe headmistress, Miss Minchin, who attempts to stifle Sara‚Äôs creativity and sense of¬†self-worth.

Title: Scooby-Doo! and the Legend of the¬†Vampire
Text:

["Citizen Kane. The Godfather. The Shawshank Redemption. What do all these movies have in common? They're not as masterful as SCOOBY DOO AND THE LEGEND OF THE VAMPIRE.
Rarely does cinema get so exciting. The way Scooby and Shaggy eat those Scooby snacks like it's no tomorrow. What is in those snacks, I'll never know. Some sort of illegal substance that gets the consumer to submit to any command. 
Forget Norman Bates, Darth Vader, Hannibal Lecter, The Joker. The YOWIE YAHOO is the most terrifying villain in cinematic history. Just the name alone sends shivers down the spine. 
With directing more skilful than that of Scorsese, a script more electric than one penned by Tarantino , and a story more brilliantly complex than Hitchcock's works, this is really essential viewing for any self proclaimed cinephile.
This is a FILM. I haven't seen this in 10 years and oh my the

Title: I‚Äôm Your¬†Man
Text:
Alma is a scientist coerced into participating in an extraordinary study in order to obtain research funds for her work. For three weeks, she has to live with a humanoid robot tailored to her character and needs, whose artificial intelligence is designed to be the perfect life partner for her. Enter Tom, a machine in human form in a class of its own, created solely to make her¬†happy.
['trying to figure out what was weird and what was just german', 'Thoroughly watchable and deceptively wise - there is obviously the initial thrill of Dan Stevens speaking German (!) but the strength of his performance goes way beyond that - hypnotic, magnetic body language and candid affection, without losing glimpses of spontaneous humour too. Shades of 
Little Joe
\xa0and 
Her

mundanity
\xa0of loneliness and the performance of romance, in all forms. Terrific script and vivid performances. Cannot wait to rewatch!', 'do bisexuals get 2 robots?']

Title: Detroit
Text:

 is one of the scariest films I've ever seen.
This film reminded me of 
Funny Games
 and 
Passion of the Christ
.
Will Poulter's character is more evil than Michael Myers, Jason, and Freddy Kruger.
Fuck.", "I'm from Detroit. I've lived in and around the city for the majority of my life. This movie has nothing to say about this city, the uprising of '67 or, most damningly, what it's like to be black in America. Detroit (the movie) is the cinematic equivalent of Ramsay Bolton from Game of Thrones; it luxuriates interminably in the depths of human depravity without ever arriving at a meaningful conclusion. Maybe the hopelessness I felt watching Detroit was intentional. It certainly doesn't feel like we've made any progress in becoming a more empathetic and just society since '67. Still, what's the point? For a black audience member, I don't see how there's anything to be found here that with which‚Ä¶

Title: Kelly‚Äôs¬†Heroes
Text:
A misfit group of World War II American soldiers goes AWOL to rob a bank behind German¬†lines.
['I love any movie that makes the unspeakable horrors of World War II seem like having fun with the boys.', '‚ÄúFeel-good war movie‚Äù is kind of an oxymoron, but I‚Äôll take it.
Clint Eastwood, again acting as the symbol of peak masculinity in cinema, plays a disgraced WWII officer with a chip on his shoulder who leads a rag tag group of American soldiers behind enemy lines after discovering the location of a secret stash of Nazi gold in this buddy adventure that ends up being 70% heist mission, 30% lighthearted comedy.
Along for the ride are Telly Savalas, Don Rickles, and Donald Sutherland in what may be his best comedic turn outside of M*A*S*H (which released the same year) as Sergeant ‚ÄúOddball‚Äù, the spaced-out tank commander. Also deserving of a shout out is Carroll O‚ÄôConnor, here playing a 2-star‚Ä¶ 
more', '"We're just soldiers, right? We don't even know what this war's all about. All we do is we fight and we die, and for what?"
this is a terrific caper film; rollicking, hilarious, cynical...war as an act of pure self-interest. nobody seems to care just where all that Nazi gold came from.']

Title: W.
Text:
The story of the eventful life of George W. Bush‚Äîhis struggles and triumphs, how he found both his wife and his faith‚Äîand the critical days leading up to his decision to invade¬†Iraq.
["Fascinating for Stone in that it both lacks (mostly) simple empathy and yet (confoundingly for some) still refuses to paint Bush as actively malevolent as opposed to merely stupid. But I think the real problem here is that Stone reserves a special scorn for people who don't believe in anything, and that makes for a fundamental disconnect, something that didn't plague, say, NIXON, and it poisons everything here with smugness, especially in the dull laundry list of its subject's many famous gaffes but also in the depiction of Texas culture and Bush's fratboy personality as some rancid nightmaricana (tm) even while there's an attempt to get inside the man's crippling anxiety in the shadow of his father and family. Nice try but too timid on all fronts.", 'For whatever reason (checked by the box office rejection of 
Nixon
 and 
Alexander
, the rushed production, or just a general lack of inspiration) Stone can't muster up any of that manic urgency that fueled 
JFK
 and 
Nixon
 and instead makes the kind of flat, prestige, ripped-from-the-headlines moron failson lifetime movie anyone else could have. "Who do you think you are? A Kennedy? You're a Bush! Act like one." A very sad whimper of a conclusion to his trilogy on American presidents but the re-enactment of Bush nearly choking to death on a pretzel while watching football was pretty funny, and Brolin gets pretty close to selling that line about how ‚Äúenhanced interrogation techniques‚Äù remind him of his frat days.', 'Saw this movie opening weekend at Union Square and sat right behind Anna Wintour. This has been a film review.', "didn't know that 
Colin Powell and 
Condoleezza Rice 
were the standouts 
on HBO's Westworld.", 'why the fuck would you make a weirdly sympathetic portrait of george w. bush in 
2008 
of all years', "The ever underappreciated Oliver Stone made a lingering political portrait that dared to dissect, with means of psychological probing, the professional fallacies and personality inadequacies of George W. Center stage is the astounding Josh Brolin, stupendous going from good ol' boy recklessness to overblown hubris that 
he
 is the only one who could ever steer the country right. As president, George Jr. wants to outshine his father‚Äôs legacy; the father whose course of action as former president was too slow, not thorough enough. The film sees baseball as W.‚Äôs first love obsession, and politics as not so much as a love obsession but as a heritage entitlement. The subversive factor is that the film only seems to bask in the‚Ä¶ 
more", 'committing war crimes to own your poppy', '"Axis of... Hatred?"
"No... something about it just misses..."
This highlight-reel of the Bush Era's Greatest Hits felt redundant in 2008, and now plays like pure 2000s kitsch. It's an eerie and uncanny experience seeing these once-familiar incidents badly re-enacted by celebs.
The tone veers gracelessly from earnest drama to ham-fisted satire (we see a cable news show called "Spinball"). Every piece of exposition is crammed with factoids. Certain of the performances (Thandie Newton as Condoleezza Rice, Jeffrey Wright as Colin Powell) would not have passed muster on MadTV. This started filming in May 2008 and was in theatres by October, and the production values are only slightly better than a Syfy Channel original.
This is a one-star movie, but I'm giving it an extra half-star for Dreyfuss and Cromwell, and for the fact that I was entertained throughout.', "Oliver Stone's film about George W. Bush paints an interesting picture of our 43rd president. Stone's not really known for subtlety, but he does seem to seek some sort of balance here, showing us W.'s likable side along with his flaws, and giving us some insight into the family issues that drove him. Josh Brolin does a remarkable job of sustaining that balance, and it's primarily his performance that holds our interest through the film.", 'george w. bush is thanos', 'While I agree that Stone's made-too-soon cinematic treatment of Dubya's time spent as commander-in-chief feels incomplete and in many ways, soft, I like it. a lot. I like how it keeps its focus more on the man than on the failures of his administration, I like how it's structured and paced, I like the "daddy issues" theme that runs throughout the narrative, and even though he doesn't disappear into the role, I like Brolin's portrayal. To me, this is Stone's most underrated movie, and it's not even close.', 'Almost gotta admire the balls on Oliver Stone for somehow thinking it was a good idea to make a sympathetic Bush biopic in 2008 of all fucking years']

Title: Lady in the¬†Water
Text:
Apartment building superintendent Cleveland Heep rescues what he thinks is a young woman from the pool he maintains. When he discovers that she is actually a character from a bedtime story who is trying to make the journey back to her home, he works with his tenants to protect his new friend from the creatures that are determined to keep her in our¬†world.
["This corpse has been picked over plenty, and while I'll stipulate that it's a bit undercooked and pretty silly, on a rewatch I think it's one of those things you just have to deliberately slide into, which makes sense given that it's all of a piece with SIGNS and THE VILLAGE in its depiction of an insular community or group united by belief. You can choose to read Bob Balaban's character as a snipe at all critics, or you can take it as a representation of blanket, unfeeling skepticism. Up to you. Anyway, Shyamalan may exhibit all manner of ill-advised creative hubris but that doesn't mask his exceptional capabilities as a visual filmmaker. It's hard to make an ugly movie‚Ä¶ 
more", '"He's hearing the voice of God through a crossword puzzle."
Acho que s√≥ o Apichatpong acredita tanto no poder sugestivo da hist√≥ria oral como o Shyamalan. E √© uma cren√ßa no sentido de uma f√© m√≠stica mesmo, f√© em uma mitologia fantasiosa que foi perdida, uma mitologia essencialmente narrativa que parte da infantiliza√ß√£o de alguns elementos justamente para revelar uma ess√™ncia prim√°ria e poderosa das coisas. 
O melhor de tudo √© que o Shy faz isso com um humor t√£o espirituoso quanto exc√™ntrico. Toda a deslocaliza√ß√£o cotidiana desse filme parte de uma ridiculariza√ß√£o meio frontal das coisas, mas √© justamente a f√© nesses elementos rid√≠culos que os torna grandiosos. Fora todo um senso de uni√£o que o ambiente coletivo gera,‚Ä¶ 
more', "84
M. Night Shyamalan's penchant for isolated communities, totems of loss and tragedy, and eccentric, fantastical concepts is given its most inwardly emotional landscape in 
Lady in the Water
. An apartment complex, 'The Cove', is situated as a battleground for Shyamalan's anger - towards the Iraq war, his bruised ego, and his critics - while manifesting as a convoluted, at times cloyingly sincere bedtime story. But there's real pain buried deep down. And Shyamalan, teaming up with famed DP Christopher Doyle, works with his collaborators to bring it all to the surface. It's such a fragile movie. Watching 
Lady in the Water
, it seems to fall apart, again and again, while Shyamalan picks up the scattered pieces and gently glues‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Charade

Soon, she and Peter are giving chase to three of her late husband‚Äôs World War II cronies, Tex, Scobie and Gideon, who are after a quarter of a million dollars the quartet stole while behind enemy¬†lines.
['watching audrey hepburn touch the cleft in cary grant\'s chin, and then proceeding to ask "how do you shave in there?" is \npeak. cinema.', '"Of course, you won\'t be able to lie on your back for a while but then you can lie from any position, can\'t you?" -a pretty sick Audrey HepBURN', '"Charade" is the most Hitchcockian Hitchcock that Hitchcock never Hitchcocked.']

Title: 3 Men and a¬†Baby
Text:

Title: News from¬†Home
Text:
Belgian filmmaker Chantal Akerman lives in New York. Filmed images of the City accompany texts of Akerman‚Äôs loving mother back home in Brussels. The City comes more and more to the front while the words of the mother, read by Akerman herself, gradually fade¬†away.
["thank god i watched this at home where i get to say morning to my mom tomorrow because if i wasn't i don't know how i'd be able to handle myself right now", "It's too easy and reductive to say of Akerman that she, in comparison to her male contemporaries, found the heart beating within structuralism. But as affecting as her work is‚Äîand 
News from Home
, soundtracked to Akerman reading her the alternately doting, melancholy and passive-aggressive letters sent to her by her mom, is acutely painful at times‚Äîit is more accurate to say that the director best understood the applications of structuralism not merely to cinema formalism but to the patterns of quotidian life. Akerman's domestic films from this period explored the crushingly numbed rhythms of interior life, but her New York movies expanded this scope to shared spaces and public existence. 
News from Home
 marks the crest of this extrapolation, with‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Sweetheart, at first you wrote so often']

Text:

["[theatrical version]

Title: Calvary
Text:
After being threatened during a confession, a good-natured priest must battle the dark forces closing in around¬†him.
["Can't fault anyone turned off by the glibness of CALVARY, that slight sense of caricature and quirk that permeates the parishioners of Father James' (Brendan Gleeson) little Irish village ‚Äî especially when wrapped in such grimness (revenge, death, sexual abuse). But dammit, doesn't this clash capture the sublime folly of existence?
How do you cope with the darkness, the everyday malaise? These characters, like so many of us, detach via alcohol and sex, or in less self-destructive fashion, lose themselves in books; McDonagh softens the despair with humor. Sometimes all you can do is laugh.", 'but who killed the dog', 'A thing of rich and raw beauty isn't usually found in cinemas at this time of year. It's predominantly a period when brash blockbusters try to numb our minds and perfunctory cash grabs attempt to pry open our wallets. But John Michael McDonagh's 
Calvary
 defies this logic vehemently. It's a film that's imbued with staggering gorgeousness, verisimilitude and a whole heap of panache. Not to oversell it, but 
Calvary
 is to John Michael McDonagh what 
In Bruges
 was to his brother, Martin. It is, and I predict will be, one of the finest films of the year. 
From the stark prologue which begins in a confessionary box with the chilling lines: "
I first tasted semen when I was seven years‚Ä¶

Title: Navalny
Text:
Follows the man who survived an assassination attempt by poisoning with a lethal nerve agent in August 2020. During his months-long recovery, he makes shocking discoveries about the attempt on his life and decides to return¬†home.
['Truly a badass move to cold call your attempted murderers to ask for a performance review', 'The phone call scene is one of the most amazing things I‚Äôve ever seen.', 'At the very least, Daniel Roher‚Äôs ‚ÄúNavalny‚Äù hinges on one of the most remarkable moments I‚Äôve ever seen in a documentary. It‚Äôs just after sunrise on a snow-white morning in December 2020, and the film‚Äôs namesake ‚Äî gregarious Russia of the Future leader and fearless Putin critic Alexei Navalny ‚Äî sits at the kitchen table of the remote German cabin where he‚Äôs been hiding since FSB agents tried and failed to assassinate him with the Soviet-era nerve agent Novichok four months earlier. To Navalny‚Äôs right, investigative journalist Christo Grozev operates some recording equipment. To his left, his unflappable campaign manager cracks her knuckles to relieve the tension. His wife Yulia and their two teenage children are still asleep upstairs.\nWith‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Cemetery¬†Man
Text:
Cemetery watchman, Francesco Dellamorte, is tasked with dispatching the recently deceased when they rise from their¬†graves.
['Dellamorte
 
Dellamore
 sounds better than cemetery man, but I digress, this cinematic artform is a masterwork in vibes and the last true gasp of Italian horror‚Äîa weirdo banger that feels like the culmination of years of lurid linguini and it‚Äôs a damn masterpiece.
For years now, since I was a teenager in the late 90‚Äôs, I‚Äôve had trouble sleeping. Whether due to anxiety, existential dread, teenage angst, or annoying neighbors just being too loud, the slightest sleep disturbance has always woken me up, and kept me that way. Luckily, I‚Äôd always have films to fall back on that would help take me away to dreamland, and In those particular moments of insomnia,\xa0
Dellamorte Dellamore
\xa0has been there for me. Like heroin, I‚Äôd‚Ä¶ 
more', 'It‚Äôs a work of art, a swath of style and contradiction. It‚Äôs a zombie movie with its own canon. It‚Äôs equal parts Lynch and Raimi. It‚Äôs foreign to an American like me, yet it‚Äôs in English. It‚Äôs a love story in a unique triangle. Its ugliest images are some of the most beautiful I‚Äôve seen in a horror film. It‚Äôs a buddy film with a parallel universe Curly Howard as the buddy. It‚Äôs 
The Walking Dead
-creative-kills 20 years before 
Dead
 was born. It‚Äôs gothic and simultaneously hip.
‚ÄúI‚Äôd give my life to be dead‚Äù
 - Dellamorte\xa0
It is absurd. And it makes perfect sense.', "Poor sad Francesco.
Trapped in a world that doesn't love him but can't do without him. Not liked by anyone but accepted as a useful mean. He lives outside of society because his only company is death.
He desires what we all desire. He wants love. He desires it so much that it becomes an obsession. An obsession that will destroy his beloved and his only friend.
He tries everything to avoid his fate. Wants to escape and live a normal happy life. Start over somewhere else.
But death doesn't just let his best and dearest companion go and so in the end our hero has to realize that he can't escape his calling.
He is Francesco Dellamorte. Saint Francis‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: The Thin Red¬†Line
Text:
The story of a group of men, an Army Rifle company called C-for-Charlie, who change, suffer, and ultimately make essential discoveries about themselves during the fierce World War II battle of Guadalcanal. It follows their journey, from the surprise of an unopposed landing, through the bloody and exhausting battles that follow, to the ultimate departure of those who¬†survived.
["I heard people talk about immortality,
 but I ain't seen it. 
 l wondered how it'd be when l died. 
 What it'd be like to know that this breath now
 was the last one you was ever gonna draw. 
 l just hope l can meet it the same way she did. 
 With the same... calm. 
 Cos that's where it's hidden -
 the immortality l hadn't seen.
What's it like to be lying in the middle of an unfamiliar jungle with birds singing around you, the sun making it's way through the trees to lightly shine on the guy next to you, dying of a bullet wound to the gut, knowing you will be next if you get up and run towards‚Ä¶ 
more", "Nature as witness to men's destruction. Trees as tombstones circling us, venomous snakes interrupting gun battles, shy plants withdrawing from a soldier's touch. Sunlight piercing through layers of green and landed on an injured man's face as he listened to his comrade telling him that he's going to die, a lizard watched quietly... unaffected, unforgiving. 
Do you imagine your suffering will be any less because you loved goodness and truth?
An epic emotional journey showing the lunacy and unreality of war, where every bullet whooshing past is a jumpscare, every explosion a trauma. Watch, digest, lie down and think. You will cry, if not at the realization that there is no such thing as a numbness to death, then at the beauty of every scene. Go hug a tree, let the melanesian choirs flow through and cleanse you. (I swear I heard them before. When I was very young. Where was it? Where was it?)", 'The moment Terrence Malick realized voiceover narration could be whispered']

Title: Castle¬†Freak
Text:

['75
Castle Freak 
asks the important questions, such as: what if there was a castle? And in that castle, there was a freak?', 'Castle Freak is a movie that understands that the very heart of Gothic Horror is the horror inside every family. The failures, the recrimination, the shame, the weaknesses and the violences, both grand and petty, constitute and erode family cohesion and definition. That the mistakes made in error or fury or sadness encode themselves into the following generations, shaping their experience of the world, delimiting their potential, and setting the stage for furtherance of the family curse, which, sadly, is redundant. Title: Manos: The Hands of¬†Fate
Text:
A family gets lost on the road and stumbles upon a hidden, underground, devil-worshiping cult led by the fearsome Master and his servant¬†Torgo.
['"Without Manos: The Hands of Fate there would be no 2001: A Space Oddyssey."
 -Stanley Kubrick
"Robert Smith Jr and Russ Huddleston's score is the reason I started composing"
 -John Williams
"I almost quit show business for good the first time I saw Manos. I mean, when a performance as brilliant as John Reynolds' Torgo already exists why would I even bother trying..."
 -Jack Nicholson', "Manos: The Hands of Fate was praised for its visual effects, performances, production values, direction, score, cinematography, story and emotional depth. Among other awards, it was nominated for 14 Academy Awards and won 11, including Best Picture and Best Director, tying Ben-Hur (1959) for the most Academy Awards won by a film. With an initial worldwide gross of over $1.84 billion, Manos: The Hands of Fate was the first film to reach the billion-dollar mark. It was the highest-grossing film of all time until Avatar (2009) surpassed it in 2010. A number of re-releases have pushed the film's worldwide total to $2.257 billion, making it the second film to gross more than $2 billion worldwide after Avatar. It was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry in 2017.", "Stripped of annoying wisecracking robots this is not only an inscrutable piece of anti-cinema but also a glorious piece of accidental outsider art, an unnerving, arrhythmic ocean of crummy tinkly jazz, desolate sets, murky shadows, and weird Freudian sex panic misogyny. Awkward shot lengths and jump cuts, blurred focus, and stilted out-of-sync-dialogue merge into this sustained, ugly seepage of dread, inadvertently conjured by sheer ineptitude and a spring-wound 16mm camera's operational idiosyncrasies."]

Title: Wuthering¬†Heights

Earnshaw‚Äôs son, Hindley, resents the child, but Heathcliff becomes companion and soulmate to Hindley‚Äôs sister, Catherine. After her parents die, Cathy and Heathcliff grow up wild and free on the moors and despite the continued enmity between Hindley and Heathcliff they‚Äôre happy ‚Äì until Cathy meets Edgar Linton, the son of a wealthy¬†neighbor. √ó

Title: Roma
Text:
A virtually plotless, gaudy, impressionistic portrait of Rome through the eyes of one of its most famous¬†citizens.
['"You never have to jerk off; that's what's nice about Rome."
Though his previous film (
The Clowns
) had been a relative disappointment for Federico Fellini both critically and with audiences, the early-1970s still represented a period of international ascendancy for the Italian maestro. This outpouring of veneration would reach its zenith with 1973's 
Amarcord
, a series of bawdy episodes depicting Fellini's early years in the provinces during the nascent era of Italian fascism. But just before 
Amarcord
 Fellini would first tackle 
Roma
, a love poem to his adopted home whose depiction in 
La Dolce Vita
 had made him a household name a dozen years prior. Like 
Amarcord
 it is structured in vignettes, though 
Roma
 is an altogether more experimental film‚Äîmerging‚Ä¶ 
more', "He directed a fine number of bona fide classics (I would need two hands to count them), but his essay-mosaic, part drama / part documentary / part dreamscape 
Fellini's Roma
 is the only one of them that I crave watching repeatedly. You can call it my favorite of his.
Through the course of a dozen or so vignettes, Fellini pores over the good, the bad, the ostentatious -- key example of that is a Vatican fashion show where the costumes at get bigger and bigger, then more glittery and blindingly glittery. How could these costumes possibly get any more pompous, you wonder, as it goes on and on up until the climax of the scene: We have a top (!),‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Monument versus motion appears to be a central theme to Federico Fellini‚Äôs 
Roma
, an abstract homage to the city itself that contains characteristically semi-autobiographical and self-deprecating elements in its amorphous narrative and episodic structure. More of a highly-personal, coming-of-age vision of the Eternal City than anything as directly self-referential as his more lauded works like 
8
 
¬Ω
 or 
La Dolce Vita
, Rome in all its contradictory glory is the true star of this endearingly bizarre, encoded love letter. Though I‚Äôve only seen 3 ¬Ω Fellini films, I‚Äôm not prepared to say it isn‚Äôt my favorite of them so far‚Äîwhile still exemplifying hallmarks of grotesquerie and hyperbole, Fellini also manages to flesh out his relationship to Rome and its identity as‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Like Father, Like¬†Son
Text:
Ryota Nonomiya is a successful businessman driven by money. He learns that his biological son was switched with another child after birth. He must make a life-changing decision and choose his true son or the boy he raised as his¬†own.
["an apocalypse of cuteness, the Citizen Kane of Disney Dad movies. humane, complex & heartbreaking to the hilt. i'm genuinely disturbed by how much of my future self i saw in the film ‚Äì\xa0it's an uncanny portrait of the dad I'm afraid of being. methinks some of my less enthusiastic colleagues fundamentally misconstrued the central questions of the film.\ni don't think Kore-eda's narrative is preoccupied with questioning whether the rich / cold man is a better father than the poor / warm man. the former is clearly the protagonist of the film, it's not a contest - this is *his* story, and that story is essentially about... well, no way of saying this without it sounding overly sentimental... it's about‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'such a poetic and deeply human film .... how does hirokazu kore-eda do it ??? one of the best directors in this business i think', 'there‚Äôs nothing more beautiful than the way kore-eda handles families, it just makes me cry every single time']

Title: Mask
Text:

Title: The¬†Untamed
Text:
Desperate to flee but consumed by fear, Alejandra, a young mother and working housewife, is trapped in a violent and unsatisfying relationship with her husband, Angel. She leans on her brother Fabi√°n for support, but he has secrets of his own. All of their lives are turned upside down by the arrival of the mysterious Veronica. She convinces them that in the nearby woods, inside an isolated cabin, dwells something not of this world that could be the answer to all of their problems‚Ä¶ something whose force they cannot resist and with whom they must make peace or suffer its¬†wrath. √ó
['Once it was over, the dude next to me whispered to himself "what the fuck?"', 'Sydney Film Festival 2017 - #2
There is a scene in this film where one of our main characters, Veronica, meets a stranger in a diner. Curiously, she asks him about his practice of going out into the wilderness to hunt wild boar. Little does he know that in a way she is also a hunter, except inversely she goes to the city to lure people into the wilderness. Specifically, she takes them to a clearing in the forest wherein lies a cabin inhabited by a tentacled alien fuck monster.
That might give you the sense that it is some kind of Mexican version of Under The Skin meets Shivers. And you would be partially correct. But director, Amante Escalante‚Ä¶ 
more', 'A horrifying octopus creature that can hurt you or make you have an orgasm, depending on the situation.
Horror used as a metaphor for sexuality and domestically abusive relationships.
I just wish this movie leaned harder into the weird. The hints at the fantastical I was loving, but ultimately felt it left me with frustratingly little of it.']

Title: The Right¬†Stuff
Text:
As the Space Race ensues, seven pilots set off on a path to become the first American astronauts to enter space. However, the road to making history brings forth momentous¬†challenges.
['one of the great entertainments.
and golly gee whiz did it inspire INTERSTELLAR. it also inspired this entry to be so uninteresting, because i watched the film for a piece related to Interstellar, which is the film that has completely sapped my critical faculties dry this weekend.', '‚ÄúThere was a demon who lived in the air‚Ä¶‚Äù
Director Phillip Kauffman‚Äôs love letter to the Mercury Space Program is really a love letter to a certain ephemeral essence. It can easily be dismissed as a love letter to American exceptionalism, provided you overlook its constant, subtle and not so subtle reminders that even in its finest hour, America had - and has - a long, long way to go. 
The Right Stuff
 loves America deeply without ever losing perspective.
It‚Äôs influence can be found everywhere and it ranks high on my list of films that shouldn‚Äôt exist yet somehow do.', '73/100
Begins and ends weakly: the Yeager prologue strains too hard to be iconic (and is rife with tin-eared dialogue, unlike the rest of the movie‚Äî"We did it! We finally broke the sound barrier" someone cries, as if anyone in earshot or in the audience hadn't worked that out‚Äîwhile the epilogue ("And for a brief moment, Gordo Cooper became the greatest pilot anyone had ever seen") just feels like a cheap shot...especially given that it's spoken by Levon Helm, who also plays Yeager's gum-loaning wingman. But the arrival of Jeff Goldblum and Harry Shearer in minor roles heralds a marvelous change of pace, and Kaufman's affectionate satire of the Mercury program's training regimen and PR campaign enlivens docudrama conventions by‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Cloverfield
Text:
Five young New Yorkers throw their friend a going-away party the night that a monster the size of a skyscraper descends upon the city. Told from the point of view of their video camera, the film is a document of their attempt to survive the most surreal, horrifying event of their¬†lives.
['the best part in this movie is when tj miller shuts the fuck up', 'Still the best film ever made about 9/11 -- about the 21st century -- 
Cloverfield
 is an unparalleled expressionist masterpiece. People talked about how it ripped its "don't show the monster" technique from 
Jaws
, but it's closer to Lovecraft than anything else. Furthermore, it's an idea wholly indebted to the film's own era. We're afraid of what we don't know, what we can't see. Films like 
War of the Worlds
 come close to touching on post-9/11 anxieties so potently, but the first-person perspective gives 
Cloverfield
 the edge. Putting us in a single subjective point-of-view accentuates the terror (emphasis on terror) of everything we can't see or understand. The uncontrolled images create these chaotic spaces and incomprehensible geographies. It's an event‚Ä¶ 
more', 'camera battery goals']

Title: Farewell My¬†Concubine
Text:
Two boys meet at an opera training school in Peking in 1924. Their resulting friendship will span nearly 70 years and endure some of the most troublesome times in China‚Äôs¬†history.
['you‚Äôre young and you‚Äôre small in a world that is massive and cruel. it takes everything from you. you don‚Äôt quite understand everything, but you know that it hurts when they hold you down, when they take everything from you. and you know that you‚Äôre alone. until suddenly you‚Äôre not. because one boy looked at you and showed you kindness and understanding.\nand then you grow up with him in a life that neither of you chose with an identity that neither of you chose to have. but whether you had a choice or not doesn‚Äôt matter. you devote your life to the art, to pretending, you devote your entire self to being a fake version of you. life imitates‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'Leslie Cheung was truly extraordinary. Who else could give such a fragile performance, like a pendulum swinging from one extreme to the other? So restrained yet absolutely unhinged. So vulnerable yet completely vicious. So alone yet always surrounded by crowds. So filled with self-loathing yet so absolutely self-serving.', 'So epic, terrifying, and beautiful. Leslie Cheung is a legend.']

Title: Butterfly¬†Kisses

But it also plays on all the tropes of the genre and gets very meta in a‚Ä¶

Title: Diary of a Country¬†Priest
Text:
An inexperienced, sickly priest shows up in the rural French community of Ambricourt, where he joins the community‚Äôs clergy. But the locals don‚Äôt take kindly to the priest, and his ascetic ways and unsociable demeanor make him an outcast. During Bible studies at the nearby girls school, he is continually mocked by his students. Then his attempt to intervene in a family feud backfires into a scandal. His failures, compounded with his declining health, begin to erode his¬†faith. √ó
["***One of the best 150 films I have ever seen.***
Bresson's minimalist scope in his masterful and ahead-of-its-time essay on fortitude, faith and humanity allows us to appreciate how many directors including Tarkovsky, Bergman, Bu√±uel, Vl√°cil and even Scorsese grew up admiring this legendary milestone of metaphysical proportions. Exclusively aimed towards those that recognize cinema as an art and search for several perspectives regarding the most transcendent questions of our existence, Journal d'un Cur√© de Campagne punches the soul of its viewer with a catastrophic magnitude.
100/100", 'All is grace.', 'I‚Äôd place this film alongside 
The Passion of Joan of Arc
 and 
Winter Light
 
as one of the greatest ever made about faith. Unlike so many works that try to move or impress through big gestures, here everything is stripped down, restrained, almost austere. There seems to be no intention whatsoever to seduce the audience ‚Äî and perhaps that‚Äôs precisely why it resonates so deeply. It‚Äôs a film that bears the weight of the sacred without ever pointing to it directly, allowing faith, doubt, and suffering to emerge gradually ‚Äî in silence, in the spaces between words. It offers not just a portrait of a man but the intimate agony of a tradition that, surrounded by growing skepticism and a‚Ä¶
 
more']

Title: A Tale of¬†Autumn
Text:
Magali, forty-something, is a winemaker and a widow: she loves her work but feels lonely. Her friends Rosine and Isabelle both want secretly to find a husband for¬†Magali.
["The way Rohmer shoots conversations between two people in this is fascinating. Characters talk objectively about their love lives together in a two-shot, before, usually as one of them says something the other doesn't agree with/want to talk about, one of them leaves the frame. The camera stays as it is, leaving one character alone in a shot made for two, while Rohmer cuts to the other in a shot of their own. The conversations continue as if nothing has happened, cutting back and forth between the two shots, and the characters generally reunite within one frame after talking a little more, but the distance between them in these brief moments, however small, feels enormous, suggesting a divide between them that bubbles under the surface of every word they're saying.", 'I‚Äôm going to create Tinder accounts for all my single friends and go on dates on their behalf just to feel like I‚Äôm in a Rohmer movie for once. I need this.', "Tinder is CANCELLED. Let's use newspapers."]

Title: Woman in the¬†Dunes
Text:

['shovel your way out of the shit', '"No, no, dig 
up

Title: Fearless
Text:
After surviving a plane crash that kills many others, Max Klein develops a sense of invulnerability, leading to radical, compulsive actions. Can a psychologist and a fellow guilt-ridden survivor bring him down to¬†earth?
["FEARLESS, by Peter Weir is an underrated and underdiscussed movie compared to some of Weir's other films. It's a moving & profound meditation on grief, loss, guilt and mortality featuring career best performance from Jeff Bridges. Loved the last 10 mins, wonderful use of Gorecki‚Äôs Symphony No 3.", "*Fearless* had a big impact on me when I watched it in my late teens. It made me reconsider what I choose to watch. If a movie I had never heard of could move me so much, I realized I was missing out by only sticking to popular films from big directors. 
The film delves into the psychology of characters grappling with survivor's guilt following a plane crash. The first hour (largely) lacks a soundtrack, featuring subdued dialogue and modest filmmaking techniques. This creates a sense of distance between the audience and the characters, which can be frustrating. 
We experience the emotional confusion of the plane crash survivors alongside them. The feeling of numbness is palpable as Jeff Bridges' character‚Ä¶ 
more", "62/100
In 1992, I wrote a screenplay, my third, called 
The Flight Not Taken
. (Yes, I know that's a lame title. Never came up with a better one.) It was about a guy who, through a series of bizarre coincidences, winds up just missing a plane that subsequently crashes, killing everyone aboard. Having previously been a devout atheist, he now decides that there is a God, and that God spared him for some grand purpose; this transforms him into an insufferable prick, and the bulk of the movie is told from the point of view of his wife, a high school teacher who teams up with one of her students to manufacture coincidences around him in the hope of snapping‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Freaky¬†Tales
Text:
In 1987 Oakland, a mysterious force guides The Town‚Äôs underdogs in four interconnected tales: teen punks defend their turf against Nazi skinheads, a rap duo battles for hip-hop immortality, a weary henchman gets a shot at redemption, and an NBA All-Star settles the¬†score.
['Never kill yourself, some cool kid could hand you a mixtape.', 'Pulp Fiction
 meets 
Scott Pilgrim Vs. The World
 with a sprinkling of 
The Warriors
. No, I will not explain.', 'I am not exactly sure where the line between homage and cheap imitation begins or ends. It‚Äôs not exactly a black and white answer, but it‚Äôs something that crossed my mind while walking out of 
Freaky Tales
. A movie that very proudly wears its inspirations on its sleeve, but maybe that‚Äôs the distinction? Proudly. Warmly embraces the love for Tarantino, Hill, and Carpenter rather than coyly pretending they don‚Äôt exist? 
Im not sure, but what I am sure is that I adored this. Did I adore it because it invokes the style of filmmakers I admire? Probably. But I love a movie dedicated to a city (for this movie, it‚Äôs Oakland). I love a movie that explicitly loves movies. I‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Vice
Text:
George W. Bush picks Dick Cheney, the CEO of Halliburton Co., to be his Republican running mate in the 2000 presidential election. No stranger to politics, Cheney‚Äôs impressive r√©sum√© includes stints as White House chief of staff, House Minority Whip and Defense Secretary. When Bush wins by a narrow margin, Cheney begins to use his newfound power to help reshape the country and the¬†world.
['VICE is an *incredibly* damning portrait of Dick Cheney, in that verrrrry few people could inspire a movie this bad ‚Äî this self-satisfied, this tonally incoherent, this misjudged ‚Äî and *still* not have it rank among the 10 worst things they‚Äôve ever done.\nAdam McKay was an ‚Äúimportant" filmmaker until the moment he started trying to become one. i have endless faith that he‚Äôll figure things out, but these recent history disaster satires (disastires?) aren‚Äôt it.', 'There are of course pieces of this that are funny and clever and maybe even occasionally startling...look man, it\'s hard to argue that it isn\'t at least engrossing. But don\'t be fooled, just like THE BIG SHORT this is another McKay film about how you aren\'t mad enough or informed enough, not as smart or caustic or active as you should be. The idea that nobody knew Dick Cheney was evil human garbage consumed by the pursuit of power and/or money and was responsible for the "legal" taking of, what, how many untold thousands of lives (an accusation it literally directly levels at the audience) is, to put it mildly, completely fucking smug and condescending. I guess we were collectively‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'Ugggghhhh I‚Äôm too young and uninformed about politics to understand how much of this was accurate or how good of a job they did at portraying Dick. So with that being said I guess that‚Äôs why I like it a bit more than the rest of Letterboxd. I loved the performances, I actually dug how unsubtle it is, despite some messiness and a few cringey scenes I‚Äôm sorry to say that I genuinely enjoyed this.']

Title: The First¬†Time
Text:
A spark of attraction smolders, then ignites, between two teens from different high schools who meet by chance at a¬†party.
["Movies like this are why a five star rating system doesn't quite work. Sure, if you're going to compare The First Time to the films of Terrence Malick or Krzysztof Kieslowski, it's not going to hold up... but that's why - while I don't believe in placing films into boxes or set genres - it's important to remember when you're watching a film like this that it was created for a specific target audience. It's not obscure, or experimental, or groundbreaking, but it's 
cute.
 And that's all that it ever tries to be, and at that, it succeeds. So I leave you with this piece of advice: if you're picky about the films that you watch, or only enjoy watching‚Ä¶

Title: Capone
Text:
The 47-year old Al Capone, after 10 years in prison, starts suffering from dementia and comes to be haunted by his violent¬†past.
['Clinical experimentation, which is what I should have expected from Trank ‚Äî a filmmaker clearly not being given enough credit ‚Äî at this point, but it caught me off guard nonetheless. The comparisons to 
Gotti
 (of which this is essentially an opposite), et cetera, simply had me prepared for an entirely different, and altogether much more by-the-books experience. I was not expecting a bizarro, fractured, absurd, genuinely terrifying, purposefully off-putting and deeply, deeply sad study of a haunted psyche. 
Capone
 almost ‚Äî and emphasis on the almost ‚Äî plays like a feature length adaptation of the very finale of 
The Irishman,
 directed by Mike Flanagan in 
Haunting of Hill House
 mode. There‚Äôs an extended sequence in the middle of the‚Ä¶ 
more', "Credit has to be given to Trank here for the deeply uncommercial premise of taking a mythic figure who inspired an entire genre of film for a century and tackling the ugliest, most unglamorous, and pitiable period of his life. He commits to it well enough but unfortunately, he doesn't quite have the filmmaking chops yet to get this to the next level it needed to go imo. The whole thing is a bit too dry and literal (a lot of time is taken up by vague expository gestures towards a lost son, hired goons, buried money, police surveillance, etc) when it should be more psychologically unhinged and swept up in the atmosphere/paranoia. It's also not particularly visually imaginative work‚Ä¶ 
more", 'A necrotic gangster biopic that doubles as one of modern cinema‚Äôs most unforgiving self-portraits, Josh Trank‚Äôs ‚ÄúCapone‚Äù does for Scarface what Gus Van Sant‚Äôs ‚ÄúLast Days‚Äù did for Kurt Cobain: Not a lot, and in excruciating detail. But while both films offer a bleak look at the final chapter of a fabled rock star‚Äôs life, this one has the chutzpah to be so much bleaker; if Van Sant‚Äôs movie was strung out, Trank‚Äôs is utterly zombified.
Hardy once again combines the fearless commitment of early Marlon Brando with the utter unintelligibility of much older Marlon Brando, embodying the legendary crime boss like a rotting corpse. Alphonse Gabriel Capone (aka ‚ÄúFonzo‚Äù or ‚ÄúFonz‚Äù) has been suffering from neurosyphilis for more than‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Bohemian¬†Rhapsody
Text:
Singer Freddie Mercury, guitarist Brian May, drummer Roger Taylor and bass guitarist John Deacon take the music world by storm when they form the rock ‚Äôn‚Äô roll band Queen in 1970. Hit songs become instant classics. When Mercury‚Äôs increasingly wild lifestyle starts to spiral out of control, Queen soon faces its greatest challenge yet ‚Äì finding a way to keep the band together amid the success and¬†excess.
['1
"How many times do we need to teach you this lesson, old man?" 
Abominable. Chickenshit exploitation of queerness and public persona, in addition to being formally inept. Every single element of this movie is subpar, lacking in nuance and a solid foundation of existence. All of the reaction shots are gold - everyone is lost: in geography, character motivation, respect of authenticity or even some semblance of cinematic coherence. Nothing is even remotely aware of its functionality. The film is honestly surreal in its dumpster fire hubris. Rami Malek's prosthetic teeth have an agenda of their own, I swear. I would say this is like a modern SNL sketch, but at least they're trying. The fake wigs and cheap‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Maybe movies were a mistake. 
One of the most astonishing, eccentric performers of all time and this is the insipid, formulaic garbage you give him? Any interest in the nuances and artistry of Queen takes a backseat to making their lives and works fit into a Greatest Hits rise and fall biopic;\xa0watch as a painfully self-conscious performance stumbles through a barely dramatized Wikipedia overview in between montages of songs you like being simplified into little digestible, lowest-common-denominator origin stories everyone can pat themselves on the back for knowing. Are we so far removed from 
Walk Hard
 that people once again buy these clich√©s that were tired even before the mid-2000s? 
We're talking about a movie that opens on the "cough‚Ä¶ 
more', '"I don't have time to be their cautionary tale."
Freddie says this to his bandmates when he reveals his diagnosis with HIV. It‚Äôs an ironic scene, really, given it takes place entirely because this film turned him into one.
Freddie‚Äôs contraction of HIV and eventual death are framed within the film as a tragic inevitability, of which he and his manipulator are to blame. It's his punishment; for his ego, for pushing his band members away. Pushing them away, that is, by embracing his sexuality.
This sexuality is "awakened" within the narrative by Paul Prenter, Freddie's personal manager. The film turns him into a one-note villain, there only to take advantage of Freddie. It is through Paul that he's introduced‚Ä¶

Title: Angels in the¬†Outfield
Text:
