Title: Swamp¬†Thing
Text:
Mutated by his own secret formula, Dr. Alec Holland becomes Swamp Thing; a half-human, half-plant superhero who will stop at nothing to rescue government agent Alice Cable and defeat his evil arch nemesis‚Ä¶Even if it costs him his¬†life.
['I read an article where a writer said ‚Äúit‚Äôs difficult to ignore that 
Swamp Thing
 ultimately is, at core, a rubber-suit monster movie‚Äù
Difficult to ignore? Why the fuck would I want to ignore that? That‚Äôs exactly what I want! Adrienne Barbeau, Ray Wise, the Bond Villain from Octopussy, and David Hess as a scumbag henchman in a Wes Craven swampy superhero movie? I‚Äôd sign up for that anyday. I haven‚Äôt watched this since the early or mid 90‚Äôs so I didn‚Äôt know what to expect this time around...
The opening 20 minutes were fantastic and 
REALLY
\xa0had me excited for this revisit, almost feeling like an action infused early 80‚Äôs\xa0
Friday the 13th
\xa0sequel with its Henry Manfredini score and good guy‚Ä¶ 
more', 'That suit is something else. 
A classic that takes itself too seriously for its own good in some scenes. But you can say its clumsy charm makes it oddly entertaining, yet the chaotic "feel" of the movie adds a layer of confusion. I found myself watching it with a sly grin, not entirely displeased, though its style occasionally shifted that grin into something more strained and disappointed.
The film actually holds something profound within, portraying itself as the sum of its own fate, forced to take full responsibility for itself. The appreciation of nature and coexistence with it are ever-present, embedded in the characters of the story. Maintaining balance in the universe emerges as the most important theme. Humanity remains‚Ä¶ 
more', '‚ÄúNot long ago, in the unexplored reaches of an unmapped swamp. The creative genius of one man collided with another‚Äôs evil dream, and a monster was born!‚Äù
Swamp 
Thang
.\xa0
Wes Craven‚Äôs love letter to rubber-suited monster creature features of the 50‚Äôs; there‚Äôs romance, one hell of a mossy swamp setting, gunfire and smoke, David Hess in army attire, and that banner photo perfectly encapsulates the entire mood from our plant monster‚Äî the most sympathetic being.\xa0
‚Äú
There is great beauty in the swamp -- if you know where to look.
"
Far from Wes Craven‚Äôs best and is oftentimes a huge mess with its pacing but it‚Äôs hard not to love how compassionate Swamp Thing is!\xa0Also who doesn‚Äôt love seeing David Hess and Adrienne Barbeau duke it out ‚Äî love when she hits him over the head with a gasoline tank; that poor gorgeous head of hair!']

Title: Bottle¬†Rocket
Text:
Upon his release from a mental hospital following a nervous breakdown, the directionless Anthony joins his friend Dignan, who seems far less sane than the former. Dignan has hatched a harebrained scheme for an as-yet-unspecified crime spree that somehow involves his former boss, the (supposedly) legendary Mr.¬†Henry.
["Watching such an unstylized Wes Anderson film is so weird, like it feels like I've stumbled onto some illegal footage I was never meant to see", '"what are you putting that tape on your nose for?" "exactly!"', "i'm literally so far up wes anderson's ass now, how far up do you want me to go wes?"]

Title: The Dead¬†Zone
Text:
Johnny Smith is a schoolteacher with his whole life ahead of him but, after leaving his fiancee‚Äôs home one night, is involved in a car crash which leaves him in a coma for 5 years. When he wakes, he discovers he has an ability to see into the past, present and future life of anyone with whom he comes into physical¬†contact.
['movie about how being right all the time gives you migraines', 'This dad is willing to sacrifice his kid‚Äôs life just to watch some hockey. You gotta respect it.', 'Undervalued Cronenberg if you ask me‚Äîand easily my favorite offering from him behind 
Videodrome
, 
The Dead Zone
 might not be as accessible as 
The Fly
 or filled fleshy body horror, but it 
is\xa0
bleak, gripping, relevant, and romantic.
In a filmography filled with disgusting\xa0vile images oozing with drippy flesh, stomach/armpit death orifices, car crash orgasms, and bubbling pus, the finale of 
The Dead Zone
\xa0has perhaps resonated with me the most‚Ä¶ plus it‚Äôs a great reminder that a normal looking body horror-less villain can sometimes be\xa0more frightening and disgusting than a goo oozing mangled flesh husk.\xa0
A classic in my eyes‚Ä¶ and one that could easily slip into my top four at any time.']

Title: Malum

Being given a couple mil to remake your very good indie shot for shot into something glossier but worse is the most baller shit in the world or deeply humiliating. Can‚Äôt decide which. this

Title: Superman¬†III
Text:
Aiming to defeat the Man of Steel, wealthy executive Ross Webster hires bumbling but brilliant Gus Gorman to develop synthetic kryptonite, which yields some unexpected psychological effects. Between rekindling romance with his high school sweetheart and saving himself, Superman must contend with a powerful¬†supercomputer.
['Richard Pryor: The Movie featuring Superman', 'the best kind of evil Superman where he uses his powers to just be kind of a dick to everyone for no reason', "Yeah okay, I know Superman III is one of my favourite films ever but like, I'm just struck how much of an accurate comic book movie it is. It's full of vivid colours (that's why it's so good when evil Superman ends up in a slightly darker suit, the kind of suit that would just be fucking standard now) and grandiose sets (hi, welcome to my underground cave with a sentient super computer).\nWhen I watch a superhero film, I want to be pulled into a world where things are unfathomable. The man is already an alien who can fly and is immortal, I've checked out any basis of reality at the door, please go wild. That's why Superman III‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: Miami¬†Connection
Text:
In a world where ninjas dream of being rock stars and rock stars dream of being ninjas, a martial arts rock band goes up against a band of motorcycle ninjas who have tightened their grip on Florida‚Äôs narcotics¬†trade.
['A bad movie with so much effort and sincerity that it turns into a legit good movie.', 'But also, in its own way, five stars.', '"They don't make buns like that down at the bakery!"
 
The best worst movies aren't made ironically or with a winking eye, they're made with passion and sincerity. All those "movies" made by The Asylum can go to hell, and as much as they may try, they aren't even an ant compared to the cinematic mammoth that is known as 
Miami Connection
. True pride and emotion was put into this film, and as inept as it is, I don't think there is anything as purely enjoyable as this oddball tale of friendship and loyalty. 
In my eyes at least, I don't think any other "so bad it's good" film can compare to 
Miami Connection
, but really, I can't help but‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Zatoichi
Text:
Blind traveler Zatoichi is a master swordsman and a masseur with a fondness for gambling on dice games. When he arrives in a village torn apart by warring gangs, he sets out to protect the¬†townspeople.
["Dumb people: you can't do self-serious action and wacky comedy well at the same time.
Takeshi Kitano: hold my sake", "constantly draws your attention to its own overt artificiality. disguises everything: that woman is a man, those dice are fake, his cane hides a sword, this old guy is a mob boss, the blood is digital. eyes can't be trusted. Kitano trades his usual static deadpan for faster cuts and a moving camera, absolutely none of which his legendary protagonist -- who is totally in on the joke -- can see. and yet we're constantly sonically locked in to his perceptions, especially in the hidden music he hears everywhere. 
there's a final plot twist i won't disclose that, along with Kitano's characteristic style of humor, adds to a general sense of dismissiveness of the material on his part. that's really‚Ä¶ 
more", "Action!: The Campy, The Violent and The Plot Twist‚Äî Kitano's Lingering Violence
In a similar vein to movies such as 
Yojimbo
 and 
13 Assassins
, Kitano takes on the samurai genre in a way I wasn't expecting, mainly because the film is unevenly tonal it is.
It features the director's trademark humor and meditative pace with a character that's a badassery in essence, and Takeshi oozes the character with a form of cool that for many could rival some of the best fictional samurai characters ever created. Though at the same time, I couldn't help but feel some potential was wasted and a lot of the focus was placed on secondary characters that I couldn't really connect with, whose writing for‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Speed¬†Racer
Text:
Speed Racer is a young and brilliant racing driver. When corruption in the racing leagues costs his brother his life, Speed must team up with the police and the mysterious Racer X to bring an end to the corruption and criminal¬†activities.
["so this is a joke right? 5 stars for speed racer? weirdly enough, speed racer is a movie that means so much to me. that's not a normal thing to say. but it's true.\nmy brother died in 2011. he was 7 years old and never went a day without smiling and making everyone around him smile. his favorite movie, and mine at the time as well, was speed racer. i talk about this movie now as a joke, considering how bright and insane it is. but in 2011, in a car accident, my brother died, leaving me with an emotional mother and a drunk father. i was left with movies and speed racer was what was left of carter.‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'Felt like it was made by 12-year olds (non-derogatory)', 'While maybe not as consistently engaging, this is genuinely in the same lane (haha) as Spiderverse and Fury Road in terms of visuals. If you had any doubts that this wasn‚Äôt a good movie please revisit the ‚ÄúNon-ja‚Äù joke.']

Title: One Direction: This Is¬†Us
Text:
‚ÄúOne Direction: This Is Us‚Äù is a captivating and intimate all-access look at life on the road for the global music phenomenon. Weaved with stunning live concert footage, this inspiring feature film tells the remarkable story of Niall, Zayn, Liam, Harry and Louis‚Äô meteoric rise to fame, from their humble hometown beginnings and competing on the X-Factor, to conquering the world and performing at London‚Äôs famed O2 Arena. Hear it from the boys themselves and see through their own eyes what it‚Äôs really like to be One¬†Direction. √ó

Title: The Great¬†Wall
Text:
European mercenaries searching for black powder become embroiled in the defense of the Great Wall of China against a horde of monstrous¬†creatures.
["any movie with pedro pascal wearing eyeliner is a five star movie to me. no, don't look at my rating, look at me", 'This isn‚Äôt that bad if you only give it half of your attention and if that half is the half with Pedro Pascal', 'Directed by acclaimed Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yimou (a master of rhythm and composition who has given us excellent prestige dramas such as 
Raise The Red Lantern
 and 
To Live
, yet also evocative, extravagantly-staged Wuxia pictures like 
Hero
 and 
House of the Flying Daggers
), 
The Great Wall

Tremors
. Try and reconcile that for a second. Having finally experienced what is fundamentally a $150m b-movie, it‚Äôs easy to see why this was an impossibly difficult film to market, and why, for the American marketing in particular, they chose to just go with a simplistic ‚ÄúMatt‚Ä¶

Title: The 400¬†Blows
Text:
For young Parisian boy Antoine Doinel, life is one difficult situation after another. Surrounded by inconsiderate adults, including his neglectful parents, Antoine spends his days with his best friend, Rene, trying to plan for a better life. When one of their schemes goes awry, Antoine ends up in trouble with the law, leading to even more conflicts with unsympathetic authority¬†figures.
["I think people overlook how hard it is to be a kid. All kids at one point feel unwanted, unloved, or uncared for. It's universal, which is why this movie is so incredible. It takes something as simple as a broken household and makes it for everyone, something anyone can relate to.\xa0
The acting and score in particular are outstanding. The cinematography is gorgeous, and you can tell it has inspired many filmmakers today. Many aspects of this film also reminded me of 
Mommy 
and 
I Killed My Mother
, both Xavier Dolan films (which is a great thing). I honestly am in love with this film and it's true, brutal, and heartbreaking story.", 'The little scene where he stands in the police car driving away, looking out of the window with the bars in front of him and tears in his eyes just killed me...', 'i want to slap every single adult in this movie']

Title: Immortals
Text:
Theseus is a mortal man chosen by Zeus to lead the fight against the ruthless King Hyperion, who is on a rampage across Greece to obtain a weapon that can destroy¬†humanity.
['Henry Cavill is shirtless a lot so who cares if it‚Äôs good or bad (it‚Äôs actually okay).', "I just can't help myself, I love Tarsem Singh. His visual palette is just completely different than that of most directors. Immortals is no exception. He gives this film a unique aesthetic, conjuring up some scenes and scene transitions that are completely out of the box. 
The problem here is the script, however. The idea is sound, trying to provide some sort of origin to mythology, but the execution is a bit out of tune. It plays out like a messed up pantomime version of the classical myths, which sometimes worked, but most of the times didn't.
If you're, like me, willing to tag along for the ride there is a great deal of fun to be had and I truly feel it should be watched at least once for the visuals.", "Pretty bland stuff on the page but still one of the better attempts at a modern 
Conan the Barbarian
 and an essential hot couch guy text. Has a gruesomely grounded approach to its mythical image-making and some drop-dead gorgeous, nonsense production design choices you can‚Äôt help but respect. I'd happily watch another one of these, especially if we could figure out a way to bring drip god Mickey Rourke back."]

Title: The New¬†World
Text:
A drama about explorer John Smith and the clash between Native Americans and English settlers in the 17th¬†century.
["When aliens invade earth and unforeseeably exterminate our entire race in the passing of a millisecond with their incomprehensible bio-weaponry, the only human being that they're going to spare is Terrence Malick.", 'The fourth movie in my Terrence Malick screening series, and maybe my sentimental favorite Malick film. 
We watched the Extended Cut, which is absolutely my preferred version. This gentle, deeply felt epic impresses me more each time I revisit it. What appears to be a deceptively simple story hides fathoms of complexities, all anchored on a perfect performance by then 14-year-old actress Q'orianka Kilcher. This is a movie about discovery, love, fate, the inevitable tidal wave of history, and - ultimately - an aching regret. There are few lines as perfectly written and acted as "I may have sailed past them". 
My little screening group is becoming more polarized with each Malick film we screen, which is no surprise. While‚Ä¶ 
more', 'It is so cool that Terrence Malick is real']

Title: Sabotage
Text:
Karl Anton Verloc and his wife own a small cinema in a quiet London suburb where they live seemingly happily. But Mrs. Verloc does not know that her husband has a secret that will affect their relationship and threaten her teenage brother‚Äôs¬†life.
['This shit is absolutely cold blooded.', "I wasn't expecting much from this one but I genuinely loved it. This is a brilliant exercise in suspense as Hitchcock squeezes you until you're dry at certain unforgettable moments. Moments that are boosted by brilliant editing. The man makes directing thrillers look like a walk in the park. Sabotage is the opposite of Hitchcock's country traversing thrillers as it is primarily shot in one location. I found this to be rather refreshing with a sinister plot on such a small scale. 
This film hardly feels dated at all and I think it holds up very well. Sabotage is a quick entertaining blast that I intend to come back to.
Hitchcock Ranked List", 'Melodrama and suspense mix and ignite with explosive stakes in ‚ÄúSabotage.‚Äù\xa0
A director just partway into his prolific career could do worse then making a film that is worksmanlike. But, that is indeed the most apt descriptor for Alfred Hitchcock‚Äôs ‚ÄúSabotage.‚Äù An adaption of a Joseph Conrad novel, ‚ÄúSabotage‚Äù has a confidence of structure that would never allude its creator still had a full half century of work yet to come.\xa0
Clocking in at a slight hour and seventeen minutes, ‚ÄúSabotage‚Äù has not a wasted shot, dialogue line, or breath. 
Every single second exists merely to build suspense for the one to come.\xa0
So it is, that ‚ÄúSabotage‚Äù gives no explanations as to the string of terrorist bombings that progress‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Good¬†Time
Text:
After a botched bank robbery lands his younger brother in prison, Connie Nikas embarks on a twisted odyssey through New York City‚Äôs underworld to get his brother Nick out of¬†jail.
['Imagine your worst panic attack.
Times it by 100.', "A green Sprite bottle, given almost a mythical introduction in a frenetic monologue, slips out of the hand of a character and roles into a puddle of water. The camera, finally imparted from its intense close-ups to a God's eye long shot, lingers just for a second as it rolls into a puddle where it could be misconceived as trash. An object of everyday life that has been signified with narrative agency (A MacGuffin up there with the Arc of the Covenant) once again resembles its indexical reality. No neon lights or close-ups to enlarge its importance, just a piece of misplaced trash 
left by some dirtbag scum
.
This movie is what happens when we observe the trash we avert our eyes to‚Äî
what we're taught to ignore
‚Äîand really look at what's inside.", 'when robert pattinson dyes his hair blond and runs around erratically he's a good actor but when i do it i'm "hysterical" and "scaring the children"']

Title: Ella¬†Enchanted
Text:

This birthright proves itself to be quite the curse once Ella finds herself in the hands of several unscrupulous characters whom she quite literally cannot disobey. Determined to gain control of her life and decisions, Ella sets off on a journey to find her fairy godmother who she hopes will lift the curse. The path, however, isn‚Äôt easy ‚Äì Ella must outwit a slew of unpleasant obstacles including ogres, giants, wicked stepsisters, elves and Prince Charmont‚Äôs evil uncle, who wants to take over the crown and rule the¬†kingdom. √ó

Title: Another¬†Woman
Text:
Marion is a woman who has learned to shield herself from her emotions. She rents an apartment to work undisturbed on her new book, but by some acoustic anomaly she can hear all that is said in the next apartment in which a psychiatrist holds his office. When she hears a young woman tell that she finds it harder and harder to bear her life, Marion starts to reflect on her own life. After a series of events she comes to understand how her unemotional attitude towards the people around her affected them and¬†herself. √ó
['For a while, I was sort of annoyed by Marion\'s tendency to narrate the events of her own life in such an on-the-nose manner. Then it hit me that OF COURSE Marion (Gena Rowlands, masterful) would do that- she\'s the sort of person who would want to neatly package all of her actions with a minimum of emotional fuss, just to "set the record straight," if only to herself. Once I got over that hump, the movie as a whole got pretty heartbreaking, being the story of a woman who deludes herself that everything\'s fine because her sense of balance depends on it. The packaging and available synopses for this make it sound like the "another woman" of the title‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'Beautiful film. \xa0Sad, smart. \xa0Sven Nykvist, Gena Rowlands, Gene Hackman, that gorgeous Satie music. \xa0Hits different when you get older.', 'Thank god for Gene Hackman‚Äôs impeccable acting ability. If it wasn‚Äôt for him, I think I would‚Äôve killed myself, because this film is painfully boring.']

Title: Torso
Text:
A masked serial killer with psychosexual issues strangles female coeds with scarves before dismembering them. When a wealthy student identifies one of the scarves and thinks she has a lead on a suspect, she becomes the killer‚Äôs next target, retreating to her family‚Äôs remote cliffside villa with three of her¬†girlfriends.
['"What you see on the screen is not a work of abstract art. What you see are fragments of one of your classmates who was barbarically murdered."', "Torso begins as we the voyeur gaze upon a couple making love overlaid with the sounds of a university art history lecture on the tensions between the dramatic and the aesthetic in the representation of suffering bodies during the Italian Renaissance, and how in the art of Perugino, tears were shown but not blood, even in martyrdom, as he portrayed local peasantry as sacred Christian figures. That this discussion takes place at the beginning of Sergio Martino's Torso, a critical film in the transition from giallo to slasher along with Bava's Bay Of Blood, establishes a conscious abandonment of the more mannered aestheticism of the giallo for a more direct and streamlined violence, one which is expressed in and through‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Suzy Kendall has perfect eyes for a giallo film. So expressive and beautiful. 
I saw this years ago so revisiting the film was fun. Forgot many of the details. Watched the Blue Underground Blu-ray on the 3/5 and then the Arrow Blu-ray a couple of weeks later because I wanted to see how two different distribs handled this giallo (but more of a slasher prototype) classic. Both Blu-rays are great but different. It really shows that the colorist has major influence on the feel of the film. 
Great comparison article between discs:
cinapse.co/torso-blu-ray-screen-comparisons-arrow-video-vs-2011-release-3e12a29164fd
Fantastic extras on the Arrow disc but the Blue Underground disc also has some goodies.']

['GRACE HAS BOB‚ÄôS DEAD WIFE‚ÄôS HEART', 'Oh to have a posse of Irish/Italian grandpas commentating on your love life while they play cards', 'One of the more criminally under-appreciated romantic comedies of this century.']

Title: Crazy¬†Heart
Text:
When reporter Jean Craddock interviews Bad Blake‚Äîan alcoholic, seen-better-days country music legend‚Äîthey connect, and the hard-living crooner sees a possible saving grace in a life with Jean and her young¬†son.
["Melodramatic certainty in finding oneself, seasoned with Bridges' absolutely brilliant performance. A pretty solid package overall that works precisely because of Jeff.
It's not a new story starting point. An artist battling in the depths, with only one way to go‚Äîup but there is twist on it. The film's core revolves around self-deception, that subtle yet dangerous drift into isolation. As hope and love take on deeper meaning, the film moves with a steady, assured rhythm. It sings, acting as a seamless bridge between characters, drawing the entire narrative together in a way that pulls you in effortlessly.
With the soul of country music, Cooper weaves a quiet magic‚Äîa stillness steeped in the fatigue of life. Bridges' character is a‚Ä¶ 
more", 'This story of love and music, which earned "The Dude" Jeff Bridges his well-deserved Oscar, does a superb job of keeping you on the edge of your seat thanks to the way it plays with your expectations by making you assume that this is a film about a musician who is progressively losing his place as a legend in the industry and is reduced to being miserable. Similarly, there were times when I feared our protagonist might burst and humiliate himself on stage, speeding his downfall.
Much of this anticipation is due, in part, to Jeff Bridges' outstanding performance, who does a wonderful job playing on the self-destructive side as well as the weariness, but there's something about him that‚Ä¶ 
more', 'You know exactly whats in store and how its gonna tread along, but its that kinda movie where the comfort lies in the familiarity. Jeff Bridges is the heart n soul of the melodrama and he breathes life into the musical biopic. The final 20 odd minutes gave a unexplainable serene satisfaction. And along with the wonderfully soothing country songs and beautiful direction from Scott cooper, it makes up for a highly satisfying slice of life tale.']

Title: Schumacher
Text:

Title: Seaspiracy
Text:
Passionate about ocean life, a filmmaker sets out to document the harm that humans do to marine species ‚Äî and uncovers an alarming global¬†conspiracy.
['ConspiraSEA was right there and they still named this Seaspiracy?! a crime! against cinema!', 'documentary filmmaker discovers capitalism', "While the subject is important, I really hated the presentation and editing. Especially in the first half, it seemed like Ali was just playing super spy an acting as if this information wasn't out there already. I think the biggest crime of all is having the footage from the traditional whale hunt on the Faroe Islands interspersed with black screens. An amazing moment of sadness and violence in the climax of your film ruined by chaotic editing. Style over substance."]

Title: Till
Text:
The true story of Mamie Till Mobley‚Äôs relentless pursuit of justice for her 14 year old son, Emmett Till, who, in 1955, was lynched while visiting his cousins in¬†Mississippi.
['DANIELLE DEADWYLER THE WOMAN THAT YOU ARE!!!!!!!!!!
My head literally hurt from how hard I cried watching this, but to my surprise (and satisfaction), this was 
far
 from the ‚ÄúBlack trauma porn‚Äù many were worried it would be from the first trailer. Writer/director Chinonye Chukwu treats this material with the tender thoughtfulness it deserves, truthfully honoring Mamie‚Äôs heartache, but sensitively showcasing her riveting rise as a major figure in the civil rights movement all the same. It‚Äôs a tricky tightrope to walk, but Chukwu makes it look like child‚Äôs play.
Still, at the end of the day, 
Till
 belongs to Danielle Deadwyler first and foremost, who delivers one of the greatest depictions of grief I‚Äôve ever seen in cinema and, in a just world, should not just be a sure thing for an Oscar nomination for Best Actress, but a real threat to win as well.
2022 Ranked', 'Thanks for keeping this story alive', "Devastating to watch, and the worst of it is that we haven't come very far since then."]

Title: Heart of¬†Glass
Text:
A small Bavarian village is renowned for its ‚ÄúRuby Glass‚Äù glass blowing works. When the foreman of the works dies suddenly without revealing the secret of the Ruby Glass, the town slides into a deep depression, and the owner of the glassworks becomes obssessed with the lost¬†secret.
["With no hint of hyperbole, one of the strangest films I've ever seen and, most likely, ever created. 
The theme here is similar to Herzog's Aguirre. Again he is flirting with the meticulous descent into madness but his scope has changed. Heart of Glass deals not with the madness of obsession but the madness of loss. Herzog has also opened up his scope from a single individual or small group to an entire village. 
Heart of Glass is about a small Bavarian village whose sole craft, it appears, is a glass blowing factory. The pride of the village and factory is the Ruby Glass, glass that is forged with the red tint of Ruby. The glass is beautiful and the‚Ä¶ 
more", "I want to know what Herzog is reading that he finds these obscure figures of German history. Like 
Kaspar Hauser
, this film has plucked an eccentric obscurity from the annals of history and turned him into an enigmatic cinematic figure, though this one has a few more layers of obfuscation in that our shepherd prophet shares not even a name with his inspiration. Everything about this film is off, awkward, weird, and the strange prophecies of Hias the Shepherd are only a small part of it.
Famously, Herzog hypnotized his actors before their scenes, teaching them their lines under hypnosis. I don't know if that had anything to do with the part where the short, old man seems to be‚Ä¶ 
more", 'I see scurrying saints tying their boots together to keep from falling. I see galvanic shifts in this town where blood pumps right of center. I see expanses of rotting corpora; exposure spread across screaming ranges; periosteal rot; many scratches on the calcified cartilage of ribs and skulls and spinal fragments. I see up higher an adiabatic brume flowing against languor ‚Äôcross the lips of the sky. I see myriad shivery beasts: ducks of Muscovy, big blackish cows, invisible bears, birds agog to view humanity. I see slow dances with dead men. I see fires set in honor of the apocalypse. I sit draped off the far edge of the precipice. I see the end(s) of our world.']

Title: Bride &¬†Prejudice

Title: Between the¬†Temples
Text:
A grief-stricken cantor in a crisis of faith finds his world turned upside down when his grade school music teacher re-enters his life as his new adult Bat Mitzvah student. The two forlorn souls develop a special¬†connection.
['My favorite thing about being Jewish ‚Äî and it‚Äôs just so hard to pick between classic hits like ‚Äúunleavened bread,‚Äù ‚Äúhaving shoulder hair at 15,‚Äù and ‚Äúbeing used by right-wing nationalists as an excuse to justify the same kind of genocide that tends to be inflicted upon us every other century or so‚Äù ‚Äî is that I‚Äôve always felt like the religion and its attendant culture places an unusual emphasis on being alive. Six thousand years of trying not to die can do that to you. We don‚Äôt believe in heaven, and we don‚Äôt believe in hell; when someone passes, we say ‚Äúmay their memory be a blessing,‚Äù and when we pray on Yom Kippur (one of the few days‚Ä¶ \nmore', "there's embarrassment, and there's secondhand embarrassment, and then there's watching the dinner scenes in this", 'god level sound design including a recurring gag so funny i was physically shaking from laughing so hard']

Title: The Hidden¬†Fortress
Text:
In feudal Japan, during a bloody war between clans, two cowardly and greedy peasants, soldiers of a defeated army, stumble upon a mysterious man who guides them to a fortress hidden in the¬†mountains.
['This unexpectedly became "family movie night" when my older boy -- he\'s 8 -- walked into my office and said, "So Star Wars is really about the two droids?" and I said, sort of. I explained that George Lucas had seen Hidden Fortress and liked telling a larger story through the supporting characters. So I showed him the first ten minutes of the movie, reading the subtitles aloud so he could keep up. He loved it. I was worried about the violence but it\'s the tamest of samurai pictures. Then my youngest came in -- he\'s 5 -- and started watching. They were completely hooked. Then my wife came in for the last hour, and we watched as a family. And that\'s how my boys saw their first Kurosawa and first b&w samurai movie.', 'maybe a hot take but this is the perfect entry point for kurosawa', 'At certain points in their careers, even cinema‚Äôs greatest auteurs have needed to cover their asses with a hit; it‚Äôs the nature of the beast, and even the most thoroughly housebroken of pets still needs to be fed. For Akira Kurosawa ‚Äî a soft-hearted tyrant who lorded over his sets like an emperor, tamed the feral Toshir√¥ Mifune into one of filmdom‚Äôs most nuanced stars, and remapped the possibilities of his medium with arthouse classics and rousing samurai epics alike ‚Äî that wasn‚Äôt going to be a problem. At least not at the height of his powers. \nKurosawa had earned a tremendous amount of goodwill after the critical and commercial success of 1954‚Äôs ‚ÄúSeven Samurai,‚Äù and by 1958 he‚Äôd spent‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Snowtown
Text:
Based on true events, 16 year-old Jamie falls in with his mother‚Äôs new boyfriend and his crowd of self-appointed neighborhood watchmen, a relationship that leads to a spree of torture and¬†murder.
["It didn't even snow", "Can't wait to never see this again", "Film#53 of 'It's June Jim, but not as we know it'
Relentless. That's what this film is. After finishing this I felt fatigued, drained and quite depressed. Any film that manages to accomplish that deserves a compliment, even if it purposefully kicked my ass for about two hours.
This true story of Austraila's most notorious serial killer is anything but an attempt to glamorize violence or exploit it. It is more an examination, you could even say it isn't about the killer at all. The focal point lies with his stepson, who is a victim of circumstance, stuck in a life that can only lead to despair. Violence, abuse and an absence of love are the order of the day‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: The Poseidon¬†Adventure
Text:
When their ocean liner capsizes, a group of passengers struggle to survive and¬†escape.
['Now this is a story all about how this boat got flipped-turned upside down', '‚ÄúThe Poseidon Adventure‚Äù turns survival horror on its head by making the vices of its victims into their greatest moral strengths.\xa0
Amongst the slate of other disaster films of its era, ‚ÄúPoseidon‚Äù is a league or two above the rest. That‚Äôs because - amidst the fiery devastation - it actually persuades the audience to care for its cast of characters.\xa0
Each of the soon-to-be-sufferers in the film is introduced with a surefire vice: Gene Hackman‚Äôs preacher is a merciless objectivist, Ernest Borgnine married a prostitute 
and
 suffers from seasickness, and Shelley Winters‚Äô retired shopkeeper has gained more than a few pounds in her silver years.\xa0
Director Ronald Neame makes these failings so obvious; it seems to lay the fates of‚Ä¶ 
more', 'that morning after performance‚Ä¶ so iconic. this is beyond cheesy in structure/style and dated in some characterizations but it does (somewhat) effectively capitalize on its aspiring scale, most notably during the obvious climaxes. this sort of middling, lavish contemporary genre-epic is nowhere to be found anymore so i have to love it for being so emblematic of its time']

Title: Babel
Text:
Tragedy strikes a married couple vacationing in the Moroccan desert, which jumpstarts an interlocking story involving four different¬†families.
['one gun... really fucked everything up and made everyone sad', 'hi and welcome to the museum of movie kisses! our first exhibit is: the kiss brad pitt gives cate blanchett while she pees in a pan', "A film about language and communication would normally grab my interest immediately. For the better part of this film the sheer quality and topics of most of the separate stories managed to do just that. There is enough to enjoy here, with strong performances and interesting subjects. \nIt is, however, also infuriatingly moronic in its contrived and forced narrative link. It makes a capital mistake in that it feels the incessant need to 'mean something'. It does so by force feeding us a link that is supposed to give the separate stories a common meaning/purpose. What it fails to recognise is that the stories by themselves manage to bring across the commonality just fine, keeping the uniqueness of their narrative and clearly distinct feel.\nIt is extremely annoying that in its attempt to please its audience and naive need to tie up loose ends it fails to see the quality that is already there."]

Title: Decision to¬†Leave
Text:

['"
The moment you said you loved me, your love is over. The moment your love ends, my love begins
."
It begins with the mountain and ends with the sea. The two contrasting images always accompany the film. Like Seo Rae's dress, some people think it's green; others see blue. The wallpaper in her home shows patterns of mountain peaks, but upon closer look, they look like thousands of waves crashing into each other. The mountain and the sea seem so close, yet are always out of each other‚Äôs reach. If the wise love the water and the benevolence the mountains, the lovelorn will always choose to stay behind in the earth. No one ever wanted to leave but always having to pass by.

Title: Sorry,¬†Baby

An insanely impressive directorial debut from Eva Victor.", 'the cat distribution system works when you need it the most', '"i feel guilty when i don't think about it."
knocked the wind out of me. such an original and disarmingly authentic approach to this subject matter - and the endless up-and-down that follows - that handles every twist and turn in its tone with overwhelming honesty and empathy.
shockingly hysterical without ever losing sight of the heart and soul of its story, and shatteringly sincere without ever sacrificing its sly sense of humor. eva victor is one movie in and already a master storyteller in my eyes - and the beautifully subtle build to the reveal of this title‚Äôs meaning is all the proof of that talent you need.
truthfully just immensely thankful for this film in ways i can‚Äôt even put into words right now.
‚Äúit‚Äôs just like that sometimes.‚Äù']

Title: Bambi
Text:
Bambi‚Äôs tale unfolds from season to season as the young prince of the forest learns about life, love, and¬†friends.
['Here are some reasons why 
Bambi
 is the greatest animated film ever made:
- It shows life in all its little imperfections and grand tribulations. 
- The amount of joy, humor, tears, and discovery to be found within its tight 70 minute run-time is indescribably beautiful. 
- The characters are layered, fully-formed, and crafted to perfection. 
-The animation is second to none, showcasing subtle details and landscapes that blow me away after every viewing. 
- The classic themes are as potent and wonderful as ever. 
- A scene involving death is the most emotional scene in the history of animated cinema. 
- The music is breathtaking, especially in the "April Shower" sequence. 
- This movie has Thumper. Enough said.', "Didn't think there was enough story content or compelling character moments to sustain a feature film sadly. If this was a short film I'd love it", 'Nothing really happens but it looks GORGEOUS while nothing really happens.']

Title: The Final¬†Conflict
Text:
Damien Thorn has helped rescue the world from a recession, appearing to be a benign corporate benefactor. When he then becomes U.S. Ambassador to the United Kingdom, Damien fulfills a terrifying biblical prophecy. He also faces his own potential demise as an astronomical event brings about the second coming of¬†Christ.
['Sam Neill is great but a horror movie where Jesus Christ, the Nazarene triumphs? No thanks üëé', 'Still the same ominous doomsday vibes. Still the same Catholic reverb of gloom & shame. Still the same intriguing pro/antagonist (this time played by a devilishly great Sam Neill). Still the same bloody kills & insane death scenarios (mauled by a pack of Beagles??). Still the same wayyy too dark escalation of depravity, which might‚Äôve somehow gotten even more sinister here (a baby assassination spree?? And they show it??? Fuck, dude). Yep, it‚Äôs definitely an 
Omen
 movie!
Not all of it makes sense and the ending loses some steam after peaking with all the really hopeless shit, but I honestly don‚Äôt mind the conclusion and can appreciate the commitment to its hardcore messianic shtick. Adult Damien is a cool concept that I wish we could get more of and any time there‚Äôs a secret coalition of priests-turned-hitmen doing literally anything at all, I‚Äôm in. Would absolutely watch again and still very much maintain that this franchise is heavily undervalued.
Watch:\xa0
THE INFERION CLOSET', '"There is only one Hell, the leaden monotony of human existence."
In which Sam Neill makes a total mood out of Damien Thorn. While it's lacking in terms of narrative drive‚Äîthere's only so much you can do when your protagonist is both the literal Antichrist and the sole interesting character in the movie‚ÄîI must give props for how thoroughly bonkers it proves to be. Going all-in on end times prophecy and the Second Coming, it's a genuine relic of Reagan-era Satanic Panic, and the fact that it exists at all, that it was produced with real studio dollars and played to a considerable audience, is wild. I'd bet money that plenty of people who bought tickets weren't even horror fans.']

Title: Land and¬†Freedom
Text:
David Carr is a British Communist who is unemployed. In 1936, when the Spanish Civil War begins, he decides to fight for the Republican side, a coalition of liberals, communists and anarchists, so he joins the POUM militia and witnesses firsthand the betrayal of the Spanish revolution by Stalin‚Äôs followers and Moscow‚Äôs¬†orders.
['The sobering truth that factionalism is tragically endemic in the left. The right only have to preserve and protect the status quo, the left have to beat them and plot a course for a new world. The battle against the right is hard enough to win, but the battle to get everyone who wanted change to agree on just what that change should look like...that's the hardest fight of all. 
"But our day will come"
See previous - and more in-depth - review 
here
.
PS, Coogan was a cool guy.', "I watched this without subtitles and I'm literally terrified that you're supposed to watch this with subtitles because most of the movie was in Spanish.....did I just waste an hour and forty-four minutes of my life because I'm a dumb film snob and thought that maybe it was a directorial choice? Maybe so. If you're supposed to watch it with subtitles, please don't tell me because it'll ruin my life", 'filmic communism? Ken Loachs early war drama 
Land & Freedom
 has a certain stasis to live off from, determining statics making it unwieldy and aloof. characters are treated stepmotherly, possibilities to establish love interests or a crime-and-punishment story arc are abandoned. individual storylines are disregarded in order to let all elements of the group of freedom fighters having the same amount of spotlight. 
the history of the european left is the focal point of Loachs interest. their collapse is portrayed in protocolaire fashion, the tensions between communists and anarchists shown in absurdism. it‚Äôs a thesis movie, Martin Lutheresque. in one moment the camera doesn‚Äôt move, just showing a debate for 20 bone-dry yet idealistic minutes. 
Land & Freedom
 shows the decay of the political left, yet has a stubborn and determinate final image: the granddaughter of the protagonist spreads spanish soil over her granddads grave, the red banner and clenched fist reached into the sky.']

Title: Forbidden¬†Zone
Text:
A mysterious door in the basement of the Hercules house leads to the Sixth Dimension by way of a gigantic set of intestine. When Frenchy slips through the door, King Fausto falls in love with her. The jealous Queen Doris takes Frenchy prisoner, and it is up to the Hercules family and friend Squeezit Henderson to rescue¬†her.
["if that's what satan is really like then send me to hell asap please", 'Avante garde, lewd musical featuring a butler frog from a different dimension and the always amazing Susan Tyrell. \nDont watch this sober... With the exception for oingo boingo fans.', 'See, this is funny because blackface and Three Stooges-style rape and referencing Hitler and repeatedly having characters call a cross-dressing character faggot then sending that character off by having them dive into a cell of Arabic caricatures begging to have her asshole fucked to death is all automatically funny. See cause it\'s like, transgressive. So it\'s funny and interesting by default, and definitely not boring try-hard absurdity.\nI liked 3 things: 1) The "Pico & Sepulveda" number (not an original song). 2) The "Minnie the Moocher" number (not an original song). 3) In the classroom there\'s a Kenzo clock drawn in crayon with a spinning gun and knife attached to it. The one good non sequitur in the movie.']

Title: A Page of¬†Madness
Text:
A man takes a job at an asylum with hopes of freeing his imprisoned¬†wife.
['to the joker it‚Äôs just a page', 'this is bj√∂rk‚Äôs favorite movie i just know it is', 'An unnerving, guilt-ridden and surreal silent era nightmare that is stripped of title cards that might help balance you and instead drops you head-first into the horrifying images of masked faces, expressionist dancing, torn photographs and literal dreams/fantasies trapped within concrete walls and prison bars. The uncanny use of non-linear editing and shifting, subjective perspective creating this stylish psychological fracturing effect as these past lives lost in time try to come to violent terms with the tangible reality of their current institutionalized surroundings. This should be as well-known and studied as the German expressionists.']

Title: Holiday¬†Inn

Title: Maelstr√∂m
Text:
A young woman‚Äôs life spirals into chaos after she is involved in a hit-and-run accident. Then she encounters a mysterious man named Evian who offers her an opportunity for redemption. Narrated by a¬†fish.
["i can't come up with anything clever to say but just know that the deeper i dive into denis villeneuve's filmography the more fucked up i become", 'wish denis would get a little weird with it more often', 'Villeneuve is such an auteur.
While Blade Runner was a defining science fiction, expertly helmed with vision and without compromise, I miss the early films.
This is my first watch of Maelstrom ‚Ä¶ Villeneuve‚Äôs follow up to the tiny August 32nd on Earth, and his groundbreaking Polytechnique. Here, you can see a writer / director just bursting with ideas and themes and visuals. A study of death, and culpability, and blame, and remorse, and contrition blended with the cycle of life. 
And talking fish.
A magnificent film that I‚Äôll have to wait for a second watch to proclaim a masterpiece, but I‚Äôm right on the edge now.
Enemy is my greatest hope. It‚Äôs a hope that Villeneuve, now a darling of Hollywood, will still sneak away and create a brilliant low budget masterpiece like this now and again.']

Title: Spielberg
Text:
A documentary on the life and career of one of the most influential film directors of all time, Steven¬†Spielberg.
["Sure, this is a wholly uncritical look at a director's work‚Äì with heavy involvement from the director himself‚Äì but fuck if I didn't find this all so electrifying. It's weird to say this about a man who is literally one of the only household names as far as directors go, but I have never done much of a deep dive into Spielberg's work or thought of him past being the famous populist director, so getting to see a direct examination and discussion of his themes and obsessions and his early beginnings and even just getting footage of him at work and hearing people talk about how he works was fascinating and enthralling and invigorating.\xa0It brings me back to being a‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'Watching Scorsese fangurl over Spielberg is pretty much the most adorable thing ever.', "I would've pretended HOOK didn't exist, too."]

Title: The Last¬†Starfighter
Text:
Video game expert Alex Rogan finds himself transported to another planet after conquering the video game The Last Starfighter, only to find out it was just a test. He was recruited to join the team of best Starfighters to defend their world from the¬†attack.
["Finally got around to see one of those movies I‚Äôve heard almost my entire life. Especially its reputation as an 80s sort of classic.
And it doesn‚Äôt take that long for you to realize why. It possesses all the characteristics of a classic; it's a film that embodies the essence of its era, akin to a time capsule, but it's also one that you can still enjoy today. I heard there‚Äôs a remake in the making, and while I can see how it could work for a reimagining, I also fear it will lose a lot of its magic. At least it retains a lot of the essence of the decade. Then again, they made 
Jumanji
 work, so who knows?‚Ä¶ 
more", "After my first viewing of this film as kid, I came away with three things: 1) I wanted to live in a trailer-park, 2) Catherine Mary Stewart was all I would really need to be happy in life and 3) I wanted to fly that damn ship. 
The Last Starfighter, directed by Nick Castle (the first Michael Myers), is a slightly more than lightweight, slightly less than impactful sci-fi drama about a young man who qualifies for interstellar combat by being a arcade stud. Alex Rogan (Lance Guest), the young man, lives in the greatest trailer park on earth. Scenic, friendly, charming and quirky with a restaurant, a video game and the prettiest T-park girl ever (ol' C.M.S.). This is‚Ä¶ 
more", '(2020 Summer Blockbuster Series)
Well, I guess you could say these Play Station 2 level graphics ... were way ahead of their time in 1984.
"Things change. Always do. You'll get your chance! Important thing is, when it comes, you've got to grab with both hands, and hold on tight!"
The Last Starfighter is a super cheesy and dated intergalactic adventure, but it did have some charm to it. The premise is fun as a high school senior is recruited by aliens to fight for them as a Starfighter based on his skills playing an arcade game. But his almost never-ending stream of cliched reluctance throughout this hero's journey was a major drag.
"Listen, Centauri, I'm not any of those‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The¬†Captive
Text:
Ariane and Simon met down by the water. Simon has managed to prize Ariane away from her friends, a bunch of free and arrogant girls, and move her into his place, with her own room at the end of the hall and her own bathroom next to his. He has taken on Andr√©e, one of the girls from the bunch by the water, to watch over Ariane, escort her wherever she goes and report back to him on everything she does. Andr√©e becomes Ariane‚Äôs accomplice. She‚Äôll tell lies for her, and with her, and most likely they‚Äôll make love together when the mood takes¬†them. √ó
['she gay bro stop', 'This and Eyes Wide Shut would be a wonderful double feature about the assumptions that men have about women and how those assumptions serve to only hurt the male ego, which in turn makes men feel they have permission to hurt women (or wildly indulge in male fantasies that justify his careless and bad behavior so that the man can even out the pain he believes the woman has put him through).\xa0
Akerman is a genius and slowly becoming my great love.\xa0
This could have been called ‚ÄòAs You Like‚Äô or ‚ÄòI Know Why the Cage Bird Sleeps‚Äô.', "I've never read Proust, but I kinda want to. I have a feeling that, at most, this captures the spirit of his work, but perhaps not even that. Akerman has made an intriguing tale of a man obsessed with his girlfriend's private life. He himself is bound by physical malady and social responsibility (and probably mental instability), and so he keeps his girlfriend on an invisible leash that, for much of the film, it's not entirely apparent that she feels. 
And for most of the film, it seems, he is the captive, held in prison by his jealousy and paranoia, but there's a crucial moment in the third act wherein Simon sets Ariane free, and then the film reveals itself.‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Cop¬†Out
Text:
Detectives Jimmy and Paul, despite nine years as partners, can still sometimes seem like polar opposites‚Äîespecially when Paul‚Äôs unpredictable antics get them suspended without pay. Already strapped for cash and trying to pay for his daughter‚Äôs wedding, Jimmy decides to sell a rare baseball card that‚Äôs worth tens of thousands. Unfortunately, when the collector‚Äôs shop is robbed and the card vanishes with the crook, Paul and Jimmy end up going rogue, tracking down the card and the drug ring behind its theft, all on their own time and without any backup‚Äîexcept for each¬†other. √ó
['Well first of all, I don't buy that these two guys have been partners for nine years.
The worst movie ever made, and yet somehow not even the worst Kevin Smith movie. Scientists are still studying this paradox.
This is an example of "expanded cinema." The various podcasts and Q&As where Kevin Smith badmouths Bruce Willis must be considered extensions of the text.', 'An excruciating buddy cop "homage" on the page brought to the screen by someone you would assume had never seen a movie before, let alone the ones being ripped off so poorly you almost want to retroactively make them culpable for inspiring this lame afterimage of a once towering genre‚ÄîBruce was in 
Last Boy Scout
 for god‚Äôs sake! After the tenth time the "joke" is just that the two cops brutalize and torture someone in ugly studio comedy sheen and shout IMDb quotes page movie references at each other you might find yourself wondering what the point of our time on this Earth is, and if you look closely enough you'll see your feelings reflected in the eyes of most‚Ä¶ 
more', 'In the pre-Twitter chat board days, my forum of choice as a teenager and young adult was the View Askewniverse board, owned and operated by Kevin Smith himself. And let me tell you, no one in human history ever worked harder than Smith fans did in 2010 to convince themselves that this was good or even salvageable. I‚Äôve never read the original, mega-hyped 
A Couple of Dicks
 screenplay, but even if radical rewrites occurred it‚Äôs difficult to fathom that anything about it was actually that impressive if even the barest bones could have made this possible. 
This is a buddy cop parody in which the only parody consists of characters broadly lampshading genre tropes, calling attention to clich√© without upending‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Patton
Text:
‚ÄúPatton‚Äù tells the tale of General George S. Patton, famous tank commander of World War II. The film begins with Patton‚Äôs career in North Africa and progresses through the invasion of Germany and the fall of the Third Reich. Side plots also speak of Patton‚Äôs numerous faults such his temper and habit towards¬†insubordination.
['‚ÄúPatton‚Äù succeeds utterly as a biopic for its insistance on remaining the detailed portrait of a single man ‚Äî despite the immensity of historical events unfolding around him.\xa0
This determination of focus also becomes the central dramatic conflict of the work: will General George Patton succeed in claiming full personal glory not just of his own film, but of the entire Second World War?
Franklin J. Schaffner executes a maneuver of genius directorial subversion with the movie. He is so assured of his own hand, that he does let his subject run away with the picture. Or - it seems almost as if Schaffner only lets the military legend think that.\xa0
‚ÄúPatton‚Äù - superficially, and especially at its much-parodied American‚Ä¶ 
more', '170 minutes of one classic scene after the next, truly an outstanding movie and possibly the best War movie ever made.', 'that Patton, he sure was ornery', 'the great man theory of history, the movement of bodies, the duty of chivalry, the love of struggle, the end of principles and the beginning of systems. politics as the continuation of war by other means. 
twilight of the gods', "Franklin James Schaffner subsequent feature after his critical and commercial achievement of 
Planet of the Apes
 sees the filmmaker crafting an epic biographical war film about U.S. General George S. Patton which won seven Oscars at the 43rd Academy Awards. Working from a script by Francis Ford Coppola and Edmund H. North, which is based primarily on Ladislas Farago's biography 
Patton: Ordeal and Triumph
, its setting is World War II and George C. Scott plays Patton.\xa0
It encompasses the wartime achievements of the controversial General, commencing with a famous opening sequence and his entrance into the North African campaign and terminating with his expulsion from command after his candid complaints of US post-war operations. Schaffner instantly favours the use of‚Ä¶ 
more", 'I‚Äôve seen Patton more times than I can count. My dad isn‚Äôt the biggest movie buff, but there‚Äôs a handful of movies he had to have in the house, and Patton was one of them. As I was growing up, the old two-tape VHS release sat on top of the TV* in a place of honor, alongside Ghostbusters, Platoon, and Big Trouble in Little China. One of my first memories of film watching is the striking opening of the movie, where George C. Scott walks out to address the troops (and the audience, by extension) with nothing but a giant American flag as a backdrop. It was a riveting opening when I was 10 and it‚Äôs riveting now that I‚Äôm‚Ä¶ 
more', 'As I mentioned in my 
The Last Emperor
 review
, biopics usually come in two shapes: the all-encompassing from-birth-to-death biopic, or the focused "the bit of the subject's life they're best known for" biopic. 
Patton
 falls in the latter category, detailing U.S. General George S. Patton's efforts between 1943 and 1945 during World War II.
There are two problems with 
Patton
 that, in my opinion, make the almost three-hour sit not dull per se, but not very eventful either. Firstly, for all Patton's boasting and blustering about bravery, he as a general stays on the sidelines when it comes to battle, literally observing the battlefield from a safe distance away with his binoculars. As a result, those battle scenes don't carry‚Ä¶ 
more', '‚ÄúIf mountain ranges and oceans can be overcome, anything built by man can be overcome‚Äù
So glad I finally got to watch Patton! I‚Äôve owned it for some time now but never found a good time to put it on. It was everything I hoped it would be! Just a fantastic character study on one of America‚Äôs most famous generals\xa0
There isn‚Äôt a more ideal fit for the character than George C Scott and he is brilliant in the role! I‚Äôve liked him quite a bit in other movies but I think this just might be my favorite performance from him. The opening speech is as iconic as advertised!
The action could‚Äôve suffered from being a result of its time‚Ä¶ 
more', "Patton 
is definitely one of the best films out there in the war genre. The telling of the U.S. General George S. Patton during WWII falls nothing short of being mesmerizing. 
George C. Scott was given the role of a lifetime here and really transforms into Patton. The way he commands your attention to the screen is second to none. Such a fantastic performance- as I couldn't see any other actor pulling it off the way Scott did. 
The opening monologue alone makes this film one of the most significant that's ever been made!", 'My Uncle Carl served in World War II and was one of those who hated General Patton. \xa0He was incapable of mentioning Patton‚Äôs name without an expletive or two preceding it. \xa0I remember him being very unhappy with me when he learned that I had seen PATTON in the theater, probably thinking that the movie glorified the General. \xa0So, I never discovered why he harbored such animosity.
\xa0 \xa0
PATTON brought to mind so many thoughts as I was watching it today with my 24-year-old daughter who was seeing it for the first time:
\xa0 \xa0
* I‚Äôve heard PATTON described as both a pro-war and anti-war movie. \xa0To my mind, it is neither. \xa0It is a biography. \xa0As the‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Awesome cinematography. George C. Scott embodies the iconic general to perfection.
The opening is considered a classic rightfully so, but the rest of the film is as relentless and grandiose as the speech, if not even more.', 'Old blood and guts General Patton may have been rough around the edges, but given the chance he was out to prove just how much ass kicking his soldiers could do on their way into Berlin.
"We are advancing constantly and we're not interested in holding onto anything except the enemy. We're going to hold onto him by the nose and we're going to kick him in the ass. We're going to kick the hell out of him all the time and we're going to go through him like crap through a goose!"
(Quick Hits) ... Spoilers:
- For anyone not in the know, the tune Patton is saluting to in the opening is 'To the Colors', which is the‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Tabu: A Story of the South¬†Seas
Text:
On the South Pacific island of Bora Bora, a young couple‚Äôs love is threatened when the tribal chief declares the girl a sacred¬†virgin.
["Whereupon Murnau ceases speaking the language of dreams, & masters the language of cinema for us all.......another one of these final works where by some mysterious series of coincidences the director strips down their formal sensibilities to the most essential parts. No lighting, shadows of grass yes - but it is mostly bodies in composition. Bodies always posing, expressing. 
At the same time, it is Murnau's most fatalistic work - therefore his most philosophical. Aquarium meets aquarium - like this film is set in the middle of time, where one social system collides with another. 
It is fatalistic because the lovers are doomed from the start - infact 
Murnau can be seen as postulating that love can only authentically survive **outside**‚Ä¶ 
more", "93/100
Love across boundaries; a story of serene nature shifting into nebulous societal necessities. What was once calm, composed, lush turns greedy and bound to modern pleasures. That such an universal romance tale becomes complex, even grandiose in its details is a result of Murnau's static beauty; never sacrificing clarity but depicting every facet with a more defined eye. 
Tabu
 could've felt weightless because of its classical roots, but instead it thrives. From the opening moments to the final brushstroke, F.W. Murnau redefines cinema by taking it back to the beginning. Being one of the final Silents, it's remarkable that 
Tabu
 is reminiscent of a hopeful birth instead of an elegy. If only Murnau hadn't left us so soon.", 'Defina um filme moderno:
um filme mudo de 1931 que, com exce√ß√£o de alguns efeitos sonoros e alguns planos de liga√ß√£o (cartas e comunicados que resumem algumas passagens da trama, e que por isso mesmo s√£o brilhantemente el√≠pticos, cf. anos depois Rivette e Oliveira fazendo o mesmo), √© constru√≠do quase que integralmente como um filme sonoro, alcan√ßando um grau de sofistica√ß√£o pl√°stica e r√≠tmica que anuncia tanto o realismo do p√≥s-guerra quanto o filme de aventuras mar√≠timas dos cinemas americano e europeu.
Mas tem um outro aspecto ainda mais determinante para que essa modernidade tenha tido uma continuidade (de um lado, digamos mais flahertyano: Walsh, Dwan, Curtiz, Paolella, Sollima) mais profunda e intang√≠vel (do outro, mais murnauniano: Renoir, Rossellini, Vidor,‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Those Who Wish Me¬†Dead
Text:
A young boy finds himself pursued by two assassins in the Montana wilderness, with a survival expert determined to protect him, and a forest fire threatening to consume them¬†all.
['They used to make like 15 of these a year and I was like yeah sure whatever. Now in 2021 a good 100-minute thriller for adults featuring actual movie stars feels like a rare precious gem that must be celebrated \xa0
Bonus: it‚Äôs also a natural disaster movie. The 90s are back babyyyyyyy', 'A simple but smoldering throwback to the days when all you needed to make a decent action film was a big star, a striking location, and a few cold henchman carrying those fancy machine guns with the red laser sights, Taylor Sheridan‚Äôs ‚ÄúThose Who Wish Me Dead‚Äù is nothing short of the most rock-solid blockbuster of the 1994 summer movie season. In 2021, it can‚Äôt help but feel like an unintended anachronism; as if Sheridan aimed for something that matched the gravitas he wrote into ‚ÄúSicario‚Äù or the dark portent he blew into ‚ÄúWind River,‚Äù fell very far short, and landed in a pillowy bed of old popcorn instead. That may not be high praise, but it sure as hell‚Ä¶

Title: Ricochet
Text:
An attorney is terrorized by the criminal he put away years ago when he was a¬†cop.
["90
Gah, this is just delightful. Trash heaven. Denzel Washington faces off against John Lithgow. Full-tilt crazy, both of them. Basically a Harvey Dent vs. Joker movie. Feels like a toxic blend of erotic thriller and 'wrong man' tropes, but that still doesn't account for the prison sword fight between Lithgow and Jesse Ventura. So gleefully violent and nasty. Its sleaze holds no bounds. Not to mention that composer Alan Silvestri crafted a musical score like his life depended on it. All for a wacky late-nite psychological thriller that features death by both circular saw *and* big pointy spike. Have I made it clear enough yet? Watch it!", "In which a supposed cat-and-mouse 
Dirty Harry
 sequel spec-script about a deranged criminal coming back to viciously stalk and torment the cop/DA who put him away years earlier 
Cape Fear
 style was instead placed into the hands of an absurd alchemy of 80s action maestros (Joel Silver, Steven E. de Souza and Russell Mulcahy) and turned into one of the most psychotically excessive and sleazy 90s thrillers I've ever seen. 
Denzel is impeccably cast as the superhumanly charismatic, good-looking and ambitious LA public law official whose carefully crafted moral image/reputation is tarnished by a series of ruthlessly punishing, psychosexual public spectacle gamesmanship set pieces with John Lithgow's wonderfully hammy comic book supervillain meets slasher serial killer psycho who orchestrates what‚Ä¶ 
more", "Borders on outright transcendent in terms of how utterly deranged it's willing to get, let down only by an obviously test audience approved ending where it seems to wake up and remember it's a Hollywood film. Still there is some outright jaw dropping stuff in this, to the point where you will wonder if it's even a real movie at some points."]

Title: Paris Is¬†Burning
Text:
Where does voguing come from, and what, exactly, is throwing shade? This landmark documentary provides a vibrant snapshot of the 1980s through the eyes of New York City‚Äôs African American and Latinx Harlem drag-ball scene. Made over seven years, PARIS IS BURNING offers an intimate portrait of rival fashion ‚Äúhouses,‚Äù from fierce contests for trophies to house mothers offering sustenance in a world rampant with homophobia, transphobia, racism, AIDS, and poverty. Featuring legendary voguers, drag queens, and trans women ‚Äî including Willi Ninja, Pepper LaBeija, Dorian Corey, and Venus¬†Xtravaganza. √ó
['"Some of them say that we\'re sick, we\'re crazy. And some of them think that we are the most gorgeous, special things on Earth."', '‚ÄúYou‚Äôve left a mark on the world if you just get through it.‚Äù', "The most beautiful movie I've ever seen. Not in aesthetic, but in spirit; watching these stunning men and women live so freely, so safely, and so joyfully in this safe space they've created, a space where they're allowed to be themselves as much as they're allowed to be the dream versions of themselves‚Äì it's like a religious experience. There's nothing as wonderful as watching people feeling on top of the world that wants to kick them down. Couldn't help but smile through so much of it‚Äì I am warm and full of love!! God bless Pepper LaBeija. Happy Pride, everyone."]

Title: Men in¬†Black
Text:
After a police chase with an otherworldly being, a New York City cop is recruited as an agent in a top-secret organization established to monitor and police alien activity on Earth: the Men in Black. Agent K and new recruit Agent J find themselves in the middle of a deadly plot by an intergalactic terrorist who has arrived on Earth to assassinate two ambassadors from opposing¬†galaxies.

Title: The¬†BFG
Text:

['A giant gets hit in the balls', "WHYYY???????

Spielberg directs the shit out of it (it's best moments have the warmth and visual wit of a live-action Miyazaki movie), and it's hard to imagine someone making a better adaptation from the same source material (that Mark Rylance sure knows what's up), but *oooof* is it obvious that there isn't really a movie here.", 'The entire sequence in the Castle is simply

Title: Mr.¬†Klein
Text:
Paris, France, 1942, during the Nazi occupation. Robert Klein, a successful art dealer who benefits from the misfortunes of those who are ruthlessly persecuted, discovers by chance that there is another Robert Klein, apparently a Jewish man; someone with whom he could be mistakenly identified, something dangerous in such harsh¬†times.
["Losey's best film and one of the most horrifying movies I have ever seen, the greatest film about fascism.", '"Tell me, the Kleins‚Äîare they French-French, or are there Jews in your family?"
Without question the oblique thriller 
Mr. Klein
 (
Monsieur Klein
) is the most compelling of the three Joseph Losey films I've now managed to see‚Äîthe others being the Harold Pinter collaborations 
Accident
 and 
The Go-Between
. In fact I'll grab the lowest-hanging fruit around and concur with the chorus who have deemed it potently Kafkaesque.
Set in 1942 Nazi-occupied Vichy France, Franco Solinas' screenplay revolves around Robert Klein (Alain Delon), a disreputable Parisian art dealer who buys paintings at pennies on the dollar from Jewish collectors desperately seeking their escape. Turnabout ensues when Klein finds himself the addressed recipient of a local Jewish newspaper, though he initially assumes the‚Ä¶ 
more', 'In occupied Paris in 1942, a refined art dealer of Alsatian birth and Catholic religion takes advantage of the racial laws to do golden business with Jews, forced to sell off their property to escape from France. Robert Klein is a selfish man, cynical and disinterested in everything that happens around him, until he discovers the existence of his namesake of Jewish origin, finding himself embroiled in a disturbing exchange of identities. 
Aided by a splendid screenplay with Kafkaesque implications, written by 
Franco Solinas
, 
Joseph Losey
 masterfully combines the themes of double, otherness and anti-Semitic persecution. 
Mr. Klein
 is a film as tense as a thriller, of great visual suggestion and strong allegorical value, aimed at transcending the historical contingency‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: A Most Violent¬†Year
Text:
A thriller set in New York City during the winter of 1981, statistically one of the most violent years in the city‚Äôs history, and centered on the lives of an immigrant and his family trying to expand their business and capitalize on opportunities as the rampant violence, decay, and corruption of the day drag them in and threaten to destroy all they have¬†built.

being a gangster ain't easy, but it sure is *easier.*

Title: The House by the¬†Cemetery
Text:
After a doctor kills his mistress and himself while researching the mysterious previous owner of his Boston home, his colleague, Dr. Norman Boyle, takes over his studies and moves his family into the Boston mansion. Soon after, Boyle‚Äôs young son Bob becomes plagued by visions of a young girl, who warns him of the danger within the¬†house.
['Fulci‚Äôs\xa0Henry James tombhouse nightmare... slathered in a hazy New England atmosfear that oozes with dissonance.\xa0
Dreamy.
House by the
 
Cemetery
 feels like the perfect melding of 
City
 
of Living Dead
 and 
The Beyond 
(and a few other classic Fulci-isms), the previously mentioned Henry James, and much to his dismay.. 
The Shining
\xa0(Sorry lucio it‚Äôs true even though you deny it lol)\xa0taking\xa0the best elements that 
shine
 and 
turning
 
the screw 
all the way up with gratuitous gore, brutal stabbings, and one hell of an iconic murder House... not just by a cemetery, but 
IN
 
one! 
Not my favorite of the trilogy, but I‚Äôll never say no to watching this James/
Shining 
mashup‚Äîthe new blu underground release looks fantastic and I can‚Äôt stop listening to the soundtrack (one of my favs!).
If there was a gate to hell, I can think of no better doom house to sit on top of it than this. 5 stars.', 'Lucio Fulci‚Äôs Barbarian (2022)
Now, if you know me, you know I‚Äôm not a huge fan of Fulci‚Äôs more convoluted outings, namely the first two entries in his 
Gates of Hell
 trilogy (although they‚Äôve grown on me a bit over time). However, for this final entry, we‚Äôre treated to a much more straightforward house-at-the-edge-of-the-apocalypse story serving as an H.P. Lovecraft/Henry James tribute that also happens to have been partially shot right in my hometown of Concord, MA.
The autumn vibes and New England colonial style setting do wonders for my nostalgia, but honestly even without that it‚Äôd still be a pretty decent banger of a movie. I mean, it‚Äôs Fulci, and with Fulci comes an overabundance of indulgent Fulci-isms (namely‚Ä¶ 
more', 'everyone gets stabbed in the WORST PLACES TO GET STABBED']

Title: The Quiet¬†Girl
Text:
A quiet, neglected girl is sent away from her dysfunctional family to live with relatives for the summer. She blossoms in their care, but in this house where there are meant to be no secrets, she discovers¬†one.
['yes i am crying over a single biscuit', "they really got the feeling of when you're a child and things just happen to you and everything dimly feels like your fault.\namazing kid.", 'Cinema as an empathy generating machine. The world from a nine-year old‚Äôs perspective, yet through my own eyes, it‚Äôs terrifying. A child‚Äôs life as the most vulnerable thing in the world. 94 minutes of drama, so beautifully crafted, it has to be seen on the big screen. It‚Äôs tight, and nothing is spared. All the info you need is there. When you‚Äôre given just enough of a beat to foreshadow even the next shot, and it then plays out as expected, I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôve ever seen that before. Everything clicks into place. This is absolute cinema.']

Title: The ABCs of¬†Death
Text:
An ambitious anthology film featuring segments directed by over two dozen of the world‚Äôs leading talents in contemporary genre film. Inspired by children‚Äôs educational ABC books, the film comprises 26 individual chapters, each helmed by a different director assigned a letter of the alphabet. The directors were then given free reign in choosing a word to create a story involving¬†death.
["A is for Arse
B is for Bollocks
C is for Crap
