A for Apocalypse: Directed by Nacho Vigalondo. Wife tries to kill indestructible husband and fails. He doesn't seem bothered though. Twist at the end. Not too bad.
B is for Bigfoot: Directed by Adrian Garcia Bogliano. Man and woman want to make out but can't because kid won't go to bed. Woman tells kid a scary story about Bigfoot who eats the hearts of kids at night if they're out of bed after 8. It works but then they're killed. Not by Bigfoot. Again... not too bad and at‚Ä¶ 
more", "Before I begin, I think this project should be commended for what it tries to do. The idea is interesting and has produced some wonderful, creative outbursts. As there is absolutely no link between the stories I've decided to review and rate each segment separately. The final rating is the overall average rating.
A is for Apocalypse - Allright. Rather violent and even manages to put in a twist in its short running time. Too bad the twist doesn't really help the story. 3 stars.
B is for Bigfoot - Boring. Really boring. Weak story, poor acting, manages to get just about everything wrong. 1/2 star.
C is for Cycle - Cool. Great concept, perhaps a bit too complex for‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Night and¬†Fog
Text:
Filmmaker Alain Resnais documents the atrocities behind the walls of Hitler‚Äôs concentration¬†camps.
["That image of the women's hair will be ingrained in my mind forever. I actually vomited. Night and Fog stands beside Baraka as one of the most powerful documentaries of all-time, one exposing the beauty of our world, and the other, this one, exposing the very heart of darkness, the very core of the deepest abyss imaginable. \nResnais summoned the courage to bring us the blackened, cold piece of cinema that every other filmmaker was afraid to bring us. There's nothing else to say; the film speaks for itself. I'm not even going to tell you that it's a must-see, because I wouldn't blame anyone that decides to pass this beast up... but it is, without question, one of the greatest films ever made.", "i can't in good conscience rate the realities of human suffering. this is gonna stick with me for a while", "When I was 16, I went on a school trip to Germany. It was a rare opportunity, and I lucky enough that my parents were willing to scrape up enough to send me. During the trip, we visited Dachau. I don't remember much about the trip, but every last bit of Dachau is etched in my mind. I've always found the darker parts of humanity fascinating, and it was darker in some ways than anything my teenage mind could fathom. They showed a film detailing what happened in Dachau, and it remains the most scarring, disturbing film I've ever seen. A friend who saw the same film took something else from it, a sense of hope, as the film ends‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: Cat‚Äôs¬†Eye
Text:
Three short stories linked by a stray cat that roams from one tale to the next, in this creepy triptych that begins as Dick tries to quit smoking by any means necessary. Next, we meet Johnny, an adulterous man who‚Äôs forced by his lover‚Äôs husband onto a building‚Äôs hazardous ledge. Finally, Amanda is threatened by an evil gnome who throws suspicion on the family¬†cat.
['Well of course I‚Äôm going to give 5 stars to a movie about a beautiful cat who wanders through some crazy situations before ultimately facing an evil gnome and becoming a hero. That‚Äôs just a given.
Also, the middle story is one of the most tense and panic-inducing 30-ish minutes of cinema possibly ever. I‚Äôve had at least a couple of drinks and I‚Äôm not even recovered and I‚Äôve seen this before so I knew what was going to happen BUT STILL.
Side note: that poster also gets 5 stars for the obvious reasons.', 'that cat needed its own television series', 'If I could pinpoint the first anthology style horror movie I watched, it would probably be\xa0
Creepshow
\xa0followed by 
Cats Eye
. I loved both and the\xa0amount of nightmares the third segment in this, 
General,
\xa0gave me was legendary lol. In retrospect, that troll is adorable with his devious mumbles and evil grins‚Äîbells jingle jangling from his jester cap as he throws himself over blankets and floor strewn toys in\xa0little Drew‚Äôs room. Nightmare fuel for little me, I even have a faint memory of getting anxious looking at the taped off tv vhs spine with spooky makeshift Stephen King font title writing courtesy of my father.
Looking back now I actually love all of these segments‚Äî
Quitters INC
 with its awesome and ridiculous/suffocated in smoke‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: El¬†Sur
Text:
A woman recalls her childhood growing up in the North of Spain, focusing on her relationship with her¬†father.
['When we‚Äôre young, we see the world through a set of eyes we will never get back. Everything is larger than life; the unknown a fabled mystery and, for many of us, our parents can seem at times like mythicized figures. They do and say things that seem almost otherworldly to our adolescent cognition. At least for me, I found my father to have prodigious abilities both physically and mentally; what he was able to do seemed unbelievable at times, and his many great accomplishments, coupled with his sibylline past that I knew next-to-nothing about apart from his time in the Army, then following a band called The Grateful Dead where he eventually met my mother, created a baffling mystery‚Ä¶ 
more', "You have a mystery inside you. A whole world of everything your parents ever did before you were conceived‚Äîa world that you can never enter, never comprehend, though you might strain in vain for a glimpse. Estrella, the heroine of 
El Sur
, tries to solve that mystery by rummaging through her own piecemeal memories. Her voiceover structures this interior pilgrimage; dissolves and fades to black demarcate each block of the past. She remembers her impolite questions, her na√Øve mistakes. She recalls the acoustics and the softness of the light in each room of her family's house. She dwells with objects: hand-colored photos, a skein of red yarn, her father's pendulum. She doesn't find her answers, but the fact that she looks brings me to tears.", 'On a purely visual level, Erice is unparalleled.']

Title: The Human Condition II: Road to¬†Eternity
Text:
Kaji is sent to the Japanese army labeled Red and is mistreated by the vets. Along his assignment, Kaji witnesses cruelties in the army and revolts against the abusive treatment against the recruit Obara. He also sees his friend Shinj√¥ Itt√¥hei defecting to the Russian border, and he ends in the front to fight a lost battle against the Russian tanks¬†division.
["Who knew 
Full Metal Jacket
 was a remake?
Barely ekeing out 
A Soldier's Prayer
, 
Road to Eternity
 is my favorite of the three. Sure, it's got structural similarities to Kubrick's film, with volume 3 detailing Kaji's torturous boot camp training (complete with a bathroom suicide), and volume 4 containing the trilogy's grand-scale battle sequence, but what makes 
Road to Eternity
 so great is Kaji finally coming into his own, understanding the 'whys' of his idealism, and understanding the necessity of sacrifice to fulfill his dream of a better world. It's here, on the doorstep of war, that Kaji comes to realize ideas alone cannot make progress, there must be bodies to contain them. It's a much more complicated spectrum of‚Ä¶ 
more", "Human goodness is a tricky one to portray in art. It is incredibly easy to make the character into a myth, a legend, the perfect individual who never makes mistakes, who is equipped with the perfect moral code, and whose circumstances enable him to do 'absolute' good by everyone, every time. In short, into someone who doesn't exist.
It is equally easy to suffocate him in bloated heroics, breathing life into the kind of unthinking individual who headlessly rushes into battle ‚Äì and comes out victorious amidst the heavy tank fire, one against a thousand, obviously. I continue to be fascinated by the character of Kaji in 
The Human Condition
 as he is neither of the above two. 
He is‚Ä¶ 
more", '‚ÄúTo hell with your family, the fate of Japan is at stake!‚Äù
The second part in Masaki Kobayashi‚Äôs immense anti-war epic 
The Human Condition\xa0
sees our pacifistic protagonist Kaji faced with the mounting pressure and cruelty of the military as he‚Äôs forced into the army he so desperately attempted to avoid; continuing its confronting depictions of atrocities with thoroughly captivating storytelling and precise character exploration. Developing on the morality and compassion of\xa0
No Greater Love
, 
The Road to Eternity 
employs its themes to even greater effect as the focus is shifted inward on the structure of the training army; barely representing the combat of war as we see the soldiers repeatedly abused and Kaji‚Äôs optimism mature to form a more realistic and‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The Last King of¬†Scotland
Text:
Young Scottish doctor, Nicholas Garrigan decides it‚Äôs time for an adventure after he finishes his formal education, so he decides to try his luck in Uganda, and arrives during the downfall of President Obote. General Idi Amin comes to power and asks Garrigan to become his personal¬†doctor.
['Bet he wished he picked Canada.', "The consensus view of this one is: Forest Whitaker is awesome, the rest of the movie is mediocre. I disagree. Forest Whitaker is awesome, and the rest of the movie is infuriating, awful horseshit. The propensity of films about Africa to end up starring white people is a long-time annoyance to me, and this movie is the absolute most egregious case I've ever seen. The reign of Idi Amin is just not compelling on its own merits, it only gains relevance if it is observed by a white protagonist whose character arc is the most important thing happening on the screen at any given moment. It's bad enough that the main character is a white hanger-on, and that the tragedy‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'Forest Whitaker‚Äôs HUGE fart was 100% the best part of the movie']

Title: Blind¬†Chance
Text:
Witek runs after a train. Three variations follow on how such a seemingly banal incident could influence the rest of Witek‚Äôs¬†life.
['You can never go wrong with Kieslowski.
This movie has the best ending of any of his films.', "a lot of the smaller nuances in plot went over my head because of the specific politics at play here. by the third act i was finally getting invested but it felt a little too late in the game for the ending to really stick. still a solid warm up for when i eventually attempt dekalog... i'm petrified", 'I‚Äôm sure I wrote a good review of this movie in a different timeline.
Maybe I got into a car accident, head on collision, slammed my head into the steering wheel. I went into a coma, woke up 4 years later, ate through a straw for a month, re-learned to read and write, became incredibly proficient as a writer, fell in love with my nurse, then rediscovered my love of cinema after scrolling through TV channels and watching 
Elf
. After dedicating the next ten years of my life to watching film, I discover this film yet again, and pour my heart and soul into writing the letterboxd diary entry, perhaps using fancy words, descriptive allegories, and just the right amount‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Dirty Dancing: Havana¬†Nights
Text:

Title: Barfly
Text:
Downtrodden writer Henry and distressed goddess Wanda aren‚Äôt exactly husband and wife: they‚Äôre wedded to their bar stools. But, they like each other‚Äôs company‚Äîand Barfly captures their giddy, gin-soaked attempts to make a go of life on the¬†skids.
["Things I noticed after peeping this gem on the big screen: 
The ink stain on Hank Chinaski's shirt pocket.
The way, well, BARFLIES wince and scuttle from daylight like cockroaches in a crumby linen closet. 
The sunglasses and slicked back hair of a paramedic who doesn't give a fuck. 
Wanda's look of despair when she realizes her cooked drunk-stolen corn is green and not worth chowing.
My surprise seeing Robby Muller listed as cinematographer. 
Still, 
Barfly
 contains one of the greatest movie endings of all time. Elliptical, down'n'dirty, working stiff funny, and weirdly poetic like most Bukowski prose. New day, same old shit. 
SIDE NOTE: I like Bukowski, but he's definitely one of those authors (unfairly) ruined by fans: misogynistic‚Ä¶ 
more", "Mickey Rourke, the Brando who wanted but couldn't.", "84/100
[originally written on my blog]
Foolishly dismissed this at the time as an overly romanticized self-portrait, and then somehow managed to further misremember it as grim and serious, so imagine my surprise to find that it's actually the flophouse version of a screwball comedy. Rourke's Chinaski may only vaguely resemble Bukowski, but it's a gloriously daffy performance (albeit inadvertently poignant now in the way its foreshadows his own dissolution); he adapts his soft-spoken sleepy boy shtick into an air of genial bewilderment, as if perpetually surprised to still be alive and conscious. And Schroeder, who hadn't yet gone Hollywood, ducks sentimentality at every turn‚Äîit takes expert tonal control to depict the protagonist getting beaten over the head by his‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Peppermint¬†Candy
Text:
In the spring of 1999, a group of old friends gather to celebrate their 20 year reunion. Among the group is Yeong-ho, a cold, unhappy man, whose demeanor puts a damper on the festivities. The seriousness of Yeong-ho‚Äôs depression becomes apparent when he climbs a railroad bridge and looks like he might jump. At this crucial moment, memories of seven crucial episodes from Yeong-ho‚Äôs past flood his¬†mind.
['‚Äúi don‚Äôt want to die alone! i need one bastard to come with me.‚Äù
sol kyung-gu plays a character emblematic of his country‚Äôs deteriorating autocracy, in one of the best performances i‚Äôve ever seen. the delicate seams of his career and marriage unraveling over time, paralleling the failing economic state of south korea in the 80‚Äôs and 90‚Äôs. inveigled by the masculine climate of a militarized society, our anti-hero, yeong-ho becomes increasingly volatile as a saga of misfortunes ensues, each more distressing than the last.\xa0stripped of hope, yeong-ho seals his fate in front of an oncoming train. told through reverse chronology, director lee chang-dong uses\xa0the metaphorical train to elucidate our protagonist‚Äôs ceaseless suffering, ploughing on a self-destructive path. 
peppermint candy
 is a gripping analysis of the human condition, against cruel stages of industrialized life. this was a phenomenal introduction to lee‚Äôs work, paving my way for 
burning
!\xa0
the part where his military boot crushed the spilled peppermint candy.. lol deep', 'The life of a violent misogynist asshole told in reverse order so that the audience might wonder why he became a prick thereby putting up with his bullshit for 120 minutes only to forgive him if they buy into the idea that being a bastard all your life can be caused by one incident in the past.
Yeah, I really did not appreciate this one.', 'This is very well-made. I really appreciate the creative reverse chronological flashback story structure. That said, it's difficult for me to get emotionally invested in--much less enjoy--a narrative where the protagonist (Yeong-ho) is such an unconscionable piece of shit for the vast majority of it.
It doesn't matter that "it all makes sense" by the end, especially since an 
explanation
 of behavior does 
not
 excuse said behavior (i.e., being abused doesn't justify abusing others). Also, it doesn't matter that Lee Chang-dong masterfully weaves psychoanalysis and South Korean history into the protagonist's story. 
Intellectually, sure, the abovementioned is cool. But what's acknowledged both "too late" (last 20min of a 
2+
 hour movie) and "after the fact" (reading analyses 
after
 the movie)‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Dogfight
Text:
In the fall of 1963, Eddie Birdlace is an 18-year-old Marine Corps volunteer who is about to ship out with three of his buddies for a tour of duty in Vietnam. Planning a massive blowout for their last night in San Francisco, Eddie, his buddies, and a number of other Marines set up a contest they call a¬†‚Äúdogfight‚Äù.
["i don't ask for much but i would like river phoenix back", "one of the few movies i've ever seen where the two leads seemed like real people who felt real love for each other, which made this absolutely fucking devastating. my heart was beating so fast the last 20 minutes i thought i would pop. sweet and funny and sad and an amazing soundtrack, too. kick something out of the romance/coming of age canon and replace it with this, please. this is perfect.", "When I was around fourteen, I was at a church dance and my dad pointed out a girl who was sitting alone in the corner.\xa0‚ÄúStrange that no one has asked the prettiest girl in the room for a dance.‚Äù
Rising to the challenge, I stood up, marched across the floor, and held out my hand to her. ‚ÄúWould you like to dance?‚Äù
Now, a year or so earlier I had gotten glasses, but as I was afraid of how they might affect my social standing, I vowed to never wear them in public, choosing to go through life blind rather than be targeted for potential ridicule based on my appearance.
Because of this, it wasn't until after I‚Äôd extended my‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: You Can Count on¬†Me
Text:
A single mother‚Äôs life is thrown into turmoil after her struggling, rarely-seen younger brother returns to¬†town.
["Lonergan's always been especially good at finding emotional truth/clarity in the smallest of moments but there's a brief moment here where Ruffalo's character Terry, finally returning home after years of estrangement from his hometown, observes the local cemetery (where his parents are buried) just before the local town sign on his bus ride in that so simplistically yet vividly captures the fear of dying in a small town (also see: insignificance, laced with pity & regret) that I had to pause right there and take a break... Too real.", 'This film looks and sounds like a stereotypical, sappy film that will try and pull your heartstrings. But only one man can make this film a heartfelt, genuine piece of cinema. That man is Kenneth Lonergan. Kenny is a filmmaker that tells the truth. He knows this life, he knows these people, he knows how to be genuine with his films. He makes films to tell the stories of people with baggage. Real people. People you would meet in real life. Ordinary people.', "Irreconcilability of split paths but damn if the pain of it isn't worth trying anyways. The complexities of the sibling relationship deepen when they're all that they have and form a tight forever-ness even when they depart. Living together or living cross-country, having accord or having a feud, there's always a sense that they'll be there for each other when it really matters regardless of history. That's family. Nobody yells at my sibling but me."]

Title: Dune
Text:

The spice exists on only one planet in the entire universe, the vast desert planet Arrakis, also known as Dune. Its native inhabitants, the Fremen, have long held a prophecy that a man would come, a messiah who would lead them to true¬†freedom.
['David Lynch, holding up 3 identical head shots of Kyle MacLachlan: hmmmm...now..I wonder who will be playing the lead in my next movie....', 'Felt like I showed up two hours before the final exam for a class I never attended and tried to skim through the entire textbook. Title: Some Came¬†Running
Text:
A former novelist returns to his small Midwest town after serving in the Army during WWII, to the chagrin of his social-climbing brother, and becomes close with an easy-going professional gambler and torn between two very different¬†women.
["when shirley maclaine said she didn't understand frank sinatra's story but she loved it anyway in the same way she didn't understand frank but loved him anyway, and he immediately melts, i started crying. she makes me so sad i love her so much.", "93
Layers of potent sadness in this picture, and it's all sourced from the actors. Frank Sinatra's brutal, lonely demeanor. Shirley MacLaine's tragic complexity. Dean Martin as a drunken rambler, a catalyst for the tension to break and expand across these wide Minnelli frames. There's not much plot here for a film based on a 1,200 page novel but the depth of feeling is immense. Watching it, I felt like I couldn't reach the bottom, with every subsequent scene re-contextualizing the last. Final sequence is explosive, sure, but the lingering intimacy is what got to me - a grave forever written in painful memories and vicious regret.", 'A man of perpetual motion upsets the delicate stasis of a small town community in Vincente Minnelli‚Äôs ‚ÄúSome Came Running.‚Äù
Based on a novel penned by James Jones, author of ‚ÄúFrom Here to Eternity,‚Äù ‚ÄúRunning‚Äù deals in the writer‚Äôs milieu of war‚Äôs psychological and social ripples. ‚ÄúRunning‚Äù stars Frank Sinatra (also of ‚ÄúEternity‚Äù) as a rambling veteran who returns home after 16 years away; not all of them in actual combat.\xa0
‚ÄúRunning‚Äù is the pinnacle of director Minnelli supplanting the lush and intricate scene compositions seen in his musicals to a straight dramatic setting. During the climactic and now iconic carnival sequence, Minnelli even drove Sinatra to depart the set in rushed aggravation over meticulous devotion to his mise en‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye¬†Done

Title: Michael¬†Collins
Text:
Michael Collins plays a crucial role in the establishment of the Irish Free State in the 1920s, but becomes vilified by those hoping to create a completely independent Irish¬†republic.
['Julia roberts: what‚Äôs going on with the irish war of independence\xa0
Michael collins: lmao don‚Äôt worry about it babe\xa0
Julia roberts: okay ‚ù§Ô∏è yay ‚ù§Ô∏è', "Anyone expecting from Neil Jordan's 1996 film the definitive account of the life of Michael Collins and the fight for a free Ireland will be sorely disappointed. Jordan was perfectly placed to deliver a modern epic, but instead his film harks back to the kind of thing John Ford did back in the 1930s and '40s. 
When I first saw this as a young man I was quite impressed by it, but I didn't know my Irish history as well as I would come to do and I think that's why, upon this rewatch, I wasn't as keen - because the problem here is historical accuracy and Jordan's decision to fictionalise much of the story. 
It's one thing to alter‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Ngl, I was a bit disappointed.
On one hand, I got to actually educate myself better about the whole Irish conflict that led to their independence and also understand a little better the animosity between the Brits and Irish fellas. And yeah, I mean, that 
Massacre at Crooke Park
 alone paints the English government in a monstruous light, and that wasn‚Äôt even the worst. 
Also, Liam Neeson gives one of his best performances, to the point that it hurts me even more that he has decided to go from this incredible dramatic, Oscar-worthy actor to this bland action star appearing on largely VOD movies that find their way into theaters. His work here is not on the same level as‚Ä¶

Title: Made in Hong¬†Kong
Text:
Hong Kong 1997, where young people dream of love and death, suicide and murder. Moon is a cynical young debt collector, smitten by Ping, a young woman dying of kidney disease. A suicide note from a student they don‚Äôt know ends up intertwining their¬†fates.
['Fruit Chan is like the angrier Wong Kar-wai. Psychological love is present but stripped down, and the only thing left is angst. Dreaminess fills the entire film, our characters want to dream, but nihlism eventually takes over and the only reward they get is nothing but shattered hopes and dreams. Features a low-key optimistic version of the cemetary scene from \nDangerous Encounters of the First Kind\n.', 'The key film of 1997 Hong Kong: a powerful neo-neorealist drama about what it means to be young, dumb, and absolutely chock-full of cum on the dirty streets of Hong Kong. Shot in real and very shitty apartments plastered with posters for western cultural products, and with synch sound that really lets you hear the Hong Kong street noise. With its story of a young man hurtling towards a bleak destiny that he is almost powerless to stop, I asked myself "This is a parable about the city itself, correct?" and then checked online and found that it is.', "On Hong Kong's sense of abandonment."]

Title: Long¬†Weekend
Text:
When a suburban couple goes camping for the weekend at a remote beach, they discover that nature isn‚Äôt in an accommodating¬†mood.
["Apart from 
Possession
 (1981) this is the most unsettling movie I've watched.
A couple whose relationship is falling apart decide to spend a weekend camping at the beach to try and save their marriage. The only problem is, they're the most hateful characters I've seen. With no respect for their surroundings they litter and kills animals. The only thing they hate more than the environment is each other. They argue over the most mundane things and lash out with the cruelest remarks they think of just to hurt one-another.
If that wasn't enough to make this weekend seem long, Mother Nature herself may be trying to kill them. Strange occurrences keep happening and they only get more and more terrifying‚Ä¶ 
more", 'The message seems to be ‚ÄúRespect life. Or else‚Äù.
Another one of those great old under-appreciated Aussie horror films (or ‚ÄúOzploitation‚Äù if you prefer) like 
Next of Kin
 (1982) and 
Patrick
 (1978), among others. Simple concept: a couple takes a long weekend break of camping presumably to get a little quality time. Sure, real simple.
Brimming with creeping dread, there are copious amounts of foreshadowing indicating that nature is mounting some form of revenge on the guy who disregards the environment. He litters, he starts brush fires, kills animals, chops a tree because ‚Äúwhy not‚Äù‚Ä¶ you can feel the disdain for this guy building up within the contrasting beauty of his surroundings.
Something much deeper is brewing between this couple,‚Ä¶ 
more', "Colin Eggleston joins a group of directors, notably Peter Weir and Nicolas Roeg, who ushered in a new wave of Australian psychological cinema in which the plot and tone felt as if you were caught in a dream, or worse, a nightmare.
Unfortunately, unlike these two directors' other efforts in this genre (Walkabout, The Last Wave, Picnic at Hanging Rock), this film is completely ambiguous and nothing seems to happen. I mean, our characters are assaulted and put through unusual scenarios, but even with all of this, one can't help but sense that the picture is seriously lacking in plot. Finally, it appears that the entire film is about some form of Karma surrounding certain death at the end and‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Olympus Has¬†Fallen
Text:
When the White House (Secret Service Code: ‚ÄúOlympus‚Äù) is captured by a terrorist mastermind and the President is kidnapped, disgraced former Presidential guard Mike Banning finds himself trapped within the building. As the national security team scrambles to respond, they are forced to rely on Banning‚Äôs inside knowledge to help retake the White House, save the President and avert an even bigger¬†disaster.
['INT. STUDIO WAREHOUSE-NIGHT
We‚Äôre in a dark studio warehouse where films go to die. An endless sea of shelves filled with scripts and film reels of movies that never saw the light of day.
In the sea of darkness, we see a flashlight. We reveal three men, a SECURITY GUARD, and two HOLLYWOOD EXECUTIVES. 
HOLLYWOOD EXECUTIVE #1 is holding a tracker.
SECURITY GUARD:
You said it went off about a day ago, right?
HOLLYWOOD EXECUTIVE #1:
Yeah. It rarely happens. We usually send interns down here to find stuff whenever we run out of ideas.
HOLLYWOOD EXECUTIVE #2:
I hate it down here. It stinks of bad decisions.
HOLLYWOOD EXECUTIVE #1: 
Decisions of those who lived before us.
SECURITY GUARD:‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I‚Äôve seen everyone‚Äôs bad reviews and I‚Äôve decided they‚Äôre all wrong. This movie rips.', '"... i lost faith"
terrorism literally staged as a home invasion so america can play out its good-guy-with-a-gun fantasy on an explosive scale and so that, instead of meditating on how we actually respond to trauma (like a similarly-premised craven film 
Red Eye
, which is an invasion thriller about assault/trauma with post-9/11 subtext), we understand that the only response to a collective tragedy is to double down on all of america's worst national traits. this is a film that has a president that boxes so we know, without a doubt, that he is willing to sweat and bruise for america, a place where exertions of physical strength is the only real strength. a film where the hero brutally tortures & kills‚Ä¶

Title: Intolerable¬†Cruelty
Text:

['Ridiculous. A screwy romantic satire about two sociopaths whose ultimate turn on is each others‚Äô greed. Feels like a Coen script filtered through a studio lens, where someone told George Clooney (and no one else) this was a Looney Tunes cartoon. It‚Äôs even shot so differently from everything they‚Äôve done.\xa0The character of Herb Myerson feels like the sole fantastical element they included here as a hint of a much weirder, much Coen-er movie, but nothing else comes close! Can absolutely see why someone (past me included) would not like this, but there‚Äôs something so distinctly crazy about it that I can‚Äôt help but dig it. It‚Äôs too clever, too strange, too subversive in all the cleanest possible ways. Like the Coens‚Äô version of \nThey Came Together\n.', 'measure your life in mediocre movies you watched for beautiful women', 'I earnestly believe George Clooney makes this work because he is the greatest working actor alive']

Title: Flashback
Text:
Frederick Fitzell is living his best life‚Äîuntil he starts having horrific visions of Cindy, a girl who vanished in high school. After reaching out to old friends with whom he used to take a mystery drug called Mercury, Fredrick realizes the only way to stop the visions lies deep within his own memories, so he embarks on a terrifying mental odyssey to learn the¬†truth.

He's so good in this."]

Title: OPAL
Text:
A curious girl investigates the cries she hears coming from a forbidden house across the¬†street.
["POV: You're at a party and I attempt to explain why this short-film is a masterpiece and why you should totally check it out. To me, this micro-movie is about our desperation for blissful happiness and the self destructive ways we attempt to obtain it. Each member of the family is lost in their own obsessions may it be entertainment, appearance or drugs. They all want an escape, including Claire who dreams of a better life as Opal. Ironically, their harmful pursuits of escape are what drive Claire further into the attic where her own delusions lie, showing the continuous cycle of abuse. In the end it's shown that they all want the same escape that Claire does, but as‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'This happened to my buddy Opal', "sir, this is an opal's."]

Title: Kisapmata
Text:
A young woman gets married but her authoritarian father refuses to let her out of his¬†sight.
["That harrowing feeling when you thought all the suffering is over, but then you realize there's still 30 minutes left", 'With the recent news of a double murder committed by a police officer that happened in my country, 
Kisapmata
 has never been more relevant than ever. The mystery drama is based on a true murder-suicide case that happened back in 1961, where a police man committed three murders and suicide after a tumultuous case of domestic dispute. Machismo is heavily shown in this film through the character of Vic Silayan, who used his previous occupation as a police officer and brusque attitude to terrorize his family, in guise of protection. The domineering nature of the father is reflective of the macho-feudal system that this country propagated since then and the normalization of women oppression and abuse has been rampant back‚Ä¶ 
more', "Pitch perfect. There isn't a single scene that outstays its welcome, and there isn't a moment that feels out of place. It's tight and oppressive, the suffocating presence of Dado felt even when he isn't on camera. It's about him in the end: a man who demands control, who cannot stand not getting his way. He claims love, of course, and there are moments when his brusque nature might even seem charming. But make no mistake: all he wants is to feel powerful, to rule over his little kingdom.
We have a history of that in the Philippines.
It's great to see this restored. I'd been told before that there was little hope of seeing this movie again in its‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Avengers:¬†Endgame
Text:
After the devastating events of Avengers: Infinity War, the universe is in ruins due to the efforts of the Mad Titan, Thanos. With the help of remaining allies, the Avengers must assemble once more in order to undo Thanos‚Äô actions and restore order to the universe once and for all, no matter what consequences may be in¬†store.
['Thanos: 
I am inevitable.

Title: Queen¬†Christina
Text:
Popular monarch Queen Christina of Sweden must choose between love and loyalty to her nation when she unexpectedly falls for a Spanish¬†envoy.
['Omg there was only one bed', "Two kisses and a crossdressing sequence were enough. To any queer woman, Christina could not be more queer, even if she does spend most of the film in love with a man. To any trans person, Christina is a fountain of dysphoric behaviors and triggers. This film, with its tragic hetero-romance, is as openly queer as it probably could be. Two kisses, and a crossdressing sequence. It somehow manages to convincingly have two women be in love, and two men, but with only three characters, because subtext can isolate moments and spin them into whole universes. In reality, she was in love with a woman and left not for a man but for herself. Hollywood tries in their own ways to honor that, but it's still laden with this unnecessary connection. (The film itself, all massive old Hollywood-built sets and snowy landscapes and that low angle on the coronation scene is just stunning, truly stunning.)\nPride month: 10/30", 'Turning straight friends gay, one Garbo movie at a time.']

Title: Femme
Text:
Jules is a drag artist in London who withdraws into himself and loses his career after a horrific attack. Months later, he recognizes one of his assailants in a gay sauna and quickly realizes he has the perfect opportunity to get¬†revenge.
["FEMME is a perpetual push and pull. Between masculine and feminine, dom and sub, victim and victimiser, soft and hard, Preston and Jules. But as the film progresses and deepens its two characters, binaries are blurred and burned, breaking the boundary between the two and the absurdity and toxicity of inhabiting just one. Our reaction to the film isn't binary either. We are caught in the fraught feeling of being both repelled and compelled by the actions of Preston, and the increasingly sinister revenge that Jules seeks to partake in. It's a testament to the power of the films performances and filmmaking that in the moment of realisation for Preston, you are able to extend a feeling of empathy to‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'George MacGay', 'The straights thought they could beat Chun-Li??']

Title: Kikujiro
Text:

The two begin a series of adventures which soon turns out to be a whimsical journey of laughter and tears with a wide array of surprises and unique characters along the¬†way.
['No one even fucking dies in this but the ending still wrecked me more than most other Kitano movies, which usually involve someone fucking dies.', 'Cold are human beings towards those who fail to fit in. Fulfilling conventional roles within a society is what many people strive to achieve in order to not be an outcast. A family, a job, and so on. Without those, people are looked at differently; their different choices in life unwillingly becoming a focal point of their personality trait from the perspective of someone snug within the comforts of a conventional lifestyle and smug enough to pass on judgement because of it. 
A boy living with his grandmother; his father deceased and his mother living far away. He wants to meet the woman who birthed him and supposedly works hard far away for his sake. Smokes of melancholy and splashes‚Ä¶ 
more', 'A charming and heartwarming Kitano story, with an elegant direction and a hypnotically slow pace. The heartwarming factor will not disappoint. His proper use of silences is now applied to comedy, and instead of "sudden bursts of violence" like I have described before, we get sudden bursts of hilarity. His camera work is truly genius, because he understands the power of an image in any given context.
78/100']

Title: The Perfect¬†Storm
Text:
In October 1991, a confluence of weather conditions combined to form a killer storm in the North Atlantic. Caught in the storm was the sword-fishing boat Andrea¬†Gail.
['John Sea Reilly', 'A crew of desperate fishermen put it all on the line to turn their luck around ... but mother nature had other plans.
"You could be a meteorologist all your life... and never see something like this. It would be a disaster of epic proportions. It would be... the perfect storm."
Since my kids loved 'Twister' I was looking forward to showing this to them, but there were two aspects that they were not into. The movie does get off to a slow start as we are introduced to each member of the crew and their loved ones. I then tried to explain to them that time is well spent, since it builds an emotional foundation for the characters. But‚Ä¶ 
more', "The Perfect Storm
 since 2000, has been one of my favourite guilty pleasures. A film where despite all the bad acting (Diane Lane), poor plotting, awkward staging, cack dialogue and persistent cheesy music - I've wholeheartedly loved since my first watch. 
Something about it FEELS like a movie in the grandest sense - there's a bigness to the film that has always charmed me. 
The many characters are modestly drawn but feel human nonetheless and as mentioned earlier - the score plays throughout the entire movie - but I LOVE the score. It's perfect for the sweeping sea spectacle we're watching. 
But tonight that sheen has started to wear off. *sigh* I've always been able to see through its weaknesses‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Seven¬†Beauties
Text:
Pasqualino Frafuso, known in Naples as ‚ÄúPasqualino Seven Beauties‚Äù is a petty thief who lives off of the profits of his seven sisters while claiming to protect their honor at any cost, Pasqualino is arrested for murder and later sent to fight in the army after committing sexual assault. The Germans capture him and he gets sent to a concentration camp where he plots to make his escape by seducing a German¬†officer.
["To all the ones who watched this film, oh yeah!
To the ones who haven't yet had the chance, oh yeah!
To all the ones who will watch it again, oh yeah! oh yeah! oh yeah!", 'Giancarlo Giannini‚Äôs eyes should have won an Oscar each for their hypotonic conveyance of intermittent terror and subterfuge. Behind those sparkling pearls lies either animalistic instincts or Machiavellian machinations.\xa0
Lina Wertm√ºller understands that there is poetry in such mystery. To set her inscrutable lead against the violent tides of crime and genocide makes for a tempestuous narrative rich with artistry, wit and feeling. Wertm√ºller not only paints a passionate portrait of moral pestilence, but does so with such vivacious vision as to rival even Fellini himself.\xa0
The first film I have seen of hers shall certainly not be my last.', 'my first i-talian film is now my favorite!\xa0
seven beauties
 is lina wertm√ºller‚Äôs picaresque tale, illustrating survival as satire. pasqualino, our low leveled opportunist is a drifting, fabio-type. the only son of seven heavy-set sisters, he assumes the macho role of protecting the family‚Äôs honor. his honorable facade comes crashing down when he murders one of the girls‚Äô fianc√©-in-waiting/pimp and has to answer to a nazi concentration camp among other forms of character castigation. from there we witness amorality of surviving purely for individualistic rapacity, captured with hypnotic artistry.\xa0
the focal point disregards rising fascism until its brutality spills to the feet of our anti-hero. sardonic humor fades and we are left with a grim debasement of humanity. despite its‚Ä¶

more', 'Score : 9.2/10 ‚úÖ
You keep saying sorry, but you‚Äôre not sorry. You not sorry even a little bit.

Title: The Wind That Shakes the¬†Barley
Text:
In 1920s Ireland young doctor Damien O‚ÄôDonovan prepares to depart for a new job in a London hospital. Damien joins his brother Teddy in the Irish Republican Army, but political events are soon set in motion that tear the brothers¬†apart.
['cillian murphy: yells in irish
me: nods understandingly', "Revolutions are not clean. The British occupation of Ireland was barbaric and brutal. Whilst 
The Wind That Shakes the Barley
 may be exaggerated according to some, it is hard to deny the oppression Ireland faced during centuries of occupation. Irish independence is still a prickly topic, but British actions in the 1920s were wrong and Ken Loach is brave for unequivocally showing that in his film, although it's sad that it does require bravery to highlight anti-imperialist sentiments. 
As a film 
The Wind That Shakes the Barley
 is one of unrelenting terror and bloodshed, filled with constant chaos. The working class accents and dialects are keenly preserved, all shouting over each other as debate and war never stops. However what‚Ä¶ 
more", 'It‚Äôs about the horrors and contradictions of the Irish Civil War in 1922.\xa0
I remember showing this in a community centre in our constituency, and Ken came to talk to us about how he made the film. Thank you Ken!

Title: Beasts of No¬†Nation
Text:
Based on the experiences of Agu, a child fighting in the civil war of an unnamed, fictional West African country. Follows Agu‚Äôs journey as he‚Äôs forced to join a group of soldiers. While he fears his commander and many of the men around him, his fledgling childhood has been brutally shattered by the war raging through his country, and he is at first torn between conflicting revulsion and¬†fascination.
['African child soldiers, young boys who fight the causes of powerful men is the subject of this feature film from Cary Joji Fukunaga. Since it was released simultaneously on Netflix and in cinemas it has been boycotted by the largest theatre chains, but I am certain that the film will reach its audience anyway. Taking place in an unnamed war-torn African nation it centers around a young boy named, Agu, who is forced to join one of three warring factions after democracy collapses in his country.
I had very high hopes for 
Beasts of No Nation
 which was met with mixed reviews during its film festival run and it did not disappoint at all. First of all, it is an‚Ä¶ 
more', "more City of God than Apocalypse Now, stronger on leadership & indoctrination than madness of war (though a gruesomely sublime 15-minute sequence in the middle aces the latter). Elba and the kid are strong, and CJF certainly has the chops in several different categories, but he couldn't really break this story the way it needed to be broken.
(and Dan Rohmer's ambient M83 synths are way out of place)", "I guess the only way Hollywood views Africa is as an entire continent ravaged by nothing but conflict & suffering and in a way, 
Beasts of No Nation
 is another exemplification of that. That's not to say that the film doesn't have any merit, for it is definitely a powerful, provocative & compelling piece of work but the entertainment industry's immoderate fascination with the civil war subject is still worth questioning.
Set in an unnamed West African country, the story concerns a young boy named Agu who after witnessing his family being gunned down by soldiers flees from the village but inadvertently runs into the rebel forces and is coerced to join them in their fight. The plot follows Agu's harrowing journey‚Ä¶

Title: The Sword of¬†Doom
Text:
Ryunosuke, a gifted swordsman plying his trade during the turbulent final days of Shogunate rule, has no moral code and kills without remorse. It‚Äôs a way of life that leads to¬†madness.
["Ugh. Tatsuya Nakadai's cold, soulless eyes are terrifying.
At odds with my preconceived notion of cinematic samurai, Nakadai's Ryunosuke is established as amoral, even for a virtual mercenary. His progression into madness, coupled with his swordsmanship, make the film feel ahead of its time by following the 'bad guy' instead of having a tragic turn bring the protagonist to his lowest point within the film itself. Director Kihachi Okamoto further freshens the pic by sharing the narrative focus with several disparate groups that are either in Ryunosuke's crosshairs or are trying to put this mad dog down, so as not to overexpose the star's mystique and brooding dread. Finally, if Okamoto's stunning compositions (so dense!) or the prospect of seeing Toshiro Mifune decimate a group of r≈çnin in the driving snow isn't enough to turn you on to 
The Sword of Doom
, I don't know what will.", 'Yo this movie has fkin ninjas in it', "There is a reason why Tatsuya Nakadai is 
the most

A film in which a villain played by Tatsuya takes center stage is impossible not to love, also it has one of those abrupt endings that causes you to just sit back in a disorientated state for hours, I hope there's a reason or a story behind it."]

Title: The¬†Core
Text:
Geophysicist Dr. Josh Keyes discovers that an unknown force has caused the earth‚Äôs inner core to stop rotating. With the planet‚Äôs magnetic field rapidly deteriorating, our atmosphere literally starts to come apart at the seams with catastrophic consequences. To resolve the crisis, Keyes, along with a team of the world‚Äôs most gifted scientists, travel into the earth‚Äôs core. Their mission: detonate a device that will reactivate the¬†core.
['Easily in the top ten of the stupidest movies I‚Äôve ever seen and I loved every second of it.', 'when they said "unobtanium" i screamed', "I gave a presentation on the science of disaster movies for my geology course this week. Among the inaccuracies cited were 2012's ludicrously slow pyroclastic flow, the incorrect usage of low-silica lava in Dante's Peak, and the entire plot of The Day After Tomorrow. Still, even among this stiff competition, one film managed to stand out. It is a film about American scientists using a pulse weapon to send earthquakes at our enemies, resulting in the magnetic field shutting down. A group of scientists must then use an experimental substance called unobtainium to drill through the magma and detonate nuclear bombs to get the core spinning again. Along the way, they encounter enormous diamonds, geodes, and innumerable other violations of the laws of thermodynamics.\nI can't stress enough how wonderful of a viewing experience The Core is, but if you haven't seen it yet, I recommend it with no reservations. It truly is an experience like no other."]

Title: Mad Max Beyond¬†Thunderdome
Text:
Mad Max becomes a pawn in a decadent oasis of a technological society, and when exiled, becomes the deliverer of a colony of¬†children.
['The first Mad Max movie that screams "from the director of Happy Feet"', "A+ for production design, car chases, Mel Gibson's hair, ‚ÄúWe Don't Need Another Hero,‚Äù and Tina Turner's costumes.\nD- for turning one of the bleakest franchises in film history into a kid's cartoon, complete with wacky character names, cutesy gibberish language, and lil' rascals banging baddies in the face with frying pans.", "A town run entirely on pig shit is one of the best metaphors for Hollywood I've seen in a while."]

Title: V/H/S/94
Text:

['‚Äúrat man‚Äù
That‚Äôs actually just james corden in his final form', 'Let‚Äôs not kid ourselves - the Veggie Masher infomercial and its chaos was obviously where this peaked', 'The VHS franchise is finally back! This new addition, despite its share of subpar segments as expected, does provide some refreshing excitements, but I do feel like it has eventually overstayed its welcome since it has obviously run out of its original indie spirits and lost its creative impulses.
Out of its 5 segments, only the one from Indonesian director Timo Tjahjanto, who has already proved his horror visions in VHS 2 with his magnificent cult segment, is well above average, thanks to its abundant gore, bonkers effects and its bold tap into the realm of humanity and morality. Everything else, from the sewerage monsters, to the haunted wake, and to the goofy, supernatural conservatives roast, despite their respective glimpses‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: PK
Text:
A stranger in the city asks questions no one has asked before. Known only by his initials, the man‚Äôs innocent questions and childlike curiosity take him on a journey of love, laughter and letting¬†go.
['"Which god should I believe? You all say that it\'s only one god. I say, no... there are two gods. One is the one who created us all. The other one is the one created by people like you."\nThe world is confusing. There\'s a lot to understand, to hate, and to love. I agree religion does separate people. Different beliefs, different faith, and different gods. We assign meanings to things that\'s why sometimes they\'re different. Despite the differences, we can still be united. We just gotta respect each other. Just because you believe in something, doesn\'t mean you have to make others believe in them as well. Let them believe what they wanna believe.', 'Imagine Amir Khan running towards you, full speed, with his dick flapping around.', 'A comedy drama that smartly questions the religious superstitions and myths, with enjoyable quirks and detailing. However beyond a point it gets repetitive with inconsistent dialogues, until it picks itself up with a good final act. Rajkumar Hirani needs to be lauded for the interestingly conceived concept. Aamir khan delivers a hilariously funny performance, well supported by the rest of cast. Despite of the flaws, it still manages to engage and entertain.']

Title: Smokin‚Äô¬†Aces

Yeah.", 'An amphetamine-fueled existential crisis firing on all cylinders, tightly packed for all of us. Soo...just pure fun.
Wildly chaotic, seemingly for no greater reason than Carnahan‚Äôs urge, maybe even a half-hearted attempt to channel someone else‚Äôs style. I‚Äôd seen this movie before, but the memory didn‚Äôt hit me until Chris Pine started using Ben Affleck as a ventriloquist dummy. And honestly, I was kind of surprised I‚Äôd forgotten watching it, because the final act‚Äôs full-blown madness turns out to be a real treat, as long as you leave your brain at the coat check and just enjoy the ride.
There are a lot of familiar faces here, which also means a lot of characters and with a film like this,‚Ä¶ 
more', "The premise is actually enjoyable, with some wonderful over the top performances.
I really didn't care for the energy drink aesthetic though...."]

Title: Leprechaun
Text:
A demonic leprechaun terrorizes a group of young people whom he believes stole his¬†gold.
['lets have some fun this beat is sick
youre gonna get killed by a pogo stick', 'It‚Äôs March 17th so let the Lepre-thon begin.
Saw this tidbit... I don‚Äôt know the validity of it but here goes: ‚ÄòOne scene required the Leprechaun to find and eat Lucky Charms cereal, which the company gave them permission to do. Upon seeing the finished film, the company was displeased and would not allow them to use the scene and the film makers had the choice to either cut the scene or to re-shoot it, costing them more money. They chose to re-shoot it, replacing the brand name with an obvious spoof of the name brand cereal, and, made one last additional surprise ending scene while they were filming. Furious with the cereal company for making them re-shoot the scene, they pulled the kid character aside and had him say a new line. His line, "Your luck just ran out!" was changed to "Fuck you, Lucky Charms!" as an obvious reference to the whole ordeal.‚Äô
The more you know?', 'It‚Äôs not a good film.
But good film or not you can‚Äôt not be entertained by a Leprechaun riding the following things:
- A tricycle
- A wheelchair\xa0
- A small toy car
I mean seriously where else are you gonna get a pogo stick death?
Warwick Davis relishes the role and Jennifer Anniston is next level cute in this. Like good grief it‚Äôs so unfair. If time travel was real I‚Äôd go back to ask her out and be rejected I don‚Äôt care.']

Title: The¬†Idiots
Text:
A group of people gather at a Copenhagen suburban home to break all the limitations and to bring out the ‚Äòinner idiot‚Äô in¬†themselves.
["Lars von Trier is a self-loathing narcissist. That may sound like an oxymoron, and as unfair as reducing a person to a few simple words is, that's as basic a description as I can come up with for him. He is a class clown, an insecure extrovert, and a clever little devil. He's a romantic ashamed of his own passions, and the films he makes are his way of explaining, through allegory and in a roundabout ways, why he feels the way he does. At first glance, he seems to revel in being divisive (as I myself once thought), but after watching 
The Idiots
, it's becoming clear that it's simply too frightening to express himself without the aid of a‚Ä¶ 
more", '"being an idiot with you is one of the best things i've ever done."
absolutely essential, of course. much more to come for a von Trier retro piece timed to NYMPHOMANIAC / BREAKING THE WAVES Criterion.', 'the only place i could find this for free was on a website called effedupmovies.comü§ß']

Title: A Raisin in the¬†Sun
Text:
Walter Lee Younger is a young man struggling with his station in life. Sharing a tiny apartment with his wife, son, sister and mother, he seems like an imprisoned man. Until, that is, the family gets an unexpected financial¬†windfall.
["hate to break it to you beneatha, but you're gay", "This film adaptation of Lorraine Hansberry's play is not one that feels far to distant from its theatrical roots - and although Daniel Petrie's adaptation is one that exemplifies that quality above all else, it still reaffirms the resonance left behind by the original play.
In telling the story of a struggle faced by an African-American family, what makes Petrie's cinematic take on 
A Raisin in the Sun
 work its wonders can be felt through how the cast (the same people who had performed these characters onstage) puts their life into every role. Every member of the Younger family feels like you've known them so closely, but it also helps that you can still feel the claustrophobia present within the‚Ä¶ 
more", 'one of the greatest american plays ever written and ever to be written']

Title: Medium¬†Cool
Text:
John Cassellis is the toughest TV news reporter around. After extensively reporting about violence and racial tensions in poor communities, he discovers that his network is helping the FBI by granting them access to his footage to find¬†suspects.
['1968: A studiously dispassionate and amoral fictional reporter played by Robert Forster has a political awakening when he realizes that his bosses have provided his reportage to the FBI in the film 
Medium Cool
2024: CNN cameras linger on the faces of Columbia University student protestors as they are unmasked by police.', "Truly brilliant, and genuinely upsetting. 
Artists have created a lot of work illustrating the horrors of fascism and it just doesn't seem to have made much difference. Not enough anyway.", "Political cinema was prominent around the world during the 1960's and in 1969 comes cinematographer-turned-writer/director Haskell Wexler with his own revolutionary 
Medium Cool
, which plays out along the lines of a news story. When satires like 
Dr. Strangelove
 and 
The Manchurian Candidate
 or thrillers like 
Fail-Safe
 have come out, Haskell Wexler sheds light on the nation's growth without any sort of compromise coming along the way. He shows America as it was back in the summer of 1968, but at the same time a story of great importance arises that places it almost along the lines of Gillo Pontecorvo's 
The Battle of Algiers
 or Costa-Gavras's 
Z
 regarding how they handle such sensitive material. On his directorial debut, Haskell Wexler brought‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Text:
Despondent over the closing of his karate school, Cobra Kai teacher John Kreese joins a ruthless businessman and martial artist to get revenge on Daniel and Mr.¬†Miyagi.

Terry Fucking Silver.

:\xa0

The 113-minute story is about a nuclear-waste-dumping billionaire who goes undercover as a destitute karate instructor in order to subvert a teenager's chances at a regional, bragging-rights-only tournament in an effort to generate publicity and credibility for a chain of dojos run by the abusive and disgraced villain from

 Because it sounds completely insane when you say it like that. Also, like 25% of the run-time is fixated on the dangerous relocation on a single tiny tree, for some reason.

Title: The Cat o‚Äô Nine¬†Tails
Text:
A newsman works with a blind puzzle-solver to uncover a deadly conspiracy linked to a genetic research¬†facility.
['More discrete than its predecessor, 
Cat o‚Äô Nine Tails
 has never been a go to giallo or Argento movie for me... at least that was the case ten years ago or so, and now I adore this movie‚Äîdefinitely my kind of moody euromystery jam... slathered in an odd eugenics plot, tense setpieces (death milk, mausoleum scene), and one of my favorite things in cinema‚ÄîA rooftop finale! Tamer than its trilogy bookends, there‚Äôs still hands getting ripped up by elevator wire and a person getting their face smashed as a train bulldozes over them... contorting the bloodied corpse as if it were set to tumble mode.
James Franciscus and Karl Malden standout big time, especially Malden as the blind crossword puzzle‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Not one of Argento‚Äôs best, but he‚Äôs a god and I feel like if I rate it any lower than three stars, I‚Äôll get struck by lightning, so yeah, don‚Äôt hate me my lord.', "#Giallo
Argento keeps amazing me. He is able to mold his style within the tonal trio of crime‚Äìgiallo‚Äìcamp, and his combination never once feels off. He takes a more stern turn with 
The Cat o‚Äô Nine Tails
, showcasing that he is able to pull off a shadow-tinged crime thriller peppered with dark humor just as adeptly as he can choreograph brutal murder scenes to unapologetically funky music. 
That is not to say his certified brand of 1st person POV shots are lacking here. One of my favorite scenes is at a train station where we see the world directly with the killer's eyes. He frantically looks left and right, afraid someone is going to recognize him, as he plans to‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Kill Bill: The Whole Bloody¬†Affair
Text:
Quentin Tarantino‚Äôs complete cut combining Kill Bill: Vol. 1 and Vol. 2 follows The Bride, a former assassin who awakens from a four-year coma after being shot by her mentor and lover, Bill. She embarks on a vengeful quest to eliminate Bill and the Deadly Viper Assassination Squad who betrayed¬†her.
['Regal Pyramid Mall Cinemas, Ithaca, NY
October 10, 2003
I drove a black Saturn SL1 to the mall. The car belonged to my girlfriend, although we were broken up at the time. This is relevant because we weren‚Äôt apart long and would eventually spend the rest of our lives together. We were in college, she in Baltimore, me in Western New York. How I got the car amidst ‚Äúthe break‚Äù is beyond me. Her dad owned it, technically, I was just the boyfriend. But I was happy to have it. So I drove to the mall for a date I‚Äôd circled in red pen on the calendar. 
I went with my friend Mox, a fellow Tarantino allegiant. We‚Äôd seen the‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Let's face it, there really isn't a better way to watch "Kill Bill" than this. It was originally envisioned as a massive, four hour action epic, complete with full color massacre scenes, until Tarantino declared that it was too long for mainstream audiences and decided to split it into two. To make things worse, the MPAA refused to give Kill Bill a desired R rating because of the ultra bloody scenes. To compromise, Tarantino made the offending scenes black and white, to make the blood less pronounced (I guess) and since then, the original uncut version has been all but lost.
But apparently they do still show it at festivals, and Tarantino has plans to bring the full cut to‚Ä¶ 
more', "I've got a lot wrapped up in this emotionally. It's a foundational moment in one of my very best friendships, and VOL. 1 came out just a couple months after I started working at Scarecrow, just full to bursting with references to movies I was just beginning to learn how to love. At the time, I thought I'd been waiting my whole life to see KILL BILL. Then I waited almost the same amount of time again to see this version, which is just incalculably great and the only way it should ever be watched. Even the makeshift home version you can cobble together if you have the right discs doesn't hold a candle to the real thing. While I was watching it at the Vista last night it was the best movie I have ever seen, and certainly the screening was one of the best moviegoing experiences I have ever had."]

Title: The¬†Captain
Text:
Germany, 1945. Soldier Willi Herold, a deserter of the German army, stumbles into a uniform of Nazi captain abandoned during the last and desperate weeks of the Third Reich. Newly emboldened by the allure of a suit that he has stolen only to stay warm, Willi discovers that many Germans will follow the leader, whoever he¬†is.
['Zieht runter. Echt runter. Und √ºberzieht den Irrsinn dann auch ein wenig. Die Botschaft w√§re auch ohne die eine oder andere Szene, Grausamkeit oder Idiotie im B√ºrokratie-Vakuum des zu Ende gehenden 3. Reiches gut angekommen. Und auch ohne diese wenigen Momente, die in die Gegenwart greifen. Aber sollte auch nur die H√§lfte von dem Gezeigten tats√§chlich so passiert sein... sollte man inst√§ndig hoffen, beten, agieren, kultivieren oder einleiten, dass es nie wieder zu solch einem Zustand kommt. Kein Film, den man sich gern noch mal ansehen will. Obwohl er von sehr vielen Darstellern gut, widerw√§rtig, schwitzend, verzweifelt, gehorsam und irre gespielt wird. Und obwohl die schwarzwei√üen wie √§sthetisierten Bilder genauso perfekt passen wie der sp√§rlich dr√∂hnende Soundtrack. Denn irgendwann f√ºhlt sich alles so bitterkalt und schmerzhaft an wie das Abspritzen mit Eiswasser aus Hochdruckschl√§uchen. Oder eben so falsch wie dieses Schaf im Wolfspelz, um das es hier geht.', 'Der Hauptmann
 is no easy watch. Everything from the dark humor to the soundtrack makes this one of the most suffocating movies I have seen. Because of that it leaves a very strong impression and gives a lot of food for thought. And all of the moviegoers seemed to feel that up to a certain level, because nobody said a word after the end credits had rolled.
Der Hauptmann
 is about power and complicity and as a viewer it is impossible to escape the dark psychological decline of the main character. Herold has just escaped death several times when he comes across a deserted car where he finds some food and the uniform of a high German officer. When he‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Audiovisuell reizvolle Abrechnung mit der zunehmend popul√§ren Bagatellisierung von Nazi-Verbrechen, die vor allem im √∂ffentlich-rechtlichen Fernsehen immer st√§rker um sich greift. ROMMEL, UNSERE M√úTTER UNSERE V√ÑTER, NICHT ALLE WAREN M√ñRDER‚Äî ja, wir haben es verstanden! Der gemeine deutsche TV-Gucker und Programmkinog√§nger sehnt sich nach dem Mythos des 
guten Nazis
(sic). Man m√∂chte endlich wieder mit den T√§tern mitf√ºhlen d√ºrfen.
W√ºrg!
Der in hiesige Gefilde zur√ºckgekehrte Regie-Exilant Robert Schwentke setzt einen gro√üen Haufen auf diese Attit√ºde und serviert uns knapp zwei Stunden stinkenden, teuflischen Irrsinn, ausge√ºbt von stinkenden, teuflischen M√§nnern in l√§cherlichen Uniformen. Dass DER HAUPTMANN nicht frei von dramaturgischen Holprigkeiten und Geschmacklosigkeiten ist, liegt dabei in der Natur der Sache.
Ein erfreulich kantiger, unbequemer Film und schwarz-wei√üer Lichtblick im zeitgen√∂ssischen deutschen Kino.']

Title: High¬†Anxiety
Text:
A psychiatrist with intense acrophobia (fear of heights) goes to work for a mental institution run by doctors who appear to be crazier than their patients, and have secrets that they are willing to commit murder to¬†keep.
["Undoubtedly one of Mel Brooks' weaker efforts, but one that has always piqued my interest. I think a lot of it is because I grew up seeing clips of the film on TCM all the time, so in many ways, this is the most ingrained of all the director's films on my mind.
Still, it's Mel Brooks, and the man can't help but be funny. While I didn't laugh aloud, I did find myself chuckling frequently. On a second viewing, it's evident that you have to know Hitchcock's films to get a lot of the gags; for example, the presence of this random photographer at the airport might come off as dumb and senseless unless you've watched 
Torn Curtain
.
All‚Ä¶ 
more", '"High Anxiety" represents to me the moment when Mel Brooks started to "lose it" in a sense. Whilst it's a nice tribute to the films and style of Alfred Hitchcock, satirising a handful of his classic films such as "Vertigo," "The Birds," and "Psycho," It doesn't have the blistering social commentary of "Blazing Saddles" or the hilarious belly-aching laughs of "Young Frankenstein." In a sense, it feels like a generic spoof film that's lacking any sort of depth. The film does contain some funny moments that brought about a couple of chuckles, but nothing much beyond that. 
"High Anxiety" uses "Vertigo" as its main plot to create its narrative. The story is pretty bland, and it doesn't have the wit‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Had high anxiety waiting 45 minutes for Madeline Kahn to finally show up as the Hitchcock blonde and then proceed to completely steal the show.']

Title: Victim
Text:
A web of blackmail and murder attracts the attention of a barrister with a seemingly idyllic life, threatening to derail his career on the path of¬†success.
["Imagine that you're an actor who's secretly gay, and you're approached to play the part of a man who's secretly gay. Now imagine it's in a society where being homosexual is a crime punishable by jail time. How would you respond?
This is the situation that Bogarde found himself in when approached to do this film in 1961, and by all accounts he didn't hesitate. The whole project is similarly startlingly brave. It's hard to find a modern analogue, but inserting yourself into what was such a heated topic at the time opened the stars and producers to a whole heap of criticism and abuse.
Viewed now, the film is still quite startling, mainly for a modern audience in its‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Victim
 is not only a cultural milestone, but a defiant act of protest. The very idea that homosexuals were victims rather than perpetrators was a bold counter to the laws which governed LGBTQ+ people and the representation of homosexuality in the media which had pushed them to the peripheries of a perverse underworld. The first film to use the word "homosexual" did far more than pay lip service. 
By modern standards, this film remains progressive albeit drawing on far less developed ideas of queerness. 
Victim
 was regarded by the censors for dangerous in suggested homosexuality was a choice: a notion we disregard today for a far more accepting reason. Yet at its core, Victim is probing the state of LGBTQ+‚Ä¶ 
more', '"If it was love why should I want to stamp it out? Why would I do that if it was love?"
the widespread, calculated conditioning of self-loathing so plainly on display is so fucking much to bear. piling on itself and spilling out onto others. the body count among these handful of characters.... i literally cant think about it anymore. i love you dirk bogarde']

Title: O-Bi, O-Ba: The End of¬†Civilization
Text:
The world has been ravaged by nuclear war. The planet is frozen and radiation kills anyone or anything that ventures outside of ‚ÄòThe Dome‚Äô. Soft is a shepherd for the last remnants of humanity who have gathered together as they await rescue from a mysterious craft known only as ‚ÄòThe Ark.‚Äô He wanders among the masses, performing his regular daily tasks; keeping morale from plummeting, wooing prostitutes, squashing rebellions, and sometimes feeding the hungry. But as the true and sinister nature of ‚ÄòThe Dome‚Äô comes to light, Soft must ask himself if humanity is worth¬†saving‚Ä¶ √ó
["This is like two steps shy of being hilariously absurdist, instead it's depressingly absurdist (still kinda funny?) mostly because it feels as relevant now as I'm sure it did almost 40 years ago. Bureaucratic contradictions lead to a post-truth politics, propaganda agents deliberately employed to spread belief in a coming Ark that will save humanity while loudspeakers regularly deny the existence of this Ark until no one is really sure what to believe in, even the administration that invented the Ark.
Existing now as a noumenon, it is something un-sensible and un-knowable as a thing-in-itself which can only be indirectly experienced through its manifestations as phenomenon. This seems inconsistent initially as the Ark itself is clearly not real (it it?)‚Ä¶ 
more", 'There‚Äôs a scene in 
O-Bi, O-Ba: The End of Civilization
\xa0where we see a group of people training themselves to walk on tightropes, their reasoning being that when the fabled savior ship comes to transport them from the giant bunker they‚Äôre imprisoned in (nuclear war has made the outside world uninhabitable), they can avoid ‚Äúthe terrible crush for the entrance‚Äù\xa0and calmly amble up the ship‚Äôs moorings to secure passage. Like rats.
By design, it‚Äôs an absurd metaphor, but the more I think about it, the less absurd it seems. Having attended multiple tent revivals in South Georgia, let me tell you, tightrope walking registers pretty low on the crazy-meter when considering the lengths to which people will go to ‚Äúassure‚Äù their‚Ä¶ 
more', "Ngl, by the end of the movie, I was dancing like Brad Pitt in 
Burn After Reading
 to that elevator music.
One of those movies I'm not sure how it made its way onto my watchlist, but I'm glad it did. Honestly, I didn‚Äôt find a lot of the writing engaging, but that‚Äôs probably on me. I did like some of the commentary on society, religion and other themes that are usually associated with the post-apocalyptic genre. The performances are really good, namely Stuhr, I believe, as the main character, a man that comes up with this idea of a vessel that will save the lives of those living in this vault that‚Äôs slowly cracking down. The twist, it seems‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Vitalina¬†Varela
Text:

['i‚Äôll get 9 hours of sleep and have a large iced coffee and *still* pass the fuk out during a pedro costa\xa0
(i say this with love)', '"I prefer the films that put their audience to sleep in the theatre. Some films have made me doze off in the theatre, but the same films have made me stay up at night, wake up thinking about them in the morning, and keep on thinking about them for weeks." - Abbas Kiarostami
Vitalina Varela
 is despairing, hyper-slow cinema. To watch this after a weary day crushes the soul. Yet it sticks, burying itself into your darkest contemplations. It is a film of faithless faith, days as dark as the night, and a character sketched entirely by his absence. It is 2 hours of a woman's inner suffering, soaking in secrets and lies, darkness and eventually nothing. 
Vitalina Varela

Title: Dead Man‚Äôs¬†Shoes

Title: To¬†Live
Text:
Married couple Fugui and Jiazhen endure tumultuous events in mid-20th century mainland China as their personal fortunes move from wealthy landownership to¬†peasantry.
['regimes will continue to crush, people will continue to adapt', 'Humanity is strong.
When we lose our shelter, our loved ones - we choose to live. 
When our society and power structures force us into labor we didn‚Äôt want - we choose to live. 
When we watch the world around us burn and deteriorate - we choose to live. 
When we watch our pain cycle and continue in our children, in our children‚Äôs children - we still choose to live. 
Even in the face of extreme loss, grief, despair, trapped in a situation we can‚Äôt escape - humans will find a way to persevere. Because we choose to love, to hope, and to live.', "I'm not sure what it is but I love movies that span decades and tell us a large story, even more-so if it's focused on ordinary people. These sorts of 'grassroots epics' tend to move me the most, as we see how the forces of time affect those who are most susceptible to such change.
To Live
 is one such film, something that I knew would move me close to tears several times and also something that I find really hard to explain why.
It might be because of how relatable it is and thus belongs with films like Lulu Wang's 
The Farewell
 and Jia Zhangke's 
Mountains May Depart
, dramas that focus on how Chinese families must swim and adapt‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Take¬†Out
Text:
An illegal Chinese immigrant falls behind on payments on an enormous smuggling debt. Ming Ding has only until the end of the day to come up with the¬†money.
['One of the most special, most authentic New York City movies ever made. Also one of the most simultaneously human and inhumane. If you had to explain to someone the rat race the 20th and 21st centuries have turned the mere act of survival into for most this is the bible. The way the world punches you when your life is already punishment enough and the fact that we keep going in the face of that. In the face of all of that, we keep going. Maybe when we finally have a break, we have a picture we look at that makes the world go quiet, and maybe that‚Äôs enough.', 'always tip your delivery guy', "One of the most surprising things about this film is that it was completely in the Mandarin language. I knew it was about an illegal Chinese immigrant, but the dialogue is... really good. Co-directed by Tsou Shih-Ching, who would go on to produce pretty much all of Sean Baker's subsequent films, I feel like she really brought out a lot of personality and intimacy to this film. The characters feel so genuine and relatable.\nA bit unrelated but in 1995, Lars von Trier and Thomas Vinterberg created the Dogme 95 movement where they created films based off a set of rules. Pretty much by stripping down all production value, the story/acting/characters would be at the forefront of the film. Ironically,‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: Stroszek
Text:
Bruno Stroszek is released from prison and warned to stop drinking. He has few skills and fewer expectations: with a glockenspiel and an accordion, he ekes out a living as a street musician. He befriends Eva, a prostitute down on her luck and they join his neighbor, Scheitz, an elderly eccentric, when he leaves Germany to live in¬†Wisconsin.
["The ending is justifiably legendary, but what really got to me were the moments of innocent joy - three friends gazing at a map, the sparkling new but very humble dreamhouse, the pleasure Bruno gets from playing his music and taking care of Eva. Much of the humor is terribly melancholy, and I mostly found those scenes endearing or sad rather than funny. Herzog knows life is a painful struggle but he isn't angry about it, just determined to tell a quiet sad story. Life is pain, the American dream is garbage, people are ruthlessly cruel, but there are songs to sing.
The mindless dancing chicken as a metaphor for life's repetitiveness and mankind's idiocy, sure. But a chicken doesn't‚Ä¶ 
more", 'We are all tragic, dancing chickens.', 'Werner Herzog went looking for a serial killer, and found America instead.\xa0
The idea of ‚ÄúStroszek‚Äù apparently occurred to Herzog somewhere in Wisconsin, along the way to unearth the alleged grave of Ed Gein‚Äôs mother to record for a documentary feature.\xa0
The true crimes of the Oedipal corpse flayer make for a somewhat more direct link to the other work they inspired; Hitchcock‚Äôs ‚ÄúPsycho.‚Äù Herzog, maybe to the credit of his own brand of awe, ultimately was more strongly affected by the landscape of what even other flyover states would deem flyover territory: the plains of Nekoosa, Wisconsin.\xa0
The progression from a documentary about a man that made human skin lamps to ‚ÄúStrosek‚Äù is more logical than it sounds. Mostly‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Cliffhanger
Text:
A year after losing his friend in a tragic 4,000-foot fall, former ranger Gabe Walker and his partner, Hal, are called to return to the same peak to rescue a group of stranded climbers, only to learn the climbers are actually thieving hijackers who are looking for boxes full of¬†money.
["Endlessly, beautifully committed to loud, nasty violence, never missing a chance to beat the hell out of its hero and leave a bloody mess of his enemies. Lithgow makes a terrific villain, totally having a blast matching Sly's every punch with a terrible quip. Bench-pressing a guy onto a stalactite has to be one of the all-time great action movie kills. No contrivance is omitted in its pursuit of cheap thrills. And then there's the fantastic late-analog spectacle. Literally every trick in the book is deployed here, from (outstanding) matte-paintings to miniatures to rear-screen to good old fashioned practical stunts. It's Bond level, really a superb technical achievement. The plane-to-plane transfer sequence is worth it alone (and essentially remained unequaled until THE DARK KNIGHT RISES). Harlin's best movie in a walk.
Edit: Can't believe I forgot to mention Rex Linn's constant, literally frothing-at-the-mouth apoplectic rage.", "The opening scene of this movie vividly renders one of my greatest nightmares...dating someone who's into outdoorsy stuff like hiking, mountain biking, climbing, etc.
Solid. Good action. Great locations. Rooker, Stallone, Lithgow, Leon and Sides God Rex Linn.", 'Free Solo
 meets Four Loko in this 90s Stallone action classic (which feels more like a product of the 80s than it does the 90s) where sad boi Sly mopes around a snowy mountaintop before getting tangled up with murderous psychopath John Lithgow and a criminal crew that somehow actually feels representative of realistic coworker interaction in how much they just can‚Äôt fucking stand each other. Sure, it‚Äôs a total 
Die Hard
 rip-off, but it‚Äôs got giant explosions, bloody kills (shoulder pressing a dude into a stalactite is ‚Äúfuck yeah‚Äù incarnate), gorgeous mountain matte painting backdrops, and enough extreme climbing stunts to give cliffheads (is that a term? Idk) a full body orgasm. Plus, it features the sickest mid-air heist ever filmed by a guy not named Chris ‚ÄúTop Dawg‚Äù Nolan. As long as you can make it past the low key super traumatizing opening scene, it‚Äôs one boss ass time.
Underrated Movies that More People Should See']
