Title: The Enigma of Kaspar¬†Hauser
Text:
The film follows Kaspar Hauser, who lived the first seventeen years of his life chained in a tiny cellar with only a toy horse to occupy his time, devoid of all human contact except for a man who wears a black overcoat and top hat who feeds¬†him.
['"The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser", and other translations of this title is a disgrace to the original German title, "Every Man For Himself, and God Against All". It's obviously that Herzog want's to shake our view on the world by allowing us to observe the world with a fresh mind through the eyes of Kaspar Hauser. The movie is actually not that mysterious, and to me it don't seem that it's in Herzog's intentions to make a mystery film either.
The story of Kasper Hauser is madly intoxicating, and I was so caught up in the story and the character of Kaspar that I barely noticed the construction workers outside my house! Bruno S. is simply amazing as the troubled‚Ä¶ 
more', "In many ways feels like the most measured, literary distillation of Herzog's key preoccupations - the utter absurdity of cultured civility, the struggle to know the unknowable and to find meaning and art within struggle, all filtered through a style which is distinctly less experiential than much of his other work (especially his collaborations with Kinski). Here his camera isn't so much a journeyman as it is a Brechtian observer, more immediately inspired by other German New-Wavers such as Fassbinder in the way he wrings emotion and humour out of the somewhat stilted, artificial rhythms which he's consciously working with here. Bruno's wide-eyed, singularly odd performance works in near-perfect contrast to the satirical civility which surrounds him - the first‚Ä¶ 
more", 'It is God who hides us, chained, in the basement from the time we are born. It is God who sets us free. It is God who appears occasionally to rap us with his stick. And it is God who comes to stab us when our time in the world is done. It is every man for himself, and God against all.
The Herzog project marches on.']

Title: I Shot Andy¬†Warhol

Title: Spartacus
Text:
The rebellious Thracian Spartacus, born and raised a slave, is sold to Gladiator trainer Batiatus. After weeks of being trained to kill for the arena, Spartacus turns on his owners and leads the other slaves in rebellion. As the rebels move from town to town, their numbers swell as escaped slaves join their ranks. Under the leadership of Spartacus, they make their way to southern Italy, where they will cross the sea and return to their¬†homes.
['I audibly gasped when Spartacus chopped a guy‚Äôs hand off and it spurted blood because I didn‚Äôt think movies were allowed to do that back then', "I can see why this feels like for-hire work when you look at Kubrick's filmography but when compared to other old-fashioned analog epics this is honestly among the more beautiful and intimate of them with finely-tuned performances from some reliable greats (Douglas, Laughton, Ustinov, Olivier, etc) and insanely gorgeous spectacle sequences that simply serve to amplify fast and Trumbo's material which was clearly inspired by their blacklisting and is very emotionally engaged with its basic ideas of class solidarity and spectacle/violence as both tool of entertainment and revolution. What an ending too! With the path of literal and ideological freedom lined with corpses. Glad I decided to blindly pick up the new 4K blu-ray (one of the best-looking ones I've seen so far tbh) and finally get around to this one.", 'One of its taglines says, "More titanic than any story ever told!" which actually isn't very far from the truth. Notorious for being the only feature in the legendary film career of director Stanley Kubrick for which he didn't have complete artistic control, 
Spartacus
 is breathtaking in both scope of its ambition & scale of its production and, just like every other Kubrick film, is an influential example of its genre.
Set during the 1st century BC, 
Spartacus
 tells the true life story of its titular character, a rebellious slave being trained at a gladiatorial school, who begins an uprising which soon spreads across the Italian Peninsula, resulting in the freedom of thousands of slaves but when his plan to flee‚Ä¶

Title: The Boys in the¬†Band
Text:
A witty, perceptive and devastating look at the personal agendas and suppressed revelations swirling among a group of gay men in Manhattan. Harold is celebrating a birthday, and his friend Michael has drafted some other friends to help commemorate the event. As the evening progresses, the alcohol flows, the knives come out, and Michael‚Äôs demand that the group participate in a devious telephone game, unleashing dormant and unspoken¬†emotions.

The fact that over half of these brilliant actors lost their lives to AIDS in the proceeding decades is absolutely fucking heartbreaking.', "Who's Afraid of Virgina Woolf but they're all Elizabeth Taylor.", 'The boys went in for a birthday party, expecting a fun night, but all they got are depression, grief, regret, confusion, and a hard reality slap. 
The Boys in the Band

Title: Peggy Sue Got¬†Married
Text:

And they're in a DOO-WOP GROUP?? Coppola you absolute legend", "when i'm in my forties, when i have kids and decades of memories, i'll watch this, and i'll reflect on all the pains and joys of adolescence, the mistakes, the beauty, the sexual experiences, the regrets, the unforgettable moments of perfection and everything else in between. right now i'm in the middle of mine and i'm already grappling with my existence, my future, my mistakes. and i see this and i think about life changing so drastically, i think about forgetting what my mum looks like young, how my dad smiled, my gran's voice and very presence, about my grandparents not being in the world, about my friends dying, about the fucking turbulent existence i've got ahead of me and‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

For shame, people.üíÄ‚ö°Ô∏è\nThis is a classic!üòà', 'the dark comedy about gentrification in brooklyn that you didn\'t know you needed. stiller and barrymore bounce off each other so well and are cast perfectly as a landlord couple who try to kill their elderly neighbor because they can\'t evict her. ben stiller even says "Rent control sucks!!!" at one point lol. it\'s not a lost masterpiece or anything but devito\'s sense of humor is twisted enough and there\'s enough style to keep it going. when was the last time you saw a mainstream comedy with wacky canted angles and frequent match cuts? not to mention some great gross out gags (drew barrymore vomits on ben stiller\'s face) and a steller supporting cast (wallace shawn, maya rudolph...)', 'That old woman sure was a diabolical hag.']

Yes. 
It's called, "doing crime". 
Congratulations, you just made a crime thriller with extra steps', 'i liked it when the racists died']

Title: Robin Hood: Prince of¬†Thieves
Text:
Nobleman crusader Robin of Locksley breaks out of a Jerusalem prison with the help of Moorish fellow prisoner Azeem and travels back home to England. But upon arrival he discovers his dead father in the ruins of his family estate, killed by the vicious sheriff of Nottingham, Robin and Azeem join forces with outlaws Little John and Will Scarlett to save the kingdom from the sheriff‚Äôs¬†villainy.
["So many things about this movie aren't good but I still kind of like it because it's having fun and we don't get movies like this at all anymore.", "There was a brief stretch in the early 90's where I watched this every other day and it was absolutely my favorite movie lol. Not gonna lie‚Ä¶ this dumb and very long film still holds up for me, Freeman and Rickman are wonderful, I love Michael McShane as the boozed up friar tuck, and it‚Äôs always a pleasure seeing Michael Wincott and his raspy voice play a scuzzball during the 90‚Äôs.
Also, the Michael Kamen score is amazing.", '"Locksley! I'm gonna cut your heart out WITH A SPOON!"
I'm pretty sure that if I watched this for the first time today, I wouldn't like it. I'd detest all of the inaccuracies, plotholes and dodgy accents. 
But I didn't see this for the first time today. I've seen this countless times since I was a kid and back then it was only the film's sense of adventure that mattered to me and still does now. 
Robin Hood: Prince Of Thieves, to this very day, never fails to transport me back to my 12 year old self.']

Title: Cowboy Bebop: The¬†Movie
Text:
The year is 2071. Following a terrorist bombing, a deadly virus is released on the populace of Mars and the government has issued the largest bounty in history, for the capture of whoever is behind it. The bounty hunter crew of the spaceship Bebop; Spike, Faye, Jet and Ed, take the case with hopes of cashing in the bounty. However, the mystery surrounding the man responsible, Vincent, goes deeper than they ever imagined, and they aren‚Äôt the only ones hunting¬†him.
['Fact: Cowboy Bebop is the greatest show to have ever aired on television, animated or otherwise.
Fact: this movie is two hours of Cowboy Bebop.
Fact: this movie is two hours of the greatest show to have ever aired on television, animated or otherwise.
Fact: this was bloody fucking awesome and it makes me miss this beautiful show even more than I already did.
See you, space cowboy.', "Among the most detailed and demonstrably lived-in pieces of futurism ever concocted, up there with BLADE RUNNER and ALIENS for both impeccable function and designer violence, not to mention a perfect extension of the origin series' unique, tantalizing melancholy. I don't know anything about anime, but of what little I've seen this is a stealth masterwork.", "About life, of choosing the life we want to live and living fully in the present and making the most of this short life we have in the world in spite of, and because of, it being all we can do.
I think, in so many ways, 
Knockin' on Heaven's Door
 is the greatest film at encapsulating this. 
Cowboy Bebop
 is known for a lot of things but one thing that always stood out to me was its dedication to verisimilitude, of portraying the little things and the little people and the little places that surround the big. I don't say 'important' for the latter because the little 
is
 important, perhaps the most important aspect to be found in the‚Ä¶ 
more", '‚ÄúI love the kind of woman that can kick my ass.‚Äù', "I feel like there's at least a dozen other episodes that would've better suited the length of a feature film than this story, but it's hard to complain about getting extra time with these amazing characters.
Still haven't seen the final 4 episodes yet, so no spoilers in the comments! (Oh, wait, never mind >:)", 'how the hell did Spike survive being shot several times and thrown off a train oh who cares this movie is amazing', 'Asks big questions like what if Bob Dylan were a bio-terrorist war vet and also not like Bob Dylan in any discernible way', "Turns out I underrated the shit out of this movie when I first saw it.
Perfectly paced, beautifully composed space-western-noir propelled by Yoko Kanno's reliably astounding music, the undercurrent of deep melancholy hit me a lot harder this time around, as did its depiction of endless bureaucracies within bureaucracies crashing into each other and creating monsters and orphans of chaos. Sometimes we can't help being the victims of fasci-capitalism. We're all just scraping to get by without losing our heads. Vincent's final words to Electra read doubly heartbreaking today.", "I've gone through this entire series and the movie twice in the span of less than a month, and I'm about to go through it a third time. It's one of the quintessential pieces of anime that opened a floodgate for me into an obsession for an entire medium. Endlessly rewatchable, and still a fantastic display of action and artistic achievement.", '"Sorry I'm just a bounty hunter, i don't really give a damn what happens to the world" - Spike
Ein is such a good doggy. 
The animation and music is out of this world and in my opinion a step up from the show (which I love and rate a 4.5). I didn't emotionally connect to the story QUITE as much as I hoped but even with that considered this is an exceptional film that is well paced and engaging. It's hard to make a movie based on a TV show but this is an effective effort that I will revisit.', 'For having just finished the show I will incapsulate this movie into my review. This has so much ramshackle material of bounty hunters with different aesthetics and a talent for always being impoverished that is shown throughout with the food that they eat yet also have so much earnestness that obvious it was an inspiration for "Firefly" but somehow this actually earns more stripes for it's nature and that surprises me considering I came to this just now and enjoyed "Firefly" when it came out. I feel like this show is an emotional rubik's cube with easy understanding of it's manipulation but complex nature to know how it works.', 'The decision to slot this plot-wise in-between episodes 22 and 23 is a smart one, because by placing it in the middle but after the characters have a rapport with one another, you kind of get "peak 
Bebop
 gang" and in many ways that's really what the show is about. Placing the movie after the series would have made the ending of the show feel cheapened and lose a lot of its bittersweetness, and placing it before the series would have been interesting but without the balance that Faye and Ed bring to the group (and no adorable Ein either!). In this sense, I'd like to see more anime movies that do a similar thing of essentially being just another‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: A Man and a¬†Woman
Text:
A man and a woman meet by accident on a Sunday evening at their childrens‚Äô boarding school. Slowly, they reveal themselves to each other, finding that they have something deeply in¬†common.
["French cinema is truly one of humanity's greatest gifts to the world", 'Woman sends a "U Up?" telegram and man drives 3,000 miles to have sex.
No but actually... I'm FUCKING WRECKED AFTER THIS MOVIE. Good night.', 'Such prowess, such poetic beauty ‚Äî the pure essence of love, wrapped in an intermittent whisper between memory and hope.
The cinematic beauty of the film is very distinctive, but its aesthetic grounder arises, paradoxically, from limitation. The choice to alternate between black-and-white and color, often interpreted today as a stylistic decision, was in fact born out of a lack of budget to film the entire work in color. For me, this practical limitation transforms into an act of pure poetry: the black-and-white aligns with melancholy and nostalgia, while the color highlights moments when the present comes alive, as if emotion itself had the power to bring color to the world. This accidental convergence of necessity and art reveals an‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Born in¬†Flames
Text:
In near-future New York, ten years after the ‚Äúsocial-democratic war of liberation,‚Äù diverse groups of women organize a feminist uprising as equality remains¬†unfulfilled.
["Democratic socialism will not save us.
Inspired by Marxist writings on women's issues (Borden is not specific about which ones), this film posits a democratic socialist United States and explores the idea of an incomplete revolution. It's interesting to note that director Lizzie Borden identifies as an anarcha-feminist; aspects of the film feel critical of the state to some extent, but other aspects reflect a Marxist Leninist understanding of the need for fighting chauvinism. A critique of social democracy as being unfit to address sexism, racism, and homophobia makes sense; any political approach which insufficiently addresses imperialism is doomed to uphold all of those and more. In the film, it never addresses this aspect of social democracy, instead taking an‚Ä¶ 
more", "You could just scroll a feminist call to revolutionary action across a blank screen with no soundtrack at all, and I think I'd give it 5 stars. It gets me pumped. It makes me happy to know someone made a film about this. It makes me feel not so alone and powerless to see so much effort put into something like this. But on top of being a fierce, powerful message, it's also well thought out. It's illustrative. It's interesting.
Since this isn't merely a textual call to action, but an actual film, I actually love it more. I am gushing over this. This is gushing. It illustrates class struggle, feminist struggles, and racial struggles through familiar lenses, but also‚Ä¶ 
more", 'An angry, funny, aggressively rhetorical and didactic metadoc, Peter Watkins-style, about an illusion of socialist utopianism deployed as a pacifying distraction of the patriarchy! A totally tantalizing idea I'd never given much attention to, but here we see multiple splinter collectives of variously disenfranchised ethnic, gender, and social groups battling in the hearts, streets, and especially screens of a fictional future society that's still subject to white, male, corporate-controlled media and power structures. Conflicting "progressive" agendas (from grassroots "Take Back the Night"-style protest to outright terrorism) struggle for dominance. Truly a seminal piece of revolutionary art. See this awesome movie.']

Title: Rolling Thunder Revue: A Bob Dylan Story by Martin¬†Scorsese
Text:
Part documentary, part concert film, part fever dream, this film captures the troubled spirit of America in 1975 and the joyous music that Dylan performed during the fall of that¬†year.
['Even after 45 years, no one can agree on why Bob Dylan called that tour ‚ÄúRolling Thunder Revue‚Äù ‚Äî it might be one of those things that only gets more elusive over time. The ‚ÄúRevue‚Äù part is easy enough: Dylan was famous enough to do what he wanted, but too frazzled to do it alone, so he extended an open invitation to the best minds of his generation to join him for a series of intimate shows across the United States; it would be a folk happening and a freewheeling gypsy caravan and a chance for a busful of beautiful seekers to go out and look for whatever it was they were trying to find.
The reason for ‚ÄúRolling Thunder,‚Äù‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Personal taste, interest, preference, the like would leave me pretty biased in favor of this. Putting all that aside, it is the best film I‚Äôve ever seen.', '"Life isn't about finding yourself or finding anything; life is about creating yourself and creating things."
Disclaimer:
 When it comes to Bob Dylan, I don't have an objective bone in my body‚Äîonly wonder and gratitude. Though if you're looking for criticism, I will have a bit for Martin Scorsese down the line.
I think it would be instructive to begin with a thumbnail description of the actual Rolling Thunder Revue's celebrated first leg because Martin Scorsese's 
Rolling Thunder Revue: A Bob Dylan Story by Martin Scorsese
\xa0intentionally (and mimetically) obfuscates the subject at its heart. Somewhat crestfallen by his lucrative but dispassionate 1974 return to national touring (with The Band) following eight years off the road, Bob Dylan approached friend and‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Flight of the¬†Navigator
Text:
12-year-old David is accidentally knocked out in the forest near his home, but when he awakens eight years have passed. His family is overjoyed to have him back, but is just as perplexed as he is that he hasn‚Äôt aged. When a NASA scientist discovers a UFO nearby, David gets the chance to unravel the mystery and recover the life he¬†lost.
["This doesn't make a lick of sense, the kid is charitably speaking a total charisma-free brat, and the horrible psychic trauma this whole thing would have inflicted on this entire family is tantalizingly shrugged off. Loaded with incredible practical VFX. 7-year-old me wanted nothing more than to live this movie. There's even a part where he gets to go live at NASA and they give him his own room, a waitress with a robot, a TV, and a bunch of toys. He seems not that into it!", 'Hearing Pee Wee voicing this alien spaceship was a trip. I just love how they practically told Paul to play his famed character. I mean, they sort of came up with some cheap excuse to make it feel less out of place, but that was so hysterical. I wonder how kids must have felt coming into this movie exciting; they would get one of their favorite characters voicing this alien, and what would you know, they literally had one of their favorites voicing this alien.
As for the movie, this was a real great time. It lost me towards the second half, where it‚Äôs basically Paul just riffing and Cramer just fooling around. The first part is stronger and the‚Ä¶ 
more', "A true childhood staple of mine. I somehow never owned this over the years so I treated myself to the blu ray. I remember watching this countless times on TV in my youth. I think it used to play on the Sunday night Disney programming way back when. Pure 80s nostalgia and a perfect Sunday afternoon flick. 
This viewing held up pretty well. I'm always taken back to how much the plot messed me up as a youngin. The idea of coming home and finding different people living in your home was horrifying. And then finding out your family is 8 years older but you are the same little twerp?? Fuhgetta bout it! 
This movie is mad cheesy but it's‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: La Terra¬†Trema
Text:
In rural Sicily, the fishermen live at the mercy of the greedy wholesalers. One family risks everything to buy their own boat and operate¬†independently.
['I really don‚Äôt like to take an artist‚Äôs sexuality into consideration when looking at their work, simply because I believe art comes through a person, not from a person, from a place where we‚Äôre all 
one
 and without an ego. But there‚Äôs something to be said about the way Visconti, who was gay, chooses, lights, portrays men. And not in a superficial way‚Äîhis characters are rarely drop dead gorgeous, nor does he use the camera to make love to them or anything like that. I really don‚Äôt quite know how to put it, other than maybe, just maybe, he understands men a little better, he really shows them from the inside out. And there‚Äôs something about the way he carries them into my world that moves me‚Äîwith a raw gentleness, and they always stay.', 'Luchino Visconti‚Äôs ‚ÄúLa Terra Trema‚Äù vibrates with the raw potency and passion of male bodies in motion.\xa0
Fully departing from the trappings of his noble upbringing as the son of a Milanese Duke; Count Visconti‚Äôs ‚ÄúTerra‚Äù is a communist outcry of a film. \xa0
But Visconti is not so wanton as to leave all beauty behind for politics. He frames the fishermen subjects of ‚ÄúTerra‚Äù with a sense of classical sensuality.\xa0
With an entire cast comprised of Sicilian non actors, Visconti - most famous for the luxuriated wealth of his latter works - is content to act here as more of a detached witness to his subjects‚Äô meagre lives. Each day, market, and man - fades into the next.\xa0
The‚Ä¶ 
more', "***One of the best 150 films I have ever seen.***
A longstanding monument of neo-realism made by an aspiring Italian communist that openly criticized neoliberalism in the world's economy. Labor exploitation has always been a politically important issue. La Terra Trema: Episodio del Mare is a controversial and extraordinary masterpiece, even visually, with the powerful presence of the sea as an inert character, as a prophet of upcoming misfortunes. Nature is not the one to blame, or destiny, for that matter; it's the economic structure.
100/100"]

Title: Cold¬†Fish
Text:
Shamoto runs a small tropical fish shop. When his daughter Mitsuko is caught shoplifting at a grocery store a man named Murata steps in to settle things between the girl and the store manager. Murata also runs a tropical fish shop and he and Shamoto soon become friendly. However Murata hides many dark secrets behind his friendly¬†face.
['Japan‚Äôs 
Breaking Bad
 but with fish instead of meth', "Welp, this is it. I've found it. 
Sono's best work.
 I know it's too early to say, given that I'm only knee deep into his crazy filmography. But as of now, I can't possibly imagine anything that can top this. If Sono were to make something even funnier, darker, or generally greater than 
Cold Fish

Again, Sono mixed all kinds of genres together as if he's making a cinematic fruit punch. To some it may be considered tedious, to me I see it as his invaluable trademark. The mood shifts constantly and it's almost impossible to predict what will happen in the next scene. From the first murder down the daughter's‚Ä¶ 
more", "Welp, I guess I'm done with other directors now. SONO 4 LYFE!!!!
In my 
review
 for 
Suicide Club

review

In an interview, Sono once said that he disliked the films of Yasujiro Ozu, and that he would classify himself‚Ä¶

Title: Summer of Soul (‚Ä¶Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be¬†Televised)
Text:
During the same summer as Woodstock, over 300,000 people attended the Harlem Cultural Festival, celebrating African American music and culture, and promoting Black pride and unity. The footage from the festival sat in a basement, unseen for over 50 years, keeping this incredible event in America‚Äôs history lost ‚Äî until¬†now.
['Lin-Manuel Miranda simply will not leave me alone', 'Black is beautiful, black people are beautiful, and this film is one of the greatest testaments to that beauty I have ever seen.', "The same summer as Woodstock 1969 a series of free concerts were held in Harlem's Mount Morris park that featured: Nina Simone, Sly and the Family Stone, BB King, The Staples Singers, Mahalia Jackson, Stevie Wonder, Gladys Knight and The Pips, and David Ruffin among many others and was attended an audience of 300,000 black people. The fact that footage of this concert was lost in someone's basement for fifty years and that virtually no one, save for the attendees remembers that this took place is a stunning cultural atrocity. It's astonishing if you go back and watch the Woodstock concert film or Gimme Shelter, just how unlistenable and trash most of the performances were compared to this show of‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: The Postman Always Rings¬†Twice
Text:
A married woman and a drifter fall in love, then plot to murder her¬†husband.
['tfw the postman rings twice', 'Loove Lana Turner in this!!
Having nearly nothing to do with the postman ringing twice, I think a better name for this film would have been
\xa0Curiosity Killed the Cat
. It‚Äôs a pretty classic noir set up, a guy with nowhere to go and a femme fatale with someone she needs to knock off. This one works so well on the chemistry between Turner and Garfield. Unlike double indemnity which it is often compared to, they seem like there are feelings between them going both ways, as opposed to the femme fatale just using the protagonist to get what she wants.
I love the noir format, when done right, it seems like it never loses me. It is only frustrating that‚Ä¶ 
more', '"Do you love me so much that nothing else matters?"
Driven to dangerously myopic levels of forbidden passion, hapless drifter Frank (John Garfield) and closeted hellcat Cora (Lana Turner) are undone by formulating, executing and attempting to conceal a haphazard murder under the guise of an accidental death.\xa0
The Postman Always Rings Twice
 marks a rather encouraging introduction to filmmaker Tay Garnett, who worked in various capacities for such luminaries as Hal Roach, Mack Sennett, Frank Capra and Cecil B. De Mille before launching his own directorial career in the 1930s. Though James M. Cain's scandalous 1934 potboiler of same name had already formed the basis for two screen adaptations, Garnett's 1946 version‚Äîscripted by Harry Ruskin and Niven Busch‚Äîwas the‚Ä¶

Title: No Half Measures: Creating the Final Season of Breaking¬†Bad
For the¬†Birds
Text:
One by one, a flock of small birds perches on a telephone wire. Sitting close together has problems enough, and then comes along a large dopey bird that tries to join them. The birds of a feather can‚Äôt help but make fun of him - and their clique mentality proves embarrassing in the¬†end.
['Three minutes of sheer stupidity. Brilliant.', 'Guess we all know where angry bird started!', 'Now this is a true underdog story. For real though, I think we all relate to the big bird in this short. He‚Äôs just trying to hang with his buds, but they want to kick him off. Then karma slaps them in the ass. I wish real life worked like that. Overall, it‚Äôs short, simple, and sweet, and that‚Äôs what I love about these shorts.']

Title: Sphere
Text:
A spacecraft is discovered on the floor of the Pacific Ocean, presumed to be at least 300 years old and of alien origin. A crack team of scientists and experts is assembled and taken to the Habitat, a state-of-the-art underwater living environment, to¬†investigate.
["I love movies. You can just make up anything and that's your movie.", 'I thoroughly enjoyed the stupidity this movie displays while trying so desperately to be intellectual sci-fi. Samuel L. Jackson visits the sphere, starts acting erratically while eating eggs, and then Sharon Stone writes in her notebook ‚ÄúAre eggs spheres?‚Äù', "I'd like to make the case for 'Sphere'.\xa0\nThe film has somewhat of a poor reputation and legacy. It suffered from numerous problems throughout its production including a jumble of script revisions; budgetary handwringing that setback the shooting process; and some obligatory reshoots. And it still went onto become a commercial and critical failure. It never found cult status with future audiences and has largely been forgotten in the years since, which is a real shame because I think 'Sphere' is one of the most interesting mainstream sci-fi releases of the 1990s. It is frightening, suspenseful, thought provoking, and uncommonly weird in all the right ways, with a great cast of A-list actors bringing the (admittedly) hokey B-movie premise to‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

['For 2 hours I am 11 years old again and Josh Hutcherson is the love of my life.', "Flipped's little brother", '"Love is an ugly, terrible business practiced by fools. It\'ll trample your heart and leave you bleeding on the floor. And what does it really get you in the end? Nothing but a few incredible memories that you can\'t ever shake. The truth is, there\'s gonna be other girls out there. I mean, I hope. But I\'m never gonna get another first love. That one is always gonna be her."']

Title: House

: 10/60
There are so many things to be fascinated by in this beautiful, wild movie, but two things really stick out to me. Obayashi talks about them in the interview on the Criterion materials:
One is the war and the atomic bombings. Obayashi is originally from Hiroshima. He says, quietly and candidly, that most his friends didn't survive the bombings, as a child. The second is Obayashi's sense of how children view and experience the world. He talks about their easy attraction to the strange and mysterious. Where, he says, adults see

Title: Critters
Text:

["So...this may sound like midlife crisis crazy talk, but I've had it with here/where my life is at right now, and so I've come to a very important decision on where my journey is taking me:
Grovers Bend, Kansas.
I am serious. It looks amazing. I want E.T's mom to be my mom. I wouldn't even mind having to live on a farm because I would have an awkward Billy Zane to tell me about what life is like in the big city instead of make out with me. Billy Zane does not seem to want to make out with anyone in this movie. And that would be okay with me because he is not really my kind of thing.‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Look, I know it‚Äôs cliche to compare this thing to 
Gremlins
, but like‚Ä¶come on‚Ä¶it‚Äôs pretty much just 
Gremlins
. A lighthearted horror-comedy about a bunch of silly little delinquent alien furballs terrorizing simple middle America townsfolk? They get hungry and you aren‚Äôt supposed to let them eat or else things get worse? They have sharp teeth and an evil laugh and roll around in balls like Sonic the Hedgehog on bath salts? It‚Äôs 
Gremlins

As is that ‚ÄòPower of the Night‚Äô song which someone somewhere thought was so good they had to play it like eight times throughout the movie. Sure could‚Äôve used a hell of a lot more action, though. Less antagonistic porcupine behavior, more devouring young Billy Zane in a barn. Notes to live by for any movie.
Best of: Creature Features', 'Small town 50‚Äôs sci fi beamed Into the 80‚Äôs is one of my favorite things, and 
Critters
\xa0is just that‚Äîcomplete with a proto slingshot-wielding bart simpson, bounty hunters, Johnny steele, M. Emmit Walsh, billy zane, all star 80‚Äôs mom Dee Wallace, and troublemaking Critters doing what they do best.
One of the movies my childhood friend charley and I would watch every weekend when my folks would drop me off at his house so they could go party and get loaded with his parents. Between this and 
Tremors
\xa0I can‚Äôt really say I know which one we watched more, but I can tell you that we wore out both tapes, and my deep love for 50‚Äôs sci-fi snorting lines of 80‚Äôs aesthetic‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The¬†Counselor

more', '"We will not be diminished by the brevity of our lives."

I've never fully bought into McCarthy's mercilessly cruel & fatalistic worldview, but something about the aggressively masculine, contradictory and primal existentialism he wanders here, as unsubtle as it is, is deeply fascinating to me. And accompanied by some of Ridley Scott's most vivid, richly detailed mise-en-sc√®ne & a lush sense of style that can explode with grotesquerie when required, capturing the way money is used as a bad paint job on a world that more closely resembles a garbage dump filled with corpses. Title: Gold Diggers of¬†1933
Text:

['"What's the show about?"
"It's all about the Depression."
"... We won't have to rehearse that."', 'Live your life like it‚Äôs a Pre-Code movie.', "It's arguably the most heightened and heartbreaking evocation of the Great Depression ever filmed: an unforgettable portrait of a people betrayed by their country, gripped by a crisis not of their making, disillusioned, dehumanised and dismissed. Rife with righteous fury, dripping with anguish, and populated by marching masses almost zombified by hopelessness, it's a piece of socialist art pitched somewhere between poetry and propaganda. And it's a number in an otherwise innocuous Hollywood musical from 1933.
For most of its running time, Gold Diggers of 1933 is a standard crowd-pleaser. Though its first half has numerous wry references to poverty, one chilling line from Aline MacMahon about the lengths to which out-of-work chorus girls might be forced to go, and‚Ä¶

Title: After the¬†Hunt

['kind of obsessed with how much this barely works', 'shocked at how much of 
The Social Network
‚Äôs DNA is all over this', 'One of the stupidest scripts of 2025.
The whole film presents itself as a weighty declaration, circling around delicate themes as if mere proximity to them could grant it moral and intellectual authority. What is born, however, is not depth but total dispersion: a collage of ideas, none of them developed with the clarity or focus necessary to truly matter. The result is a work desperate to convince its importance, yet increasingly unsure of what it actually wants to say.
The cast is forced to grapple with dialogues that twist them into knots, caught between artificial gravity and utter incoherence. I‚Äôm not saying there‚Äôs no proof of their competence, but the script abandons them, making them seem terrible, delivering lines‚Ä¶

Title: The Human Condition III: A Soldier‚Äôs¬†Prayer
Text:
After the Japanese defeat to the Russians, Kaji leads the last remaining men through Manchuria. Intent on returning to his dear wife and his old life, Kaji faces great odds in a variety of different harrowing circumstances as he and his fellow men sneak behind enemy¬†lines.
['There‚Äôs a scene about 515 minutes into this nine and half hour movie where our protagonist, Kaji - having fully made the transition from manager of a Japanese prison labor camp to POW of a Soviet prison labor camp - comes before the Russian management of the camp to answer for his attempts at democratizing the POWs. 
Kaji is, as far as he knows himself, a socialist. Many times throughout the six part filmic cycle he is referred to as a ‚ÄúRed‚Äù. At the very least he‚Äôs actively against the monarchical fascism of his own country, Japan, who he has been forced to go to war for. But here in the labor camp he has seen none of the class‚Ä¶ 
more', "The Human Condition I = Schindler's List
The Human Condition II = Full Metal Jacket
The Human Condition III = Saving Private Ryan, 1917, The Pianist
Watch the whole trilogy in one day, what a ride! what a day!", "All things must end...
And so it goes without saying that we should not expect to come through this epic tale without the weight of existence bearing down upon us. Through Kaji we celebrate the stoic and prevailing strength of ideals, the resonance of a resilient conscience and voice for truth and compassion. Described by a Japanese villager as a ''Paragon of virtue'', Kaji's quest to reunite with his love Michiko is an all conquering force that echoes right past the films final frame.
This final chapter sees Kaji leading his remaining followers, and other Japanese soldiers he meets along the way through dense forest, fighting for survival against Russian troops and Chinese militia and avoiding enemy capture, ultimately leading‚Ä¶

Too ambitious for its own good with a very simple central theme hidden underneath a huge amount of unnecessary and pseudo-intellectual babble.

These things could have provided for a fantastic and rich film. But this film's potential strength is buried under an avalanche of philosophical ideas, scientific theories and stylistic overkill, leaving a film only to be admired for its ambition, even though it is in the end an empty shell.

['Bergman relaxes a bit with this one and sticks to more easygoing topics like suicide, incest, mental illness, and hatred. Title: The¬†Return
Text:

['A real masterpiece of nostalgia for childhood, even though it‚Äôs someone else‚Äôs.
The sound design and music and cinematography bring me back.
Love this movie.', 'This was probably one of my most anticipated watches. In a very short span of time, director Andrey Zvyagintsev has gone from being unknown to me, to becoming one of my favourite directors; an auteur rubbing shoulders with the likes of Kubrick and Malick. This is pretty amazing considering I‚Äôve only seen two of his films. I‚Äôm happy to say that The Return, a favourite of many of my LB friends, only further cements that position.
What I appreciate about Zvyagintsev the most is his deft skill at subtly weaving context into his very straight forward, and narratively economical, stories. Rarely is the symbolism worn on its sleeve, but rather quietly hinted it; so quietly in some cases that you‚Äôre‚Ä¶

Title: Syndromes and a¬†Century
Text:
A story about director Apichatpong Weerasethakul‚Äôs parents who were both doctors, and his memories of growing up in a hospital¬†environment.
["I'm continually impressed with how Weerasethakul resists the dogmatism of his dichotomies. Mostly a film about the differences between rural and urban life, and coming out in the end on the side of rural (or at least on the fusion of rural and urban that a robust public park system provides), he nevertheless finds room for nice moments of fellowship in the antiseptic Bangkok hospital (the ladies with liquor in the leg, the young man who plans to have the same life as everyone else, except it will take one year longer) as well as failed interpersonal connections out in the country (the several unfulfilled romances circling Dr. Toey and of course the legend of the farmers who find gold‚Ä¶ 
more", 'If 
"it's a film about heart,"
 according to Joe, and 
"about feelings that have been forever etched in the heart,"
 then what does it mean that these feelings transfer between lives? The obvious is the implication that the 'heart' is something which lives outside our physical body, able to move from one life to the next so as to be 'forever'. Reincarnation is a natural conclusion and is one that Joe himself happy accedes; it is a major theme across his films after all.
It's not that simple though, and if it were then this film would suffer for it. The dualism-repetition in the film's structure escapes easy explication, unable to be precisely defined but nonetheless a presence. It exists,‚Ä¶ 
more', "I have a hard time writing things about this film because for the most part I don't understand it, but then I stare at it as it happens to me and I feel like I do. Feels like something that's just under the surface, too murky to see, even when squinting, what the figure is, a curious black hole in a ventilation pipe, a tiny little version of the tallest tree, a"]

Title: Love¬†Letter
Text:
Hiroko attends the memorial service of her fianc√©, Itsuki Fujii, who died in a mountain-climbing incident. Although Itsuki‚Äôs mother says that their old house is gone, Hiroko records the address listed under his name in his yearbook and sends him a letter. Surprisingly, she receives a reply, and discovers it came from his old classmate, a girl who also happens to be called Itsuki¬†Fujii.
['„ÅäÂÖÉÊ∞ó„Åß„Åô„ÅãÔºüÁßÅ„ÅØ ÂÖÉÊ∞ó„Åß„Åô
Memories are, for the lack of a better word, strange. While the facts and chronology stay unchanged, one can feel differently or discover something new in the process of remembering the past. Memories can often be a source of sadness and regrets, especially when death becomes one of the facts. But we live on memories. We need them to go forward, to grow and to be.', "You can grow with someone as you live together, learning new things about them which never seems to end. But once they're gone, that process stops, and it's almost like their existence becomes frozen in time. Life goes on, and maybe you go on, but they can't; they are what your last memories of them are, your last image of them are, in stasis.
Love Letter
 sees a woman experiencing this, her fianc√© gone and her unable to move on. Thankfully, fortuitousness is free when it comes to cinema, and she meets another woman who used to not just know her fianc√© and not just share his name, she also shares the widow's looks. Fortuitousness should start charging.
As the‚Ä¶ 
more", 'You whisper someone's name and it fades away in the crowd. "It might be her", you think, but she doesn't notice you in the sea of people. Isn't that how memories are? Fractured and fragmented, slowly dissolving and mixing with each other with the passage of time? The further we move away from the past, the deeper they burrow in the far reaches of our hearts. Almost all of them perish, except the most important ones. Among the never-ending line of blurred faces and forgotten names, the select few memories which survive without getting diluted ought to be something special, right? Or is it that they revolve around someone special? 
If it's someone special, even the most mundane experiences of‚Ä¶ 
more']

["Elizabeth Olsen is so adorable it's terribly distracting.", 'things to take away from this film:
1) elizabeth olsen deserves the whole world (but I already knew that)

(2022 update: i wrote this review 5 years ago and i need everyone to know in the present jason sudeikis is nasty man and i do not like him anymore)', 'is there a single person out there that doesn‚Äôt have an insane amount of chemistry with jason sudeikis...... that charismatic bastard....', 'i wanted to like this one way more than i did
but elizabeth olsen shines like a million stars and she deserves the entire world. someone give it to her', 'This script was written by a machine learning algorithm.', 'this was nice if a little predictable but i nearly burst into tears at the end ahhh', 'was this good or am i just in love with lizzie?', 'almost nothing about this movie is profound but idc jason sudeikis and elizabeth olsen hot', '"
We're all so frightened by time, the way it moves on and the way things disappear.
"
Well this was a touching little film. Starts off shaky, but once the main plot's made clear it gets better. Predictable, yes, and a story of a father and son being estranged is nothing new. Regardless, I felt genuine emotion between them and it was sweet seeing their journey to mend what's broken.\xa0
Really good performances from Ed Harris and Jason Sudeikis. The script really has TWO instances where Elizabeth Olsen is told she's really beautiful, why bother when we all know that!\xa0
"
We take pictures to stop time, to commit moments to eternity. Human nature made tangible.
"', 'introducing a new religion where we worship elizabeth olsen as she sits in a convertible with her hair flowing in the wind!', 'A really well done movie. The story has been done to death before and you can pretty much see every story beat coming from a mile away, but I was shocked at how much I ended up liking this. Harris, Sudekis and Olsen are all terrific in their roles, the film has a strong emotional core and quite a few parts in the third act really hit me. It might not be a home run but this is on Netflix right now and I would strongly recommend giving this a watch. Destined to be one of the most under-appreciated films of the year.', 'my new goal in life is to go on a road trip with lizzie before i die']

Title: Zero Dark¬†Thirty
Text:

["Five stars.
Fine, four and a half, because I know certainty freaks you guys out, but it's a five.", 'I mean the movie's entire thesis is that we were thirsty for revenge and we went to extreme lengths to get it. Eventually -- almost accidentally -- we got it. Then that 
sliver
 of "justice" irrevocably upended every single value we hold for ourselves, so now what? 
We did this shit, and this is what it means for us.', '‚ÄúNot a single scene is staged. ... Everything is genuine. And there is no tendentious commentary for the simple reason that there is no commentary at all. It is history‚Äîpure history.‚Äù

These facts are based on an overwhelming compilation of authentic evidence and testimony. My picturization of history as it happens requires, therefore, no apology, no defense, no 'explanation.'"

Title: Hold Your¬†Breath

Title: Get¬†Carter
Text:
Jack Carter is a small-time hood working in London. When word reaches him of his brother‚Äôs death, he travels to Newcastle to attend the funeral. Refusing to accept the police report of suicide, Carter seeks out his brother‚Äôs friends and acquaintances to learn who murdered his sibling and¬†why.
['Lmao England is the grimmest place on Earth. This can be summed up by the very last scene of this movie which depicts what I can only describe as a reverse ski-lift, neatly ferrying giant piles of coal slag down a hill and dumping them directly in the ocean.\nUPDATE - thinking about the very first scene of this movie, where Michael Caine and several of the ugliest men in history all wear suits, suck on big cigars and watch still pornographic images together in a Kodak projector slide show while leering and saying shit like "that geezer\'s got his socks on."', "Stone-cold revenge neo-noir filmed with a filthy, brute force single-mindedness that serves Michael Caine's intensely horny and sadistic mission to steamroll/punish just about everyone he comes into contact with. Pure shot of mud-caked nihilism.", "Classic British gangster film without which Guy Ritchie could not exist and Quentin Tarantino would be significantly different. Michael Caine is precisely as sympathetically psychotic as the best of Scorsese's villain-protagonists. Impeccable pacing and escalation. Some interesting framing choices including an abundance of obstructed close ups (vaguely reminiscent of Wong Kar-Wai). Classy parallel editing especially between a speeding car and a sexual encounter. Controversial film about the tragic irony of vengeance which pushed the boundaries of on-screen sex and violence. A bit slow and convoluted, but rewarding for attentive audiences."]

On one hand, you‚Äôve got Michael Keaton in fine form, wryly bringing John Hughes‚Äô screwball antics to life and surely putting a smile on even the toughest customer‚Äôs face. Title: The¬†River
Text:
Director Jean Renoir‚Äôs entrancing first color feature‚Äîshot entirely on location in India‚Äîis a visual tour de force. Based on the novel by Rumer Godden, the film eloquently contrasts the growing pains of three young women with the immutability of the Bengal river around which their daily lives unfold. Enriched by Renoir‚Äôs subtle understanding and appreciation for India and its people, The River gracefully explores the fragile connections between transitory emotions and everlasting¬†creation. √ó
['For my money, this movie has the best ever voiceover narration, the best ever dance sequence, the best ever use of dissolves, cross-fades and fades to blacks, the best ever use of colour, and the best ever line of dialogue, to wit:
Valerie: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not crying because you are going. I‚Äôm crying because It is going.‚Äù
Captain John: ‚ÄúIt? What it?‚Äù
Valerie: ‚ÄúThis. Being together, in the garden. All of us happy, and you with us here. I didn't want it to change‚Ä¶ and it's changed. I didn't want it to end‚Ä¶ and it's gone. It was like something in a dream. Now you've made it real. I didn't want to be real."', "This deserves a better review than I can write tonight. 
Every narrative thread in this film reinforces the central themes of death and rebirth. There are several tales here, most centered on the one-legged Captain John. He is the subject of desire for several of the young ladies living in the area to him as he stays with his cousin, Mr. John. Each of these plotlines culminates in pivotal moments that Captain John describes as moments of either death or birth. As we watch him struggle with his injury and bemoan his outsider status, we see his journey along with the others toward completing a cycle. 
Without going into a synopsis of the film, suffice it to say that there's‚Ä¶

Title: Sin¬†City
Text:
Welcome to Sin City. This town beckons to the tough, the corrupt, the brokenhearted. Some call it dark‚Ä¶ Hard-boiled. Then there are those who call it home ‚Äî Crooked cops, sexy dames, desperate vigilantes. Some are seeking revenge, others lust after redemption, and then there are those hoping for a little of both. A universe of unlikely and reluctant heroes still trying to do the right thing in a city that refuses to¬†care.
['Adapting a comic book series on the film canvas is one thing but translating it into a live-action motion picture in a manner that it brings the comic book to life in an almost literal sense while mirroring the events of the novel frame to frame is something truly extraordinary. And that's what 
Sin City
 is; something never done before, something never seen before & something never experienced before.
Based on Frank Miller's graphic novel series of the same name, 
Sin City
 is presented in 3 primary chapters (
That Yellow Bastard
, 
The Hard Goodbye
 & 
The Big Fat Kill
), each lifted directly from the novel & is presented in a non-linear & overlapping order (unless you're watching the "Recut, Extended & Unrated" version). A non-related‚Ä¶ 
more', '"Care for a smoke?"
My (film noir-ish) reaction to the film-
Night time.
 A little after 8:00 PM.
Lousy dogs barking outside loud enough to be heard outside this lousy town, but they don't matter. At least not at the moment because I just got done revisiting a goddess...
She calls herself City...Sin City to be exact. She's not like any other of those comic broads you see in those graphic novels. I always thought graphic novel was just some artsy term for comic book, but I'm getting off topic. She isn't like some comic book broad. She IS a comic book broad. A goddess that leaped off the page and onto celluloid. A fantasy out of a dream and‚Ä¶ 
more', "merely duplicating the frames isn't sufficient to recontextualize Miller's frozen gravity, his temporal snapshots. all that's left is a fealty to his brutish, stupid masculinity. noir is more than black and white bleakness but Rodriguez never met an aesthetic he couldn't half-ass. nothing's worth doing if you can't greenscreen it in your garage."]

But\xa0\nI Know This Much Is True\xa0\nis without a doubt an utterly masterful adaptation of Wally Lamb‚Äôs novel and a work that once again shows why Cianfrance is one of the finest storytellers working today.', 'A real feel-good experience.']

With enormous cone-shaped heads, robotlike walks and an appetite for toilet paper, aliens Beldar and Prymatt don‚Äôt exactly blend in with the population of Paramus, N.J. But for some reason, everyone believes them when they say they‚Äôre from¬†France.
['If this movie came out today it would be hailed as a timely comedy about the immigrant experience in America and xenophobic government agents. Also, David Lynch wishes he could produce a body horror image as troubling as the sight of Beldar‚Äôs smooth, crevice-free ass. In conclusion, narfle the Garthok.', 'I‚Äôm just like \xa0the coneheads but instead of being an alien I‚Äôm just autistic', 'Best SNL movie. Hits me in all the feels. Had such a crush on Connie when I was a young cone. Love Chris Farley in this so much. Cried pretty much every time he was on screen. Just a cutie. Miss him every day.\nDon‚Äôt think it occurred to me until this watch that these characters have to be (at least subconsciously) Dan Aykroyd processing what it‚Äôs like being autistic, right? All the literal speak and social ineptitude. The difficulty with affection. The lack of facial expressions. The sensory stuff. Being good with tech. The food.']

Title: Jodorowsky‚Äôs¬†Dune
Text:
In 1974, Chilean-French director Alejandro Jodorowsky embarked on the quixotic project of adapting Frank Herbert‚Äôs influential novel Dune (1969) for the big screen. After investing two years, and millions of dollars, the gigantic project ended in failure; but the artists Jodorowsky brought together to carry it out continued to work together, and ended up laying the foundations for modern science fiction¬†cinema.
["Watching this I was initially intrigued and a little amused, but then became quickly and thoroughly pissed off. What little worth this documentary has as a showcase for Moebius and Christopher Foss's concept art just makes me wish I'd read a coffee table book instead; the rest of the doc, meanwhile, is devoted to telling us how brilliant, how ambitious, and how eccentric an artist Alejandro Jodorowsky really is. I swear, the filmmakers giving him a blow job would've been faster and certainly much cheaper. After 90 minutes of his pontificating, supplemented by hagiographic interviews with fans and collaborators, this supposed Great Visionary of Our Time just sounds like a self-aggrandizing blowhard asshole.
To paraphrase Francis Ford Coppola, the story‚Ä¶ 
more", '"I am not a normal person. 
I am living in a normal body, 
but my mind is not normal."
"To have hands, 
to have fingers, 
is weird. 
Real life is weird, 
to have fingers?"
"Five cats and a woman. 
That is all I need in life."
"Most directors make films with their eyes; 
I make films with my testicles."
Alejandro Jodorowsky may honestly 
be my favorite person in the world.', "I might be this movie's biggest fan. Looking over my colleagues' ratings and reviews on Letterboxd, I see a lot of unimpressed folks, and a fair number who downright hated this thing, and hated Jodorowsky. I find Jodorowsky an absolutely delightful storyteller (the Keith Carradine anecdote! Vitamin E!), but to each his own. Some critics I've read are particularly offended by the documentary's claims that his unfinished DUNE in some way inspired many great movies that followed, like ALIEN and the original STAR WARS. The film makes bogus claims and therefore cannot be trusted.
Jodorowsky's elaborate storyboard and concept art book may or may not have found its way into the hands of the creators of later movies. Either way,‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Neruda
Text:
It‚Äôs 1948 and the Cold War has arrived in Chile. In the Congress, prominent Communist Senator and popular poet Pablo Neruda accuses the government of betraying the Party and is stripped of his parliamentary immunity by President Gonz√°lez Videla. The Chief of Investigative Police instructs inspector √ìscar Peluchonneau to arrest the poet. Neruda tries to escape from the country with his wife, the painter Delia del Carril, but they are forced to go¬†underground.
['gael garc√≠a bernal: *breathes*
me: üëåüëÄüëåüëÄüëåüëÄüëåüëÄüëåüëÄ good shit go‡±¶‘Å sHitüëå thats ‚úî some goodüëåüëåshit rightüëåüëåthereüëåüëåüëå right‚úîthere ‚úî‚úîif i do ∆Ωa“Ø so my self üíØ i say so üíØ thats what im talking about right there right there (chorus:  ≥·∂¶·µç ∞·µó ·µó ∞·µâ ≥·µâ) mMMMM·é∑–úüíØ üëåüëå üëå –ùO0–û‡¨†OOOOO–û‡¨†‡¨†Oooo·µí·µí·µí·µí·µí·µí·µí·µí·µíüëå üëåüëå üëå üíØ üëå üëÄ üëÄ üëÄ üëåüëåGood shit', "Even in the moments when this doesn't quite work, Pablo Larrain's direction excels. 
Neruda 
 demonstrates Larrain's penchant for untraditional biopics in a way that is fresh and desperately needed. Similar to 
 Jackie
, this film concentrated on the more abstract elements of its subject's life, focusing on the intersection between art and politics, truth and fiction. Gael Garcia Bernal is great (of course), but it's Larrain's talent for capturing and crafting a story with the camera that makes this special. There were three particular sequences in this that left me in awe. 
The Q&A with Pablo & Gael after was nice and they've definitely seen each other's dicks.", "66/100
A.V. Club 
review
. Kinda wish Neruda himself barely figured in this, as the stretches that approximate a straight biopic are comparatively turgid. Everything involving the Pirandellian detective who pursues Neruda, on the other hand, positively sings‚Äîin large part because Garc√≠a Bernal is confident enough to do virtually nothing, allowing Larra√≠n to sculpt a void of a performance around his classically handsome features. What's more, Larra√≠n and his regular D.P., Sergio Armstrong, have found an arresting, uniquely digital analogue to 
noir
 shadows, creating silhouettes that look as if they're encased in crushed velvet. Scenes of Neruda declaiming the glories of Communism, or composing 
Canto General
 while in hiding, can't compete with the lush imagery and meta-textual playfulness that dominate the film when he's not around, even though Luis Gnecco deftly sidesteps all the Great Man pitfalls. Half masterpiece, half tolerable."]

Title: The Eternal¬†Daughter
Text:
An artist and her elderly mother confront long-buried secrets when they return to a former family home, now a hotel haunted by its mysterious¬†past.

Title: Hello, Goodbye, and Everything in¬†Between
Text:
Clare and Aidan, after making a pact that they would break up before college, find themselves retracing the steps of their relationship on their last evening as a couple. The epic date leads them to familiar landmarks, unexpected places, and causes them to question whether high school love is meant to¬†last.

Title: The Life and Death of Colonel¬†Blimp
Text:
General Candy, who‚Äôs overseeing an English squad in 1943, is a veteran leader who doesn‚Äôt have the respect of the men he‚Äôs training and is considered out-of-touch with what‚Äôs needed to win the war. But it wasn‚Äôt always this way. Flashing back to his early career in the Boer War and World War I, we see a dashing young officer whose life has been shaped by three different women, and by a lasting friendship with a German¬†soldier.
['The Archers really were that good, huh? I never expected this to be anything less than a masterpiece, but the sheer complexity of characterization on display here really floored me. I'm particularly taken with Anton Wolbrook's Theo Kretschmar-Schuldorff and his longer section on the loss of family, home and children at the onset of the second world war. He shakes and quivers, but tries to maintain his composure when he utters sarcastically that his children are "good nazi's". He failed as a parent here, because he couldn't keep his children away from the seduction of Hitler's evil, but moreso than that he failed as a military officer because in his eyes world war II would have never happened if he‚Ä¶ 
more', "one of the most sophisticated movies i've ever seen, both politically and aesthetically -- as a satire, i have a hard time thinking of an equal. a story which seems quintessentially english, but also subverts and challenges the notion of 'englishness' at every turn -- the mention of the british empire's boer concentration camps at the beginning is no accident, as candy's romanticism comes to clash with everything that the 'stately' notion of englishness carefully smooths over -- the techniques and evils of colonialism becomes the internalized logic of fascism, the hypocrisies of the english to criticize the germans when really they partake in the same disgusting philosophies -- but that's the states, not the individuals, the individual soldiers fighting‚Ä¶ 
more", "Part of The Archers Season - 1942 to 1957
Since I joined Letterboxd, I've only had reason to hit the 5 star button for a viewing of a film during my lifetime here on six occasions, and three of those were for films I'd seen before. Out of all them, I probably hit it for The Life And Death Of Colonel Blimp twice as quick as for any of the rest of them. What a wonderful, wonderful film.
I did a little bit of reading up about it beforehand as I really did not know anything about it all and I have to say that I was a little bit daunted by it before I started. Not because of its‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: David Byrne‚Äôs American¬†Utopia
Text:
A filmed version of David Byrne‚Äôs Broadway show, a unifying musical celebration that inspires audiences to connect to each other and to the global¬†community.
["feels reductive to just call david byrne a musician when i think he's really the world's greatest children's television host with a brain that probably functions like one of those extremely complicated million-gear machines you see in a children's book. he's raffi for adults. his work rides a very goofy line of earnest loving optimism and sarcastic cynical criticism, like an alien who doesn't understand why we do the things but has come to love our patterns all the same.
maybe i just think of his work as childish because it always makes me feel childlike; untethered and happy, swaddled in the comfy and smart way he speaks but encouraged by the exuberant, full and constructed feeling of his music‚Ä¶

The signature image from Jonathan Demme‚Äôs totemic concert documentary ‚ÄúStop Making Sense‚Äù finds Byrne getting lost inside his own comically large silver business suit; maybe it was a Kabuki-like expression of a man being swallowed alive by runaway capitalism, or maybe ‚Äî as Byrne maintains ‚Äî he just wanted to make it look like his head had shrunken down to a funny size.

Title: Blue¬†Collar
Text:
Fed up with mistreatment at the hands of both management and union brass, and coupled with financial hardships on each man‚Äôs end, three auto assembly line workers hatch a plan to rob a safe at union¬†headquarters.
['character in this named ‚ÄúDogshit Miller‚Äù and you‚Äôre telling me paul schrader isn‚Äôt one of the best screenwriters to ever do it?', 'Neck and neck with HALLOWEEN for best American film of 1978. Notable for being the knife handle to Carpenter‚Äôs blade. Fascinating in the way Schrader unreservedly sprays his venom at every institution and abstract concept he can think of: capitalism, management, unions, the justice system, technology. I wish the 70s were longer in part so we could have seen more films like this and fewer consumed by the gauzy, gauche excess of the decade that followed. With Schrader, the dingier (LIGHT SLEEPER; AUTOFOCUS; FIRST REFORMED), usually the better.', "Not only Schrader's best film but has the honor of being the only film to feature a dildo fight between Harvey Keitel and Richard Pryor."]

Title: Blue¬†Crush
Text:
Nothing gets between Anne Marie and her board. Living in a beach shack with three roommates, she is up before dawn every morning to conquer the waves and count the days until the Pipe Masters competition. Having transplanted herself to Hawaii with no one‚Äôs blessing but her own, Anne Marie finds all she needs in the adrenaline-charged surf scene - until pro quarterback Matt Tollman comes¬†along‚Ä¶

FACT!', 'we used to make movies like Blue Crush in this country']

Title: Clifford
Text:
When his brother asks him to look after his young son, Clifford, Martin Daniels agrees, taking the boy into his home and introducing him to his future wife, Sarah. Clifford is fixated on the idea of visiting a famed theme park, and Martin, an engineer who helped build the park, makes plans to take him. But, when Clifford reveals himself to be a first-rate brat, his uncle goes bonkers, and a loony inter-generational standoff¬†ensues.
['This movie is unhinged. Martin Short is a true psychopath, Charles Grodin is doing Joker before \nJoker\n, and the entire third act feels like it uses ‚Öî of the movie‚Äôs budget in a way I couldn‚Äôt have seen coming. There‚Äôs no resolution. Everyone just stops being insane. Incredible. As someone who grew up just thinking ‚Äúokay so he makes weird faces and people love it, I guess?‚Äù about Martin Short- I get it now! He‚Äôs Clifford!', 'I found this to be deeply perverse and upsetting', 'LOOK AT ME LIKE A HUMAN BOY']

Title: The Boy and the¬†Beast
Text:
Kyuta, a boy living in Shibuya, and Kumatetsu, a lonesome beast from Jutengai, an imaginary world. One day, Kyuta forays into the imaginary world and, as he‚Äôs looking for his way back, meets Kumatetsu who becomes his spirit guide. That encounter leads them to many¬†adventures.
['Director Mamoru Hosoda is a big talent no doubt, but the The Boy and the Beast was very disappointing. Not a bad movie, enjoyed the start and some other parts, the animation looks great, just let down by the story, the random mythology bit put me right off this. The Fantasy world was brilliant where animals rule, loved the monk pig, The Beast training scenes were funny, The films just goes downhill when it goes back to the human world. The fights scenes are surprising realistic. The dialog is awful, Lots of spoon-feeding of characters emotions. I had the same problems with Summer Wars, loved Wolf Children & The Girl Who Leapt Through Time. The Boy and the Beast lacks the impact and emotion of those two animation classic.', "I laughed, I cried, I smiled.
The Boy and the Beast surpassed every single one of my expectations, I adored this film. This is an emotional roller-coaster of a film, I cared, but not only that I cried, three times. The characters and their relationships felt so genuine that when they were in their worst moments, I felt legitimately bad for them and when they were in their best I smiled. This movie explores topics such as friendship, family, not knowing where you belong, etc. It's shockingly mature and it was wonderful handled. The animation is stunning, the music is beautiful, the story is heartbreaking and mature, the characters are fully developed, it's just fantastic. Within thirty minutes I knew that I was going to love this film and I sure as hell did. I didn't expect to give this movie five stars, but it left such an impact on me that I just have to. See this movie.", 'JUNIMATION II: F*** YEAH!
So this has been one of those films I‚Äôve been meaning to watch for a long time but for some reason, always forgot to put it in the queue or something.
And in many ways, it was as excellent as I expected. The premise and the world-building are great. Always love me as a student and master story, especially when the student is a bit of an a‚Äîhole and/or we have a reluctant master. And this one delivers on both. There are some pretty amusing bits, like when Kyuta starts mimicking Kumatetsu. The animation is great from the character design like the apomorphic bear human or the other animal humanoid creatures, the art design, what I‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Friday Night¬†Lights
Text:
A small, turbulent town in Texas obsesses over their high school football team to an unhealthy degree. When the star tailback, Boobie Miles, is seriously injured during the first game of the season, all hope is lost, and the town‚Äôs dormant social problems begin to flare up. It is left to the inspiring abilities of new coach Gary Gaines to instill in the other team members ‚Äì and, by proxy, the town itself ‚Äì a sense of self-respect and¬†honor.
['CW: racism, sexism, ableism, homophobia (implied?), capitalism, America
It's not even coded. It's not subtext. The final team to beat is "black." The film acknowledges this within the context of the story, but it doesn't acknowledge the full sociological or historical context of it. It doesn't seem to understand that posing the Panthers as a mostly white-led team desperately trying to win as underdogs against African-American non-characters is part of the tainted tapestry of American history, the densely woven narrative that has demonized and commodified African-American physicality for centuries. That the film frames these underdogs effectively as people to root for makes me uneasy. Further, the touching father-son drama between abused and abuser is horrifying in its emotional impact.
This‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Texas seems like a horrible place to live.', 'The 1988 Odessa Permian Panthers are the worst losers in the history of sports. Absolute bums with a Mickey Mouse schedule and a disgraceful performance in a Texas State Championship they only got into on a coin toss.']

Title: Popeye
Text:
Popeye is a super-strong, spinach-scarfing sailor man who‚Äôs searching for his father. During a storm that wrecks his ship, Popeye washes ashore and winds up rooming at the Oyl household, where he meets Olive. Before he can win her heart, he must first contend with Olive‚Äôs fianc√©,¬†Bluto.
['One of the weirdest things I've ever seen. It's barely a movie. It's like Robert Altman made 3 Women and kept looking at Shelley Duvall and saying to himself "God, DAMN that woman looks like Olive Oyl" and then he couldn't get it out of his head and it gave him bad dreams and he was begging his brain, "PLEASE, stop, I don't want to make a Popeye movie!" but his brain just kept showing Shelley Duvall going "Ohhhhhh!" in a high pitched voice and finally Robert Altmans therapist told him to just make the damn thing and he did it to make the nightmares go away... It's fuckin' weird, man.', 'The closest Hollywood has ever come to 
Playtime
. Confounding on the first 10 viewings, but fully becomes a masterpiece around viewing #50, by which time every single citizen of Sweethaven will feel like your friend. Shelley Duvall should have gone home with Mr. Oscar. The "Everything is Food" number is as good as cinema gets. The production ran out of money and so the last stretch admittedly suffers, but even when this movie isn't working it's still fun to spend time in.
The new Blu-Ray is stunning, showcasing Giuseppe Rotunno's cinematography like I've never seen before. Every shot is so full of detail that it actually hurts to watch a little.', 'Directed by Altman, written by my boy Jules Fieffer, great nonsense songs by Harry Nilsson like "Everything is Food", lots of great physical comedy, gags, pratfalls, things of that nature, great character actors like Ray Walston, Bill Irwin, Paul Dooley, Linda Hunt, Dennis Franz and Donald Moffit, a real life cartoon village built on Malta, Shelly Duval looking more like a real cartoon character than any performance in history. An absolute joy. It's disgustapatin' how disrespected this movie was.']

Title: The Fault in Our¬†Stars
Text:
Despite the tumor-shrinking medical miracle that has bought her a few years, Hazel has never been anything but terminal, her final chapter inscribed upon diagnosis. Title: Planes, Trains and¬†Automobiles
Text:
An irritable marketing executive, Neal Page, is heading home to Chicago for Thanksgiving when a number of delays force him to travel with a well meaning but overbearing shower curtain ring salesman, Del¬†Griffith.

Title: Army of¬†Darkness
Text:
Ash, a handsome, shotgun-toting, chainsaw-armed department store clerk, is time warped backwards into England‚Äôs Dark Ages, where he romances a beauty and faces legions of the¬†undead.
["Probably my favorite of Raimi's trilogy because the main character is at his most entertaining here, and while I find this one's insane tonal whiplash and absurd out-of-nowhere concepts to be utterly at odds with the previous two films, they're silly and distinct and memorable and fun enough to make this film the most consistently engaging out of the three to me.
...but enough about Spider-Man 3.", 'don‚Äôt know what it was about evil dead and evil dead 2 that made sam raimi look back at them and decide the only logical conclusion to the trilogy was to send ash to 1300 AD to fight a skeleton army but i absolutely love where his mind was at', '76

Title: Orpheus
Text:
A famous poet in postwar Paris, scorned by the Left Bank youth, is in love with both his wife Eurydice and a mysterious princess. Seeking inspiration, the poet becomes obsessed and follows the princess from the world of the living to the land of the¬†dead.
['a poet LITERALLY falling in love with death? the frenchest thing that has ever happened', 'It would make sense that everybody speaks french in hell', "80/100
Cocteau understands dreams, and he also understands how certain effects can be transporting even if they're transparent. The journey to the underworld, for example, plainly has Heurtebise standing motionless before a rear-projected, moving Orpheus, but knowing that doesn't make it seem any less uncanny. (Equally great: Orpheus asking Heurtebise why the latter's hair is blowing around when there's no wind, and being told it's a stupid question.) The oneiric quality beautifully serves Cocteau's inspired reinterpretation of the myth, in which one of the most powerful love stories of all time instead becomes a portrait of the artist's obsession with death, viewed through the rubble of WWII. As with 
Beauty and the Beast
, my only quibble, though a significant one,‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Session¬†9
Text:
Tensions rise within an asbestos cleaning crew as they work in an abandoned mental hospital with a horrific past that seems to be coming¬†back.
['‚ÄúI live in the weak and the wounded...doc.‚Äù
It‚Äôs a bit nerve-wracking to rewatch a film for the first time since creating your Letterboxd account and putting it in your top 4. Will it live up to that honor? Was it really 
that
 good or was it nostalgia? Was I high the first time I watched it? Probably, but still.
It‚Äôs been a few years since I watched this and over a year since I placed it in my top 4 so I was a little hesitant about rewatching it because I was worried it wouldn‚Äôt be the ‚Äúperfect time‚Äù for what I claim as one of my favorite movies. Well, all that worry was for nothing because, after this‚Ä¶ 
more', "You stick with this job too long, it'll mess you up man. It gets inside of you - the stress.
This is probably one of the strangest horror films I've ever seen. 
It's cheap looking but superbly acted and directed. 
It's got a cheesy setup but turns into something you don't expect. 
It's got Horatio Cane in a haunted asylum. 
Does it sound good already? Well, a lot of people would be inclined to disagree. But ignore those Netflix star ratings, because I think 
Session 9
 is a great little horror flick that I think is horribly underrated and unjustly criticized. Some of those complaints are valid but some I believe we're born out of viewers simply not getting what‚Ä¶ 
more", "40/100
Having frequently argued that horror movies are scarier when they leave rationality behind (and that recent celebrated horror films like 
The Babadook
 and 
Under the Shadow
 suffer from being so blatantly allegorical), I now find myself in the uncomfortable position of having to complain that a horror movie makes no damn sense. On the one hand, Anderson and Gevedon provide multiple red herrings, suggesting that the entire crew may be influenced by some malevolent entity (strongly implied, by both parallel editing and cheesily booga-booga sound design, to be released when Mike opens the box of session tapes). On the other hand, Gordon murders his family very early on‚Äîan act that's telegraphed so blatantly and 
repeatedly
 that nobody could possibly‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: The Bad and the¬†Beautiful
Text:
Told in flashback form, the film traces the rise and fall of a tough, ambitious Hollywood producer, Jonathan Shields, as seen through the eyes of various acquaintances, including a writer, James Lee Bartlow; a star, Georgia Lorrison; and a director, Fred Amiel. He is a hard-driving, ambitious man who ruthlessly uses everyone on the way to becoming one of Hollywood‚Äôs top movie¬†makers.
['It almost feels like even back then, Douglas was looking at his peers thinking, "I'm outlasting every last one of you pinheads. I'm hitting 100. I will be 
the
 oldest living legend someday."', 'Movies are made on emotion, but Hollywood consumes only a cannibalistic diet of its own hatred. Any love in the mix, comes up only as a vomit of bile.\xa0
Slammed between two bright musical comedy masterpieces; ‚ÄúAmerican in Paris‚Äù and ‚ÄúBand Wagon,‚Äù Vincente Minnelli created ‚ÄúThe Bad and the Beautiful,‚Äù one of the most vitriolic and self-loathing films ever made about filmmaking.\xa0
‚ÄúBad‚Äù is tale told in three part flashback; the account of Kirk Douglas as an ambitious producer who destroyed three relationships along with three lives, of the three people he once held most dear.\xa0
Douglas, ever at his best when he is playing the worst of humanity, is also at his most frustratingly manipulative in the part of‚Ä¶ 
more', '"Don't worry. Some of the best movies are made by people working together who hate each other's guts."
A big studio exec calls a writer, a director, and an actor into his office to pitch them a gig with a big producer they all hate. The director had his pet project, his cinematic baby, stolen out from under him; the actor was negged into a romance with him, after which he cheated on her; the writer's wife died on his watch, and he had his Hollywood breakout script overtaken and driven into the ground. "But, no!" the exec tells them. "Look closer! Can't you see how all these awful experiences brought you to where you are today?" 
The thesis here‚Ä¶ 
more']

This team of Dark Arts specialists must unravel the mystery of Earth‚Äôs supernatural plague and contend with the rising, powerful villainous forces behind the siege‚Äîbefore it‚Äôs too late for all of¬†mankind.
['just imagining alfred cleaning off the dozens of ‚Äúconstantine‚Äùs written on the walls', "Why have Batman be the one to assemble the team, when all he can do is basically just stand around and growl at all the supernatural stuff happening around him?\nThe best thing about this was having Matt Ryan back as Constatine. For that alone i'll give it three stars. Well that, and Swamp Thing!", 'Batman is HIM. Bro said "Boo" to a ghost.']
