Title: The Time to Live and the Time to¬†Die
Text:
An autobiographical film based on Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien‚Äôs memories of his youth growing up in Taiwan after emigrating from mainland¬†China.
["Boiled down to synopses, all coming-of-age films are effectively the same: initial confrontations with love, death and desires that shape a protagonist's relationship to the world. Yet Hou Hsiao-hsien's version of this story is so singular it is as if I'd never seen one of these films before. His sense of visual time-keeping is singular, turning what is on paper a simple conceit (returning to the same spots from different camera angles) into something ineffably complex and poetic. His sense of history is likewise all his own, managing to ground his avatar against a backdrop of major social changes while fixating him within a context that so many Hollywood films attempt and come off as maudlin and condescending. Hou's histories‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Some of the greatest films will make you feel right at home even though their settings are not exactly like your own. Culture specific as they may be, they have the sort of universality that can endear them to any person in any part of the world. They will make you feel nostalgic about times you have never lived through. The way they show life in all its pain and glory, through all the heartache and hopefulness, is downright magical. 
The Time to Live and the Time to Die
 performs this magic to perfection. It is a nearly unmatched Asian family portrait, perhaps only matched by the two best Edward Yang works.
What makes this all the more fascinating is‚Ä¶ 
more', "The movie begins with Hou's own voice recounting the story of his family's move from Mainland China first to Taiwan and then to the small southern town of Fengshan, spoken over a series of images that serve to familiarize us with the family, their home and its environs, elegantly setting the unhurried rhythm of the film that is to follow. The camera finally locates the ten or eleven year old Hou himself, known throughout the film by his nickname A-Ha, and tracks with him. Throughout the first half of the movie, A-Ha will occupy the center of the frame, the camera moving to keep its focus on the boy as he goes about his various adventures. In the second half,‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Conan the¬†Destroyer
Text:
Conan is commissioned by the evil queen Taramis to safely escort a teen princess and her powerful bodyguard to a far away castle to retrieve the magic Horn of Dagoth. Unknown to Conan, the queen plans to sacrifice the princess when she returns and inherit her kingdom after the bodyguard kills Conan. The queen‚Äôs plans fail to take into consideration Conan‚Äôs strength and cunning and the abilities of his sidekicks: the eccentric wizard Akiro, the warrior woman Zula, and the inept Malak. Together the hero and his allies must defeat both mortal and supernatural foes in this voyage to sword-and-sorcery¬†land. √ó
["With 
Conan the Barbarian
, John Milius made a great standalone film. It was, however, Conan in name only. It wasn't Robert E. Howard's creation at all. They could have called it something else entirely, and it still would have been a great film. Furthermore, while the literary incarnation of the character could have sustained a franchise, spanning dozens of films, Milius' take was really intended to be a one-and-done affair. However, this wouldn't stop Dino De Laurentiis from trying to cash in on the success of 
Barbarian
. He started off by making one of the best decisions ever. He brought in Roy Thomas and Gerry Conway to write the script, in an effort to bring Conan back to his literary‚Ä¶ 
more", "No masterpiece, but better than I remembered. DESTROYER actually doesn't make a great double feature with BARBARIAN; the first CONAN is a prehistoric melodrama with philosophical musings (plus graphic beheadings) while the sequel is much more of a children's adventure film with comedic interludes (plus graphic beheadings). When it's not being compared to BARBARIAN, though, I think it works pretty well. The action's solid, the fantasy elements are fun (and very comic book-y, no doubt because two of the CONAN comic writers, Gerry Conway and Roy Thomas, dreamed up the story), and the comedy is genuinely funny (Schwarzenegger's drunken acting is a particular highlight). 
The DVD I watched tonight looked like garbage but this thing was shot by Jack Cardiff; I bet the Blu-ray is gorgeous. Plus, Wilt Chamberlain plays a guy whose sole mission is to protect the virginity of a young girl, which is incredible casting.", 'Fight! - Stallone v. Schwarzenegger: A Rivalry of Muscular Proportions
So I always heard this sequel wasn‚Äôt that good, pretty much destroying (see what I did there) any chances of more sequels, though I believe 
Red Sonja
 counts as one? But yeah, some of the good stuff, like the great cinematography by the legendary Jack Cardiff, is great, particularly those landscape shots. The glossiness blends well with the fantasy of it all. The action and violence were pretty good. Lizard people were unexpected. Some of the production design was pretty nice. Olivia d‚ÄôAbo looks stunning. Arnie still delivers, though some of the magic seems to be gone. Grace Jones does well being feisty and kickass. Unfortunately, the story as a‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The Princess Switch: Switched¬†Again
Text:
When Duchess Margaret unexpectedly inherits the throne & hits a rough patch with Kevin, it‚Äôs up to Stacy to save the day before a new lookalike ‚Äî party girl Fiona ‚Äî foils their¬†plans.
['can‚Äôt wait for there to be so many sequels where it gets to a point the cast is entirely made up of vanessa hudgens', 'I SAY BRING ON THE PRINCESS SWITCH: TOKYO DRIFT!', 'The Princess Switch 4: Switch Squared\nit is the year 2057. there are hundreds of vanessa hudgens running around maldovia and no one knows where they keep coming from.\ni wait with baited breath to be saved from this hostile takeover.']

Title: The¬†Signal
Text:
On a road trip, Nic and two friends are drawn to an isolated area by a computer genius. When everything suddenly goes dark, Nic regains consciousness ‚Äì only to find himself in a waking¬†nightmare.
["Classic case of someone pretending to be smarter than he is, resulting in something painfully simple smothered in artsy fartsy tosspottery, i.e. wankism.
Vapid characters, nonsensical dialogue, no interesting central conflict to drive the story, poor acting, random slo-mo shots that serve no purpose other than to increase the running time and torment me longer, a plot that goes from being deliberately obtuse to stupendously dull, all leading to an ending that will only surprise you if you've never seen a film before (something I feel is the case for 90% involved in making this).
The Signal got on my tits.", "I'm still trying to figure out what the whole point of the movie actually was...", 'Looked good, kept my interest and desire to know more!
But they were too stingy with the sci-fi thrills and far too reliant on wowing us with an ending that we could all see coming from a mile away!']

Title: Kiss the¬†Girls
Text:
Forensic psychologist and detective Alex Cross travels to North Carolina and teams with escaped kidnap victim Kate McTiernan to hunt down ‚ÄúCasanova,‚Äù a serial killer who abducts strong-willed women and forces them to submit to his demands. The trail leads to Los Angeles, where the duo discovers that the psychopath may not be working¬†alone.
['ü•õüî´', 'This is a totally by-the-numbers, schlocky but engaging 90s detective thriller with corny serial killers, elevated by a measured performance from Morgan Freeman. \nAnd that scene of Freeman shooting through a carton of milk was badass.', 'I guess they can‚Äôt all be Silence of the Lambs.']

Title: The¬†Wave
Text:
Although theorised, no one is really ready when a mountain pass above the scenic and narrow Geiranger fjord in Norway collapses and creates a tsunami over 300 feet high. A geologist is one of those caught in the middle of¬†it.
['Seems like a smart place to build a town', 'I started watching 
The Quake
\xa0and I wasn‚Äôt sure if it was a direct sequel or a companion movie, but about 5 minutes in I realized it‚Äôs a direct sequel s I figured I‚Äôd better go back and watch this again since it‚Äôs been a couple of years.
It‚Äôs real good y‚Äôall. Like why are American disaster films so fuckimg cheesy when Norway is over here making that shit that gives you the real feels?! I laughed, I cried (almost, I‚Äôd have to have an actual soul to d that so no), I cheered at the happy ending and believe me this movie earns that ending because it puts you through absolute hell getting there.
Gonna watch the sequel tomorrow and am already feeling like we need an entire series of this family just having the worst day ever no matter where they go.', "It's been ages that I didn't see kinda disaster movies. FYI I was a huge fan of 
Deep Impact, Twister, Armageddon, War of the Worlds, Independence Day, The day after tomorrow and so on. 
But here it is. Let's get into this review. Go in for!
I actually surprised that this small budget 
Norwegian
 movie blew away critics with special effects to rival Hollywood blockbusters. Simple story and it borrows many disaster cliches but it's slow pace. Allows the audiences to broil in the tension and grow attached to the whole characters which makes the inevitable destruction all the more compelling every disaster.
 
One of those movies with a really great plot that leaves you thinking. Watch the whole thing. It had me gripped from the start to the unexpected ending. What a blow out!
It was only a matter of time."]

Title: Mo‚Äô Better¬†Blues
Text:
Talented but self-centered trumpeter Bleek Gilliam is obsessed with his music and indecisiveness about his girlfriends Indigo and Clarke. But when he is forced to come to the aid of his manager and childhood friend, Bleek finds his world more fragile than he ever¬†imagined.
['The cinematography in this movie knocked me out, so much so that I wish I could drop everything and just rewatch all of Spike Lee and Ernest Dickerson‚Äôs movies together just for the camerawork. It‚Äôs not even that it‚Äôs flashy, because it‚Äôs not. It‚Äôs just so \nexpressive\n. The moves, the framing, the colors. Incredible.', "Secret MVP is Giancarlo Esposito's character who keeps trying really hard to be French", 'Following up Do the Right Thing was such a giant hill to climb that people overlooked that this is one hell of a movie.']

Title: Analyze¬†That
Text:
The mafia‚Äôs Paul Vitti is back in prison and will need some serious counseling when he gets out. Naturally, he returns to his analyst Dr. Ben Sobel for help and finds that Sobel needs some serious help himself as he has inherited the family practice, as well as an excess stock of¬†stress.
['vitti having a panic attack because he has to get a job and pay taxes is so me', "The year is 2058.
The risen oceans have enveloped the earth.
The last remaining humans are confined to villages atop mountains, desperately clinging to the minuscule peaks of civilization.
Production on 
Analyze Whom?
 has stalled because the nose fell off De Niro's corpse again.", "You.. you ...you're good doc .. you ..you ..you"]

Title: The Phantom of the Opera at the Royal Albert¬†Hall
Text:
A disfigured musical genius, hidden away in the Paris Opera House, terrorises the opera company for the unwitting benefit of a young prot√©g√©e whom he trains and loves. The 25th anniversary of the first public performance of Phantom of the Opera was celebrated with a grand performance at the Royal Albert Hall in¬†London.

But you're going to go through life thinking that girls don't like you because you're an outsider. And I want you to know, from the bottom of my heart, that that won't be true. It'll be because you're an asshole."]

Title: Come¬†True
Text:
Looking for an escape from her recurring nightmares, 18-year-old Sarah submits to a university sleep study, but soon realizes she‚Äôs become the conduit to a frightening new¬†discovery.
['Fantasia #17
Very good score; very cool dream visuals; very unnecessary romance; very dumb ending; and I lost interest very quickly', '"ùë∑ùë≥ùë¨ùë®ùë∫ùë¨, ùëæùë®ùë≤ùë¨ ùëºùë∑!"

‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Original sci-fi horror film that takes its inspiration from Cronenberg (both father and son) and Lynch, but still retains its own vision and execution. It‚Äôs filled with surreal nightmare sequences which results in a creepy atmosphere. But\xa0where it distinguish itself is in the style, its stylistically shot with some blue filter and lighting, the ambient synth soundtrack (Electric Youth!) give it some retro vibes to it, there‚Äôs even a scene which is almost a hommage to 
Drive
. Maybe the third act is a bit weaker than the first two, but it‚Äôs ending - which some might dislike- is quite strong and above all daring. Refreshing stuff, more of this please.
New addition to:\xa0
purple wave']

Title: Catfish
Text:
Nev, a 24-year-old New York-based photographer, has no idea what he‚Äôs in for when Abby, an eight-year-old girl from rural Michigan, contacts him on Facebook, seeking permission to paint one of his photographs. When he receives her remarkable painting, Nev begins a friendship and correspondence with Abby‚Äôs family. But things really get interesting when he develops a cyber-romance with Abby‚Äôs attractive older sister, Megan, a musician and model. Title: The Quiet¬†Man
Text:
An American man returns to the village of his birth in Ireland, where he finds love and¬†conflict.
['This is probably the Ford film which has taken me the longest to get around to - I've always been aware of it's subtext and critique, but it never fully clicked with me until now. Maybe it was the poor quality of previous home video versions of the movie, coupled with the jarring jump to this new one. But under this viewing I found it to be among one of Ford's most complex and audacious films - more than mere Irish "blarney," this is another film on issues of representation, and if it is not quite as successful as something like Fort Apache in this regard, it's merely because it's not as jarring, and dares to be entertaining at times‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Honestly not sure what to make of this? For my whole life I‚Äôve heard my parents complain about it as this obnoxious cartoon presentation of Ireland full of bad stereotypes and bad accents (relevant info: my mom is from Ireland and I‚Äôve spent a lot of time there), but for much of the movie I actually found it pretty lovely? Like, sure, it‚Äôs not realistic but it‚Äôs such a staggeringly gorgeous fairy tale place, such a clearly idealized presentation made by someone not from there, that it gets away with painting with a broad brush.
But then there‚Äôs just the way John Wayne handles Maureen O‚ÄôHara physically: throwing her around roughly, breaking in doors she‚Äôs locked, dragging her by the‚Ä¶ 
more', "93
Bonnets swaying in the wind. Booze and greenery and ritual. A man of violence returns to his homeland in order to reckon with himself and the possibility of a romantic future. Maybe, just maybe, on a sheer compositional level, the most beautiful picture in the history of the cinema. I might be saying that a bit loud but gosh just look at those images! On a big screen, the fantastical trials and tribulations of John Ford's Ireland manifest in a mythic register. Larger than life."]

Title: Zero Fucks¬†Given
Text:
Cassandre, 26, is a flight attendant for a low-cost airline. Based in Lanzarote, she‚Äôs always willing to take on extra hours and carries out her duties with robotic efficiency. On the side, she just goes with the flow and floats between Tinder, parties and lazy days. When she suddenly gets dismissed, she is forced to return¬†home.
["I don't know a single person who watched this for any reason other than Ad√®le Exarchopoulos", 'For most people, the late capitalistic demand for employees to go full automaton at the start of every shift ‚Äî to smother their own humanity under a membrane of cheap uniforms, fake smiles, and heartless corporate jargon ‚Äî is something of a turnoff. For Cassandre (Ad√®le Exarchopoulos), the stone-faced heroine of Julie Lecoustre and Emmanuel Marre‚Äôs fly-by-night travelogue ‚ÄúZero Fucks Given,‚Äù the requirement to gate-check her emotions is the entire reason she decided to become a Wing Airlines flight attendant in the first place.
A pretty but withdrawn Belgian twentysomething who totally lost her bearings before she even had a chance to leave home, Cassandre looked to the sky for escape after her mom died in a car accident, and‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Cassandre has nothing to show for her life except an innate talent at running away from it.\xa0
A flight attendant for a budget airline, she is envied by her childhood friends in Belgium for her privilege to exist without attachments. And also, questioned on how it‚Äôs possible to even do so. \xa0
The answer lies in the title of the film, ‚ÄúRien √† foutre,‚Äù a French expression that more or less translates to the work‚Äôs English name, ‚ÄúZero Fucks Given.‚Äù\xa0
Cassandre, played by the exquisitely talented Ad√®le Exarchopoulos, travels with an immense weight of mental baggage wherever she goes. As part of her professional training, she is required to hold the image of a perfect smile for thirty seconds, and‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Big Deal on Madonna¬†Street
Text:
Best friends Peppe and Mario are thieves, but they‚Äôre not very good at it. Still, Peppe thinks that he‚Äôs finally devised a master heist that will make them rich. With the help of some fellow criminals, he plans to dig a tunnel from a rented apartment to the pawnshop next door, where they can rob the safe. But his plan is far from foolproof, and the fact that no one in the group has any experience digging tunnels proves to be the least of their¬†problems.
['Marcello Mastroianni and his son. Marcello Mastroianni and his wife. Marcello Mastroianni and his beret. Marcello Mastroianni.', 'In the mediocre production scene of the late 1950s, 
Big Deal on Madonna Street
 has the merit of demonstrating that even in Italy it is possible a cinema that goes beyond dialectal sketching, entertaining with intelligence and good taste. The result of the thematic, stylistic and professional maturity acquired by 
Mario Monicelli
 with some previous works, the film tells the hilarious story of a gang of petty thieves who decide to organize in a meticulous way a big "scientific heist". The director, here also a screenwriter together with 
Age & Scarpelli
 and 
Suso Cecchi D'Amico
, relies on a very fast pace and a barrage of irresistible gimmicks, but his work goes far beyond the farcical reinterpretation of some famous caper movies‚Ä¶ 
more', 'marcello mastroianni is just a frazzled little papa with his hat and his broken arm and his tiny screaming baby. i love him so much.']

Title: Dreamcatcher
Text:
Four boyhood pals perform a heroic act and are changed by the powers they gain in return. Years later, on a hunting trip in the Maine woods, they‚Äôre overtaken by a vicious blizzard that harbors an ominous presence. Challenged to stop an alien force, the friends must first prevent the slaughter of innocent civilians by a military vigilante ‚Ä¶ and then overcome a threat to the bond that unites the four of¬†them.
['ok so...you know how i complain about movies by male writers/directors that obviously have no idea how women talk or interact with each other? this script is like if a bunch of women had to guess how men talk to each other', "look, it ain't boring", 'This movie is so amazing. 
The protagonists come across a corpse in the the middle of the forest and, in a very tense scene, they reach out to touch it and then the corpse rips a huge fart. 
And then, later, a different dude in the woods is dying a horrible death, and he's screaming in pain and the other characters are so scared and then the guy dying starts ripping these huge farts. And the protagonists seriously start complaining about how smelly it is. 
You may not know this, but this is based on one of my favorite Stephen King books, "Fart Ripper."
And then all these aliens and kids with magical learning disabilities show up. 
This movie is so amazing.']

Title: Lost in¬†America

Title: The Incredible Shrinking¬†Man
Text:
A dangerous combination of radiation and insecticide causes the unfortunate Scott Carey to shrink, slowly but surely, until he is only a few inches tall. His home becomes a wilderness where he must survive everything from spiders living in the cellar to his beloved¬†cat.
["A beautifully austere and absurd early, Atomic-age anxiety sci-fi body horror movie realized with a real sense of physical struggle/danger via jaw-dropping analog FX survival setpieces (Arnold expertly deploys a combo of forced perspective, compositing and production design which genuinely make you believe Grant Williams is going toe-to-toe with various enlarged objects) that eventually give way to Richard Matheson's grander, more despairing, almost cosmic existentialism. The tone of the ending I think is supposed to be tinged with optimism but after spending so long dealing with every minute struggle of our shrinking protagonist, watching him come to terms with feeling like he no longer has any purpose or place in the world (by accepting a new form existence) still felt pretty damn dark and lonely.
Full discussion on ep 220 of my podcast SLEAZOIDS
.", "Starts with a simple, funny high-concept premise and spins it into surprisingly dark and philosophical places. The early scenes are especially impressive in their subtlety, Carey's fears that he may be somehow shrinking call to mind cancer or wasting disease - nothing funny about that. 
Later in the movie, living in a grotesque dollhouse inside the home he used to be happy in, he thinks about suicide - so yeah, this is not your typical 50s scifi schlock (no offense to 50s scifi schlock, which I love so much). The more adventurous set-pieces are great too, the cat is genuinely frightening, as is the tarantula, and I loved the effect of the main character swimming for his life in what‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Honey, I Shrunk!
or
Robinson Crusoe Downstairs
Peak merging of analog technical craft and mid-century sci-fi. Manages to plumb the depths of psychological darkness inherent in any transformation/body horror story without losing any of its pulp fantasy veneer. The cosmic existential philosophy is just purple icing on the stale cake. All of the people involved in creating these new fangled "dark, gritty, realistic" comic book movies should be forced to study this. (And because I can't help myself) It's a small story that feels big.']

Title: A Bigger¬†Splash
Text:
An American couple, Paul and Marianne, spend their vacation in Italy and experience trouble when Marianne invites a former lover and his teenage daughter to visit, which leads to jealousy and dangerous sexual¬†scenarios.
['The vibes on this remain off the charts, I continue to see it as one of the best movies of the 2010s. I can‚Äôt wait until more people discover it after seeing 
Challengers
, because it‚Äôs the skeleton key, much more so than 
Call Me By Your Name
. The quick zooms, peeled fruit, tight two-shots, uneasy intimacy, bodies bodies bodies. Glorious ‚Äò70s needle drops up the wazoo. Everything Ralph Fiennes does should be studied by NASA, it‚Äôs rocket fuel. I love the generational, gender and genre blurring‚ÄîLuca has such a handle on dippy rich European artists and their handlers spending money and sweat until there‚Äôs too much coke, drink, and excess to keep things straight anymore. Our Consumption God! A filmmaker for our times.', '***THIS IS AN AWARDS PIECE I WROTE ABOUT RALPH FIENNES AND WHY HE SHOULD WIN ALL THE OSCARS FOR THIS MOVIE***
Ralph Fiennes is never going to win an Oscar.
He‚Äôs too slippery, too snake-like, too hard to pin down. He plays cruelty for laughs, and uses humor to break your heart. He plays supporting roles with the all-consuming intensity of a lead, and lead roles with the evasiveness of someone who‚Äôs just passing through. He‚Äôs human category fraud.
But if Fiennes gets overlooked for his irrepressible work in Luca Guadagnino‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Bigger Splash,‚Äù it won‚Äôt be because he was submitted in the wrong race; it‚Äôll be because he appears to be having way too much fun for a drama.‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Dakota Johnson: -every quote that Forever 21 has ever put on one of their shirts-

Me: This deserves four and a half stars']

This movie is 100% a masterpiece. The visuals are perfect, the acting, ESPECIALLY from Amy Adams, is wonderful. The fucking score, Jesus Christ. Everything about this movie is absolutely amazing. Title: Investigation of a Citizen Above¬†Suspicion
Text:
Rome, Italy. After committing a heinous crime, a senior police officer exposes evidence incriminating him because his moral commitment prevents him from circumventing the law and the social order it¬†protects.
["The film as recrimination of reality because reality itself could not reconcile itself. It is paradoxical that those in power stay in power even, or perhaps most, when they are most indicted, because who's going to believe the word of a nobody citizen against that of one above suspicion? It can't be happening, even when it is happening, already happening, because it can't possibly be happening. Mass cognitive dissonance; the powerful warp how reality is experienced. These abuses are absurd because absurdity is a tool, unbelievable, so they are no longer believed. It is only in retrospect that the paradox is unpacked, abuses confessed to because they are relegated to the past. These things 
used
 to happen but not anymore. Now? That's absurd. There 
is
 no abuse. Something like that could not possibly happen now.", '‚ÄúEveryone is innocent here.‚Äù
American Psycho
 meets 
Rope
 meets an ‚Äúevery politician, billionaire, and figure of authority should eat shit and die‚Äù mentality. An all too real black satire that transcends borders, cultures, generations, and political lines in depicting the outright arrogance of those who wield the ‚Äúrules for thee but not for me‚Äù power to protect themselves from scrutiny and self-righteously determine the consequences of their own pompous actions. I could go on for hours waxing a symphony of hatred towards the untouchable narcissists of society who freely deal in corruption, bribery, blackmail, extortion, censorship, persecution, and murder knowing full well that even if they were to lead Johnny Law by the nose and explicitly confess all their sins,‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Junesploitation
: Day 4 ‚Äì Cops!
The impotence of state power.
Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion
 is a title with a double meaning: it is about a high-ranking police chief who commits a murder, and the ‚Äúinvestigation‚Äù is both 
of

by
 him (of the department) to see if it‚Äôs even possible for him to be caught. As the head of homicide, he is a man of such authority and prestige that it begins to seem as though he might be immune to the law.
On the surface it‚Äôs a compelling murder mystery with hints of giallo (sexualized violence): there‚Äôs an effective tension in the question of how the (dual) investigation(s) will turn‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Hitch-Hiker
Text:
Roy and Gilbert‚Äôs fishing trip takes a terrifying turn when the hitchhiker they pick up turns out to be a sociopath on the run from the law. He‚Äôs killed before, and he lets the two know that as soon as they‚Äôre no longer useful, he‚Äôll kill again. The two friends plot an escape, but the hitchhiker‚Äôs peculiar physical affliction, an eye that never closes even when he sleeps, makes it impossible for them to tell when they can make a break for¬†it.
['The way of the gun as the only manliness measurement stick. So tight, so forceful.', "Lots to think about here re: the symbolic power of the gun, how it completely dominates the film and the two men at its center, the terror it commands and the emasculation it perpetrates. Lupino seems interested in the fragility of masculine performance in the face of an object that is itself representative of that performance's power. Also intrigued as much by her wide shots (alternately exacting in their detail and stark in their enthralling simplicity) as by her close-ups (particularly of Talman, whose every bit of stubble seems to radiate smug malice). Maybe it's just me but she seems like a real good director.", "Faces suspended in a void have nothing but their own grim performances to convey. The desert setting does not serve to create the touted claustrophobia; it's the shadows, the darkness that encompasses them in open spaces, around campfires, under the stars. Light only shows the most prominent clue to their emotional states and nothing more, leaving the viewer trapped intimately with the three men. When the light returns, the wide open spaces offer barrenness. The feeling isn't claustrophobia; it's preemptive weariness at the thought of that sweat-drenched, dry-mouthed, rock-scoured journey.\nOthers speak of the tension, but it becomes clear early on that what these men face isn't death. They face torment. Their lifespans are defined by how long an arbitrary‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: The Summit of the¬†Gods
Text:
A photojournalist‚Äôs obsessive quest for the truth about the first expedition to Mt. Everest leads him to search for an esteemed climber who went¬†missing.
['The Summit of the Gods is worth watching purely as an auditory and visual spectacle. The animation, shot composition, score, and sound design are all phenomenal. It moves a bit like an older Ghibli film, but feels more like it happens in our world without compromising depth or color. There were certain frames I had to pause for just to take it in! I‚Äôm really hoping this gets nominated for best animated feature and sound design.\xa0\nAnd, despite a narrative that can be disjointed at times, this film tells a really powerful story about obsessive behavior and why certain people dedicate their lives to achieving the impossible and testing humanity‚Äôs limits. Not impossible like, running a marathon - impossible like‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'major missed opportunity to play miley cyrus‚Äô hit single the climb during the credits', 'I really enjoyed this']

Title: Disconnect
Text:
A hard-working lawyer, attached to his cell phone, can‚Äôt find the time to communicate with his family. An estranged couple uses the internet as a means to escape from their lifeless marriage. A widowed ex-cop struggles to raise a mischievous son who cyber-bullies a classmate. An ambitious journalist sees a career-making story in a teen that performs on an adult-only site. They are strangers, neighbors and colleagues and their stories collide as ordinary people struggling to connect in today‚Äôs wired¬†world. √ó
["I watched this with my friend very early in the morning yesterday; he showed up at my house a little while after the midnight and, since we didn't start it right away, we didn't finish the movie until after 3AM... and when the credits finally rolled, we didn't say a word to each other. I glanced over at him in my peripheral vision and noticed the tears rolling down his cheeks. 
And I just knew the feeling. 
I was crying a bit too, but it was the fourth time I had seen this film, so I was just glad to have been able to share it with someone else, a friend. Why? Because Disconnect is like no other film released‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Can we just shut the entire internet off? Except Letterboxd. We can keep that around.', 'A film that has been likened to the controversial "Crash" on and off this platform, and as the film progressed, one can see the parallel between the two, where racism is swapped for the alienation generated by technology, from social networking to sex or casual chat services. And, how anxieties, personal and relationship difficulties tend to manifest negatively under the anonymity of the internet.
Over the course of the film, it tends to be fairly engaging, with one narrative certainly being better than the other, but all are compelling, and the performances are quite good. The music is also excellent, particularly the utilization of Radiohead and, I believe, Sigur Ros songs. They lend a touch of melancholy to the picture.‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The Man Who Shot Liberty¬†Valance
Text:
Questions arise when Senator Stoddard attends the funeral of a local man named Tom Doniphon in a small Western town. Flashing back, we learn Doniphon saved Stoddard, then a lawyer, when he was roughed up by a crew of outlaws terrorizing the town, led by Liberty Valance. As the territory‚Äôs safety hung in the balance, Doniphon and Stoddard, two of the only people standing up to him, proved to be very important, but different, foes to¬†Valance.
["nothing i can say that hasn't been said a hundred times before, it's brilliant in many ways but here's what stuck with me most: can you fuckin imagine walking into an empty room, lighting a lamp, and the lees marvin & van cleef are waiting for you in the dark? mindblowing that john ford managed to stick a 10 second horror movie into his western.", "Not sure I'd ever quite clocked the moment near the beginning when Ransom Stoddard demands that Tom Doniphon be buried with his gun and holster, and it's pointed out to him that Doniphon hadn't carried a gun in years. No need to. Stoddard may or may not have shot Liberty Valance, but he definitely killed Tom Doniphon.
This is a powerfully ambiguous movie in which, every time he pedantically corrects someone's grammar, Stoddard reveals himself as the secret villain. Liberty Valance probably needed to die, but at what cost? Is what has replaced him any less violent? Now that Stoddard's vision for the west has won, Liberty Valance is reborn every day as a lobbyist for some Silicon Valley tech‚Ä¶ 
more", '"When force threatens, talk's no good anymore."
-
"Votes don't stand up against guns."
The impossibility of a democratic system to contain what seems an irrepressible & inherent violence of the American psyche. Marvin's Liberty Valance and Wayne's Tom Donovan are the two most charismatic cyphers to ever grace a movie screen - both seem two sides of the same coin..but Valance's other side is actually Stoddard - Valance condones force, Donovan does not. But both acknowledge it's existence - Stewart's Ransom Stoddard refuses too, finally has to realize it exists, but brings civilization to the West with a lie - that it doesn't. Visually puny in comparison to the Monument Valley westerns, but this is one of Ford's hugest, most‚Ä¶ 
more']

About as dumb of a bag of rocks, but off the success of 
The Strangers: Prey at Night
, you can tell Johannes Roberts just likes to play around in these nonsensical genre exercises. He turned a foggy, abandoned trailer park into an 80s pop hellscape, and in the first 
47 Meters Down

With all the particles and silt, blinding lights and ominous tomb raider spaces, its nonsensical spatial configurations result in a disorienting camera un-tethered from traditional construction. While I've never disliked one of his films, I also haven't fallen deeply in love with any of them, and that trend continued with my screening of 
71 Fragments
. I could see what he was going for and admire his efforts at thematic filmmaking, but it wasn't as interesting or entertaining as I had hoped. I wanted a masterpiece, but what I get was merely exceptional.

Title: In a Glass¬†Cage
Text:
A mysterious teenager named √Ångelo cares for Klaus, a German doctor with a dark past who lives trapped in an iron¬†lung.
["reposting, because it was deleted
I had never seen any of Villaronga's films prior to watching 
In a Glass Cage,
 so I really had no idea what to expect aside from having heard that it's one of the most disturbing films ever made. Those who have said so are absolutely correct; I'd place this up with 
Come and See, Salo, Zero Day, Lilja 4-Ever
 and 
Irreversible

In order to avoid‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Arguably one of the most disturbing revenge flicks you‚Äôll ever see. Probably the most Haneke film the Austrian director has never directed. 
The cinematography has this cold, blue, and green-ish hue that adds to the repulsiveness of the film, a constant reminder of the depravity of both men. Really liked the way it also concludes, it drives home this idea that evil will never dies, it evolves. Navarrete‚Äôs score is very subtle but effective on creating this oppressive and sinister atmosphere that lingers and crawls deep into your soul. 
The performances are fantastic across the board. Casting a man who made himself for playing Hitler in a series of projects was obvious but inspiring casting for playing this once vile‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Adopting a palette of blues, greys, browns and blacks, In A Glass Cage creates a hushed, almost stilled atmosphere perfect for the nightmare tale it tells. This is a film for which a heightened, displaced sense of reality becomes more real than what realism as a style could possibly offer. Early on, it is clear that waking life is the dream of the nightmare, that what has been banished as past horror, that which must be put aside or temporarily forgotten in order to maintain the fiction of regularity, rationality, order, is the primary reality, the ground from which everything follows. The end of wartime is sometimes described as waking up from a dream, with a civilization able to put‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The¬†Mission
Text:

['the whole movie should just be them throwing things down the waterfall', 'CEO:
 "Alright I got De Niro ready to go for a new movie, what do you got?"
Roland:
 "Honestly nothing much... I have this medicore story with a pretty beautiful location in mind."
CEO:
 "Hmmmm... that doesn't sound good, we will find something else for De Ni..."
Roland slams a CD player on the table.
CEO:

Roland hits play on the player and the score starts playing.
CEO:

CEO:
 "This score is beautiful! Here is De Niros number, this film doesn't have to be good, just make sure this shit is in it!"', 'I didn‚Äôt really feel any particular way about this film as a whole.\xa0
First of all, I legitimately think this is the greatest movie score of all time. Not only that, Gabriel‚Äôs Oboe might be the single most beautiful piece of music to ever grace this planet. I‚Äôve played it at multiple weddings and hope to have it played at mine. I adore Ennio Morricone, and this score seems to capture the romantic side of him, it‚Äôs a bit of a bummer it wasn‚Äôt for a better movie.
Other than that, the movie looked beautiful, but never did much to grab my attention. I really respect these actors and their dedication, it seemed like everyone went through a lot to get this movie made.
Robert De Niro has never looked more beautiful in my opinion. He‚Äôs surprisingly dreamy here, especially given how gritty the setting is. That is all.']

Title: The Wild¬†Bunch
Text:
An aging group of outlaws look for one last big score as the ‚Äútraditional‚Äù American West is disappearing around¬†them.
['incredible action sequences and editing. made me feel terrible in my gut from start to finish. horses do not know they are in a movie', 'Lots of quality squibs in this one', "Part 1 of 
Catchin' up on Westerns
The clashing cathartic depths of violence in Sam Peckinpah's 
The Wild Bunch
 eventually settles into the aftermath of rage and personal selfishness. Never have I seen such carnage celebrated and relished in until the buzzards fly in and the women come out to pray. Every character is battling the slowly-fading lifestyle of their bravado nature, and Peckinpah lets every character dwell not in nostalgia but in remembrance. The final 15 minutes lets loose in its purity and its depravity, but in an honest way that recalls why such stories are told. 
I usually don't care for westerns, but this was just incredible."]

Text:

Title: Jersey¬†Boys
Text:
A musical biopic of the Four Seasons‚Äîthe rise, the tough times and personal clashes, and the ultimate triumph of a group of friends whose music became symbolic of a generation. Far from a mere tribute concert, it gets to the heart of the relationships at the centre of the group, with a special focus on frontman Frankie Valli, the small kid with the big¬†falsetto.
["I *DABS* LOVE *DABS* YOU *DABS* BABY AND IF IT'S QUITE ALRIGHT *WHIPS* I NEED YOU BABY *NAE NAES* TO WARM THE LONELY NIGHT", 'A certain ideal of post-war American masculinity, in its most recognizably pumped-up form, that of the mob-connected Italian-Americans of New Jersey, convenient metaphor of capitalist patriarchy in its purest form at war with the pure pure voice and soul of Mr. Frankie Valli. In any other musical biopic, the first performance of one of the great pop songs of all-time, "Can't Take My Eyes Off You", would be an unadulterated triumph, an expression that all Valli has sacrificed and lost for his art was worth it because he did 
this
. But the prevailing emotion here is sadness, not just at the personal losses Valli has suffered (family and friends) but at his utter bewilderment at the essential contradiction of his‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I love this movie too much
5/5 but I‚Äôll take off 1/2 a star to acknowledge that it‚Äôs not actually as good as I think']

Title: Partly¬†Cloudy
Text:
Everyone knows that the stork delivers babies, but where do the storks get the babies from? The answer lies up in the stratosphere, where cloud people sculpt babies from clouds and bring them to life. Gus, a lonely and insecure grey cloud, is a master at creating ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù babies. Crocodiles, porcupines, rams and more - Gus‚Äôs beloved creations are works of art, but more than a handful for his loyal delivery stork partner, Peck. As Gus‚Äôs creations become more and more rambunctious, Peck‚Äôs job gets harder and harder. How will Peck manage to handle both his hazardous cargo and his friend‚Äôs fiery¬†temperament? √ó
['Who knew storks and clouds were gay dads???', 'Don‚Äôt know if this stork has Stockholm Syndrome or is very supportive of his friend.', 'Another great example of a Pixar short that‚Äôs free of dialogue, but the expressiveness of the characters communicate their thoughts better than words ever could. As silly as it sounds, I really felt for this goofy looking stork when he was handed a shark to deliver, and I could feel how betrayed the cloud guy felt when his stork went to talk with the other cloud guy. It‚Äôs just a really nice short that can convey so much with so little.\n Pixar Short Films Ranked']

Title: Band of¬†Brothers
Text:
Drawn from interviews with survivors of Easy Company, as well as their journals and letters, Band of Brothers chronicles the experiences of these men from paratrooper training in Georgia through the end of the war. As an elite rifle company parachuting into Normandy early on D-Day morning, participants in the Battle of the Bulge, and witness to the horrors of war, the men of Easy knew extraordinary bravery and extraordinary fear - and became the stuff of legend. Based on Stephen E. Ambrose‚Äôs acclaimed book of the same¬†name. √ó
['Jimmy Fallon jumpscare', 'Not about the Jonas Brothers', "At the end of the tenth and final part of 
Band of Brothers
, right when they cut from Damian Lewis' voiceover as Maj. Richard D. Winters to the real Dick Winters himself, I got goosebumps, and suddenly I felt two or three tears falling down my cheeks. Having spent 11 hours with the men of Easy Company of the US Army 101st Airborne division, and then watching these men, Winters, Lipton, Malarkey, Guarnere, Heffron, Powers and Martin talk about the strong bond between themselves and their brothers in arms, those who died and those who survived, it hit me that this story is very real, and I didn‚Äôt feel the need to hold back my tears.

Title: H√§xan
Text:
Grave robbing, torture, possessed nuns, and a satanic Sabbath: Benjamin Christensen‚Äôs legendary film uses a series of dramatic vignettes to explore the scientific hypothesis that the witches of the Middle Ages suffered the same hysteria as turn-of-the-century psychiatric patients. But the film itself is far from serious‚Äì instead it‚Äôs a witches‚Äô brew of the scary, gross, and darkly¬†humorous.
["A purported clinical documentary on witchcraft and satanism drawn almost entirely in unhinged expressionist horror images including foggy subterranean lairs, women giving birth to hairy horned beasts, moody nighttime broomstick rides, and general hysteria/torture that doubles as a timeless document on how fearmongering and religious imagery have been used throughout history as an excuse to torture women, even in times of supposed scientific enlightenment. Has to be one of the most overtly grotesque movies made in this period including detailed accounts of medieval torture devices and on-screen baby sacrificing. I couldn't take my eyes off the incredible sets and costumes, especially when this goes full fire-and-brimstone, hellish nightmare painting imagery with pig men, skeleton horses, clawed demons, and boiling cauldrons filled with people.
Full discussion on episode 156 of my podcast SLEAZOIDS
.", "Do y'all know how funny it is to have someone walk behind you, and having to explain you're watching a silent Swedish documentary about witchcraft?", '"Oh, you learned men!"
For some reason I always thought this was a hysterical reactionary relic about the occult, but it's actually the exact opposite of that, a reason-oriented look at the phenomenon of witch hunts that even finds room for a little bit of wry humor amidst the torture and tragedy. It's also a very effective example of horror and fantastic imagery's ability to point the way towards real truths, in this case how terrible life can be when superstition and fear hold sway over those in power. A lesson like that has obvious implications that go beyond the puritan days, and which become explicit in the surprisingly sensitive last chapter.']

Title: The¬†Watchers
Text:

['the fake love island episodes were more interesting than anything involving the watchers', 'How long does it take an Irishman, a Brit, an American and an old lady to look under a rug?
8 months apparently', "There's a part early on where the main character is being taught about the medicinal properties of the various plants in the forest. One would naturally assume that this would somehow factor into the plot later on, but one would be wrong. It doesn't matter at all that this character knows about plants, and those plants will never come in useful. It's just something the movie is spending time on, even if it doesn't really matter.
They mention rules, but the rules aren't interesting. And they're defied early enough that one never really gets a sense of the consequences of the defiance. They're never supposed to show their back to their watchers, but we see that casually happening while they‚Ä¶

Title: Holy¬†Spider
Text:
A journalist descends into the dark underbelly of the Iranian holy city of Mashhad as she investigates the serial killings of sex workers by the so called ‚ÄúSpider Killer‚Äù, who believes he is cleansing the streets of¬†sinners.
["Seems like a pretty interesting real story with troubling implications about misogyny, religion, and celebrity but this can't decide whether it wants to shape that story into a serial killer POV horror film or a socially-conscious procedural, and ultimately makes the mistake of trying to do both. At once too exploitative to make its righteous, humane critiques and too dull to be good exploitation.", 'I had the opportunity to watch this for the second time in theaters; this time a Q&A with director Ali Abbasi and the film‚Äôs lead, Zar Amir Ebrahimi followed the screening, in which they spoke about the difficulty in shooting, casting and getting this film finally made, considering the obstacles they faced along the way.\xa0
For a more comprehensive review of 
Holy Spider, 
please refer to/read my first review of the film, 
here
.\xa0
‚ÄºÔ∏èSPOILERS BELOW‚ÄºÔ∏è
This time around, I‚Äôd like to just provide a focused analysis of the film‚Äôs ending ‚Äî specifically, the scene of the execution. The first thing to note is that because this is based on a true story, it couldn‚Äôt have been done any other way.‚Ä¶ 
more', "For a film that tries to expose misogynistic brutality, it surely feels ironic that most of the plot is centered around the male killer and that all violence is shown very vividly in every frame. Honestly I am just so tired of these sort of films trying to make a feminist statement and then falling into clear tropes that are the complete opposite of any sort of positive representation for women. Do we really need to have a generic revenge story and clear on-screen brutality to realise we have to respect women? That doesn't really click in my head and this just made me appreciate the off-screen violence of 
You Were Never Really Here 
so much more
 
because Holy Spider just reinforces the idea men have to protect women."]

Title: Boiling¬†Point
Text:

["Boiling Point
 is a film in Takeshi Kitano's trademark style of nasty violence in a tranquil world. The filmmaking is minimalist and filled with small does of humour. It's a calmly paced film and one which also feels aimless, perhaps due to its complete absence of exposition or explanation. Unfortunately 
Boiling Point

Title: Sophie‚Äôs¬†Choice
Text:

["her: here's how i survived the holocaust
him: please just fuck me", 'A great example of why men are always the inferior choice in telling women's stories.
Sophie's Choice
 has some extraordinary moments and they all occur when the film is focused on Sophie. Sure, perhaps he's intended to be the audience's lens for viewing her story, but it doesn't work, not for me. It is horribly tone deaf that after Sophie shares her deepest, darkest shame, we get a voice over from him saying: "I was twenty-two and a virgin and was clasping in my arms at last the goddess of my unending fantasies, my lust was inexhaustible."‚Ä¶

Title: Werckmeister¬†Harmonies
Text:
A naive young man witnesses an escalation of violence in his small hometown following the arrival of a mysterious circus¬†attraction.
["Werckmeister Harmonies
\xa0is a film of constant symbolism and allegory. It is the greatest philosophical and political allegory since 
S√°t√°ntang√≥
, another film by master auteur B√©la Tarr. 
Werckmeister Harmonies
\xa0is Tarr's most exciting film (although 
S√°t√°ntang√≥
\xa0remains his best) because it's the most brimming with ideas. Adapting the novel 
The Melancholy of Resistance
\xa0by L√°szl√≥ Krasznahorkai, 
Werckmeister Harmonies
\xa0more than matches the quality of the masterful original text. The film is more implicit in some ways, taking the dense metaphorical nature of the novel but removing the clarity of the book's multi-viewpoint narrative. What remains though is the unfolding of a Mitteleuropean tragedy, which is hypnotically enchanting and slow, and on an intimate scale with cosmic flourishes.
Werckmeister Harmonies
 is a distinctly political work, even‚Ä¶ 
more", "There is no comfort in the worlds created by Bela Tarr. He has the unique ability to create his very own universe within the stories he chooses to relate. Otherworldly, yet real, Tarr's earth is a singularly harsh and unforgiving place, a place in which he chooses to explore what we are and where we are headed.
Werckmeister Harmonies is no different. In harrowing black and white we are transported to an anonymous Hungarian town, out of which life is slowly seeping away. It is a desolate place, struck by poverty and inhabited by people for whom life is very hard. While we follow mailman Janos (the focal point of the story), we slowly pick up snippets of how bad‚Ä¶ 
more", "Why do I hold 
Werckmeister Harmonies
 aloft as the greatest film I have ever seen? A huge part of it, admittedly, and the thing that makes me think it will remain my favourite film to the day I die, is its profound personal relevance. I first saw the film about 5 years ago now, at a time when my interest in cinema was in the very very earliest stages of blossoming. It blew me away. Takes that long, images that symbolic, music that intoxicating, scenes that spellbinding, meanings that elusive... it was far too much for my uninitiated mind to deal with, but I knew that it was changing me. What's funny is that I encountered it entirely by mistake:‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Outside the¬†Wire
Text:
In the near future, a drone pilot is sent into a deadly militarized zone and must work with an android officer to locate a doomsday¬†device.
['Have you ever watched ‚ÄúTraining Day‚Äù and wondered how cool it would be if, 15 minutes into the movie, Denzel Washington took off his shirt to reveal that he was actually a semi-translucent android super-soldier with the strength of a Terminator and the emotional range of a B-team Avenger? Of course you have ‚Äî you‚Äôre only human. But screenwriters Rowan Athale and Rob Yescombe took it upon themselves to actually make that dream a reality, and the result of their efforts is a high-concept slab of ‚ÄúNetflix movie of the week‚Äù sci-fi that wrestles with some big questions about the future of modern warfare via a conceit that borders dangerously close to ‚ÄúChappie.‚Äù
It‚Äôs rare to see something that dares‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Netflix‚Äôs latest mindless action extravaganza, Outside the Wire, is a so-called anti-war movie that leaves way to much to be desired. For fans of the genre it‚Äôs just another generic sci-fi action flick, though admittedly it‚Äôs made surprisingly enjoyable by its action set-pieces and chemistry between actors Anthony Mackie and Damson Idris who both shine throughout. However, things never progress beyond formulaic and whilst Anthony Mackie and Damson Idris do a great job, by the final third act things become too convoluted and, when mixed with a rather dreadful script, the film ultimately fails to deliver on its somewhat interesting premise.
2021 Releases Ranked', 'Einmal so geliebt werden, wie Netflix unterdurchschnittliche Actionfilme liebt.']

Title: Flavors of¬†Youth
Text:
The rigorous city life of China, while bustling and unforgiving, contains the everlasting memories of days past. Three stories told in three different cities, follow the loss of youth and the daunting realization of adulthood. Though reality may seem ever changing, unchangeable are the short-lived moments of one‚Äôs childhood days. A plentiful bowl of noodles, the beauty of family and the trials of first love endure the inevitable flow of time, as three different characters explore the strength of bonds and the warmth of cherished memories. Within the disorder of the present world, witness these quaint stories recognize the comfort of the past, and attempt to revive the neglected flavors of¬†youth. √ó

Title: Bad Day at Black¬†Rock
Text:
One-armed war veteran John J. Macreedy steps off a train at the sleepy little town of Black Rock. Once there, he begins to unravel a web of lies, secrecy, and¬†murder.
['If someone had told me this movie had Spencer Tracy karate chopping Ernest Borgnine I would‚Äôve watched it years ago', '‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not only wrong, you‚Äôre wrong at the top of your voice.‚Äù
What do this film and Mr. Magoo have in common, you ask? The answer is Millard Kaufman, creator of the myope and misanthrope at the respective centers of each. Spencer Tracy plays John J. Macreedy, a WWII veteran with a paralyzed arm making an unscheduled stop in the remote desert town from which the film takes its name.\xa0
The quietly hostile locals with a secret to keep don‚Äôt like strangers, particularly ones like Macreedy who don‚Äôt answer questions or respond to increasing levels of harassment. His arm and advancing years make him a seemingly soft target to town boss Robert Ryan and his gang of thugs, led by‚Ä¶ 
more', "There's of course a lot to be said for the expressive blocking; the aggressive beauty of the Lone Pines backdrop; the muscular moralism of the writing; the wizened professionalism of Spencer Tracy; Liz Wirth's heartbreaking near-last shot, a panicked face jutting into the sky's damning black void; and on and on. But honestly, the best detail of them all is somehow Robert Ryan's red baseball cap, which to me adds this tinge of dastardly boyishness to everything here‚Äîfor its horror, the group politics at play throughout is essentially juvenile. The outsider is an outsider just because; the recourse to blaming World War II is never quite convincing, is it? Their hearts aren't in it, because the reality of it is‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: The Jazz¬†Singer
Text:
A young Jewish man is torn between tradition and individuality when his old-fashioned family objects to his career as a jazz singer. This is the first full length feature film to use synchronized sound, and is the original film¬†musical.
['it‚Äôs not even a talkie they just sing like two songs and do blackface and that‚Äôs the whole thing', "On this evidence, I'm not sure talking pictures are a very good idea.", 'I don‚Äôt think we should be as ignorant as the film is, in so many ways. Here is a film that is eternalized in cinema history not for its artistic greatness, but for its technical pioneering. Yet, it carries with it the ignorance of an era, a specter of insensitivity that the passage of time cannot justify. Is the film the milestone of sound in cinema? Yes. But paradoxically it‚Äôs a work deaf to reality itself.\nAgain, there is no denying the relevance of the film. It was the first spark of the fire that would consume the silent era, a milestone that redefined the way the stories would be told from then on. We heard, for the first time,‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Four¬†Daughters
Text:
Between light and darkness stands Olfa, a Tunisian woman and the mother of four daughters. One day, her two older daughters disappear. To fill in their absence, the filmmaker Kaouther Ben Hania invites professional actresses and invents a unique cinema experience that will lift the veil on Olfa and her daughters‚Äô life stories. An intimate journey of hope, rebellion, violence, transmission and sisterhood that will question the very foundations of our¬†societies.
['(nathan fielder voice) Olfa needed to move past her trauma. So I hired two actresses to portray her estranged daughters and had her and her other two daughters reenact everything they‚Äôd gone through.', 'An astounding experiment that grows into something trippy, beguiling and unnerving. I turned to my partner while watching this to say I felt like I was on drugs even though I was not (for once) while watching this. One of the most stunning examples of 
the feminine grotesque 
I‚Äôve seen in a very long time.', 'An extremely honest and open look at generational trauma, this portrays what drove two young girls to leave their family for ISIS with an entirely unique hybrid between documentary and collaborative storytelling. Honestly, I‚Äôm not even 100% convinced it‚Äôs ethical. It feels like listening in on group therapy, but the real girls direct the actors. The actors chastise the women they are portraying, and we jump in and out of roleplay all the time. It‚Äôs really something and gets moments from people that are overwhelmingly intimate.
I think that Kaouther Ben Hania gets away with all this blurring because it feels like there is a real bond between all the filmmakers. She managed to create a real connection on set,‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: A Bittersweet¬†Life
Text:
Kim Sun-woo is an enforcer and manager for a hotel owned by a cold, calculative crime boss, Kang who assigns Sun-woo to a simple errand while he is away on a business trip; to shadow his young mistress, Hee-soo, for fear that she may be cheating on him with a younger man with the mandate that he must kill them both if he discovers their¬†affair.
["Kim Sun-Woo only smiled on two occasions.
1. When he was shadow-boxing in front of his reflection. His grin grew wider as his punches went faster and faster. He was admiring himself; of how fearless he was, of the pain he was capable of delivering with his bare fists. Violence pleases him. 
2. When he was watching Hee-Soo perform the cello, totally enthralled by her beauty and elegance. The 
music
 pierced through every barrier he had set up, causing havoc deep within him. He was supposed to be a stone cold enforcer spying on his boss's girlfriend, yet he did not even struggle when all his teeth peeked through his lips. He was in love.
The world is not easy.‚Ä¶
 
more", 'The absurd, stubborn, twisted masculinity behind all that heroic bloodshed.', "Me: I don't like violence in movies

Title: D√©j√†¬†Vu
Text:
Called in to recover evidence in the aftermath of a horrific explosion on a New Orleans ferry, Federal agent Doug Carlin gets pulled away from the scene and taken to a top-secret government lab that uses a time-shifting surveillance device to help prevent¬†crime.
['Tony Scott saw Vertigo, scoffed, and was like "I can do this better, I'll just tack on two additional acts and throw in a time machine"', "Tony Scott takes a high-concept post-9/11 surveillance state conspiratorial sci-fi studio movie and reworks it into his own version of a Hitchcockian obsessed detective story and an expressive formal love letter to man's relationship with images/technology; together, at their very best, able to conquer fate, death, and reality... One of the most romantic films ever made. We miss you every day, Tony.", "A police procedural compounded by time travel and obsessive longing, as if someone reverse-engineered 
Vertigo
 from Chris Marker's deconstruction of it in 
Sans soleil
, then decided to wrap it up in an overarching response to the entire failure of the Bush era, from the Patriot Act to Hurricane Katrina, and then put THAT into a fragmented action thriller. The result is nearly unclassifiable, parlaying the one-sided, unhealthy romantic obsession of the savior complex of thrillers that 
Vertigo
 so brutally unpacked into a broader rumination on the security state, one that finds no value in a massive surveillance apparatus that violates every norm only to find the guilty but does find a more complex, purely fantastical hope in the idea of‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Universal¬†Language
Text:
Winter. Somewhere between Tehran and Winnipeg. Negin and Nazgol find a sum of money frozen deep within the sidewalk ice and try to find a way to get it out. Massoud leads a group of befuddled tourists upon an increasingly-strange walking tour of Winnipeg historic sites. Matthew leaves his job at the Qu√©bec government and embarks upon a mysterious journey to visit his estranged¬†mother.
['I Shoulda Never Smoke That Shit Now Im At Tha Brutalist Iranian Tim Hortons', 'there‚Äôs such a thin line between homages that re-contextualize the original material in an interesting way vs. embarrassing ripoffs that leave you wishing you were watching the good stuff (kill bill to lady snowblood vs. joker to king of comedy)\xa0but this hits it out of the park as the former. which is all the more impressive when you consider the sheer number of distinct voices it pulls from (kiarostami, tati, kaurism√§ki, andersson). i was immediately snapped back to my 2019 screening of 
twentieth century
\xa0when i couldn‚Äôt wrap my head around what i was watching but was blown away by the commitment to its artificiality. this is only slightly more coherent than 
century\xa0
(as someone who doesn‚Äôt think about Winnipeg ever) but‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Despite being set in a parallel-universe Winnipeg where the people talk in Farsi and the world around them seems as if it‚Äôs been frozen in time since the mid-1980s (when Abbas Kiarostami, Mohsen Makhmalbaf, and the other masters of Iranian meta-realism were exploding onto the international stage), the haunted but hopeful ‚ÄúUniversal Language‚Äù is an unmistakably modern film at heart. 
Described by writer-director Matthew Rankin as a piece of ‚Äúautobiographical hallucination,‚Äù this wonderfully deadpan whatsit is the work of a white 43-year-old Canadian man who fell in love with the movies a time when ‚Äúforeign‚Äù cinema was becoming more available to people outside major cultural hubs. He found that Kanoon-style fables like ‚ÄúWhere Is the Friend‚Äôs House?‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe White‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: HyperNormalisation
Text:
We live in a world where the powerful deceive us. We know they lie. They know we know they lie. They do not care. We say we care, but we do nothing, and nothing ever changes. It is normal. Welcome to the post-truth world. How we got to where we are¬†now‚Ä¶
['This is the documentary equivalent of reading Wikipedia while drunk.', 'Ultimately, Curtis‚Äô argument is that the oversimplification of complex problems breeds oversimplified solutions, and when these overly simple solutions are implemented‚Äîoften violently‚Äîthey produce unintended consequences that further complicate the calculus. I would like to keep this front and center, because while Curtis has many aesthetic and methodological weaknesses, the framing of his thesis remains sound, even if he himself is not fully beholden to it. The case for complexity is a flexible position, one that does not divide political and ideological camps into categories of right and wrong‚Äîor even of more right and more wrong‚Äîbut flattens them, from communism to fascism, across political parties and religious and cultural divides. He is not saying they are the same‚Äîa false equivalency to‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'Decades of Western politicians sacrificing lives to construct/preserve their fake reality and keep imposing their "oversimplified solutions" on "oversimplified issues", like the largest most horrific theater ever performed... And people are shocked that a racist egomaniac, with a background in fraud and reality television, might somehow be good at this game.']

Title: Into the¬†Blue
Text:

But their good fortune is short-lived, as a ruthless gang of criminals gets word of what they have¬†uncovered.
['I am in bisexual hell brought to you by Miss Jessica Alba and Mr Paul Walker', 'they don‚Äôt make movies like this anymore man.\xa0\nI miss beautifully shot, dumb, mid-budget thrillers on the high seas, whose elevator pitch was probably something like, ‚Äúa bunch of beautiful people fight under water for treasure....and cocaine‚Äù, but were earnest as hell.\xa0\nThe early aughts whipped ass.', 'i watched into the blue for the plot! (jessica alba and paul walker).']

Title: Missing
Text:
Based on the real-life experiences of Ed Horman. A conservative American businessman travels to Chile to investigate the sudden disappearance of his son after a military takeover. Accompanied by his son‚Äôs wife he uncovers a trail of cover-ups that implicate the US State department which supports the¬†dictatorship.
['obsessed with the fact that the us state department released a three page statement denouncing this film. that‚Äôs worth more than any silly little award', 'The most conventional aspect of Missing is that Ed and Beth are on opposite sides of the political spectrum, and a number of their scenes together are him trying to reckon with her ‚Äúkooky leftist views‚Äù that spit in the face of his conservative Christian Science. That Missing is helmed by one star from Old Hollywood (Lemmon) and one star from New Hollywood (Spacek) lends it an interesting air of legitimacy, so to speak. It‚Äôs not only that the horrible events of the film are happening, but they are happening to beloved Americans! The indignity! The injustice! The film goes so far to say as much just that near its conclusion, in which one of the sniveling U.S. diplomats says something to the effect that Lemmon‚Äôs Ed would not even care what the United States is doing in another country were he not personally involved.
more in fran magazine', '‚Äúthey are killing people here, and nobody knows who‚Äôs next.‚Äù
Really intense on multiple levels. At first we‚Äôre thrown into the dread of not knowing what‚Äôs happening or who to trust, the world has already collapsed into chaos. The film makes you feel the shock of sudden powerlessness, as scattered attacks erupt from a repressive, murderous regime. But the terror goes deeper than soldiers in the streets ‚Äì it‚Äôs the realization that the rule of law has been replaced by the rule of the lawless. That order can be overturned overnight, leaving nothing to hold on to. And that there is no shelter. Even the people you believed were always on your side are the ones helping to cover it‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Strawberry¬†Mansion
Text:
In the not-too-distant future, an all-seeing surveillance state conducts ‚Äúdream audits‚Äù to collect taxes on the unconscious lives of the populace. Mild-mannered government agent James Preble travels to a remote farmhouse to audit the dreams of Arabella ‚ÄúBella‚Äù Isadora, an eccentric, aging artist. Entering Bella‚Äôs vast VHS archive, which contains a lifetime of dreams, Preble stumbles upon a secret that offers him a chance at love‚Äîand hope for¬†escape.
['there‚Äôs a frog that plays jazz music and a turtle named sugar baby...need i say more', "I dream of you always. 
I dream of you now, as the world burns around me, as I feel so lost and so overwhelmed in the life I live. The rut I'm stuck in, the boulder I push, it feels effortless when I think of you. 
I dream of you in my darkest hours and in my brightest days. I dream of you when I am incapable of thinking, the love I feel transcending all else. 
We could be stranded on an desert island. I could be searching for you on the open seas. I could be buried under the mountain of my guilt, the tremendous burden of my inadequacies, the pain of my mistakes, and I would still be‚Ä¶ 
more", "Wacky, batshit, stunningly sincere. Wasn't a fan of everything but it's got the kind of unbridled creativity movies in general could use more of"]

Title: I Spit on Your¬†Grave
Text:
A beautiful woman from the city, Jennifer Hills, rents an isolated cabin in the country to write her latest novel. Soon, a group of local lowlifes subject her to a nightmare of degradation, rape, and¬†violence.
['The gratuitous nature of the rape scene, used only to create a motive for revenge, make this one insulting piece of crap. This does not empower women, it exploits them, no matter how much gore you throw at us afterwards. 
Uncomfortable to watch? Sure. Infuriating? Most definitely.', 'rape revenge movie written and directed by a man ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶..', 'Overall, fuck this movie and any motivation behind making the film. It is billed as a movie about getting revenge for being raped but it feels more like a movie made by guys that derive pleasure from watching rape scenes. 
I give this one star because the editing and directing of the first 20 minutes of the film is well-shot and creepy. In addition, the devices created to torture and kill the rapists at the end are well-designed and would have been fun in another type of horror film. 
Skip it!']

Title: The¬†Innkeepers
Text:
During the final days at the Yankee Pedlar Inn, two employees determined to reveal the hotel‚Äôs haunted past begin to experience disturbing events as old guests check in for a¬†stay.
['I‚Äôm one of those weirdos that love slow, boring, hallway roaming ghost movies‚Äîespecially when its set in a beautiful old building like the hotel/inn featured here. I dunno, I know slow burn can be an acquired taste for some but this thing oozes atmosphere that I love and is right up there with 
House of the Devil
\xa0as far as atmosphere led roaming empty house movies of the 21st century.\xa0
Around the time of this movies release I was getting back into slower brooding gothic horror and 70‚Äôs ghost story stuff, so I was so stoked for this. Title: Around the World in Eighty¬†Days

["For better and for worse, easily the most British movie I've ever seen. Fun to see all of these shots lined up in a way that you know they're cameos, but have absolutely no idea who the hell they are.
I have fond memories of watching and rewatching the 2004 Coogan/Chan remake of this film so I was very excited to watch the original, and honestly I think I enjoyed the goofy remake more! This one is pretty bloated at 3 hours, and the ending is shockingly underdone for a film that takes its time literally everywhere else‚Äì but you also get why it's so long! It's a true spectacle! Title: A¬†Cop
Text:
A Parisian police chief has an affair, but unbeknownst to him, the boyfriend of the woman he‚Äôs having an affair with is a bank robber planning a¬†heist.
['The eyes. It's all about the eyes. Alain Delon's blue eyes and Catherine Deneuve's green eyes. Eye contact between characters, between friends, between partners, between enemies. Eye contact with Van Gogh. Robbers communicate with their eyes during heists, look, nod, only a few words uttered. The camera would always follow the movement of the eyes, constantly shifting as characters exchange glances, or stare at each other.
Through Simon's (Richard Crenna) eyes we see that he's a confident robber. Calm and skillful. Through Coleman's (Alain Delon) eyes we see that he's a weary detective, sick and tired of it all. 
"No, I don't know him."
 said Simon. The camera rapidly cut between Simon's and Coleman's eyes. The tension rised exponentially. Throw‚Ä¶ 
more', 'As a big Melville fan, I found this somewhat disappointing.
This has the same signature cold style I love in many of his other movies, but the plot isn‚Äôt as gripping as his other films. It does have some technical sequences that are extremely impressive, but didn‚Äôt give me as much reason to care about its characters.
Part of it (which is partially my problem) is I was mixing up the characters all the time. There‚Äôs groups of men in trench coats all the time, and I was confused who was a good guy and who was a bad guy.\xa0
Don‚Äôt know how they got Catherine Deneuve to show up for a small supporting role but that was a fun surprise!', "Action! ‚Äì Three Auteurs: In The Wavelength of Melville
Melville‚Äôs marathon concludes with probably the weakest of these stylish crime thrillers. There‚Äôs plenty of good to be found, namely that memorable and awesome train sequence, which goes to show the director‚Äôs great skills in shooting this complex action and tense set pieces. All the performances once again are pretty good, especially Delon, who is now playing on the right side of the law and does really well as the cop trying to stop these thieves from reaching their goal. I wasn't a big fan of the blue cinematography, but I guess it adds a distinctive and distinguishing tone to the film.
All in all, not the greatest way to cap‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Impossible
Text:
In December 2004, close-knit family Maria, Henry and their three sons begin their winter vacation in Thailand. But the day after Christmas, the idyllic holiday turns into an incomprehensible nightmare when a terrifying roar rises from the depths of the sea, followed by a wall of black water that devours everything in its path. Though Maria and her family face their darkest hour, unexpected displays of kindness and courage ameliorate their¬†terror.
['what do you mean tom was 16 in this movie I THOUGHT HE WAS 9', 'mother: *literally coughing up blood so much, might be genuinely dying*\nTom Holland: mum, what are you doing? STOP IT MUM, THATS ENOUGH! \nSTOP IT!', "I understand that this is a true story but I also wish that they'd stop making films about things that happen in non-White countries and then have it star all white people... This family is extremely blessed because not only were they born into privilege and monetary stability, but they were lucky enough to have all survived AND they got to return back to their home in the end. In reality, thousands of Thai people did not get to hop on a plane; they lost not only family members, but their homes and cities. Every last thing they owned. I'd like to hear one of their stories, even if it doesn't have the Blockbuster happy ending everyone wants in order to feel better about disasters like this one."]

Title: Who Killed Captain¬†Alex?
Text:
Recognized as Uganda‚Äôs first action film, Who Killed Captain Alex? is about the aftermath of a police raid in Kampala in which a police captain is¬†killed.
['I am physically incapable of giving this any less than 5 stars', 'Best movie to feature Seal\'s "Kiss From a Rose."', 'Absolutely amazing. The DIY production, the gleeful violence, the feverish "Video Joker" emcee narration, they all mark this (at least to my questionable mind) as pure, completely guileless exploitation cinema. This is the work of people excited to see themselves on screen, an unmediated product of their own self-image. Outsiders and smarter people than myself can dissect it as ethnography, and they should, but above all it just wants to be "Uganda\'s First Action Movie", and it\'s great.']

She was always smoking. I didn't mind. It was her way of coping. She also didn't mind my way. It was being where she was. When I was near her, I wasn't just around her but

more", "Life is exhausting. I make one mistake after another. My past feels like it is clinging to me, never allowing me to move forward. Sometimes I think the pain I caused has earned me a life sentence of loneliness. However, maybe this sentence is self-imposed. 
I want to love and be loved, but to be caught in the intricate web of people's lives frightens me. A relationship with one person propels me into the orbits of others. Each loose association presents endless possibilities: both good and bad. I fear those harmful potentials far too much to risk embracing any connections at all. 
So, here I am. I exercise authority over the fine details of my life. I keep my clothes‚Ä¶

Title: Hellraiser
Text:
A young woman struggling with addiction comes into possession of an ancient puzzle box, unaware that its purpose is to summon the Cenobites, a group of sadistic supernatural beings from another¬†dimension.
['Hate to be the stick in the mud on this one - especially considering how much I loved Bruckner's THE NIGHT HOUSE - but it just doesn't work for me. It's too long, the new Cenobite designs are too glossily plastic (not to mention weirdly sexless), the mythology is a muddled mess, and it leans way too heavily on modern elevated horror trappings in order to get going (why do we have to sit through another sad addiction movie?). Kept hoping that the main character would turn out to be a new Frank (which would be a helluva perspective shift), but it just never dares to be truly daring and weird. Glad others seem to be into it (and that it's release finally got me to quit stalling and read THE SCARLET GOSPELS), but ultimately this is just a half-hearted "nope" from be.', 'oh no she‚Äôs hot', "The\xa0
Hellraiser 
franchise is a little like Survivor in that it can change its shape like liquid to fit into whatever container its placed in. It's done slasher, torture porn, 90s HBO rerun cheese, and even flirted with that most golden calf of horror: Italian feeling. With the latest installment we've finally gotten a prestige horror 
Hellraiser.\xa0
As with all prestige horror, the themes are laid bare for you so you don't have to go digging for them. This time it's addiction, one of my favorite themes due to my own addiction struggles. \xa0Naturally this caused me to watch the movie incorrectly.\xa0I kept pointing at the screen like a four year old watching\xa0

Title: A Coffee in¬†Berlin
