Oh Boy
...
Frances Ha
...
I know it is a coincidence that two Allen-esque, 
Manhattan
-ish, odes to urban existence popped up at the same time. I know that the two films are separated by ocean and kept apart by their very different relationships to history (or lack thereof). And I know that I shouldn't even contemplate lumping them in the same basket. But, to be fair, both films have gone in so hard at the black and white generational-self-examination-through-cityscape-proxy template that it would be a shame not to treat them as a set. Two listless twenty-somethings wrestling with their oh-so-self-conscious apathy, attempting to find their way in the world, or at least negotiating their relationship to it. They are like‚Ä¶ 
more", 'at least he managed to drink that coffee', 'what if LOUIE were about an entitled young german kid who had seen too many Woody Allen movies and watched none of them closely enough?
full review to come on The Dissolve.']

Title: Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason¬†Lives
Text:
Tommy Jarvis, tormented by the fear that maybe Jason isn‚Äôt really dead, unwittingly resurrects the mass murderer for another bloody¬†rampage.
['95
Iconography rising from the grave. Slasher scuzz is transformed within a Gothic zombie cemetary masquerading as laboratory, consumed with relentless carnage, all while the autumnal, whispering leaves are dissipating as slowly as the laughs. A shining example of a horror-comedy that never forgets to be scary, and one that lingers on terrifying notions in hilarious ways. Paced like a bullet, every sequence leads to the next in exponential fashion. All the audience beats hit like a bass drop. The shot of the open cabin door, the shadow of the tree branches quivering in the wind, is an all-timer.', '‚ÄúWhat do you think?‚Äù
‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre dead meat.‚Äù
Shoutout James A. Janisse üòò
\xa0
We now return to our regularly scheduled programming. 
Part V
 doesn‚Äôt exist anymore, forget about it. Jason‚Äôs dead. Oh wait. Now he‚Äôs not. Lightning crashes. Maggot-covered eyes shoot open. A hulking figure rises from an unearthed grave. A man‚Äôs heart is punched out through his chest. A legend is reborn. Nightmares are refueled. A franchise is resurrected.
\xa0
This has always been my favorite film of the series. The best thing anyone ever did with Jason wasn‚Äôt making him supernaturally invincible, it was making him 
fun
. Yeah, he‚Äôs still crushing skulls, twisting heads, and folding bodies in half, but he‚Äôs also slowly stalking people outside‚Ä¶ 
more', 'A little unfortunate that it never really manages to top its all-timer opening where it playfully announces the franchise correcting course (away from Tommy or any other "mystery" killers taking up the Jason mantle, and back to Jason with a new supernatural comic-horror tone) via a rotting, maggot-covered Jason lying in his gothic grave, accidentally brought back to life by lightning hitting the piece of steel he's been impaled with like he's in a 30s Universal monster movie, and then proceeding to punch a dudes heart out of his chest and do a James Bond credit title sequence where instead of shooting a gun he slashes his machete at the screen and cuts an eyeball open... 
But the statement is‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Stage¬†Fright
Text:
A struggling actress tries to help a friend prove his innocence when he‚Äôs accused of murdering the husband of a high-society¬†entertainer.
['If ‚ÄúRear Window‚Äù is Alfred Hitchcock‚Äôs meta masterpiece on the art of filmmaking, then it‚Äôs ‚ÄúStage Fright‚Äù that is his commentary on the theatre.\xa0
It is, however, no masterpiece.\xa0
While Hitchcock has a stage director‚Äôs eye for blocking, a consideration passed over in favor of pure camera trickery by many of his cinematic peers, his is still an outsider to the world of the theatrical tradition. So, it is little shock that his portrayal of it comes across as, well, stagey. And not exactly one a type similar to the hallowed planks of Broadway or the West End.\xa0
‚ÄúStage Fright‚Äù stars Marlene Dietrich and Jane Wyman as two duelling actress; respectively, a glamorous siren, and a mousey pretender. While Hitchcock‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Stage fright is an interesting piece in Hitchcock‚Äôs filmography being his usual suspenseful psychological thriller but mixed with a theatrical aspect and is most admirable for its daring narrative and atmosphere but it‚Äôs not entirely perfect. The film follows Eva a drama student who gets tangled in a murder mystery with her friend Johnathan. Jonathan claims he‚Äôs being framed and from then on a web of lies and deceit plague the film. The film is full of twists and turns but the whole stage aspect of the film is used in a interesting way, being used to show the characters duplicity and the use of a certain flashback at the start of the film is an incredibly interesting storytelling device‚Ä¶ 
more', "Action! - The Master & The Fan: Hitchcock's Bumping Road To Mastering Suspense
Hitchcock ventures into the world of the theatre, where a former girlfriend of a man convicted of murdering her lover seeks to uncover who the true culprit is.
Once again, Hitchcock delivers another excellent film noir in which the cinematography and performances are the real standouts. Small details Details with really no apparent relevance, such as the lighting of the eyes with the dark background, not only improve the psychological value of a scene, but it also looks really cool. All of the performances are great, but Marlene Dietrich, to no one's surprise, lashes out at everyone with her singular presence that compels you to pay attention. The‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Assault on Precinct¬†13
Text:
A highway patrol officer, two criminals, and a station secretary form an unlikely alliance to defend a defunct Los Angeles precinct against a siege by a bloodthirsty street¬†gang.
['John Carpenter is the best director of all time.', "An interracial gang wages an all-out assault on a police station. In their way is a street smart cop, a hottie with a nice rack, and a con who really wants a smoke. A blood-oath. An ice cream truck. A Real Housewife of Beverly Hills's last scoop of vanilla. A father's swift justice with a twist. Being marked for death by Che and the gang. A dispatcher's last call. A save-ass plan. A game of hot potato seals Snow White's fate. Backseat peek-a-boo. Having to wing it. Not arguing with a confident man. The ultimate last stand. Wilson finally gets that smoke. Carpenter's Mona Lisa.", 'I knew the ice cream scene was coming but I still gasped when it happened']

If you mashed a post-apocalyptic setting together with the Castlevania games and 
Bloodborne
, and portrayed the result with animation comparable to films like 
Ghost in the Shell
‚Ä¶

Title: The Last Man on¬†Earth
Text:
When a disease turns all of humanity into the living dead, the last man on earth becomes a reluctant vampire¬†hunter.
["If I was the last man on earth I would probably care little about my appearance. Vincent Price still hangs around the house with perfect hair, a sweater vest , and a tweed coat. Why? Because he's Vincent Price. Well played sir.", 'Night of the Dawn of the Day of the Living.
Manages to feel like all three of Romero‚Äôs original\xa0
Dead 
trilogy in one movie four years before that cycle even started. Lingering mood of despair coats the atmos like dust in an unkept house. Stagnant existence only kept alive by routine, zombie vampire outbreak hell scenario anchored by a top tier turn from Price‚Äîechoing the desperation and loneliness of being the last man on earth.\xa0
Days Gone Bye‚ÄîI Am Legend.
This story is so influential and I‚Äôm Super glad I didn‚Äôt watch this last year at the height of everything going down, this is a sad movie and it‚Äôs scary for a variety of reasons. The first act alone is so‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I really don‚Äôt understand what Dr. Robert Morgan is so upset about‚Ä¶sure he lost his family in a pandemic and seems to be the only living boy left on the face of the planet, but he also has an awesome bachelor pad. All things considered, the house seems to be in great shape and adequately keeps the vampires* at bay. Morgan has what seems to be an infinite supply of garlic, perfect for adding zest to his post-apocalyptic diet, while also doubling as an effective security system for his dojo. He has a top-of-the-line stereo system, and since he has no neighbors, he can blast his jazz records all night long without complaint. Morgan must have raided his local package‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Life Is¬†Sweet
Text:
Just north of London live Wendy, Andy, and their twenty-something twins, Natalie and Nicola. Wendy clerks in a shop, Andy is a cook who forever puts off home remodeling projects, Natalie is a plumber and Nicola is jobless. This film is about how they interact and play out family, conflict and¬†love.
['right after this movie ended, we watched the entire thing over with directors commentary and mike leigh literally ends it by being like "of all my movies, this is my least favorite. thank you for watching". king behavior', '77/100\nThe problem with Leigh\'s working method, I suspect, is that it\'s vulnerable to the sunk-cost effect‚Äîit\'d be pretty rough for him to orchestrate months of intense exploration with an actor and then decide that it just isn\'t working. Anyway, that\'s my preferred rationalization for Timothy Spall\'s performance as Aubrey, which is so broadly cartoonish that it repeatedly threatens to capsize what is otherwise a magnificent family portrait. Everyone else is exaggerated but nonetheless recognizably human, often with their most capable qualities deliberately hidden for a while and then deployed for maximum effect. (The mid-film reveal of Andy as a chef in charge of a large staff remains one of my all-time favorite "plot twists."). Even Nicola, who at first‚Ä¶ \nmore', "What a beautiful little slice of life. It's impressive how the family is depicted as direct and honest, but the underlying drama is how one of them is keeping a dark part of her life secret. It culminates in an argument that isn't so much an argument as an angry expression of love, and yet, it never loses its edge and realism. It's lightly silly, but never unreal. So genuine it hurt. I loved it."]

(cn: csa)
 
evidence like this

Title: Sin¬†Nombre
Text:
Sayra, a Honduran teen, hungers for a better life. Her chance for one comes when she is reunited with her long-estranged father, who intends to emigrate to Mexico and then enter the United States. Sayra‚Äôs life collides with a pair of Mexican gangmembers who have boarded the same American-bound¬†train.
['‪Cary Fukunaga may have few features under his belt, but since this debut he‚Äôs proved himself to be the most eclectic shapeshifter in the industry (watch out, Ron Howard). Writing and directing for both films and TV, he has proven to be adept at every genre ‚Äî\xa0
Maniac
 (quirky mind-bending sci fi that itself veers into myriad subgenres), 
True Detective 
(anthology crime drama)\xa0
Beasts of No Nation
 (violent war biopic),\xa0
It
 (classic horror remake), &\xa0
Jane Eyre
 (Victorian-era literary adaptation). This year, we‚Äôll even see his take on Bond (
No Time to Die
). 
Watching\xa0
Sin Nombre 
‚Äî a gritty adventure / social realist tale of a Mexican gang member and a young Honduran teen hopping trains and kindling a relationship as they immigrate to America‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Yet another phenomenal debut from a first time director. Tonight‚Äôs pick was a combination of influences. This is Thursday, which is the night we invite our neighbours over to watch either something we‚Äôve seen and loved, or something we missed that was screened at TIFF. As it turns out, tonight‚Äôs pick was Lise‚Äôs based on her loving the film ( I didn‚Äôt see it ) and the fact that our neighbours were departing for a Mexican vacation tomorrow morning.
Maybe that wasn‚Äôt the best pick, sweetie, but they sure did love it.
The previous Thursday we showed them Monsters and Men, an incredible first feature from director Reinaldo Marcus Green. Now tonight, another incredible first feature from Cary Joji Fukunaga.‚Ä¶ 
more', "Wow, what a great film. Sin Nombre is a beautiful simple story of two people who need to get a way from their lives. Willy needs to escape his gang, although he is fairly certain he will not succeed, and Sayra needs to get to New Jersey to start a new life in America. 
In a fantastic debut, Cary Fukunaga gives us a glimpse into the world of illegal immigrants and the lengths to which they will go to get a better life. The film is real and gritty. Fukunaga doesn't shy away from showing desperation, but the film is ultimately hopeful without being sentimental in the slightest. As with the rest of the film, the characters are compelling and honest and very real. Sin Nombre is definitely one of the best films of 2009."]

Title: Distant Voices, Still¬†Lives
Text:
Siblings Maisie and Tony, along with their mother, gather for their sister Eileen‚Äôs wedding. It is a joyous occasion, but through flashbacks, it becomes clear that the family was not always happy. Their father was physically abusive to his wife and left the children emotionally traumatized. As a result, the children have grown into unhappy adults, looking for love they didn‚Äôt receive when they were¬†young.
["What this film neatly does is both revel in and put the lie to nostalgia. Capturing the past through (musical) standards and brief memories, it drifts to and fro between moments of joy and camaraderie and moments of patriarchal dominance and domestic violence in such a way as to capture not just the moments but also the atmosphere of the past. It doesn't look back at the horrors and say that it wasn't all bad; it looks back at the joys and says that it wasn't all good, and yet, it lets both have as much standing as the other.
And then, the film segues seamlessly into the characters' present (which is still deep within our past) and shows the‚Ä¶ 
more", '100
"I sit and wait for the sun
To shine down on me once again
It rained when I found you, rained when I lost you
That's why I get the blues when it rains"
Terence Davies offers a lyrical sense of ritual amidst the process of ordinary life in Liverpool. Funerals and births, Christmases and birthdays, baptisms and evening trips to the cinema. Yet a typical rainy morning, as the family begins to stir and breakfast is being made, isn't exactly seen, merely heard over the soundtrack. Their presence is a ghostly remnant of a world that has already disappeared. But their voices are heard, loud and clear, singing into the night.', 'This film floored me. A narrative that seems to swirl and float like Davies‚Äô camera, through the unmoored memories of a family‚Äôs life. A loving mother, two loving daughters, and a loving son, all at the mercy of a merciless father. The melancholy that permeates even the best of times. All this strength and sadness underscored and elevated by the songs the family sings together in the pub.
The only other Terence Davies film I‚Äôve seen is 
The Long Day Closes
, and it‚Äôs beautiful. This film felt different, though. Something about Davies‚Äô camera panning across those singing faces felt transcendent. It‚Äôs a feeing I get when I watch films like 
In the Mood For Love\xa0
and 
Ordet
. Only film can do this.
Favorite Films']

Title: Cruella
Text:
In 1970s London amidst the punk rock revolution, a young grifter named Estella is determined to make a name for herself with her designs. She befriends a pair of young thieves who appreciate her appetite for mischief, and together they are able to build a life for themselves on the London streets. One day, Estella‚Äôs flair for fashion catches the eye of the Baroness von Hellman, a fashion legend who is devastatingly chic and terrifyingly haute. But their relationship sets in motion a course of events and revelations that will cause Estella to embrace her wicked side and become the raucous, fashionable and revenge-bent¬†Cruella. √ó
["EMMA STONE COULD DO JOKER BUT JOAQUIN PHOENIX COULDN'T DO CRUELLA", 'i think the ‚Äúwhy would disney make a sympathetic movie about a puppy killer? üò°‚Äù faux-outrage is the biggest SNOOZE!! you think they‚Äôre actually gonna show her killing puppies? really? think about this for more than 5 seconds then\xa0criticize this 324-billion dollar corporation for ANYTHING else! we‚Äôre drowning in a sea of reheated, lukewarm content and you‚Äôre mad at the 
one
 that lets emma stone do deranged glam-punk camp? grow UP and have some FUN!', 'the rare movie that leaves you thinking "that would've been so much better if Emma Stone had murdered a lot of dogs."
(still kinda fun tho, despite everything)']

Title: Strike
Text:
Workers in a factory in pre-revolutionary Russia go on strike and are met by violent¬†suppression.
['More modern than any film I saw in 2018: it\'s not enough to show the abuses of the systematic, or merely depict that it exists - you have to see its intricacies and functions. Because then otherwise you\'re just fighting against thin-air. Notwithstanding that one has to be almost supernaturally talented for a film this brilliant to be their first (at this point I\'d argue that Eisenstein is the only genius that cinema produced, but that\'s for another write-up), you can\'t show these functions with the traditional western protagonist system - the canon itself is part of the oppression. Not that the maneuver is reactionary: by ditching the protagonist, or characters, or "story", we can get a direct and immediate‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'join a union! still feels like the future of cinema, both technically and politically, even after almost a hundred years. makes you wonder what can still be accomplished with a camera.', "85/100\nSuffering in layers ramping and stuttering through time; rhythmic and formally confrontational to the point of exhaustion. Eisenstein utilizes Montage as an intellectual, historical springboard, but there's still the lingering horror within the graphic nature of the cuts. Edits as varied, mathematical calculations of terror and breathtaking jolts. Prettyyyyy fuckin' Major."]

Title: Beowulf
Text:
A 6th-century Scandinavian warrior named Beowulf embarks on a mission to slay the man-like ogre,¬†Grendel.

Title: World on a¬†Wire
Text:
Cybernetics engineer Fred Stiller uncovers a massive corporate conspiracy involving a virtual reality computer¬†project.
['Cinematic paranoiac, the great philosophical science fiction mindfuck noir of 1973. As far as connecting with me mentally, this is right in my wheelhouse and pulverizes all the ‚Äònot for me‚Äô slop movies I‚Äôve been suffocated by over the last few weeks here in weirdo 2020.\xa0
Even better on a revisit.', "I fell asleep during 
The Matrix
. Its themes seemed to me, at the time of its release, more or less just trite ideas that I had already read about in various intro philosophy texts and whatnot, and the areas it touched on were never my areas of interest in philosophy anyway. It muddled its religious undertones, and the ethical questions were given short shrift. Fifteen years later, I watched a movie nearly twice as long, which eschews action in favor of psychological intensity, and tackles many--but not all--of the same questions. 
It was much better this time around.
The first and best difference is aesthetic. Fassbinder has created a science fiction world that looks schlubby. It's populated by suits and‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Fassbinder's science-fiction/noir hybrid was really years ahead of its time. Not only in its ideas but in its aesthetic as well. This was such an obvious influence on 
The Matrix
. The Wachowski sisters even modeled the "what does chicken really taste like" scene after a sequence included here.
Its 3,5 hour runtime might deter some modern day viewers from watching it, but they should at least give it a chance, because it's a very rewarding watch.']

Title: City of¬†Women
Text:
The charismatic Snaporaz encounters an alluring woman on a train and pursues her through a forest. He ends up at a hotel populated by women gathered for a feminist conference, where he is an unwanted presence. Snaporaz soon discovers he‚Äôs entered a phantasmagoric world where women have taken¬†power.
["How does it feel to be the object of the female gaze, Mastroianni? The same question could be asked of Fellini, a director who was always accustomed to smother his male characters with beautiful, voluptuous women. From 
LA DOLCE VITA
 (1960) to 
8¬Ω
 (1963), from 
JULIET OF THE SPIRITS
 (1965) to 
FELLINI'S CASANOVA
 (1976), women have always been portrayed as seductive mysteries onto which debonair men have projected their dreams and fantasies. These films are strongly autobiographical in nature, almost behaving like extensions of how Fellini feels about himself. The sheen of cool that once defined his male characters, like Marcello, Guido, and Giogio‚Äîeach, you'll recall, presented as if they could tantalize and possess any woman they desired ‚Äîfeels faded and‚Ä¶ 
more", '"What kind of film is this?"
Jesuschrist, what an astoundingly immense, all-encompasing, magnificent and otherworldly stupefying film! Absolutely relentless, mad, in love with poetry and language, and having an unequaled feminist power in the entire history of Italian cinema.
Mastroianni reflects, once again, the auteur's alter-ego with a modern Casanova character named Sn√†poraz, who is virtually Guido Anselmi's character sequel under the hypothetical construction that the man is still being haunted by the same memories and fantasies, but under a pervasive sexual decay and in an era where gender empowerment has reached an unprecedented state of social equality through a passionate, multigenerational struggle. The film makes a perfect balance between being a representation of the consciousness of men in all‚Ä¶ 
more', "Fellini is still very new to me, like for example I haven't gotten to arguably his most famous movies (La Dolce Vita, 8 1/2) yet but I've really liked the now four movies I have seen from him so far. Fellini has this fascinating tendency to be, for lack of a better term, a horny ghoul, but to also be very interested in female characters as people and very empathetic toward women in his movies. There's plenty of male gaze but I don't think there's really all that much objectification since Fellini is interested in the humanity of the women he is sexualizing. I think that is one reason City of Women is so wonderful: while this movie could have‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Mad¬†Max
Text:
In the ravaged near-future, a savage motorcycle gang rules the road. Terrorizing innocent civilians while tearing up the streets, the ruthless gang laughs in the face of a police force hell-bent on stopping¬†them.
['Definitely gives off "we ran out of budget" vibes in the third act but overall an absurd directorial debut. The score goes insanely hard! I spent the whole movie thinking "Well yeah, obviously Brian May of Queen would turn out something this phenomenal" and then I checked Wikipedia afterwards and it was a different Brian May', 'i find this movie fascinating in a metatextual sense more than i actually enjoy it; the structure is insane, with a climax that feels like the inciting incident and makes the whole movie feel like a prequel. the fact that it made $100 million is baffling until you watch the making of doc on the disc and realize the car action is another case of ‚Äúthis thing only seems pretty good because it essentially invented something you see all the time now.‚Äù the movie was inspired by george miller‚Äôs morbid experiences as a doctor. it cost $400,000. so many of the stunts were just them going ‚Äúthis is gonna be dangerous but do it anyway.‚Äù it‚Äôs honestly awesome to see so many of miller‚Äôs trademarks fully formed right out of the gate, and to realize that budgets have not squashed any of his ingenuity, only accelerated it. also why does the baby have a gun for one shot', 'Not sure how I'd missed this for so long. It's a fun little B-movie that sort of drags but has a few pretty special things going for it:
1- It's only set a few years in the future. So it's sort of post-apocalyptic but they still have the news and shit. More post-apocalyptic media should take a page out of this book and calm down.
2- The budget is clearly so low that all of the car crashes are exciting to watch because you can tell they only had the one take to nail it.
3- I could be wrong but I'm pretty sure this is the movie that invented the 80s action movie trope of "all bad guys are‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The¬†Strangers
Text:
After a 4 a.m. knock at the door and haunting voices, Kristen McKay and James Hoyt‚Äôs remote getaway becomes a psychological night of terror as three masked strangers invade. Now they must go far beyond what they thought themselves capable of if they hope to¬†survive.

Title: The¬†Servant
Text:
Indolent aristocrat Tony employs competent Barrett as his manservant and all seems to be going well until Barrett persuades Tony to hire his sister as a live-in¬†maid.
['Hitchcock levels of suspense about whether something gay was going to happen or not.', "The slowest burn home invasion movie you're ever likely to see. When upper class waster Tony (an early role for James Fox) hires a new manservant to cater to his every whim in his plush Kensington pad, he gets a little more than he bargained for. Slowly but surely Barrett inveigles his way into Tony's life, to the point where he's the one calling the shots.
Dirk Bogarde's performance in this is magnetic - even early on, there are little hints of his malevolence, just in the way he looks at Tony and his tone of voice. The further he gets his claws in, the less he cares about keeping up appearances and by the end, he's completely brazen; a‚Ä¶ 
more", "#Bogarde
Mirrors tell lies. You look into one and you see you. But that's not quite right. What you truly see is only the mask you're wearing to hide from yourself. 
Mirrors distort. They show you lies that mask the truth. And they twist even those lies into truthful perversion. 
The Servant 
is like a mirror. It tells the lie of a master-servant professional relationship and masks its personal truth. Its mirror twists its lie into a skewered flip of the hierarchy: master becomes servant and servant becomes master - and in the end both become servants of their own diseased minds. 
The Servant
 is a story of degradation inflicted on the other person but most of all, yourself. If‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: The Pink¬†Panther
Text:
The trademark of The Phantom, a renowned jewel thief, is a glove left at the scene of the crime. Inspector Clouseau, an expert on The Phantom‚Äôs exploits, feels sure that he knows where The Phantom will strike next and leaves Paris for the Tyrolean Alps, where the famous Lugashi jewel ‚ÄòThe Pink Panther‚Äô is going to be. However, he does not know who The Phantom really is, or for that matter who anyone else really¬†is‚Ä¶
['Ever since I saw this movie as a kid all I‚Äôve wanted is to hang out at European ski lodges where everyone wears turtlenecks and there are impromptu musical numbers', 'The Sellers stuff? Utter genius. Everything else? Less than genius.', 'In 
The Pink Panther
 
Blake Edwards
 combines the luxurious settings of the James Bond films with a series of cultural references: advertising, comics, Jacques Tati and the Feydeau farce, but above all introduces a legendary character who will outlive his creators and the passage of time. 
Peter Sellers

In fact, in this first episode of the saga, the real protagonist should‚Ä¶

Title: Leaving Las¬†Vegas
Text:
Ben Sanderson, an alcoholic Hollywood screenwriter who lost everything because of his drinking, arrives in Las Vegas to drink himself to death. There, he meets and forms an uneasy friendship and non-interference pact with prostitute¬†Sera.
['>Nicolas Cage researched his character by binge drinking, and would film himself drunk to study his speech patterns. 
One of the great pains in my life is that I will never see this footage.', "This film kicks my teeth in in the most beautiful way every time I watch it.
Whenever an artist manages to combine and contrast beauty and reality I'm always sucked in without reservation, often leaving me wrecked but smiling. Figgis, Cage and Shue made promises here they unfortunately never kept in their later careers.
The notion of a man leaving everything behind to drink himself to death in the capital of sin is as strong as it is fraught with the danger of skirting melodrama. Figgis manages to walk this tightrope really well as he is as unrelenting for his audience as Cage's character is for himself. He cuts no corners and unveils two lives that meet, linked in misfortune,‚Ä¶ 
more", '"Hey man, you want a drink?"
"Nah, I just watched Leaving Las Vegas"
"Oh, I'm sorry. I guess I'll see you around"
"Maybe"']

Title: Silent¬†Running
Text:
After the entire flora goes extinct, ecologist Lowell maintains a greenhouse aboard a space station for the future with his android companions. However, he rebels after being ordered to destroy the greenhouse in favor of carrying cargo, a decision that puts him at odds with everyone but his mechanical¬†companions.
['murdering people to save your garden is a mood', "relentlessly corny but there's something irresistible about the idea of a miniscule oasis drifting through the cruel darkness of infinite space", 'In space, no one can hear you garden...
Douglas Trumbull's "Silent Running" is science fiction painted in broad, allegorical strokes. Taking place in a future where the Earth's natural wonders have been decimated, "Silent Running" presents a scenario where those wonders are kept alive in the cosmos but are as threatened there as they were on the planet. The film rates as a pleasant genre outing with a screamed-aloud message and a just-this-side-of-bugnuts performance by Bruce Dern.
The film's story focuses on Dern's Lowell who, along with a crew of three other men and three Power Droid-predating drones, is traveling on an American Airlines (no joke) deep space vessel. Lowell is charged with maintaining the ship's flora and fauna but,‚Ä¶

Title: Cry¬†Macho
Text:
A one-time rodeo star and washed-up horse breeder takes a job from an ex-boss to bring the man‚Äôs young son home from¬†Mexico.
['A movie where very old man Clint asks the ultimate question: why be a macho man when you can be a nice man?', "85
Good god, this is charming. Clint is fucking 91 years old, frail as hell, still up on a horse and rocking a cowboy hat and a sly smile. It's almost absurd how kind and pleasant 
Cry Macho

The Mule
 or 
Gran Torino
, this doesn't entirely operate as a rumination of legacy or icon status. At least not explicitly. Rather, it seems to fully exist in the present, a gentle and genial reminder of simple pleasures and tender moments. Completely unadorned. Most of this movie is one long second act where Clint and a boy (who Clint is escorting out of Mexico so he can be with his father) hang out in a small village with a cantina‚Ä¶ 
more", 'In a world so impatient that people have started to whine about the injustice of movies playing in theaters for a few weeks before they (finally!) become available to watch at home, Clint Eastwood has spent the last 33 years waiting for the right time to make a sleepy, featherlight neo-Western about a widowed old rodeo star with nothing to live for, and the rooster named Macho who shows him the strength he needs to find new purpose.
The Hollywood legend first considered adapting M. Richard Nash‚Äôs ‚ÄúCry Macho‚Äù in 1988, but at the spry age of 58, he felt too young to play the lead, and decided to make another ‚ÄúDirty Harry‚Äù sequel instead. During the three decades that‚Ä¶

Title: Tower
Text:
Combining archival footage with rotoscopic animation, Tower reveals the action-packed untold stories of the witnesses, heroes and survivors of America‚Äôs first mass school shooting, when the worst in one man brought out the best in so many¬†others.
["This is uniquely powerful in its choice to barely acknowledge the gunman who on August 1st, 1966 took the University of Texas hostage by climbing the campus tower and firing at civilians below, and instead allow the brave survivors to dictate the way this event is told and remembered. It's harrowing to watch as they recall specific memories of the event (like a savior's hair color, or a part of the body that still remembers being preemptively ready to have a bullet penetrate it) and see them complimented by deeply expressive rotoscope animation reenactments that beautifully capture all the detailed, human moments and feelings that swirled around such a tragic day. In the end, it's those brief moments of humanity and bravery that are going to get us through events like these.", '76/100\nSecond viewing, no change. Tried to comprehend the objections of a few friends who are troubled by the use of rotoscoping and/or (very briefly) rock music, and just didn\'t see anything remotely exploitative or unseemly. The nonstop emphasis on courage and selflessness in the face of inexplicable horror could hardly be further removed from ghoulishness*, and again repeatedly moved me to tears. Still think Maitland brings the real subjects in way too early, but I see now why he made that choice‚Äîthe cut from "I guess this is it" (spoken by the young actor playing Claire, animated) to "I guess this is the end" (spoken by the elderly actual Claire, live-action) has exactly the right lacerating effect, and the‚Ä¶ \nmore', '"I realized that I was a coward."']

Title: Like Stars on¬†Earth
Text:
Ishaan Awasthi is an eight-year-old whose world is filled with wonders that no one else seems to appreciate. Colours, fish, dogs, and kites don‚Äôt seem important to the adults, who are much more interested in things like homework, marks, and neatness. Ishaan cannot seem to get anything right in class; he is then sent to boarding school, where his life changes¬†forever.
['can you believe that i literally spent HALF the movie CRYING??????', 'A Passage to India: Dawn of the Wobble
I remember coming across this film like a few years back, somewhere during that period where that war against the cult of Ghatak over here in LB was still fresh in my mind, and it took every desire I had of ever watching an Indian movie. So yeah, this one was a victim of those circumstances.
And many of the styles, humor, and fashion feel very much of their time and can get a little silly. I guess I can tolerate it a bit more than I normally would because this is ultimately more of a family friendly film about a kid, really well played by Darsheel Safary, who everyone thought was‚Ä¶ 
more', 'The entire show is divided into two acts and one should approach the film as such: the first one builds, to the film's extents and possibilities, the troubled universe and the competitively predatory capitalist mentality that has engulfed the world, and the internal world of a misunderstood and tormented child with different capabilities and a richer vision of the world (excellent animation segments too, from the sweet opening credits to the memorable "3X9 = 3" segment). The mentality that governs from small businesses to transnational corporations is criticized to the bone: "You need to come first and be the best; anything below 95% is sacrilege", as the film says. As a professor, I identify with the destruction of this motto‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Memory
Text:
Sylvia is a social worker who leads a simple and structured life: her daughter, her job, her AA meetings. This is blown open when Saul follows her home from their high school reunion. Their surprise encounter will profoundly impact both of them as they open the door to the¬†past.
["the director clearly had a thing for jessica's gods sculpted side profile he gets me", 'Memory
 
left me a little unsure how to unpack the story here. 
Jessica Chastain 
plays Sylvia, a 13 years sober, single mother, who is followed home by a man after attending a high school reunion. The man, Saul (
Peter Saarsgard
), turns out to be suffering from dementia and memory loss, but he may or may not have a shared history with Sylvia
 
somehow. Saul‚Äôs sudden appearance in Sylvia‚Äôs
 
life dredges up complicated trauma from her past, rifts in her relationships with her mother, sister and daughter, but also provides hope for the kind of relationship she‚Äôs been missing.\xa0
Chastain 
and 
Saarsgard 
both giving incredibly moving performances I was completely transfixed by the manner in which the story unfolds. There‚Äôs a‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Jessica Chastain always delivers the most authentic and stunning performances. I don‚Äôt know if there‚Äôs an actress currently that I get more excited to watch than her, she‚Äôs so graceful and complex in her acting. This film is very depressing, it‚Äôs got a coldness and melancholia to it, which I actually really loved. Maybe depressed and somber Jessica Chastain is my new favourite type of Chastain.
I feel this is the type of movie that will linger with me and that I‚Äôll be thinking about over the next few days.']

Title: Irma¬†Vep
Text:
Mira is an American movie star disillusioned by her career and a recent breakup, who comes to France to star as ‚ÄúIrma Vep‚Äù in a remake of the French silent film classic, ‚ÄúLes Vampires.‚Äù Set against the backdrop of a lurid crime thriller, Mira struggles as the distinctions between herself and the character she plays begin to blur and¬†merge.
['"Movies are a portal to some sort of spiritual world. Some sort of spiritual world we don‚Äôt have access to anymore."
Cinephiles will claim that this is a meta(physical) love letter to and critique of Cinema‚Ñ¢, a supplement to the 
original 
Irma Vep
, but we all know it's just that "hey" text you send your ex whenever you're horny, expanded to eight edging hours.', "Olivier Assayas really did just make the first episode incredibly gay so we'd all be forced to keep watching seven more episodes about his divorce", 'I talked to Olivier Assayas
 about episodes one through four.
"But, you know, it‚Äôs me and it‚Äôs not me. Ren√© is myself and not myself. The moment I give it to an actor and write the lines, shoot it on the set with a film crew, it does become something else. In the same way Jade Lee is not exactly Maggie ‚Äî even if part of it is [Laughs] based on real life. The thing is‚Ä¶ again, I feel comfortable with it because it‚Äôs a comedy, I‚Äôm making fun of myself, I deal with genuine emotions. But I think it‚Äôs genuine emotions everyone can share: love lost, failed marriage. Sadly [Laughs] it‚Äôs a very common situation. So I touch something that is pretty universal."']

Title: Star Trek:¬†Generations
Text:
Captain Jean-Luc Picard and the crew of the Enterprise-D find themselves at odds with the renegade scientist Soran who is destroying entire star systems. Only one man can help Picard stop Soran‚Äôs scheme‚Ä¶and he‚Äôs been dead for seventy-eight¬†years.

Okay but it will feel like a long, uneven episode of the show instead of a triumphant return. You want Picard and Kirk to finally meet each other? Okay but it'll settle nothing and mostly be two actors of wildly different styles having a conversation at each other where one of them tries to convince the other not to become an LL Bean guy. You want Data to finally become a real boy? Okay but that real boy's standing in line for a show at UCB and riffing‚Ä¶ 
more", 'The one where Kirk and Picard join forces to save Data's cat
Whatever bants get delivered when these two legendary captains of the Enterprise team up are undercut by the perfunctory nature of the premise that puts them together in the first place--an energy "ribbon" that is a portal to "The Nexus" which is essentially heaven--and a climax that is just three old men running around scaffolding. Feels like this one could have been a pretty good finale to TNG but underwhelms as a movie. There's also not much for any of the rest of the crew to do outside a corny subplot about Data implanting his "emotions" chip and acting like a complete dickhead. Antagonists include Malcolm McDowell as‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I take it the odds are against us, and the situation is grim.
-Kirk

 would have made a decent series finale for

The fact is that having these two characters meet adds nothing to the film much less the‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Hole
Text:
In the final days of the year 1999, almost everyone in Taiwan has died from a strange plague that ravished the island. Supposedly spread by cockroaches, the disease sends its victims into a psychosis where they act like the insects and eventually die. The two protagonists live In a crumbling apartment building right above and below each other. The woman is on the lower floor, and the pipes above her apartment are leaking fiercely, threatening to destroy her food supply, not to mention her sanity. She calls a plumber to go check it out, and he accidentally pokes a hole through the floor of the man‚Äôs apartment. The two have never met before, and they come into contact through the¬†hole. √ó
['the last movie you expect to be a musical (not complaining)', 'A shy romantic and a quiet slacker live in quarantine, secluded by rain and decay, almost alone, in a void. An accident gives them a glimpse of each other, and slowly but surely, through happenstance, continual observation, and occasional humanity, they eventually come together. 
There are so many strange ways you could take this film, but what stood out to me is the metaphor it illustrates for loneliness and the fear of personal connection. 
A disease keeps these two strangers isolated, but it also drives them together, with the ineptitude of a plumber helping that along. As they continually interact because of this hole left between their apartments, their relationship shifts. In the urban decay (in the case of the‚Ä¶ 
more', 'maybe the best aesthetic a movie has ever had']

Title: In the Name of the¬†Father
Text:

["i'm trying to get through daniel day lewis' filmography before phantom thread and so far it's difficult because the man has not been in a movie shorter than 2.5 hours", "How could 4 people be declared guilty of a despicable crime in the absence of testimonial or physical evidence of their guilt, and with the prosecution's dependence on contradictory and insufficient admissions?
Watching this movie was like reading a book that‚Äôs a spellbinding page-turner. The last 15 minutes were a pure adrenaline rush. That courtroom scene was riveting. My blood was boiling.
This movie delivers a hammering rock soundtrack by Hendrix, Dylan, Bono and Gavin Friday, setting a high-speed pace as fast as we can absorb to match the scene‚Äôs ambiance: we breathe rapidly, our adrenaline begins to surge, and our emotions go on a rollercoaster. It‚Äôs highly worth a watch in the name of the father of Gerry Conlon.", '"Our case was so insane, that if you made it up, nobody would believe it."
(Daniel Day Lewis as Gerry Conlon)
THIS STORY, BASED ON TRUE EVENTS, BRINGS EVERYTIME AGAIN TEARS IN MY EYES, AND DESPITE THE INCORRECTNESSES, IS THIS CINEMATIC INTERPRETATION HEARTBREAKING, NOT ONLY BECAUSE OF DANIEL DAY LEWIS MASTERFUL PERFORMANCE....']

Title: Into the¬†Abyss
Text:
We do not know when and how we will die. Death Row inmates do. Werner Herzog embarks on a dialogue with Death Row inmates, asks questions about life and death and looks deep into these individuals, their stories, their¬†crimes.
["Into the Abyss
 came really close to being too much truth for me to handle. Herzog takes people who are probably the least deserving in the world of sympathy and somehow makes you sympathize with them. It's an extremely powerful and emotional look at the many dimensions and interpretations of a heinous crime. He shows all sides of the story, including the crime itself, returning to the scene of the crime and attempting to recreate the circumstances. Then he interviews everyone involved, from the perpetrators of the crime to the families of the victims to employees of the capital punishment system. It all comes together to be a poignant and impassioned plea to end the death penalty and preserve the right of every human to live. 
No matter what your personal views on the issue, I bet you would find it hard not to feel at least some small inkling of sorrow for all the lives lost in this story.", 'When you gaze long into an abyss, the abyss also gazes into you
, said Nietzsche.\xa0
This becomes terrifyingly true when you gaze into Michael Perry‚Äôs black, lifeless eyes.', '"How does time occur to you now?" -Werner Herzog, 
- Werner Herzog Ranked:https://boxd.it/3MAT6
- 5x5 Directors Challenge 3 (Herzog 3/5): 
boxd.it/7ALXq
Ready to be depressed? 
In Into the Abyss, Herzog explores a clear cut guilty death penalty case, challenging the audience to truly wish death on a fellow human being. Life is so beautiful but it can be wasted and it can be tarnished and it can be devalued and that is what this film is about. Privileged communities often have the luxury of thinking of people that have committed crimes only by their worst acts. We don't often get forced to think about their family, their humanity, the circumstances, etc. It's a fantastic documentary. 
Werner Herzog does documentaries on‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Clear and Present¬†Danger
Text:
Agent Jack Ryan becomes acting Deputy Director of Intelligence for the CIA when Admiral Greer is diagnosed with cancer. When an American businessman, and friend of the president, is murdered on his yacht, Ryan starts discovering links between the man and drug dealers. As former CIA agent John Clark is sent to Colombia to kill drug cartel kingpins in retaliation, Ryan must fight through multiple cover-ups to figure out what happened and who‚Äôs¬†responsible.
['perfectly simulates the feeling of visiting your grandpa and getting to pick a movie from his VHS stack. pure comfort food', 'Patriot Games really suffers by comparison to this much better sequel. They get rid of almost all of the Ryan family dynamics and bring on Milius to punch up the screenplay about the CIA's secret war on a Colombian cartel, yes please. Milius really brings Clancy's fetishism of American military hardware to the fore, especially in the scene where they drop a "cellulose encased laser guided bomb" on a cartel compound. Also the scene where the FBI director, his SUV convoy, and like 20 agents get owned with RPGs in a Bogota alley is still so hard. 
The "bad guys" on both the Colombian and American sides have realistic motivations, unlike in Patriot Games where they are just dumb micks‚Ä¶ 
more', "65
 
A Sunday afternoon classic. Felt weird watching this not on TNT or AMC, but it's still quite the thrill. Highlights aren't just the traditional action moments, like a crazy convoy ambush, but also the scene where Harrison Ford is attempting to print the receipts before it's all deleted off the hacked computer. Wish there were a couple more of these Phillip Noyce/Tom Clancy cable staples, because they're perfect for a lazy day."]

Title: Inherent¬†Vice
Text:
In Los Angeles at the turn of the 1970s, drug-fueled detective Larry ‚ÄúDoc‚Äù Sportello investigates the disappearance of an¬†ex-girlfriend.
['Every ticket to INHERENT VICE should come with the choice of a joint or a second ticket to INHERENT VICE. You will need one or the other.', 'paul thomas anderson: *points his camera at absolute nonsense for 148 minutes*
me: OOOOOOOOAAAAAAAAAUUUUUUUUHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!', 'as rick dalton in 
once upon a time in hollywood
 so eloquently and masterfully said 
"dirty fucking hippies"']

Title: Yannick
Text:
In the middle of a performance of the play ‚ÄúLe Cocu‚Äù, a bad boulevard comedy at a Parisian theatre, Yannick gets up and interrupts the show to take the evening back in¬†hand.
['PoV : tu discutes avec le fou du train pour pas qu‚Äôil te tue', '- Tout le monde s‚Äôen fout de ta p‚Äôtite gueule\xa0\n- Je sais bien, pas la peine d‚Äô√™tre m√©prisant', 'moli√®re has been real quiet since yannick dropped this']

Title: Star Trek:¬†Insurrection
Text:
When an alien race and factions within Starfleet attempt to take over a planet that has ‚Äúregenerative‚Äù properties, it falls upon Captain Picard and the crew of the Enterprise to defend the planet‚Äôs people as well as the very ideals upon which the Federation itself was¬†founded.
['The one in which Picard and crew foment a revolt against the legitimate authority of The Federation on behalf of a colony of reactionary, all-white settlers.
The most right wing Star Trek by far. Flagrantly goes against the primary ethical maxim of "the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few." In this case, the "good guys" who Picard helps are a Space Rhodesia of only 600 people hoarding the secret to immortality for themselves and the "bad guys" are a group of people who rebelled against the trad-morality and isolationist ignorance of their colony and became decadent through contact with the outside world. They are coded as such because they're addicted to plastic surgery and a need‚Ä¶ 
more', "Something I've found chilling about watching all of the Star Trek movies is how closely my own opinions on them seem to align with the consensus takes. A death blow for the credibility of an 
enfant terrible 
of the Star Trek movies letterboxd review world such as myself. Thank god in all of Her(!) grace that we finally made it to Insurrection, a movie I think is probably about as good as First Contact, shattering the stale and oppressive opinions of the letterboxd tastemaker machine who suffocate us all.
I think I said earlier that this movie should've been a Deep Space Nine movie. I stand by that. It should've been. I'm told that many nerds agree with me on‚Ä¶ 
more", "The question for the production team of Star Trek: Insurrection was always going to be - now we've done the Borg, where the hell do we go next? With Jonathan Frakes back in the chair after his impressive work on First Contact, the answer came in the form of the late Michael Piller, who spearheaded much of The Next Generation TV show at its peak, and takes over on writing duties for a film he seeks to take back to the roots of not so much Trek itself, but certainly the more thoughtful and allegorical TNG. Said allegory here, of course, is imperialism as Insurrection concerns a so-called 'battle for Paradise' and the forced relocation of a small group of‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: The¬†Borderlands
Text:
Vatican investigators are sent to the British West Country to investigate paranormal activity, and they find the events are more disturbing than they first¬†imagined.
['Who found the footage', "When it comes to found footage horror movies I have a sort of love (REC.2007) and hate (THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT) relationship with them and FINAL PRAYER... well it's a complicated relationship.
Final Prayer aka The Borderlands doesn't offer anything original as it follows the same routine most found footage films does but having said that it isn't that dumb of a movie there was a proper train of thought behind it and it did manage to do certain things properly rather than just pulling out a jump scares fest filled with shitty shaky cam.
The plot makes sense as the characters aren't forcing themselves in the unknown territory just to make a few bucks and are there on a‚Ä¶ 
more", '"The Borderlands", also known as "Final Prayer", has one of the most surprising and horrifying endings I've ever seen in a horror movie. 
Even though it has been spoiled to me by a goddamn list on a site, the final scene is still shocking.
And this was only possible because the film manages to build well a tense and believable atmosphere and maintain it until the final moment. 
The beginning is slow, but in the second act we have the first moment of impact involving an act of pure cruelty. Really fucked up stuff.
I'm not a fan of "found footage", but I recognize when a movie is good regardless of the style choices. In this case, as in "Afflicted"‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: What‚Äôs Love Got to Do with¬†It?
Text:
Two childhood friends now in their thirties must decide whether to follow their heads or their hearts once the man decides to follow his parents‚Äô advice and enter into an arranged marriage in¬†Pakistan.
['how did zoe win an award for her previous documentary when her cinematography skills are so appalling', 'Maybe it\'s just me, but if I asked two men "would you cheat on your wife if you knew she\'d never know?", and they both said no, but when asked why the first one answered "because I\'d know" and the second one answered "because He\'d know", I would not choose the second one.', 'ok but love contractually would have genuinely been a better title for this']

Title: Brother¬†Bear
Text:
When an impulsive boy named Kenai is magically transformed into a bear, he must literally walk in another‚Äôs footsteps until he learns some valuable life lessons. His courageous and often zany journey introduces him to a forest full of wildlife, including the lovable bear cub Koda, hilarious moose Rutt and Tuke, woolly mammoths and rambunctious¬†rams.
['Disney stop turning POC into animals challenge', 'phil collins went in so damn hard on this soundtrack i‚Äôll never be able to thank him enough what a king', 'why did the hot brother have to die']

Title: Terrified
Text:
Police commissioner Funes and three researchers of supernatural phenomena investigate inexplicable events that are occurring in the suburbs of Buenos¬†Aires.
['Not enough haunted house movies are willing to just floor it from the jump. Fuck escalating tension, just spooky ghouls and zombie kids running up on your shit immediately.', 'Terrified
\xa0takes a trio of neighborhood houses and decorates them with unsettling tension, excellent sound design and very effective scares ranging from subtle to bombastic.\xa0
The first act setup really sucked me in and it‚Äôs one of my favorite sequences of the year, the cast is solid as well... and something happens in this that appreciate so much...\xa0everyone in this movie taking clearly unexplainable supernatural scenarios very seriously. The second act approach of zig zagging characters/houses was confusing at first but ended up being right up my alley as it thickened the air with ‚Äòno one is safe‚Äô vibes.
Well acted all around with great effects, a little CGI I wasn‚Äôt super crazy about, brisk pacing (despite a lull in act‚Ä¶ 
more', "Oh mammy, suddenly my childhood fear of the old bent naked man coming from under my bed is alive n well in my life. 
That was excellent, I bloody well needed that. The willies just kept on coming, I jumped, I let out an oh, and I may even hide under my covers later! Be still my thumping heart!
Instead of smiling to see dafties get off'd I was genuinely concerned for the 3 experts and that lovely cop. See I do care!"]

Title: God‚Äôs¬†Creatures
Text:
In a windswept fishing village, a mother is torn between protecting her beloved son and her own sense of right and wrong. A lie she tells for him rips apart their family and close-knit¬†community.
['boy moms: a horror movie', '"I suppose every house around here has the same ghosts."
no doubt this will get severely overlooked and dismissed as 'just another boring A24 slow burn' but with an absolute powerhouse of a cast and a score that settles itself deep under your skin this powerful little film really deserves to not just slip under the radar!', '"Seems like the world has turned upside down." - Aileen
"It's just as fucked as it's ever been, Mom. It might look different if you're the one turning. But nothing's changed." - Erin
so true. but you know who's the one that took an upsetting turn?
Connell Waldron']

Title: Coal Miner‚Äôs¬†Daughter
Text:
Biography of Loretta Lynn, a country and western singer that came from poverty to¬†fame.
["Here's evidence traditional biopics CAN work when they take their time and tell a story instead of filming a checklist of events.", 'I do think that this is a pretty standard musical biopic, but I have to give it credit for a few reasons.\xa0
1. The screenplay was a lot better than I thought and fit these characters beautifully and naturally.\xa0
2. The performances are all terrific. Obviously, Sissy Spacek is fantastic and really did an amazing job as Loretta Lynn. Her singing is top notch and was really convincing. I also have to acknowledge Tommy Lee Jones who was weirdly really good as well.\xa0
3. This kinda set the standard and idea for every biopic. I mean this in that this was the movie that started the ‚Äúhe/she wins Oscar for being a famous person.‚Äù While that can be annoying to‚Ä¶

Title: Eternity and a¬†Day
Text:
Famous writer Alexander contracts a terminal illness. He receives a letter from his wife describing a summer day 30 years ago, and leaves his seaside home to remember his past. This journey will allow him to wander between the past and the present, and encounter unexpected people, allowing him to collect unforgettable memories in the final moments of his¬†life.
['What is it like to pass from this life into the next? Amongst the dense forest of allusion that Greek director Theodoros Angelopoulos presents, this is the one that stands out for me as the over arching theme. I mentioned this to my wife after our watch and she told me that this film was the third of Angelopoulos‚Äô ‚ÄòTrilogy of Borders‚Äô. This made perfect sense. While played as a preparation for a journey, it is in fact the journey itself. There are those who help guide us; show us the sign posts that the grownups have left. There are our loved ones who have gone before. There are our reflections on our life; our joys and our regrets. 
The‚Ä¶ 
more', "''My only regret, Anna - but is it only one? - is to not have finished anything. I left all as a draft, shattered words here and there.''
Drifting in an out of reverie and memory whilst making his final day on Earth amount to something, Alexandre (Bruno Ganz in a performance for the ages) seeks to ease his cancerous passage from this life by discovering what it was that exiled him from his life, his love and his heart, even at one point questioning his ailing mother 
''Why, mother, nothing happens as we wish? Why? Why does one have to rot in silence torn between pain and desire? Why did I live my life in exile. Tell me mother,‚Ä¶
 
more", "Although not his final film, after nearly three decades of continually putting out film after film regarding the displacement of the individual amidst the uncertain atemporality of post-modernity (at least within Greece), this certainly feels like a natural capstone to Angelopoulos's body of work. Time, history, geography, these are all dimensions he regularly anatomizes in his films yet it isn't until this one that he so resolutely dwells on that of memory, something that naturally blends all these others into one single, flattened plane.
History is, in a way, a collective memory. And within memory does time and space lose their specificity. The film follows a dying writer struggling with the knowledge that his conscious existence is about to end‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Love, Death & Robots: Automated Customer¬†Service
Text:
If your home-cleaning unit is attempting to murder you, please press¬†3.
["Basically the show 'Black Mirror' if it was told in 12 minutes.", 'I swear i heard my Alexa say "someday" while watching this.', 'I really like ‚ÄúLove, Death and Robots‚Äù because it helps distribute short films from many different filmmakers with many different styles to a wider audience through Netflix, and they are often full of originality, so I was happy to learn that they made a second season.\xa0
This short film is not really that original and not one of their strongest either and we have seen much similar stuff before, but it was still a fun little short film with a nice style.
The animation looked great and it had one of the cutest animated dogs I have ever seen, which was nice too.\xa0
The short film had some fun comments about automated customer service and just the use of robots in general, which we mostly have seen before, but they still gave it their own little touch, so it was another enjoyable short film.']

Title: White¬†Noise
Text:
Jack Gladney, professor of Hitler studies at The-College-on-the-Hill, husband to Babette, and father to four children/stepchildren, is torn asunder by a chemical spill from a rail car that releases an ‚ÄúAirborne Toxic Event‚Äù forcing Jack to confront his biggest fear - his own¬†mortality.
['adam driver standing in the corner at the party: they dont know im a leading expert on hitler studies', 'wish this was better, adam driver is the best comedic actor we have', 'The best episode of the Simpsons ever']

Title: The¬†Abyss
Text:
A civilian oil rig crew is recruited to conduct a search and rescue effort when a nuclear submarine mysteriously sinks. One diver soon finds himself on a spectacular odyssey 25,000 feet below the ocean‚Äôs surface where he confronts a mysterious force that has the power to change the world or destroy¬†it.
['It‚Äôs like James Cameron thought he might die in a year and crammed every single thing he cares about into a single movie', "93/100
 
Director's Cut
 
Just totally, utterly, unabashedly irresponsible movie-making by an egoistical madman; a deep sea epic in hangout mode, soaked in Spielbergian sentiment but hardwired through the frazzled jargon of James Cameron. If someone says the guy isn't a humanist, plop that imbecile down 'Clockwork Orange' style and show them 
The Abyss
. Each moment thrives and dances within barriers between safety and death, and masculine exteriors break away into protraits of vulnerability and love. So touching, so dreamy and grounded. Water carries dreadful, elusive weight, but what swims beneath the waves is strange and graceful. I'm never really sure if it truly sticks the landing (both conclusions are flawed), but Cameron's personal vision results in a truthful, at times batshit insane escapade. If anything, this is James Cameron's 
Interstellar
 (Nolan obviously loves this thing); a grandiose weepie confined to spouts of lingo and rare slivers of beauty, propelled and carried by ambition.", "Cameron's ONLY ANGELS HAVE WINGS and one of the greatest technical accomplishments in the history of the medium. It's easy to say they don't make 'em like this anymore, but I can hardly believe they 
ever
 made 'em like this in the first place, especially without casualties."]

Title: Operation¬†Mincemeat
Text:
In 1943, two British intelligence officers concoct Operation Mincemeat, wherein their plan to drop a corpse with false papers off the coast of Spain would fool Nazi spies into believing the Allied forces were planning to attack by way of Greece rather than¬†Sicily.
['Mediocre dramas based on true stories that nobody under the age of 50 will see are the backbone of the uk film industry', 'NO WAY HOME FOR THE AUSTEN GIRLIES', 'More handjobs than I was expecting‚Ä¶']

Title: Burlesque
Text:
Ali leaves behind a troubled life and follows her dreams to Los Angeles, where she lands a job as a cocktail waitress at the Burlesque Lounge, a once-majestic theater that houses an inspired musical revue. Vowing to perform there, she makes the leap from bar to stage, helping restore the club‚Äôs former¬†glory.
['was this good? absolutely not. five stars.', 'To watch burlesque for xtina is to show courage.
To watch burlesque for cher is to show wisdom.
\xa0
And to watch burlesque for kristen bell is to show severe cases of homosexuality.', 'my favorite part was when Christina Aguilera suddenly becomes a real estate professional and teaches Cher about air rights']

Title: Fellini‚Äôs¬†Casanova
Text:
Casanova is a libertine, collecting seductions and sexual feats. But he is really interested in someone, and is he really an interesting person? Is he really¬†alive?
["An orgy of miraculous mise-en-sc√®ne. There is no other appropriate way to describe it. A clear contrast is made between life and death, between reality and fantasy, between the search of something alive and the filthiness of the means used to seek it, between natural and artificial. Sutherland's best performance in his entire career highlights this as he ventures into the most wonderful act in the world between two people in the most dehumanizing way possible.
There are little things to be added to 
William Tell's all-encompassing approach
. This is Fellini's opera out of control, and yet assured by an immaculate direction featuring an anarchic disorder that only Europe could conceive during the worldwide New Wave film movements and exploited‚Ä¶ 
more", '"I am a creature of the elements, of air, of water‚Äî"
"‚Äîand of fire too, from what I've heard about you."
Sexual politics writ large
Fellini was fascinated with figurative Casanovas ‚Äî his films are littered with them ‚Äî so it only seems right that he eventually adapted the story of the real, literal Casanova. Curiously enough, however, he hated the character, referring to his life in an interview as a 
"void,"
 and in the film he seems to wield this antagonism not just at the one man but at the entire European ruling class, from Italy to France to Germany. And Casanova is a sensible subject matter for this sweeping social analysis: his autobiography is considered 
"one of the‚Ä¶
 
more', 'After 
La Dolce Vita
, Fellini went from being a modest director in terms of what he displayed on screen to just engross himself into the excess of life and larger than life characters which was present not only through this excentric characters but also the technical work, from costume to the production design became much complex and ambitious. Yet, at the same time, around the time he started to pick up on mythical stories and literaty adapations, personally speaking, he may have gone a bit too into the extremes.
A story about the life of Casanova, the epitome of a ladies man who tries to feel his meaningless life with sex and parties, its very on the alley of Fellini‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The Unknown¬†Girl
Text:
Jenny, a young doctor who feels guilty after a young woman she refused to see winds up dead a few days later, decides to find out who the girl was, after the police can‚Äôt identify the young¬†woman.
['ok i NEED ad√®le haenel to be my doctor', 'As my colleague Noel Murray once said in a review, ho-hum, yet another delicate masterpiece from the Dardennes. This latest deals with a young female doctor who ignores a patient at her clinic door after hours. Then she finds out the next day that the woman died, and she sets out to discover what happened. This is a terrific procedural where the procedure is basically "Be kind, care, ask questions, don\'t give up." The central performance is terrific, but the real winner is the structure, which follows a sort of neo-noir/gumshoe pattern, but keeps it personal and intimate.', 'i saw adele and i pressed play. simple.']

Title: A City of¬†Sadness
Text:
The story of a family embroiled in the ‚ÄúWhite Terror,‚Äù the Kuomintang government‚Äôs anti-communist political repression that was wrought on the Taiwanese people from¬†1947-1987.
['Unable to hear or speak, or scarred by war, or exiled from home, everyone is scattered and none of these characters is exactly whole. Entire generations now fundamentally incapable of just being.', "An era of sadness. A broken family's pain mirroring that of the country's. Deaf or dead, disabled or disappeared, this pain of being passed around as nothing more than a piece of land haunts their entire existence. Being colonised by one empire and then handed over to another, with the people who live in it being reduced to mere subjects; the old brand of suppression has been replaced by a new one. The perpetual beauty of Taiwan's landscape ruthlessly contrasts the lives of its inhabitants.
Displaced and tormented by inhumanity, the people who did no wrong suffered. A massacre brought forth by mere cigarettes, coupled with a 38 years long martial law hovered over the fate of Taiwan like a‚Ä¶ 
more", "3000 Followers Celebration
Picked by: 
Kosta Jovanoviƒá
 and 
sciallacooper
.
Politics. Change. Fear and chaos. Trauma. Disability. Hou Hsiao-hsien's 
A City of Sadness
 just captures the passage of time, using it to outline an entire history. Like Zhang Yimou's 
To Live
 and Edward Yang's 
A Brighter Summer Day
, there's something perfectly reflexive about these early 90s simple retellings of mid-century China and Taiwan. 
A City of Sadness
 covers tumultuous history, namely the White Terror and commencement of martial law in Taiwan. It deals with an intersection of ideology, as the Japanese, Mainland Chinese, and Taiwanese all face enormous change in the 1940s setting. Time was not kind to Taiwan, as it rarely is to anyone. There wasn't enough to solve the‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Driving Miss¬†Daisy
Text:
The story of an old Jewish widow named Daisy Werthan and her relationship with her black chauffeur, Hoke. From an initial mere work relationship grew in 25 years a strong friendship between the two very different characters, in a time when those types of relationships were¬†shunned.
["One day they'll remake it with Bryce Dallas Howard and John Boyega.", 'Let it sink in that this movie won Best Picture and \nDo The Right Thing\n\xa0wasn‚Äôt even nominated.', 'this is a real argument against my loose "watch best picture winners I\'ve never seen" project']

Title: Monkey¬†Shines
Text:
A quadriplegic man is given a trained monkey help him with every day activities, until the little monkey begins to develop feelings, and rage, against its new master and those who get too close to¬†him.
['"She's unbelievable, she's like a miniature person"
Allan Mann is a bitter, angry and vengeful man ever since an accident left him paralysed from the neck down. He's fed up with himself and everyone around him. All that changes when he's given Ella, a monkey trained to meet his every need. But when Ella begins anticipating Allan's thoughts, strange and deadly things start happening. When Ella stalks and wreaks havoc on Allan's fair-weather girlfriend, incompetent doctor and meddling mother, Allan realizes he must stop the cunning maniacal creature... before she fully takes over his mind!
Jason Beghe is an excellent lead as Allan, he really manages to get across his anger and frustration at being quadriplegic. He goes through joy,‚Ä¶ 
more', 'This has 
*hands down*
 the best quadriplegic, 
oral sex scene
 I have seen in my entire life! Just wow! And yes, there is also a telepathic killer monkey, whatever.
That sex scene though.. üî•
What a wonderful surprise this George A. Romero flick was.
Great times watching it with Romero fangirl, 
Michelle
.', 'It‚Äôs not even one of those clapping monkeys from the poster, that‚Äôs wild. Feels like a cross between a Robert Zemeckis drama and a Stephen King story. A little too melodramatic, with the money having the best part. Trudging along by the end, seems like Romero enjoys making them drawn out.
George A. Romero ranked']

Title: The¬†Punisher
Text:
The avenging angel of Marvel Comics fame comes brilliantly to life in this searing action-adventure thriller! Dolph Lundgren stars as Frank Castle, a veteran cop who loses his entire family to a mafia car bomb. His ex-partner believes Castle survived the blast and became the Punisher, living in the sewers and exacting vigilante violence against mob bosses throughout the city. When the populace is caught in the midst of a gang war that he caused, Castle must again emerge from the shadows and save the¬†innocent. √ó
["Frank Castle lives in a sewer lair like a Ninja Turtle, fights scuba ninjas (also like a Ninja Turtle), mumbles like Dolph Lundgren, battles the Yakuza in an old timey amusement park (where dozens of bad guys simultaneously ride one of those big slides 
while firing machine guns
), and in one scene after Frank blows up a mobster's house a journalist screams ‚ÄúHoly shit, it‚Äôs the Punisher!‚Äù
What I‚Äôm saying is, I think this is the best movie about the Punisher?", "Forget PUNISHER: WAR ZONE. Goldblatt made an 80s action masterpiece.
10 reasons why you should stop everything and watch THE PUNISHER now:
1. Dolph Lundgren (!) as Frank Castle / The Punisher.
2. Jeroen Krabbe (!) as the new don of the Italian mafia.
3. Explosions. Lots of 'em. Explosions within explosions.
4. Scuba-Ninjas. Yes, you read that correctly. Certified!
5. A deadly woman who crucifies a man with her earrings. 
6. A vision of Castle as a broken, fragile, and frustrated man. 
7. A man delivering a pizza gets his ass beaten (and pizza stolen).
8. Dutch angles that rival even those used in 
THE THIRD MAN
.
9. Jeroen Krabbe's frivolous, but totally sweet acid-washed jean jacket.
10. Castle welcoming a young boy to shoot him in the head. Sick, man.
Not convinced? 
This scene
 says it all. I dare you to show me even one comic book adaptation (recent or otherwise) with a scene as powerful and resonant.", '"What the fuck do you call 125 murders in 5 years?"
"Work in progress."
It is both a crime and somehow feels strangely right that the only movie Mark Goldblatt got to direct beside his very underrated 
Dead Heat
 (an idiosyncratic combination of Shane Black buddy cop comedy and full-blown zombie body horror movie) was one of the bloodiest movies Marvel would ever let someone make out of one of their characters. 
His work in the editing room on 
The Terminator
, 
Rambo: First Blood Pt. II
 and 
Commando
 gave him a very strong feel for the rhythm of shooting/cutting tangible action which he applies here to an incredibly silly, macho revenge action movie where Dolph Lundgren (doing his best Sylvester‚Ä¶ 
more', 'a pretty loose take on the character. lots of gritty ‚Äò80s-style action, but not much of the Punisher you‚Äôd expect', 'just me or is dolphin lundgren kinda hot', 'ghost rider and the punisher in a movie would be so tuff.', "Drago as the Punisher. Responsible for the demise of more Mafiosos than John Gotti and the Iceman combined. A thespian wino. A talking panda bear gets shot. Yakuza scuba ninjas. Champaign of death. The perfect anti-gambling message. An epic bus chase that makes Speed look like Slow. A dancing geisha. An exploding elevator. Iron Eagle's determination. Poetic justice. Dolph kicks so much ass. His one-liners are top-notch. R-rated and gritty. Low-down and dirty. The way all comics should be adapted for the big screen.", 'Consider me punished for watching this.', "one of the best comic book movies because it refuses to let the audience feel like they're in a fantasy - aside from the stark aesthetic and bizarre premise, it barely seems like a comic - even when the punisher is riding a motorcycle through the sewers or coney island, the dark and fog and angst make it feel brutal instead of goofy. the yakuza is stylish but utterly deranged, louis gossett jr gives a sad & broken performance that deserves a less ridiculous movie, the comic relief is a washed up alcoholic, dolph lundgren looks close to death even when he's delivering his perversely funny one-liners. it's undeniably fun to watch, and imo a movie this violent yet enjoyable should‚Ä¶ 
more", 'still the best Marvel movie', "Dolph Lundgren as The Punisher might have been a wet dream for Marvel and action fans alike in '89, but it was released on the same year and with a much smaller budget than Keaton's Batman. So it was largely overshadowed by the first major theatrical release of the Caped Crusader as many folks in '89 were raving about both Keaton and Nicholson's performances in the slightly campier and slightly less violent DC flick (yes, in Batman a person does get roasted alive in one of the coolest comic book scenes ever in film, but the amount of bullets flying here and the explosions and violence against kids has me considering this feature as without a doubt more violent). As‚Ä¶ 
more", 'A decent comic book film, with enjoyable fight scenes and explosions. But when you compare Dolph Lungren‚Äôs performance to Jon Bernthal‚Äôs embodiment of the character, it falls short greatly. The plot is what you expect with the Punisher.']

Title: Wedding¬†Crashers
Text:
