Title: Tigers Are Not¬†Afraid
Text:
A dark fairy tale about a gang of five children trying to survive the horrific violence of the cartels and the ghosts created every day by the drug¬†war.
['Really enjoyed this breakthrough by director Issa L√≥pez. \xa0Top notch child performances. \xa0Smart use of \xa0allegory applied to the horror genre. Great locations.\xa0
Happy I saw it in a dark movie theater... always best way to see a horror film. Streaming on Shudder after its theatrical run I believe.\xa0
Watched at Vancouver Intl. Film Center', 'Real life horrors sometimes can be more frightening, shocking and disturbing than anything a horror film has to offer. And Tigers are not afraid is not only a moving portrait that exemplifies what I mean, but also a film that challenges the strongest of hearts to face a dark story marked by violence, from the perspective of children who forcibly had their innocence corrupted.
In a period of war between drug cartels in Mexico, we follow Estrella - who after the sudden disappearance of her mother and a supernatural force begins to surround her, she seeks subterfuge with a group of orphaned children. Between all the violence connecting them - they seek the best way to survive together.
Tigers Are‚Ä¶ 
more', 'This movie is really good! Surprisingly because most of the significant characters are kids which is usually the kiss of death for a horror movie! This movie seems poetic and is crafted beautifully! Check it out!']

Title: Event¬†Horizon
Text:
In 2047, a group of astronauts are sent to investigate and salvage the starship Event Horizon which disappeared mysteriously seven years before on its maiden voyage. However, it soon becomes evident that something sinister resides in its¬†corridors.
['To think he made this and Boogie Nights in the same year. 
Such incredible versatility.', "I will forever mourn the 2 hour cut of this that supposedly went full 
Hellraiser
 inter-dimensional sex and gore but the version we've got is still a pretty nasty piece of textured sci-fi horror design work from anderson that owes a lot to 
Alien
, 
Warhammer
 and 
Doom
 and has enough vividly rendered possessions, mutilations and portals to space hell to keep me coming back to it. Love how much time is spent observing these beautifully designed spaces in carefully considered compositions like the ships heart and the microchip vents in the first half so that we know exactly where every burning, rotting and dissected body is later on. The rapid cut log of the previous ship's crew raping and cannibalising each other is one of the most disturbing things I saw when I was too young.
 full discussion on episode 131 of my podcast SLEAZOIDS
.", 'This movie is so disappointing because it‚Äôs not just bad, but it has suuuuuuch promise. Like, the psychological concept of a ship creating hallucinations to defend itself is so cool and has such potential that in the right smart hands, it could be a truly great fucking horror movie. Instead, we got a few quick frames of hellish images and a truly confusing lead character whose arc and motivation are (????) It‚Äôs like Paul W.S. Anderson went to a studio like ‚ÄúRemember Alien? Well, what if it kinda sucked?‚Äù ‚ÄúWe already did a few of those.‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay okay, but the thing about mine is that you‚Äôll be able to remake it way better in several years without my involvement.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre listening...‚Äù']

Title: The Omega¬†Man
Text:
Due to an experimental vaccine, Dr. Robert Neville is the only human survivor of an apocalyptic war waged with biological weapons. Besides him, only a few hundred deformed, nocturnal people remain - sensitive to light, and homicidally¬†psychotic.
['The first third of this movie might be one of my all-time favorite first thirds of any movie. Charlton Heston, last man on Earth(ish), losing his mind, talking to himself, playing dress-up, shooting random mutants (From his cold dead hand!), watching WOODSTOCK in an abandoned L.A. movie theater -- does it get any better and sadder than that?', "The first half hour or so of this is amazing. Just Charlton Heston driving around a desolate LA in his convertible, brutally gunning down mutant vampire cults and performing to himself/random objects in an attempt to recreate the world before the implied nuclear apocalypse. (Including running a film print of 
Woodstock
 for himself and almost completely stone-faced remarking ‚Äúthey sure don‚Äôt make pictures like that anymore.‚Äù) When the plot eventually kicks in its mostly fine, however by trying to make this a broad action/adventure story it totally whiffs the novels morally complex depiction of a protagonist who doesn't realize he's dehumanized his enemies until they do it to him.", '‚ÄúWe mean to cancel the world you civilized people made. We will simply erase history from the time that machinery and weapons threaten more than they offered. And when you die, the last living reminder of hell will be gone.‚Äù
I‚Äôm not the first one to say it, hell lots of the reviews mention it, but the first ten minutes are unbeatable. They‚Äôre so unbelievably compelling and eerie, it‚Äôs legitimately one of my favorite\xa0openings of all time.
Charlton Heston drives down empty roads that get increasingly littered with trash, cars, and corpses. He stops suddenly to open fire at a silhouette passing a window. He continually mutters sarcastic thoughts out loud as he traverses an empty, dead city. He finally‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic¬†Movie
Text:
Based on the bestselling book series, this outrageous comedy tells the story of George and Harold, two overly imaginative pranksters who hypnotize their principal into thinking he‚Äôs an enthusiastic, yet dimwitted, superhero named Captain¬†Underpants.
['THEY EVEN ADAPTED THE FLIP-O-RAMA THOSE MADLADS', 'THIS MOVIE DESERVES SO MUCH MONEY', 'We live in a time where people will accept your beliefs as long as you agree with every word they say. Disagree in any way, and you\'re labeled and ridiculed. It\'s an "I\'m offended that you\'re offended" type of world. Social media is filled with hateful slurs from all sides of the fence. Friendships end over who you presumably voted for, and it\'s almost impossible to have a healthy debate over any social-political-ice-caps-are-melting issue. Our world needs a hero. Someone who can unite us. Who are we going to call? Captain Underpants!\nI can\'t believe how awesome Captain Underpants is. We have a cool superhero, a menacing villain and fun sidekicks. Is there a movie from the MCU or DCCU‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Dracula‚Äôs¬†Daughter
Text:
A countess from Transylvania seeks a psychiatrist‚Äôs help to cure her vampiric¬†cravings.
['we stan a tragically repressed lesbian goth queen', "it's as if they wrote a half-assed script, filled it with perfectly fine actors, then cast gloria holden without realizing she would give such an incredible performance whose depth was so far beyond what the movie was prepared to give her to do that they just let her drift off alone onto some higher plane, surrounded her with fog and shadows, and hoped nobody would notice the rest of the movie couldn't catch up - in a way it worked, she truly seems like the loneliest woman in the world.", "The desperation to fit in, to be normal, to be 
straight
... Here's where we challenge the conception that reviewing films from a political lens demands older films fit today's standards (ignoring everything wrong with that assumption to do so): yesteryear's status quo can sometimes capture something inadvertently. It's not about measuring something by anachronistic standards (my standards derive from Marx and Lenin, who were old hat by 1936, anyway). It's about understanding these films through a lens of the people they left out.
This film, however, accidentally captures a very real feeling, one that sadly lingers today. 
Kat has thoroughly captured the details here
, but suffice to say that the closet drives queer people even 80 years later to wish‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Smiles of a Summer¬†Night
Text:
Early in the 20th century, middle-aged lawyer Fredrik Egerman and his young wife, Anne, have still not consummated their marriage, while Fredrik‚Äôs son finds himself increasingly attracted to his new stepmother. To make matters worse, Fredrik‚Äôs old flame Desiree makes a public bet that she can seduce him at a romantic weekend retreat where four couples convene, swapping partners and pairing off in unexpected¬†ways.
['90/100
O, for an alternate universe in which Bergman made two dozen effortlessly effervescent movies like this one and only maybe three or four somber angstfests about God's silence or whatever. Kehr's 
Reader
 capsule complains that "the light touch doesn't come naturally to the Brooding Swede," but I submit that Dave is exhibiting hindsight confirmation bias, because I see nothing even remotely labored here‚Äîthe fast pace, dry wit, deft plotting, and rueful optimism all seem as natural as breathing (whereas most of Bergman's downers might as well be set in an iron lung). A dark side is still present, but as jolting counterpoint; when, for example, Desir√©e's mother says "One can never protect a single human being from any kind‚Ä¶ 
more', '‚ÄúSmiles of a Summer Night‚Äù has all the folly and lacks all the sense of the most blissful infatuations in love and lust.\xa0
This is a film for the fools.\xa0
Ingmar Bergman‚Äôs ‚ÄúSmiles‚Äù is pastiche of the chamber drama, and also - somewhat, of his own oeuvre of work.\xa0
There are heartbreaks and betrayals, duels and attempted suicides. All are played off with the sound of trumpets, and the bang of another door slamming open on another momentary tragedy.\xa0
All the grim consequence of relationships disappears with the coming of the dawn.\xa0
‚ÄúSmiles‚Äù might be best known in some circles for being the basis of Stephen Sondheim‚Äôs musical, ‚ÄúA Little Night Music.‚Äù Of all the movie to stage adaptions -‚Ä¶ 
more', 'A Bergman movie that doesn‚Äôt make me question everything?
I liked lighter Bergman. It reminded me a lot of a Shakespearean comedy, with all the intersecting plot lines, and everything coming together in the end. I particularly liked the character of the maid, who I thought deserved more respect from the story.
Lots of little laughs and fun moments, with some darkness lurking under the surface, it strikes a very nice tone.']

Title: Frankenstein
Text:
Dr. Victor Frankenstein, a brilliant but egotistical scientist, brings a creature to life in a monstrous experiment that ultimately leads to the undoing of both the creator and his tragic¬†creation.
['I think as Guillermo falls in love, and empathy, for his Frankenstein - we begin to lose sight of why we should care about his creator, Victor.
All performances were great, but Mia Goth and David Bradley stood out to me. Christian Convery is consistently killing it whether he‚Äôs placed in a gothic del Toro movie or a crazy comedy like Cocaine Bear.
Might get some Oscar nods for Makeup and Production Design, would be my guess.', 'It‚Äôs not alive.', 'Absolutely enchanting and exciting. Guillermo del Toro is a master at keeping the grotesque horror intact while exploring a delicate and beautiful side of this monster story. Spectacular performances.
One of the most exciting experiences I‚Äôve had in a theater. Watched at the Academy Museum for the LA premiere and had the absolutely INSANE opportunity to talk to GDT after the film. I will never forget this!!!']

Title: High¬†Sierra
Text:
Given a pardon from jail, Roy Earle gets back into the swing of things as he robs a swanky¬†resort.
['"Mister, what does it mean... when a man 'crashes out'?"
as a portrait of a man escaping into himself, it's a sublime distillation of the early gangster movie. Bogart (and motherfucking *Pard*) are aces, as is Lupino with her eyelashes for days, but the accoutrement lets them down. the stuff with the crippled girl is thematically invaluable, but the hokum involved in setting it up and knocking it down is a bit much... stretches the innocence that Earle is looking for, and the redemption he's hoping to siphon from it. a lot of the small stuff doesn't connect, but Earle's slow tumble down the mountain (metaphorically speaking) is fine. 
mostly astonished by the speed with which Raoul Walsh gets things going... hurry up and wait, with some of the quickest fades in film history. a breakneck pace to let Earle self-destruct in slow-motion.', '‚ÄúHigh Sierra‚Äù is Humphrey Bogart and Ida Lupino setting the stock standards for the next decade of noir. Also, it was Bogart‚Äôs genius excuse to make a whole film into ‚Äòbring your dog to work day.‚Äô\xa0
Bogart‚Äôs turn in ‚ÄúSierra‚Äù as former bank robber Roy Earle blends the wild 30s Hollywood gangster spirit into a more nuanced portrait of an unsuccessfully reformed criminal.\xa0Where movies made lawbreakers part of the rebellious cool of Americana in the decade prior, the cons were generally little more than archetypical tricksters. They had only foibles; not humanity. 
Bogart‚Äôs Earle is a wiseguy with a soul. And a cute dog (Bogart‚Äôs own; Zero). It‚Äôs Bogart taking everything he‚Äôd learned in the Warner gangster stable and imbuing‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Marking the moment when the gritty gangster sagas of the 1930s began giving way to the romantic fatalism of 1940s film noir, High Sierra also contains the star-making performance of Humphrey Bogart, who, alongside top-billed Ida Lupino, proved his leading-man mettle with his tough yet tender turn as Roy Earle. A career criminal plagued by his checkered past, Earle longs for a simpler life, but after getting sprung on parole, he falls in with a band of thieves for one last heist in the Sierra Nevada. Directed with characteristic punch by Raoul Walsh‚Äîwho makes the most of the vertiginous mountain location‚ÄîRoy and Lupino‚Äôs Marie, a fellow outcast also desperate to escape her past, hurtle inexorably toward an unforgettable cliffside climax and a rendezvous with destiny.
This edition arrives on October 12, 2021. To learn more or pre-order, visit 
Criterion.com.']

Title: Contagion
Text:
As an epidemic of a lethal airborne virus - that kills within days - rapidly grows, the worldwide medical community races to find a cure and control the panic that spreads faster than the virus¬†itself.
["Some of the most minutely observed, expertly cut montages of the 2010s in service of a rhythmic form that moves with the same ruthlessly clinical disregard for human life as our economic and political institutions‚Äîor, I mean, a viral disease. the high-profile casting gives the viewer a false sense of safety as Soderbergh proceeds to peel Gwyneth Paltrow's face off her skull in the opening 15 minutes, just moments after showing her son having choked to death on his own vomit, and it doesn't get any easier to watch from there. as others have pointed out, that moment where Winslet tries to give her blanket to the infected man beside her in a moment of intimate movie heroism and instead, Soderbergh smash cuts to her corpse being stuffed into a bag... Just brutal stuff. Very weird experience to watch this in the middle of a literal pandemic.", 'The closest thing to ‚Äòlife imitating art imitating life‚Äô we are likely to ever see.', "Never expected Matt Damon's daughter to pick U2 for her prom slow dance song. What a twist."]

Title: Twixt
Text:
A washed-up horror novelist arrives in a sleepy town on a book tour, only to stumble into a string of eerie murders. Haunted by dreams of a ghostly girl named V and guided by the spirit of Edgar Allan Poe, he‚Äôs drawn into a nightmarish world where fiction and reality blur‚Äîand the story he‚Äôs chasing leads back to his own buried¬†guilt.
["i just found out that coppola lost his son in a speedboating accident and that he incorporated his life and trauma with the death of his boy into this film, he positions himself as val kilmer who loses his child in the film the same way. 25 years of grieving and still he had to put it into this film, his grief, his suffering and the state of consciousness where he can maybe deal with it after all this time. he'll always be gone and the scars never fade, your child being dead for longer than he was alive leaves an emotional wound that i can't possibly imagine dealing with. this is the closest he can get to catharsis, putting it into his art, trying to continue and process the pain with his films. the film was already so deeply profound and now it hits \xa0harder than just about anything.\xa0
rest in peace, gian-carlo, your memory will always live on", "*Was a 
70
, now an 
80
*
This new-ish Authentic Cut doesn't do a whole lot beyond a more ambiguous coda, and that's precisely what this movie needs. There's plenty of melancholy mystery here, not just in the plotting but also in the sensory details. Those grey-scale nighttime sequences feel like the digital endpoint of the angst and passions of 
Rumble Fish
. Love this movie.", "'Twixt' is a film aptly named, one hard to tease or puzzle out, but easy to love. Probably the most Francis Ford Coppola movie in the history of Francis Ford Coppola movies, this movie has nearly everything in it but belongs to no one set genre or style. The film it is closest to in FFC's catalog is 'Rumble Fish', which was a smaller, more personal and experimental take on the kind of story told in 'The Outsiders', so maybe it is possible to think of this as a greatly delayed 'Rumble Vampire', as thematically and even visually, it takes many cues from 'Bram Stoker's Dracula', and, like 'Rumble Fish', frequently operates in black and white with highlights and aspects‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Limelight
Text:
A fading music hall comedian tries to help a despondent ballet dancer learn to walk and to again feel confident about¬†life.
['74/100
A coda and a beginning, flawed and brilliant in the very same way. Just a beautiful story of lost fame, with a simple camera pan of empty seats destroying my tear ducts. Light cast against shadow. Charles Chaplin would forever be a master, and 
Limelight
 proves it.', 'Bone simple - just a straight shot to the heart, unafraid of big emotions. A movie in which Chaplin comes to terms with his own obsolescence while also exclaiming "madadayo!" The style is so direct and the mise-en-scene so stripped-down that it feels like it's taking place in a dream. With Chaplin, even the flaws are virtues - they're the things that make him Chaplin.
It's impossible to see Chaplin and Keaton together and not get goosebumps. The two of them spent several days together workshopping and rehearsing their big scene. To have been a fly on the wall...', 'What do you want meaning for? Life is a desire, not a meaning. Desire is the theme of all life!
Limelight
, a deeply personal film Charlie Chaplin directed later in his career,\xa0tells the moving story of an ill and deeply unhappy ballerina who is nursed back to both mental and physical health by a comedian whose years of glory are long behind him. While this movie was made after Chaplin had abandoned the persona of the Tramp, it never once fails to evoke the emotions characteristic of a Chaplin film: heartfelt laughter, followed by tears of affection, followed by more laughter and then by more tears.
With this film, Chaplin brilliantly combines his style as a director of the silent‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: RoboCop
Text:
In a violent, near-apocalyptic Detroit, evil corporation Omni Consumer Products wins a contract from the city government to privatize the police force. But when RoboCop learns of the company‚Äôs nefarious plans, he turns on his¬†masters.

Clarence Boddicker 4 Life. The GOAT movie villain. \nMake sure if you can to get the extended "Director\'s Cut" which only features an extra gloriously gratuitous 10-15 seconds of that OCP executive getting absolutely shredded by gunfire. Title: Reds
Text:
An account of the revolutionary years of the legendary American journalist John Reed, who shared his adventurous professional life with his radical commitment to the socialist revolution in Russia, his dream of spreading its principles among the members of the American working class, and his troubled romantic relationship with the writer Louise¬†Bryant.
['Beatty going "hey for my second movie as a director I\'m gonna get Stephen Sondheim and Vittorio Storaro and make a 3-hour epic about communists" is a truly baller move', "Warren Beatty's Reds has to be considered perhaps the most ambitious, frankly crazy, film released by mainstream Hollywood. It is, in 1981, a sympathetic, if critical, look at the 1917 Russian Revolution. The film focuses on the life and career of John Reed, the journalist and writer who wrote Ten Days That Shook the World. It mixes the personal and the political, spending a good deal of time looking at Reed's relationship with Louise Bryant (the amazing Diane Keaton, more of whom later), while also chronicling the revolution, through 'witnesses', montage, song, interviews. It is a mosiac of a period of time, earthed by Beatty's natural charm and the romance of Bryant and Reed.\nWarren Beatty was a force of‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'Imagine if these folks had Twitter or had to listen to Chapo or something.']

Title: All Dirt Roads Taste of¬†Salt
Text:
Tender caresses and enveloping embraces are portals into the life of Mack, a Black woman in Mississippi. Winding through the anticipation, love, and heartbreak she experiences from childhood to adulthood, the expressionist journey is an ode to connection ‚Äî with loved ones and with¬†place.
['A memory, tinged with aching rawness, emerges in ‚ÄúAll Dirt Roads Taste of Salt,‚Äù the feature debut by writer/director Raven Jackson. This memory briefly foretells the knotting stream of remembrances that roots our protagonist, Mack (played in these early childhood scenes by a sage Kaylee Nicole Johnson). It begins in 1970, with young Mack‚Äôs hands caressing a fish‚Äôs scales before throwing the suffocated creature back into the glinting water. It then jumps to her hands softly holding a fishing reel, its pole stretched across the frame. Her father, Isaiah (Chris Chalk), calmly guides her toward the catch. The director then steers us to a shot of Mack‚Äôs fingers swirling in the cloudy silt around the river‚Äôs current, and finally to‚Ä¶ 
more', '"You wanna know a secret? It doesn't end or begin, it just changes form."
a beautiful and tender piece of poetry that has changed the way i see hands forever', 'A whispered symphony of sense memories that cycles through the decades like rain water ‚Äî heavy with images and ambient sounds that trickle down from the generations above before they‚Äôre absorbed into the earth and suffused back into the air ‚Äî the vague but vividly rendered ‚ÄúAll Dirt Roads Taste of Salt‚Äù runs a little drier every time writer-director Raven Jackson loops back to squeeze another drop of meaning from the textures and traditions that connect a Black Mississippi woman to the place where she was born (and vice-versa).
Her name is Mackenzie, she‚Äôs played by a small troupe of different actresses over the course of Jackson‚Äôs freeform debut, and the body they share between them serves as a kind‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Star¬†80
Text:
Paul Snider is a narcissistic, small time hustler who fancies himself a ladies man. His life changes when he meets Dorothy Stratten working behind the counter of a Dairy Queen. Under his guidance Dorothy grows to fame as a Playboy Playmate. But when Dorothy begins pursuing an acting career, the jealous Paul finds himself elbowed out of the picture by more famous¬†men.
['I feel like I need to go take a shower', 'Terrific exploitation, simultaneously lurid true-crime sleaze and an appropriately grueling experience in the systematic and total destruction of women.', 'Bob Fosse‚Äôs ‚ÄúStar 80‚Äù is a supernova of desire. The hustler becomes the hustled, with gaze becoming gluttony of possession.\xa0
‚ÄúStar 80,‚Äù written and directed by Fosse, is based on the true life murder of a Playboy playmate, Dorothy Stratten, by her jealous boyfriend, Paul Snider. Stratten also was dating Peter Bogdanovich at the time of her death.\xa0
It‚Äôs a tangle of sex, pimps, and showbiz that is quintessentially Fosse. His imbued familiarity with the themes at hand lets him riff on the killing with a freeform liberty of factual deviation. There were accusations from both Bogdanovich and Hugh Hefner that the depiction of Stratten in ‚ÄúStar 80‚Äù was inaccurate. Fosse copped to this, but countered that the film was‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Transformers: Rise of the¬†Beasts
Text:
When a new threat capable of destroying the entire planet emerges, Optimus Prime and the Autobots must team up with a powerful faction known as the Maximals. With the fate of humanity hanging in the balance, humans Noah and Elena will do whatever it takes to help the Transformers as they engage in the ultimate battle to save¬†Earth.
['absolutely no one:\nme, every 5 minutes to the increasingly annoyed stranger sitting next to me: ‚Äúthey definitely made the robots hotter in this one right?? like i simply don‚Äôt remember them ever being this sexy ü•µ‚Äù', 'My entire life I have struggled with an addiction to the mobile app Candy Crush. Since the 6th grade I have been destroying every Apple product I‚Äôve ever gotten my nasty little fingers on with Candy Crush. The secret to never having to pay for any lives is to just go to settings and go to the Date and Time tab and put the clock ahead three hours. Every time you do this it totally fucks all the messages on your phone. At one point in January 2020 (before Covid), I had an awful manic episode and spent literal hours in the bathtub playing Candy Crush and not getting any sleep. I was failing all of my classes because I‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'I‚Äôm just a simple guy who digs a beast war every now and then.']

Title: Gallipoli
Text:
Two Australian sprinters face the brutal realities of war when they are sent to fight in the Gallipoli campaign in the Ottoman Empire during World War¬†I.
['One of the all-time great endings in movies. Crushes me every time I see it. These beautiful adventurers travel halfway around the world to answer a call unworthy of them, only to get cut down a few steps out of the trench. Why is Peter Weir not talked about as one of our greatest living directors?', "devastating.
(i'm mostly referring to the fact that young Mel Gibson bears an uncanny resemblance to Paul Mescal in this movie, but the rest of it too)", 'Cinematic Time Capsule
1981 Marathon - Film #45
‚ÄùHow fast are you going to run?‚Äù
‚ÄúAs fast as a leopard.‚Äù
‚ÄúThen let‚Äôs see you do it‚Äù
Peter Weir‚Äôs
 war film tricks you into thinking it‚Äôs actually a coming of age buddy film that‚Äôs simply using war as a back drop. 
Then once you‚Äôve let your guard down and given into it‚Äôs boyish sense of duty and adventure, he proceeds to stab you in the heart with a bayonet of cold reality that‚Äôs absolutely devastating.
‚ÄùThe thing I can‚Äôt stand about you, mate, is you‚Äôre always so bloody cheerful.‚Äù
Cinematic Time Capsule - 1981 Ranked
The New York Times Book of Movies: 
The Essential 1,000 Films to See']

Title: Silkwood
Text:
A plutonium processing plant worker is purposefully contaminated, psychologically tortured, and possibly murdered to prevent her from exposing safety¬†violations.
['As much about the immorality of the capitalist forces demolishing the lives of everyday people as it is about having hot roommates', "It's clear they're getting scared. As acceptance of the idea of socialism is coming back, especially among younger people, the media is slowly and subtly pushing anti-communist narratives back to the fore. Right now, a show on HBO about Chernobyl 
distorts the truth
 in key places to demonize the Soviets. It's an opportunistic take on a real tragedy, and so much of the working class solidarity that alleviated the horror of the tragedy is hidden from view. Meanwhile, stories like 
Silkwood
 are almost forgotten here.
The extent of nuclear toxicity in the United States is completely unknown. 
It's hidden in your neighborhood
. It's hidden in plain sight. It's in the air, water, and soil. It's everywhere, especially in the testing‚Ä¶ 
more", "Completely sends the expected advocacy drama to the back row in favor of this prickly story about a pretty unpleasant woman self-actualizing by locating her greatest innate skill: looking outside herself. Obviously the original (much thornier) ERIN BROCKOVICH. Even if that's bullshit I just made up, Streep's chain-smoking white trash Karen Silkwood is a gigantic fucking mood, plus she gets to bone Kurt Russell and Cher is gay for her. Great movie."]

Title: She Dies¬†Tomorrow
Text:
Amy is ravaged by the notion that she is going to die tomorrow, which sends her down a dizzying emotional spiral. When her skeptical friend Jane discovers Amy‚Äôs feeling of imminent death to be contagious, they both begin bizarre journeys through what might be the last day of their¬†lives.
['If we‚Äôre talking time-of-day ratings this gets a strong 2:00 AM from me', "A feature film adaptation of that thing where you mention that you don't know where your tongue is supposed to rest in your mouth", '‚Äúi love trees. i‚Äôm gonna miss them‚Äù\nmost of the time when i feel an anxiety attack coming on it was actually triggered by the random thought that crossed my mind just before it started: ‚Äúwhat if i had an anxiety attack right now?‚Äù this is kind of like that for 90 minutes. don‚Äôt expect much explanation but instead try to tune in with the melancholy vibes, which shouldn‚Äôt be much of a challenge during times like this. i feel sad most days now to some degree and found this comforting rather than upsetting. i don‚Äôt often share my anxieties and sadness with others anymore for fear that these negative feelings will be contagious and make my loved ones feel this horrible way that i do. but in a way this proves that sometimes sharing the misery is inevitable (also, unhinged kate lyn sheil is always too brilliant)']

Title: Bring Them¬†Down
Text:
When the ongoing rivalry between farmers Michael and Jack suddenly escalates, it triggers a chain of events that take increasingly violent and devastating turns, leaving both families permanently¬†altered.
['filed under things that happen when men don‚Äôt talk it out', 'as expected, the true instigator of the conflict was airbnb', 'Who fucking knew sheep farming was THAT fucking intense in Ireland!?!?']

Title: A Bay of¬†Blood
Text:
An elderly heiress is killed by her husband who wants control of her fortunes. What ensues is an all-out murder spree as relatives and friends attempt to reduce the inheritance playing field, complicated by some teenagers who decide to camp out in a dilapidated building on the¬†estate.
['I can‚Äôt even tell you how many times I‚Äôve seen this, but each viewing makes me like it more and more.
An heiress is killed and sets off a sequence of murderous events as her family and acquaintances all try to get a piece of her estate. There‚Äôs a bit of debate as to what movie was the ‚Äúfirst slasher‚Äù, but this one will always hold that title for me. There were certainly movies that came out prior to this that influenced the genre, but this one just really feels like the one that built the framework for all the slasher movies to come.
The Kills are super violent and extremely well done. My favorite would have to be that‚Ä¶ 
more', 'A Bay of Blood
 aka 
Twitch of the Death Nerve 
is not Bava‚Äôs most polished entry in his filmography, but it‚Äôs STILL nice to look at with its bay setting and memorable setpiece kills (13!)‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs also a damn classic
When I was younger I wasn‚Äôt really a big Bava guy (that‚Äôs changed over the years in a big way) but this was always an exception‚ÄîCarlo Rambaldi‚Äôs gore goes a long way here and so does that incredible stinger of an ending that gets me every time! A definite precursor of slashery goodness that would emerge towards the end of the 70‚Äôs and dominate the 80‚Äôs.\xa0
I‚Äôm at this weird stage in life where even I‚Äôd rather pop in 
Baron Blood
\xa0or 
Shock\xa0
over this‚Ä¶ but honestly any Bava banger is\xa0a perfect way to start a day.', 'It‚Äôs always ‚ÄòMario Bava laid the groundwork for the modern Slasher‚Äô and never ‚ÄòMario Bava pulled off one of the greatest twist endings in cinematic history‚Äô.']

Title: Devs
Text:
Young computer engineer Lily Chan investigates the secretive development division of her employer, a cutting-edge tech company based in San Francisco, which she believes is behind the murder of her¬†boyfriend.
['Devs is an ambitious sci-fi series from director Alex Garland. The similarities to Ex Machina were distracting at times, but these 8 episodes are more compelling and thoughtful than most of what‚Äôs out there. I thought Nick Offerman and Zach Grenier as Kenton were the best in terms of performance and character. Beyond exploring the out of control power of large tech companies, it‚Äôs more closely examining destiny.\xa0 If we knew the future could we change it, or is it inevitable? Do our choices matter at all? If they do could we go back and do things differently? This story explores all of these themes in a satisfying way.
The series is gorgeously shot, with seemless incorporation of vfx. The‚Ä¶ 
more', "[My wife comes home to see my mouth absolutely covered in berries, a surefire sign that I have eaten the big ol' pie she left to cool on the windowsill, even thought it was explicitly made for our daughter's bake sale at school]
ME: What can I say, baby‚Äì it's Devs!", 'In the new FX limited series ‚ÄòDevs,‚Äô Alex Garland takes his signature grandeur, slow horror, and juxtaposition of nature and technology to new levels by shoving it directly up his own ass. Written by someone who has never lived in San Francisco, nor spent a day around the Patagonia clad tech geeks with $60 hair cuts and AirPods permanently shoved into their ears, ‚ÄòDevs‚Äô imagines a San Francisco shrouded in fog, mystery, and murder. 
The show follows Lily Chan, you know, that girl who lived down the hall from you in the dorms freshman year? Programmer Lily Chan is Chinese American, hates wearing bras, and loves her boyfriend. After her boyfriend goes missing from work at his very big and‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Skin
Text:
A destitute young man, raised by racist skinheads and notorious among white supremacists, turns his back on hatred and violence to transform his life, with the help of a black activist and the woman he¬†loves.

As a result, the pair witness a gang of terrorists seize the tower and take its late-night occupants (including Marie- Joelle) hostage. Knowing that only they can save the day, Eric and Ramzy swing into¬†action.

Title: Ninja¬†Assassin
Text:
Ninja Assassin follows Raizo, one of the deadliest assassins in the world. Taken from the streets as a child, he was transformed into a trained killer by the Ozunu Clan, a secret society whose very existence is considered a myth. But haunted by the merciless execution of his friend by the Clan, Raizo breaks free from them and vanishes. Now he waits, preparing to exact his¬†revenge.
['Trivia.
1) After Raizo is captured by Interpol & chained to the wall, one of the agents looks at him & says, "He looks like he should be in a boy band." Rain started his career in the boy band Fanclub.
2) Korean pop star Rain had no martial-arts experience prior to filming. He trained extensively for six months in martial arts & weapons handling with stunt & action choreographers.
Timelord Thoughts.
Ninja Assassin is a underrated kick ass action flick that features brilliant fight choreography is produced by Joel Silver, The Wachowskis
& Grant Hill & sees the long awaited return of 80's legend Sho Kosugi playing the villainous Ozunu.
The fight sequences are brutal & bloody with limbs being hacked off & a ton of blood‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I remember seeing the trailer for this movie in the cinema when I was a teenager. This led me to wait for so long. as not only I had heard mixed reviews about it, but there was also the fact that I didn‚Äôt have the best internet connection (I used dial up way til the late 00s) nor did I have a family member interested in this kinda of movie at that time.
And while it was nothing new or groundbreaking, it always entertained as a sort of action-ninja thriller. I could have done it without the horrible CGI blood. While there are plenty of awesome kills and carnage, none of it works because of this.
In any case, if‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Does what it says on the shuriken.']

Title: Now,¬†Voyager

Title: The¬†Party
Text:
Hrundi V. Bakshi, an accident-prone actor from India, is accidentally put on the guest list for an upcoming party at the home of a Hollywood film producer. Unfortunately, from the moment he arrives, one thing after another goes wrong with compounding¬†effect.
['‚ÄúThe Party‚Äù is the closest that Hollywood has ever come to replicating Jacques Tati.\xa0
It‚Äôs also - unfortunately- hideously racist; even within the context of its own time.\xa0
The only non-‚ÄúPanther‚Äù collaboration between Blake Edwards and Peter Sellers, ‚ÄúThe Party‚Äù stars Sellers in brownface as a minor Indian actor that finds himself fumbling around a bigwig Hollywood house hang.\xa0
Much of ‚ÄúThe Party‚Äù - filmed only from an outline of a script - is deeply rooted in the environmental humor of Tati. But filtered through Hollywood‚Äôs lens, it becomes an experimental film that laid ground for so much of modern comedic cinema.\xa0
The improv-heavy and in-sequence shooting format is now all but standard form; cultivating invention and spontaneity that have‚Ä¶ 
more', 'birdie num nums has made it into my everyday vocabulary i fear', "Peter Sellers and Blake Edwards team together for a comedy that mostly functions as a showcase for Sellers' comedic abilities. Everything takes place at the party alluded to in the title, to which the star, who portrays an Indian actor whose career is all but over after giving the director a headache with several comic gaffes, is accidentally invited. It doesn't take long for this oddball to become the center of attention, unnerve the other guests, and maybe even spark something deeper between himself and one of them.
So far, everything I've seen from Sellers, especially of his comedic stuff, has been quite hit-or-miss. Sometimes he doesn't succeeds with me, and sometimes his work is simply enduring and endearing. In‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: The House Is¬†Black
Text:
Set in a leper colony in the north of Iran, The House is Black juxtaposes ‚Äúugliness,‚Äù of which there is much in the world as stated in the opening scenes, with religion and¬†gratitude.
['She has lovely eyes,
and a beauteous face.
She merely lives, 
in a hideous place.', 'This 20-minute documentary-short about an Iranian leper colony contains more elegance, grace, poetry, beauty, and insight into the human condition than 99% of the films released nowadays with 10 times that time. 
The House is Black
 (available to view 
here
) was the only film directed by the Iranian poet Forugh Farrokhzad, a legendary figure in feminist literature who died in a car accident in 1967, thus cutting her career tragically short. The proof she leaves behind of her total and complete understanding of cinema is unshakeable. I dare you to watch this and not come out fully tuned-in to life.
It starts with a subversive gesture. An initially scary zoom-in to a female leper, whose hijab covers her head and‚Ä¶ 
more', '"On this screen will appear an image of ugliness... a vision of pain no caring human being should ignore.To wipe out this ugliness and to relieve the victims... is the motive of this film and the hope of its makers."
... and the statement has been spoken. Farrokhzad was a stunning poetess that emptied her heart and soul to create a contrasting mosaic of Iran. God's creation and the ugliness of the unnatural colliding with philosophical wisdom. I just spent 22 minutes with her and I already miss her so terribly.
May we meet in Heaven if God allows it, Farrokhzad.
100/100']

Title: The¬†Funhouse
Text:
Rebellious teen Amy defies her parents by going to a trashy carnival that has pulled into town. In tow are her boyfriend, Buzz, and their friends Liz and Richie. Thinking it would be fun to spend the night in the campy ‚ÄúFunhouse‚Äù horror ride, the teens witness a murder by a deformed worker wearing a mask. Locked in, Amy and her friends must evade the murderous carnival workers and escape before it leaves town the next¬†day.
['Despite all the carnie grotesques in this movie, the best part for me was when a random old man points a shotgun at a boy he sees walking along the side of the road for no reason other than laughs.', 'A great location oozing with small town carnival atmos, filled with a solid cast of miscreants/jerk teenagers, frankenstein masked human-cow (?) mutant hybrid, and Tobe Hooper‚Äôs deep fried scuzz on display‚Äîas well as his macabre humor and knack for ramping up endings into loud soundwaved lunacy overdrive.\xa0
1981 was such an insane year for slasher movies and 
The Funhouse
 opening with callbacks to 
Halloween
, 
Psycho
, and Universal Monsters (Glenn Strange F-Stein poster!!!) before deciding to spend at least 30 or 40 legit minutes experiencing a local town carnival... and it was never boring for me‚ÄîI could smell the funnel cake, corn dogs, and carnivale mystique! My ex girlfriend‚Äôs family were carnival folk via their food truck business and I spent‚Ä¶ 
more', 'A24 remake of this would go so insanely hard ü§°
decided to make 
The Funhouse
 movie #1 for 
Hooptober 12
! i‚Äôm thrilled to finally try out this iconic spooky season challenge for the first year and of course we started with a Tobe Hooper film!']

Title: Blood¬†Quantum
Text:
The dead are coming back to life outside the isolated Mi‚Äôkmaq reserve of Red Crow, except for its Indigenous inhabitants who are strangely immune to the zombie¬†plague.
["What separates this from the rest of the endless current zombie wave isn't the anti-colonialist subtext or that it's the work of indigenous filmmakers, although both of those things are certainly admirable. More importantly it confidently rides a line between the usual 
Walking Dead
-style bleakness and actual satire, with a ton of terrific gore and some real honest-to-God humor instead of camp or silliness. A very good splatter film.", 'I 
love
\xa0how this movie opens... immediately setting up the perfect fog drenched lived in atmos for a movie like this to breathe. 
Plenty of sociopolitical subtext and a premise I found to be quite inspired, 
Blood Quantum
\xa0features some great performances, wonderful cinematography, top notch/tastefully done gore, and a score (especially towards the end) that really stuck to my bones‚Äîsounding like it actually came from an 80‚Äôs horror movie instead of the usual carpenter wannabe pulsating synth score that‚Äôs festering in so many movies now.
Sure there‚Äôs some familiar tropes here as far as zombie films go, but there‚Äôs a meaningful weight behind this besides the usual ‚Äòhumans are the real monsters‚Äô drop that undercuts genre films such as these. Loses‚Ä¶ 
more', "HoopTober 12
13/31 films
Category: 1 film from Canada
The whole of this film worked together pretty well. There were some things that I liked about it, and some that I did not‚Ä¶
My favorite was the score! It was composed by the writer/director, Jeff Barnaby. 
I also liked the film‚Äôs visual imagery, including the animation segments, which imo enhanced the narrative‚Äôs lore.
The ‚Äúwhite people as zombies‚Äù who took over & infested the Mi'gmaq people‚Äôs land made absolute sense. I wish they‚Äôd emphasized that more throughout the entirety of the film.
Sometimes this was boring - more than I would have hoped for. The kills & blood effects were good though. I wanted the film to feel more impactful, for me it just inches into 3 1/2 stars."]

Title: Rapture
Text:

Videodrome

Holy Christ, what a mind trip! I had never seen anything like that!
Arrebato

Rapture

Jos√© decides to help him giving him a device that allows to control time in film. The man then proceeds to film himself while asleep and finds a red frame in the film. Both will descend into a lunatic whirlpool of madness while both try to unravel the mystery hidden behind the‚Ä¶

Title: Dead &¬†Buried
Text:
After a series of gory murders commited by mobs of townspeople against visiting tourists, the corpses appear to be coming back to life and living normally as locals in the small¬†town.
['The mortuary collection.
One of those movies that has appeared and reappeared in my life for the last 25 years and it‚Äôs always made me uneasy. Small New England town with dark secrets that feels like Lovecraft Stephen King vibes yanks my chain so hard as far as personal tastes go‚ÄîIlluminating with its fog shrouded seaside mist filled atmosfear and likable northeast local yokel characters stuck in one of the best twilight zone episodes never made.
This movie has been on my mind for years, even when I‚Äôm not thinking about it, and I‚Äôve been all over this country and it‚Äôs terror by the sea fables like this that are more scary to me than any backwoods redneck nightmare because‚Ä¶ 
more', '78
From the opening shot of a B&W still photograph jumpstarted to life, I was all in. Coastal, small-town dread with a Twilight Zone narrative. Thematically resonant of the early-80s: the rebellion of small-town innocence.', "Counter-revolution, attempted time-travel, imagineering. 1981 was at the cusp of a wave-peak, the initial effort to return The United States to a 1950's White Christian Cishet Supremacist Wonderland of small-town shopkeepers, in-line law enforcement, nuclear families, with nothing to trouble the surface of the illusion. This time, this Golden Age, never existed, except in model railroads, dollhouses and the dreams of fascist demagogues whose public-private-police-state partnership of soldering business interests to Xtian Fundamentalism and Cold War Paranoia paid off handsomely after a decade of founding conspiratorial think tanks and flooding what markets could be with coded and uncoded messaging. This was an effort to create an uncanny state, a slipstream woven from money and desire and force, a haunted house‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Motherless¬†Brooklyn
Text:
New York City, 1957. Lionel Essrog, a private detective living with Tourette syndrome, tries to solve the murder of his mentor and best friend, armed only with vague clues and the strength of his obsessive¬†mind.
["New York's hottest mess is MOTHERLESS BROOKLYN. it's got everything: Edward Norton *completely* off the chain, Alec Baldwin as Mobert Roses, Willem Dafriend, inexplicably plastic digital cinematography, a 407-minute running time‚Ä¶ and a pretty good new Thom Yorke song!", 'my TIFF19 review for The Film Stage
:
Few films come out in any given year with creative choices as baffling as the ones made by Edward Norton‚Äôs Motherless Brooklyn. The story goes that when the novel came out in 1999 Norton was instantly struck by Jonathan Lethem‚Äôs acclaimed gumshoe neo-noir about a private detective suffering with Tourette Syndrome and began developing the project by as early as 2002. This was a huge period for Norton, having only just burst onto the scene in 1996 starring in Primal Fear (his very first movie, which secured him a Best Supporting Actor nomination), The People Vs. Larry Flynt and a Woody Allen film all in the same year. By 2002 he had made‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Wind
Text:
When Letty Mason relocates to West Texas, she finds herself unsettled by the ever-present wind and sand. Arriving at her new home at the ranch of her cousin, Beverly, she receives a surprisingly cold welcome from his wife, Cora. Soon tensions in the family and unwanted attention from a trio of suitors leave Letty increasingly¬†disturbed.
['A reminder that westerns were "revisionist" pretty much from the start. The frontier rendered as a hellscape of billowing sand, rain and snow, buffeting an increasingly unhinged Lillian Gish, who puts in her most expressionistic performance as a beleaguered woman swept around until she cannot think straight. This is the West as a literal howling void, a realm that exists as an unceasingly hostile force of nature outside what few shelters have been erected to protect settlers from a world so much bigger than they. The climax, of Gish being so violently buffeted that the film turns into an extended hallucination while maintaining Sj√∂strom's paradoxical brutal realism, is among the scariest sequences of the silent era.', "#Watchlist 2021
'There's nothing out there. Nothing but sand.'
Light galloping in the form of a white horse ‚Äì bringing death. 
The Wind
 is a visual nightmare of the desolate countryside blowing the soul into oblivion. It is a surreal apparition of sand and wind where the only solid footing is in the dust-filled air hurtling its victim into the nothingness. 
Sj√∂str√∂m's genius lies in his skill of joining the visible with the metaphorical. He crafts his haunting dreamscape with claustrophobic visuals that allude to the psychological elements: he suffuses the lonely countryside with a bleakness signaling the worthlessness of our protagonist, and contrasts the endless physical landscape with the rapidly narrowing space of the human psyche.
There is a‚Ä¶

Title: Saint¬†Frances
Text:
At the start of the summer, Bridget has an abortion just as she lands a much-needed job in affluent Evanston, Illinois ‚Äî nannying a six-year¬†old.
['‚Äúmy guitar class is a patriarchy‚Äù\nsuper cute and touches casually on various important topics in just the right way, amplifying it beyond the realm of just ‚Äúsuper cute‚Äù into ‚Äúactually really good‚Äù territory as well. also it‚Äôs really interesting how they managed to somehow find the cutest kid in the world', 'One of the most charming and midwest films of the last few years. Fresh and egoless take on a necessary subject. To any NY and LA readers out there, go see it this weekend! Not just saying this because Alex Thompson helped\xa0me get equipment for Keychain. (thanks Alex!)', 'This film understands how raw bodies and hearts are. The way you start crying and then cry even more because there‚Äôs a tear stain, or a blood stain, you‚Äôve given yourself a headache and you haven‚Äôt finished your work, you burnt your dinner, you sent the wrong text message, you shouted at someone you shouldn‚Äôt have and your hormones and feelings and fears and desires are all mixed up and overwhelming and you stain something else and that makes you cry even more. You‚Äôre a mess in a way that only you know, because it‚Äôs private, but that also anyone who has ever wanted to show you love will work to understand. Saint Frances knows all\xa0of this, it knows you‚Äôre tired, and it makes everything else a mess to show you that it cares, that it gets it. To show that you‚Äôre not alone, and you never will be.']

He chose them, and through these books his personality expresses itself. Each book is a touch of color. Title: The Mosquito¬†Coast
Text:
An inventor spurns his city life and moves his family into the jungles of Central America to make a¬†utopia.
["In some ways, Harrison Ford's decision to take the lead in The Mosquito Coast slightly mirrors the decision his character makes in this film.
Ford took on the role in the middle of his 1980s golden patch of critically acclaimed and universally beloved good guy roles. It's a decision that didn't really pay off - The Mosquito Coast wasn't well received critically and it didn't perform at the box office. Again, rather mirroring the failure that his character oversees in trying to relocate his entire family to the jungles of Belize.
But in some ways perhaps Ford's career has floundered in the last decade or so because he hasn't taken enough 'risks' like this. While his place as one of‚Ä¶ 
more", "Harrison Ford loves pointing, and boy does he do it a lot in this movie, where he plays the worst father on Earth. Directed by Peter Weir and written by Paul Schrader, I thought I would like this movie a lot more than I did, but it's still a pretty good portrait of why most suicide bombers start their careers as engineers.", 'There Will Be Ice']

Title: The Beaches of¬†Agn√®s
Text:
Filmmaking icon Agn√®s Varda, the award-winning director regarded by many as the grandmother of the French new wave, turns the camera on herself with this unique autobiographical documentary. Composed of film excerpts and elaborate dramatic re-creations, Varda‚Äôs self-portrait recounts the highs and lows of her professional career, the many friendships that affected her life and her longtime marriage to cinematic giant Jacques¬†Demy.
['agn√®s varda is an artist in every single form, but what makes her so special is she makes being an artist feel possible. everything in her life either turns into art, or she is able to construct art in a way that she can physically live inside of it. some artists make creating seem intimidating & it almost deters you from attempting. but agn√®s shows us how she sees life, and stitches it all together, and shows us that no person is artless. we are all creating, and telling stories, and building little houses of art to be surrounded by.', '"As a filmmaker, my only option was to film him in extreme close-up: his skin, his eye, his hair like a landscape, his hands, his spots. I needed to do this, take these images of him, of his very matter. Jacques dying, but Jacques still alive."\n‚ù§Ô∏è', 'Currently crying because I never got a chance to become best friends with Miss Agn√®s Varda.']

Title: Jigoku
Text:
A group of sinners involved in interconnected tales of murder, revenge, deceit and adultery all meet at the Gates of¬†Hell.
['Chilling cautionary tale of what happens when you get into two separate car accidents that aren‚Äôt your fault and your friend is an evil cool guy.', "Well, that was disturbing! Didn't expect this to mess me up as much as it did but here we are. So ahead of its time visually, too. It's times like this where I just hate ratings bc while it's very flawed, I can't deny how into it I was and how much it, again, disturbed me. Sheesh!", "Jigoku is without a doubt one of the most visually and thematically pessimistic movies in history. In the Jigoku world of extreme despair and torment, everyone sins and everyone deserves to be tortured forever in hell, and it certainly leaves nothing to the imagination when depicting the terrifying after life every living soul is inherently scared of.\nIn this daunting story of death-oriented nature, a car accident starts a malignant chain reaction, resulting in the death of almost every character that runs into its path. Dropping like flies is no longer an exaggeration in this wildly supernatural journey, where devil himself even contributes to the morbid game of misery and suffering. Yet the story hasn't reached its true climax until‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: Frailty
Text:
A mysterious man arrives at the offices of an FBI agent and recounts his childhood: how his religious fanatic father received visions telling him to kill people who were in fact¬†‚Äúdemons.‚Äù
['I\'ve always liked this movie. Bill Paxton\'s directorial debut is one of those hidden gems of the early 2000s horror scene. It\'s a little bumpy and rough around the edges, it isn\'t going to change the world, but the story is interesting, the performances are great, and it highlights Paxton\'s strengths both in front and behind the camera. I\'ve got a bit of a soft spot for it. \nKate\'s take: "Very dark, twisty and turny, and now I\'m rethinking my parenting strategy"', 'Bill Paxton‚Äôs directorial debut oozes that eerie 90s psychological thriller vibe, complete with a young calm, cool, and collected Matthew McConaughey narrating us through a series of chilling flashbacks. It tiptoes the line between thriller and horror with scares derived mostly from atmosphere rather than shocks or violence, which when present is mostly offscreen. It‚Äôs also one of those films that you immediately know has a twist coming, and here its God-fearing nature either works for you or it doesn‚Äôt‚Äîpersonally, I found the third act to be rife with standard low budget camp, which essentially translates to ‚ÄúI loved it‚Äù. It‚Äôs short yet quite slow, probably my one big nitpick, but it still makes for a perfect dark & stormy night type of watch.', 'Go hunt some demons boy']

Title: Death by¬†Hanging
Text:
A Korean man is sentenced to death in Japan but somehow survives his execution, sending the authorities into a panic about what to do¬†next.
["Death by Hanging
 is of two deaths: a Korean man dubbed R is hung by Japanese leaders for his crimes, but he unexpectedly does not physically die. Instead he survives, but loses his memory and thus marks the first death ‚Äì that of his identity.
So what happens now? When someone has been hung but they remain alive, unaware of any past crimes they've made? Are they still a criminal in that case, are they still guilty of their crimes if they have no recollection?
It's complicated. Many systems of law are founded on discrimination, the codifying of racism and sexism being two of the most common ones. In this case by underlying the law it becomes systematic prejudice that‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Very loosely based on a true story about a Japanese-born Korean student who raped and killed two girls in 1958 and was given death sencence by hanging five years later, 
K√¥shikei
 is √îshima's personal transformation of an ordinary execution story into an expertly directed satirical dark comedy with important undertones of criticism against capital punishment, the Japanese nationalist anti-Korean sentiment and the blood-soaked Japanese imperialism, all through a scope that intents on the ridicule of the nationalist (Minister of Education), political (Public Prosecutors), religious (Priest) and legal (District Attorney) authorities. With a stunning ability to intertwine both the comically absurd and dramatic glimpses of powerful ideas about the contradictions found in the definitions of "human justice", √îshima challenges prejudices and societal xenophobia, and invites to reflection for his time and for the times of today.
94/100', '"Everything was according to procedure."
"If you imagine something does it appear in reality?"
The routine, documentary killing of a man by the state is fractured into Brechtian slapstick when the hanging is botched and the sheer absurdity of trying to maintain a legal, moral and spiritual logic out of the cruelty of capitol punishment is rendered into both literal farce and surreal despair. It's a Kafkaesque political and philosophical exercise that could've been a heavy-handed sermon but Oshima instead stylizes with a playful sense of construction and contradiction. The many scenes of the officials doing re-enactments of R's past life and violent crimes to his dead-eyed stare (including building sets and performing both racist caricatures of his childhood and‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Detour
Text:
The life of Al Roberts, a pianist in a New York nightclub, turns into a nightmare when he decides to hitchhike to Los Angeles to visit his¬†girlfriend.
['This movie is 68 minutes long', "95/100
Well, it makes sense that the name of the main actress happens to be Ann Savage, because that's exactly what this rugged masterwork is: fucking savage. From beginning to end, the tattered rear projections and the sweaty dialogue build the ferocious tension up to a level of murderous rage and nightmarish barbarity, further enhancing the second-rate production values and the film's constant state of alarming mystery. Only running a length of 67 minutes, the dreamlike hopelessness of 
Detour
 is akin to a vision that is only encountered because of a relentless fever. 
Suggested double feature: 
Detour
/
Lost Highway
*
*Preferably at 3 in the morning.", '"The world is full of skeptics." Pure fiery, sad-sack noir; brutal and miserable right up until its final frame.']

Title: The American¬†Friend
Text:
Tom Ripley, an American who deals in forged art, is slighted at an auction in Hamburg by picture framer Jonathan Zimmerman. When Ripley is asked by gangster Raoul Minot to kill a rival, he suggests Zimmerman, and the two, exploiting Zimmerman‚Äôs terminal illness, coerce him into being a¬†hitman.
['believe it or not but bruno ganz and dennis hopper are gay in this movie, and no, I will not elaborate on that.', "An American sociopath teaches a thoughtful European how to rock in the underworld is a premise that could've very easily been turned into an exciting paperback thriller but is instead rendered here by Wenders in a sense of style that emphasizes a much slower, sicker existential feeling of corruption. Brutal ending, and Ganz and Hopper are incredible.", 'It‚Äôs so important to have that one friend who you can really be your worst self with.']

Title: King¬†Richard
Text:
The story of how Richard Williams served as a coach to his daughters Venus and Serena, who will soon become two of the most legendary tennis players in¬†history.
['gotta keep an eye out for serena', 'pretty great once it becomes a Venus Williams movie', 'Thank you Hollywood for reminding me that behind every successful child there‚Äôs an abusive parent.']

Title: The Marriage of Maria¬†Braun
Text:
Maria marries a young soldier in the last days of World War II, only for him to go missing in the war. She must rely on her beauty and ambition to navigate the difficult post-war years¬†alone.
["Maria Braun is a product of survivalism. Reduced by war and loss to a struggle just to eat and breathe, she becomes a hardened soul. It's easy to suggest that she is Germany through Fassbinder's eyes (and perhaps this is so), but I think of her more as symbolic of any people under capitalism. She becomes ruthless and materialistic. The love of her life is a memory to her, regardless of his vital state, and her motivations, whatever they were before the marriage and war, become about advancing financially more than anything else. To her, love is to be pushed aside, to be manipulated, to be controlled. Even in her most compassionate moments, she is driven to violence.
That she‚Ä¶ 
more", 'I confess it difficult for me to scrape my feelings and thoughts about 
The Marriage of Maria Braun
 into an articulate audit, much less one worthy of its due. My first encounter with Rainer Werner Fassbinder, I‚Äôm ashamed to admit, far exceeded my tepid expectations‚Äîthis film transfixed me, ransacking my subconscious while I was under its spell, and I stirred from its sorcery desolate, heartbroken and grieving.
Maria is a woman after my own heart, possessed by Hanna Schygulla in a commanding performance; a newlywed bride left alone to navigate the confusion of post-war Germany when her soldier husband, Hermann doesn‚Äôt return from his final mission. She haunts the dusty train station and rubble-filled streets waiting for her husband to‚Ä¶ 
more', "86
Astonishing in how it captures a woman utilizing Post-War confusion for her personal gain, wrestling with moral/financial repercussions and an overwhelming rise in agency. But of course, it doesn't last. As Germany picks itself up, its interior rots from the core outward."]

Title: Soylent¬†Green

With various reports of animal species becoming extinct, dwindling natural resources and man's unquenchable greed and proclivity towards arrogance I found the film even more terrifying because there is no one to save us from ourselves!

Title: The¬†Frighteners
Text:
Once an architect, Frank Bannister now passes himself off as an exorcist of evil spirits. To bolster his facade, he claims his ‚Äúspecial‚Äù gift is the result of a car accident that killed his wife. But what he does not count on is more people dying in the small town where he lives. ['The jovial 90s charm of Robert Zemeckis and the wild wackiness of Peter Jackson‚Äôs early foray into horror-comedies combine to create a movie about Michael J. Fox and his ghost friends trying to save the future of cinema from a reliance on CGI special effects. Spoiler alert: they failed.
\xa0
The VFX here were lauded in 1996; I don‚Äôt really have a problem with them as a staple of their time, especially since they still kick the ass of many, many films that came out well over a decade later, but yeah I‚Äôm not going to pretend they haven‚Äôt aged like milk in comparison to the vast majority of (my most used word pairing on Letterboxd) practical effects. Doesn‚Äôt really‚Ä¶ 
more', 'literally like a living cartoon so unbelievably goofy i was having the time of my life', "Spooktober III: The Haunting of the Blood October
Man! That Jake Busey looks a bit much psychotic than his father ‚Äì at least on this movie.
One of those films that I've been hearing about for a long time and that many people have recommended to me. And, while it begins a little slowly, it does get interesting as it progresses. The premise is rich with ideas that Peter Jackson manages to execute brilliantly, beginning with the fact that we have this supposed Ghostbuster who turns out to be a bit of a fraud because the ghosts are collaborating with him. And I also liked how it goes from being this Amblin-esque fun comedy with hints of horror, to leaning‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Love¬†Streams
Text:
Two closely-bound, emotionally wounded siblings reunite after years¬†apart.
["‚Äú
This picture, this picture; I don't give a fuck what anybody says. If you don't have time to see it, don't. If you don't like it, don't. If it doesn't give you an answer, fuck you. I didn't make it for you anyway
.‚Äù ‚Äî John Cassavetes on 
Love Streams
the perfect endcap to Cassavetes‚Äô career (
Big Trouble
 doesn‚Äôt count), and he knew it. you can sense his savoring of life in the bittersweet way he and Gena Rowlands slow dance, lit only by the light of a jukebox and the moon. in the same room, he later briefly looks straight into the camera, his face slightly obscured through the rain-streaked window, and it hits like the most intimate goodbye. i‚Äôm grateful he got to say goodbye.", 'Not just the bottomless need for love but the inexhaustible compulsion to express it, to find an outlet for it, to enact it.', 'One of the pleasures of watching a movie for me is taking leave of time. By that I simply mean not wearing a watch. And making sure to always switch off (off!) my mobile phone. It means that when you're watching the film, you have to feel how much time has passed and how much time remains. When attempting to make that calculation is too easy, and when you're right about it, you know you have a bad movie. I genuinely believe that a key barometer of quality filmmaking is when, temporally speaking, you don't know where you are. I think it might relate to that clich√© when people talk about "losing yourself" in a movie. Anyway, I was watching‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The¬†Traitor
Text:
Palermo, Sicily, 1980. Mafia member Tommaso Buscetta decides to move to Brazil with his family fleeing the constant war between the different clans of the criminal organization. But when, after living several misfortunes, he is forced to return to Italy, he makes a bold decision that will change his life and the destiny of Cosa Nostra¬†forever.
["The Italian character on trial. Not really a gangster film, but an exploration about how Cosa Nostra is intertwined in Italian society. People comparing The Traitor to something like Goodfellas are complete ignoring the local specifics and meaning of the mob and how central it remains to modern Italian identity (almost as central as catholicism). As the title promises, this is a film about betrayal, but what is betrayed is more ambiguous than simple the mob code of silence. Favino wonderful performance, one of the year's best, does a great job of both presenting Buscetta as a self-serving narcisist and selling the idea of disappointment at the modernization of the Cosa Nostra as Italy's move from one sort of organized‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'man I hate it when [checks notes] a singing restaurant santa claus reminds me I betrayed the mafia', 'Almost an hour into Marco Bellocchio‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Traitor‚Äù ‚Äî a lively but scattershot and exasperating biopic about Tommaso Buscetta, the first Sicilian mob boss to become an informant for the authorities ‚Äî the film‚Äôs charismatic protagonist (Pierfrancesco Favino) tells an interrogator a story about one of the first men he was ever assigned to kill. Bellocchio then cuts to a brief flashback that offers us more about his subject than the rest of this two-and-a-half hour film combined. The young Buscetta sees his target across a courtyard, and his target sees him. Knowing that Buscetta is there to kill him, the man takes his baby son into his arms for protection, hoping that his assassin wouldn‚Äôt risk endangering the life‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Neo¬†Tokyo
Text:
A trilogy of separate stories. In ‚ÄúLabyrinth labyrinthos‚Äù, a girl and her cat enter a strange world. In ‚ÄúRunning Man‚Äù, a racer takes on the ultimate opponent. In ‚ÄúConstruction Cancellation Order‚Äù, a man must shut down worker¬†robots.
['There is a surrealism and beauty you can achieve with animation that cannot be replicated in live action films. The fluidity of motion, the way light passes across peoples faces, it is entirely subjective to the director with wildly different results from person to person. 
Neo Tokyo is a gorgeous anthology film, full of twisted designs and blocks of primary colours laid against cool blues and steely greys. The Running Man is fantastically animated (and my favourite) though all three stories have merit. At 50 minutes it is a swift punch to the gut and it is criminal that there is a) no UK release and b) no bluray of this. 
A dark, wonderful tale of futuristic civillisation.', "JUNIMATION II: F*** YEAH!
Better than 
Love, Death and Robots
 (I‚Äôve only seen three episodes from season 1)
As with any anthology, some stories are better than others, but a consistent feature across all of them is the incredible animation. Again, I'm very lucky I randomly got around to watch all this splendid anime with some wonderful animation and styles, sometimes coming together into one project, as it‚Äôs the case with this one. Whether it‚Äôs the pretty terrifying first one, with its horror imagery and villains and creatures, or the kinda sci-fi stuff. It‚Äôs all visually stunning. I‚Äôm starting to notice the big role shadow has in these anime projects, especially the more adult stuff during this period and specific‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Anime Marches On! 2018 Challenge
1 from Yoshiaki Kawajiri
Admirable (and 
significant
) late-80's anime anthology of three distinct short stories showcasing a trio of notable talents within the genre. What it lacks in a strong narrative structure is more than made up by the 
stunning
 visual aesthetics on display.
The thin connecting thread between the animated shorts is that each segment had been showcased in the previous year's collection (which bore the same name) of short stories by celebrated Japanese science fiction writer 
Taku Mayumura
. Let's dive in...
Labyrinth Labyrinthos
 (Directed by 
Rintaro
)
I was a few moments into this segment when it dawned on me that I had indeed watched all of "Neo-Tokyo" (as opposed to just "Running Man")‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Christine
Text:
In 1974, television reporter Christine Chubbuck struggles with depression and professional frustrations as she tries to advance her¬†career.
["there is one shot of this that haunts my brain. the whole film is building up to the inevitable, the suicide of christine chubbuck on live television, this incident is why the film exists, there would be no reason to make a film about this woman if it wasn't for how she left this world. campos instead of sensationalising her like robert greene did with his great yet inferior film kate plays christine, tries to understand the person behind the suicide, and crafts an intricate portrayal of a woman, where the suicide doesn't seem like the only force driving the film. she is ostensibly a person here, her death essentially comes out of nowhere near the end of the film,‚Ä¶ 
more", '"
You might just make it after all."
I would love to talk about this film and what it did to me, but right now I'm about to lose it so I don't think I can. I hope more people do watch this though, because it's absolutely perfect.', "Rebecca Hall is aces and Antonio Campos directs with rare precision (save for the sense that there's *zero* sense of place?), but... why? to what conceivable end would they dredge up this woman's banal life and bizarre death? it doesn't work as a critique of media sensationalism, it doesn't work as a portrait of a woman struggling to have it all... 
it's reasonably compelling all the same, but ya just can't shake the feeling that there might be a more insightful, probing, and relevant way of reanimating Christine Chubbuck... but what are the odds of anyone doing *that*?"]

Title: Your Lie in¬†April
Text:
Kousei Arima was a genius pianist until his mother‚Äôs sudden death took away his ability to play. Each day was dull for Kousei. But, then he meets a violinist named Kaori Miyazono who has an eccentric playing style. Can the heartfelt sounds of the girl‚Äôs violin lead the boy to play the piano¬†again?
['Dear Arima Kousei,
It feels weird writing a letter to someone you were just with‚Ä¶
You‚Äôre the worst.
Indecisive. Gullible. Twit.
The first time I ever saw you perform, I was 5 years old. It was at a recital for the piano school I was going to. This awkward, clumsy kid came onto the stage and accidentally hit the piano stool with his butt. It was too funny. He turned to the piano that was way too big for him and the moment he played that first note, I was drawn in.
The sound was beautiful, like a 24-colour palette. The melodies danced.
The girl next to me started crying. I wasn‚Äôt expecting that at all.
And even so, you‚Ä¶ 
more', "I'M STILL NOT OVER IT GOD DAMMIT", 'I will NEVER forgive them for changing the opening song for the second half.']

Title: The¬†Heiress
Text:
In 1840s New York, the uneventful and boring days of the daughter of a wealthy doctor come to an end when she meets a dashing poorer man ‚Äî who may or may not be after her¬†inheritance.
['I love the slow subtlety of Olivia de Havilland‚Äôs character arc in 
The Heiress
, particularly in the way she changes her voice in the progression of the film. Her high, shy delivery slowly shifts into something lower, more purposeful, more confident. The mistreatment of her character is maddening in so many ways, even more so because of the fact that so many viewers see themselves in her, myself included. She‚Äôs awkward, imperfect, and her worth is wholly underestimated by everyone, but that makes her eventual transformation all the more gratifying. Olivia‚Äôs Academy Award was so well-deserved.
(This is a random observation, but another thing I like about this film is how it doesn‚Äôt glam up its stars with heavy, 40s makeup. No dark lipstick. No big eyelashes. And you can actually see Olivia‚Äôs dark circles come through. So many Old Hollywood period pieces just stick with modern makeup trends with no consideration of the time period or the characters.)
3.8/5', 'I always enjoy when a mustache is used as a plot device to signal time passing. 
timestache.', '"He's grown greedier over the years. Before he only wanted my money; now he wants my love as well. Well, he came to the wrong house - and he came twice. I shall see that he does not come a third time. I can be very cruel. I have been taught by masters." WIG MISSINGGGGG.']

Title: Avatar¬†Spirits
Text:
Bryan Konietzko and Michael Dante DiMartino, co-creators of the hit television series, Avatar: The Last Airbender, reflect on the creation of the masterful¬†series.
["Here's a review of the actual documentary.
First of all, it's crazy how Mike and Bryan just came up with the show and pitch with so little time and managed to talk about it for 2 hours or something. I guess it shows how special it was since they were so confident in it. 
(SPOILERS
: It turned out excellent.)
Second, the way they do the animation and actually treat their overseas animators is incredible. People should respect their talented artists and talk to them as people, not just workers.
Third, people who use this to review the show without seeing this actual documentary make me sad. It's on YouTube, go and watch it! 
If you haven't seen the show, let me tell you: if I wasn't so adventurous, I'd glady forget all of my favourite films and watch this show for the rest of my life.
SCORE: 7/10", 'So, I finally watched 
Avatar
. I'm only about 15 years late. Once you get past the first couple tonally-confused episodes where it can't decide if it wants to be a kid's show or something much more mature, it instantly branches out into one of the greatest shows ever made. There really isn't anything I can say about 
Avatar: The Last Airbender 
that hasn't already been said. 
It's impossible not to fall in love with this show. Every character is fully fleshed-out and brilliantly written, the animation is spectacular, the humor works really well, the action goes ridiculously hard for a "kids show", it has some of the greatest character arcs of all time; it's just pure lighting-in-a-bottle perfection. Not to‚Ä¶ 
more', "This counts as the show until it's actually added.
Zuko is literally the greatest fictional character to exist, and he's in the greatest TV show ever."]

Title: The¬†Loveless
Text:
Trouble ensues when a motorcycle gang stops in a small southern town while heading to the races at¬†Daytona.
['Is Willem Dafoe hot? A case study.', 'It makes a little bit of sense that the directorial debut of painter turned film theory grad student turned seductively violent action filmmaker Kathryn Bigelow would be an academic art film subversion on classically cool macho genre storytelling. In this case, collaborating with the eventual David Lynch producer Monty Montgomery (
Wild at Heart
, 
Twin Peaks
, and the cowboy from 
Mulholland Dr/
) on a juvenile delinquent/greaser biker film that looks back on Marlon Brando in 
The Wild Ones
 and James Dean in 
Rebel Without a Cause
 with less fondness than a kind of lethargic sadness and threatening fear. Indulging every fetishized and erotic image of an impossibly baby-faced Willem Dafoe greased up, dressed in tight black leather, brooding and smirking while‚Ä¶ 
more', "Kathryn Bigelow's debut feature seems to be fueled by some simple ideas:
- Willem Dafoe is weird sexy.
- Listless young men in leather hanging around mid-century diners, bars and garages exude a certain ineffable mood. 
- Listless young men in leather hanging around mid-century diners, bars and garages exude a threat of violence and sex.
- Listless young men in leather hanging around mid-century diners, bars and garages exude a weird sexiness. 
- Rednecks are bad people.
Minimal to the point of almost being an installation piece more than a narrative, Bigelow really shows off her painterly chops, every frame looking like Norman Rockwell trying to gentrify Tom of Finland."]
