Title: Mishima: A Life in Four¬†Chapters
Text:
A fictional account of the life of Japanese author Yukio Mishima, combining dramatizations of three of his novels and a depiction of the events of November 25th,¬†1970.
['Killing yourself to own the libs.', 'MISHMA: JAPANESE PREMIERE. Forty years after it's premiere at Cannes, "Mishima" will be shown publicly for the first time in Japan at the 
2025 Tokyo Film Festial.
 I knew this day would come. I didn't know if I'd be alive to see it.', '"A man's desire to become beautiful is also a desire for death."
Harmonizes actual events of Mishima's life, his nationalism, his persona as an artist, his fiction, and his own self-image, ultimately fully empathizing with his will to power and violent transcendence.']

Title: Ray
Text:
Born on a sharecropping plantation in Northern Florida, Ray Charles went blind at seven. Inspired by a fiercely independent mom who insisted he make his own way, He found his calling and his gift behind a piano keyboard. Touring across the Southern musical circuit, the soulful singer gained a reputation and then exploded with worldwide fame when he pioneered coupling gospel and country¬†together.
['I like how Ray goes to rehab and then the movie just...ends. And text tells us "he never did drugs again."', 'It was very bold of the filmmakers to actually go back in time and cast young Ray Charles as himself. Not many filmmakers would take such a risk.', 'Though this musical biopic is a bit overstretched with some flaws, it is just full of energy and love, powered by some fantastic performance from Jamie Foxx and refreshing blues. It addresses the psychological aspects, balancing out both his personal and professional fronts through his musical odyssey in a neat and engaging manner. A good solid watch.']

Title: A¬†Separation
Text:

My friend isn't much of a film buff, but he knew that he'd seen something special. When I asked what he liked most about it, he didn't say anything about the acting or the direction or nuances of the plot. Instead, he simply said "because that stuff really 
happened
."
Of course, my friend was not speaking literally. Instead, I think he was trying to talk about a feeling that the movie captured that transcends what we generally consider realism. It struck a nerve with him because it resonated in a deeper way than he could have ever expected. It‚Ä¶

We took her on a trip to the Philippines for Christmas so that she can celebrate her family back on her homeland, and although it almost seemed nice to see her happy to be back home for probably one last time, a thought of sadness hit me as I came to remember something she once told me. Title: 25th¬†Hour
Text:
In New York City in the days following the events of 9/11, Monty Brogan is a convicted drug dealer about to start a seven-year prison sentence, and his final hours of freedom are devoted to hanging out with his closest buddies and trying to prepare his girlfriend for his extended¬†absence.
['"It\'s all over after tonight. Wake the fuck up."\n"That\'s how I wanna remember you."\nOne of the great movies about living in your Final Moments and the collective, traumatizing, rippling effect of how it feels. Lee wields time in this to devastating effect: stretching it to absorb as many details as possible (the motions of a loved one\'s embrace, the texture of their sweat) before reality eventually constricts it. Soon there won\'t be any to remember, your dreamy relief and longing infected by all your pain and regret. The things you hate are the things you\'ll miss. Bad luck.', '"It all came so close to never happening. This life came so close to never happening."', 'Doyle is without a doubt one of the best dogs in cinema.']

Title: Shin Kamen¬†Rider
Text:
A man forced to bear power and stripped of humanity. A woman skeptical of happiness. Takeshi Hongo, an Augmentation made by SHOCKER, and Ruriko Midorikawa, a rebel of the organization, escape while fighting off assassins. What‚Äôs justice? What‚Äôs evil? Will this violence end? Despite his power, Hongo tries to remain human. Along with freedom, Ruriko has regained a heart. What paths will they¬†choose?
['Hate to say it but the Japanese might get capeshit more than we do. The bad guys being mad scientists that immediately get betrayed by every single one of their creations, all the emotional scenes being centered around going somewhere to talk to your mask, the impractical yet intimidating costumes. These were all capeshit technologies thought to be lost for centuries', 'Seeing this on an IMAX screen opening day in Tokyo inside a theater with a giant Godzilla head on the roof was one of the high points of my life. Anno is a master. On a very short list of my heroes. Didn‚Äôt understand much of it. 10/10. Perfect movie. The way he remixed elements from the original pilot was fascinating. Every time KR punched a bad guy their head popped like a water balloon filled with blood. Pure cinema.\xa0
If someone in America made a superhero movie with the energy of this or SHIN ULTRAMAN it would bring that corpse of a genre back to life.', "This plays like a KAMEN RIDER compilation film, that is somehow, made up of entirely new material. 
It starts at 120MPH (the action scene posted by the studio on Youtube is literally the first few minutes) and proceeds to vacillate between visually imaginative fight scenes and incredibly dense exposition drops - that will leave audiences not familiar with the KAMEN basics hopelessly lost. If you aren't familiar with how a human being turned into KAMEN RIDER, you won't learn it here. 
Writer/Director Hideaki Anno doesn't find a new modern-day angle on the property as he did with SHIN GODZILLA, but instead crafts a breathless approximation of the movie an 8-year-old fantasizes about after someone described the plot of KAMEN RIDER‚Ä¶ 
more"]

To a certain extent, that seems to have been Costa‚Äôs intention, and we her target audience. Title: Dirty¬†Harry
Text:
When a madman dubbed ‚ÄòScorpio‚Äô terrorizes San Francisco, hard-nosed cop, Harry Callahan ‚Äì famous for his take-no-prisoners approach to law enforcement ‚Äì is tasked with hunting down the¬†psychopath.
['I don‚Äôt care if this movie is problematic because what‚Äôs more important is that it‚Äôs awesome', "100
One of those iconic, controversial works of art where its reputation both encapsulates and muddles how it actually functions. This is every bit as grotesque and thrilling as you've heard. Clint Eastwood's Inspector Callahan is hardly as scowling or as animalistic as in the mediocre sequels (
Sudden Impact
 exempted), but it's the grounded, internal approach to his rage that makes him all the more terrifying. His anger hardly bubbles above the surface and yet merely the glimpses are monstrous. 
Dirty Harry
, above all, is a grade-A horror picture in moments, and one of Don Seigel's greatest films. The stillness and pitch-black compositions of San Francisco in the night, and the sunbaked nihilism of the day-to-day cop routine, both give‚Ä¶ 
more", '"The city of San Francisco does not pay criminals...we pay a police department."

Title: The Company of¬†Strangers
Text:
A busload of women become stranded in an isolated part of the Canadian countryside. As they await rescue, they reflect on their lives through a mostly ad-libbed¬†script.
['I need not harp on the prevailing depictions of the elderly in modern media. Suffice it to say that this film defies them with every fiber of its celluloid being. Eight beautiful and charming and most importantly very real women (one of whom is younger) find themselves stranded, and while the narrative considers their age and mortality, it also celebrates their lives--not merely their pasts and the wisdom born of experience you might find in most narratives on the elderly, but also their presents. They talk about love not just in an emotional sense, but a physical sense. They talk about how things used to be and how things are. They talk about what they love to do 
now

Title: Norma¬†Rae
Text:
Norma Rae is a southern textile worker employed in a factory with intolerable working conditions. This concern about the situation gives her the gumption to be the key associate to a visiting labor union organizer. Together, they undertake the difficult, and possibly dangerous, struggle to unionize her¬†factory.
["Needs a sequel where we see how Reaganomics deunionized Norma's plant.", '‚ÄúNorma Rae‚Äù is a film to be gifted from mothers to daughters. From fathers to sons. From sisters to brothers, and from all working people of the world amongst each other.\xa0
Martin Ritt, who evoked the toxicity of nihilistic egotism in the likes of ‚ÄúHud‚Äù and ‚ÄúHombre,‚Äù turns here to the spiritual and communal boon born of passion and revolution.\xa0
Sally Field, fresh off her ACAB turn in ‚ÄúSmokey and the Bandit,‚Äù here plays a version of real life labor organizer Crystal Lee Sutton, a factory worker who successfully led the unionization of a North Carolina textile mill.\xa0
The role won Field an Oscar; a choice that feels all but essential to this day. The actress is every misperception about‚Ä¶

Title: Air Force¬†One
Text:
When Russian neo-nationalists hijack Air Force One, the world‚Äôs most secure and extraordinary aircraft, the President is faced with a nearly impossible decision to give in to terrorist demands or sacrifice not only the country‚Äôs dignity, but the lives of his wife and¬†daughter.
['How often do you think Obama turns to someone on Air Force One and says "Get off my plane!" like Harrison Ford? Six, seven times a day?', "It's hard to overstate just how exciting and also how terrifically absurd this is; a total parody of itself. You can cringe a bit at the endless lives expended to support a dubious foreign policy decision (though it's presented as a human rights one, ok, fine) and by extension the legacy of this politician, but whatever who cares get off my plane, this is one of the great exactly-what-it-says-on-the-box movies.", 'The single most neoconservative movie of the nineties. Renders the vision and philosophy of what would become the George W Bush administration in brilliant Wolfgang Peterson/Michael Balhaus style. Here we have the president commit to using American military power to confront any evil state or group in the world at any time for any reason and shortly thereafter actually becomes John McClane when "neo-communist" terrorists take his plane and family hostage. It goes without saying that President Marshall, by selfishly choosing at every turn to be a hero and remain in a hostage situation to "save his family", by not getting in the escape pod, and routinely placing his own life in the hands of terrorists, greatly harms the United‚Ä¶ \nmore']

["If I ever thought of a title and premise as good as Shanghai Noon I would retire right there (after I sold it for like $100 million) because there's no topping that", 'If I had a dollar for every movie that had one character eavesdrop on another to hear them talking bad about them out of context, causing a rift between them that resolves in a crucial third act moment, then I‚Äôd have enough money to make one of these fun but forgettable action comedies.', 'We deserve the ‚ÄúBrokeback Mountain‚Äù treatment for these two characters.']

Title: Star Trek IV: The Voyage¬†Home
Text:
When a huge alien probe enters the galaxy and begins to vaporize Earth‚Äôs oceans, Kirk and his crew must travel back in time in order to bring back whales and save the¬†planet.
['89/100
Beginning with "save the world" importance and ending with life-affirming joy, 
Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
 is a film which shreds its urgency as it goes along, supplanting stakes for a sweet dose of environmentalism and shaggy comedy. Our characters are already so iconic in their traits that creating a humble hangout film feels like a natural progression in the Star Trek series. The heroes are obviously involved in the imminent threat, but the audience is carried away by slack scenarios and sublime mini narratives; slices of comedy which could only be achieved by a molecular understanding of these personalities. The hilarious chemistry is built around this team, their pasts, and the iconic energy their adventures hold, and even when the tone couldn't be breezier, it feels authentic. You'd have to be a double dumbass not to enjoy this.', "Insane that this works. On paper it's a mess. A bunch of visibly aging people from the future travel back in time to save two whales and the whole thing has a lightly comedic fish-out-of-water tone. What if this was the first Star Trek anything? I'll tell you what if: it would work. I know because this is the first Star Trek thing I saw as a kid. That's not totally true. I saw Worf at Paramount King's Dominion when I was, like, three. There's a picture out there somewhere of some actor holding me while I scream bloody murder because I didn't know who Worf was and that he was no threat to me as long as I didn't‚Ä¶ 
more", 'can you imagine a fourth entry in a lucrative franchise taking a hard swerve into comedy like this these days? although it's certainly choppy since it's still got a goofy, expository and "relevant" sci-fi adventure to deal with, you put a few beers in me and i'll start arguing for it as a Hawksian hangout movie born inadvertently out of nostalgic familiarity and outright fan service.']

Title: Any Given¬†Sunday
Text:
A star quarterback gets knocked out of the game and an unknown third stringer is called in to replace him. The unknown gives a stunning performance and forces the aging coach to reevaluate his game plans and life. A new co-owner/president adds to the pressure of winning. The new owner must prove herself in a male dominated¬†world.
['This film is like a 2 and a half hour line of cocaine. Movie magic.', "keeps hammering at the idea that money/corporatization poisoned the purity of the sport, but not even Stone seems to believe that bullshit. his narrative is compromised by the demands of an audience-friendly underdog come-from-behind sports movie. but if you're like me you showed up for his crackpot associative indictment of masculinity, something he directly compares to a competition that's supposedly no longer meaningful. and as for football, Stone prefigures DJANGO UNCHAINED with Jamie Foxx's attacks on the sport as institutionalized, culturally valorized Mandingo fighting. making a satire out of a sprawling subject like this requires a pretty deft touch, one Stone doesn't really possess. thankfully he makes polemics instead.", "If there's one thing you can't accuse this film of, it's lacking in style. 
Indeed, this is one of the most experimental sports films I've ever seen. 
To the full extent of his abilities, Oliver Stone uses every trick in his arsenal. A f renzy camerawork and editing; the use of handheld cameras creates the sense of a documentary and, on more than one occasion, puts the viewer in the thick of the action. This was sometimes quite successful and other times a bit excessive, much like the use of the Kuleshov effect, which involves intercutting sequences from the film with footages that symbolize and/or emphasize a scenario or notion associated with a scene or character. The cinematography is also‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Huesera: The Bone¬†Woman

['Post-punk-partum depression.', 'People are often made to feel like they have to check off boxes in life. Many of us are pressured to go to college, get a good job, buy a house, get married and have kids. Many women and queer folks may want to check off those boxes, but can‚Äôt afford to. Many of us can check off those boxes, but don‚Äôt want to. And younger people not wanting to get married or have kids can feel especially foreign to older generations who can‚Äôt fathom a life without them. As a result, parents pressure their children to follow in their steps, sometimes with dark results. In Michelle Garza Cervera‚Äôs first feature film,

Title: The Last Picture¬†Show
Text:
High school seniors and best friends, Sonny and Duane, live in a dying Texas town. The handsome Duane is dating a local beauty, while Sonny is having an affair with the coach‚Äôs wife. Paper Moon

The
 
Last Picture Show

A feel-bad movie for the ages, shot in shimmering b&w and populated by unlined young faces to make you swoon (plus careworn old faces to make you weep). Sonny's the nominal protagonist but the film bounces around Anarene at will, laying waste to any romanticized notion of small-town America...and yet it doesn't feel cynical, only brutally honest. Ellen Burstyn sets the tone as Jacy's mother, dispensing advice so hard-won and practical that it can only be ignored; Ben Johnson serves as nostalgic counterpoint, in the movie's only nod to outright sentiment. Bogdanovich, meanwhile, demonstrates a mastery of old-school composition‚Äîboots jutting from an open car window at foreground left as figures approach from background right‚Äîthat seems to have been lost‚Ä¶

["Honestly a virtually perfect albeit very Westernized recreation of a 
Heisei
-era Godzilla 
kaiju

If only they'd stop staging the monster fights at night in CGI dust clouds.", "It's like AVENGERS: INFINITY WAR, with Vera Farmiga as Thanos and the monsters as her Infinity Stones.", "12
The classic example of a creative team pulling the worst from its predecessor and failing to develop on its potential. Gareth Edwards' 
Godzilla
, as an origin for the new 'zilla incarnation and a study of humanity's insignificance amongst ancient beings, was a miraculous success even if it chose to portray the titular creature as a vehicle of Spielbergian suspense. The constant cutaways were playful and frustrating, lending the climax an extended fanboy payoff that worked for some and didn't for others. Fair enough. Enter 
Godzilla: King of the Monsters
, directed by modern cult horror auteur Michael Dougherty, which offers neither satisfying humor or credible scale for a giant monster mash, all while being stuffed with a truly terrible human-storyline,‚Ä¶

Title: Violent¬†Cop
Text:
A detective breaks all rules of ethical conduct while investigating a colleague‚Äôs involvement in drug pushing and Yakuza¬†activities.
["Mostly just Takeshi Kitano walking around to cool music and slapping people. By which I mean, it's pretty great.
Triple feature this with 
Infernal Affairs
 and Abel Ferrara's 
Bad Lieutenant
.", "quite an experience to see an action movie made up of muted colors, long still shots, a slow-motion fight sequence, a car chase set to quiet music, cops who don't carry guns, violence with an emotional impact, an antihero who you're supposed to like but not idolize - what if dirty harry couldn't hide behind a gun, and death actually meant something, and lashing out at a chaotic world as a coping mechanism was a sad and ugly thing, and the cycle never ended", 'The destructive and sadistic impulses that we try to mask with offices and badges captured in this roaming, strangely tranquil style because when you walk by something everyday you become accustomed to it. Most of this movie is just Kitano patiently walking around these beautifully composed frames of the city (sometimes humorously, sometimes sadly) like a Lee Marvin or Clint Eastwood before they are bluntly disrupted by these sudden awkward and idiosyncratic explosions of violence and their ugly aftermath. "Being a policeman is a sacred job. take pride in your work." What a debut.
Full discussion on ep 200 of my podcast SLEAZOIDS
.']

Title: Cha Cha Real¬†Smooth
Text:
Fresh out of college and stuck at his New Jersey home without a clear path forward, 22-year-old Andrew begins working as a party starter for bar/bat mitzvahs‚Äîwhere he strikes up a unique friendship with a young mom and her teenage¬†daughter.
['Cooper Raiff has this rare quality when it comes to making movies about young people figuring themselves out in that he‚Äôs so thoughtful and generous about other people across all periods of life. Coming-of-agers (at any age) are so often selfish to the point of excruciating obsession but Cooper looks out for little brothers and old friends and party guests and new loves and his mum, oh how he loves his mum. He‚Äôs a party starter! A people pleaser! An impossibly kind and big-hearted filmmaker and human who listens to others and tells them exactly how he feels (how dare he!) while also stubbornly continuing to make movies like this, so sincere, so unprovocative, when everybody else rolls their eyes and tells you it‚Äôs all too much. Maybe it is, but sometimes I think that‚Äôs vital. I loved it!', 'This movie feels like a warm hug and a gut punch all at once', 'renate reinsve: the worst person in the world\ncooper raiff: the nicest person in the world']

Text:

more", '"Eh, it's fine. It doesn't matter."

Alice Howland, happily married with three grown children, is a renowned linguistics professor who starts to forget words. When she receives a devastating diagnosis, Alice and her family find their bonds¬†tested.
['Julianne Moore is probably the most beautiful person who has ever lived on this earth.', '‚ÄúOn bad days, I feel like I can‚Äôt find myself. I‚Äôve always been so defined by my intellect, my language, my articulation, and now sometimes, I can see the words hanging in front of me and I can‚Äôt reach them and I don‚Äôt know who I am and I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm going to lose next.‚Äù\nmaybe the worst possible movie for me to watch on a plane as someone with memory issues. alice says something about feeling like her brain is dying in a way that is very reminiscent of things i‚Äôve said to partners many times. sobbed a lot', '+1 to the list of films that I will never watch again...\nEdit: I found this to be an incredibly difficult experience. It\'s probably the most realistic look at Alzheimer\'s that I\'ve ever seen, being so grounded in reality and incorporating contemporary themes such as the growing influence of technology on the world of health and medicine. As someone who had to stand by and watch and his grandmother deteriorate from Alzheimer\'s, I found this film emotionally stirring and relatable. And though I\'m a big fan of Amour - it\'s almost certainly an even stronger piece of cinema than Still Alice - I think that this is a more, as I put it previously, "realistic" look at the disease. A very frightening film, and one that I will most likely never re-visit.']

Title: The¬†Call
Text:
Jordan Turner is an experienced 911 operator but when she makes an error in judgment and a call ends badly, Jordan is rattled and unsure if she can continue. But when teenager Casey Welson is abducted in the back of a man‚Äôs car and calls 911, Jordan is the one called upon to use all of her experience, insights and quick thinking to help Casey escape, and not just to save her, but to make sure the man is brought to¬†justice.
['girl: *gets kidnapped*
halle berry in this movie: omg we have the same zodiac sign', "Third act syndrome. It's a bitch.
Third act syndrome is something that mostly occurs in high concept thrillers or horror films. It's that act where both screenwriter and director have to wrap things up, come to a conclusion and convincingly make it to the finish line. And for some reason or the other they often make all the wrong choices, making the main characters do absurd things and completely negating what they were going for in the first two acts.
In The Call, the main person to blame is Richard D'Ovidio, the screenwriter. He actually manages to craft an interesting and gripping opening with an original premise. I had high hopes I was going to be in for a great‚Ä¶ 
more", 'IM SORRY SO YOUR HUSBAND HAS A SHRINE OF HIS DEAD SISTER AND YOU DONT THINK THERES SOMETHING WRONG THERE?? ALSO WHO TOOK THE PICTURE OF HIM AND HIS SISTER KISSING??']

Title: Bad¬†Timing

['It‚Äôs a miracle that Art Garfunkel‚Äôs performance in Bad Timing didn‚Äôt immediately and forever extinguish all sexual desire on earth. 
a few more hundred words on the subject for the AV Club next week.', 'A film for anyone who‚Äôs ever wondered what Art Garfunkel‚Äôs balls look like.', "When she's seen in flashback she's always smoking, drinking or naked. In contrast when he's seen in the present he's always smoking, drinking or naked. A couple doing the right things around the right people at the wrong times, leading a lifestyle so fitted for a relationship with the other that neither even considers that their habits are mutually exclusive and not shared activities. Roeg studies action and reaction by displacing his characters from a comfortable location, in 
Don't Look Now

Bad Timing

Don't Look Now

Bad Timing

Title: This Must Be the¬†Place
Text:
A bored, retired rock star sets out to find his father‚Äôs tormentor, an ex-Nazi war criminal who is a refugee in the¬†U.S.
['sean penn is the goth rocker i never wanted to see and i fucking want to die', 'Me? Watching this for the 5 minutes of David Byrne? More likely than you think!!', '‚ÄúThis Must Be the Place‚Äù is a delicately intimate, if defiantly odd, midlife crisis road trip movie.\xa0
That is, until‚Ä¶ the Nazis shows up.\xa0
Nazis, as ‚ÄúPlace‚Äù inadvertently proves‚Ä¶ do not belong in a tender story about the self-discovery of an ageing emo rocker.\xa0
And yet, they are - indeed - present, to vast detrimental effect, in Paolo Sorrentino‚Äôs first English language film. To be fair, Nazis ruin everything. Including, what is almost a good movie by a great director.\xa0
‚ÄúPlace,‚Äù written by Sorrentino for Penn after being approached by the actor at the Cannes showing of ‚ÄúIl Divo,‚Äù begins as a moody character piece about a faded musician. Unable to connect with his family, he remains as much in‚Ä¶

Title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and¬†Evil
Text:
A visiting city reporter‚Äôs assignment suddenly revolves around the murder trial of a local millionaire, whom he¬†befriends.
['the lady chablis MVP', "Based on non-fiction work of John Berendt, Clint Eastwood's Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil is a strange but fascinating southern gothic part courtroom drama. Eastwood's direction is very laidback and far more concerned with mood and colourful characters than actual plotting or murder. The milieu/atmosphere and eccentricities of the city are the best part of the film. John Cosack is good, Lady Chablis gives a scene stealing performance and Kevin Spacey is just playing himself.", "Based on a true crime story! What makes this film intriguing has nothing to do with the murder, it has everything to do with its colorful characters! And I kid you not these characters exist in real life!
The lovely, flamboyant trans woman Lady Chablis whom just happens to play herself in the film!
Luther Driggers the man whom walked around with flies buzzing all around him (They were attached to him via string)! Oh yeah he also carries a vial full of poison just like he does in the film!
Minerva the local voodoo high priestess!
Mr. Glover the man walking a dead dog named Patrick!
I'm a sucker for strong character driven plots and this film is bursting at the seams with quirky, eccentric characters that don't just add flavor to the story.. they are the story!"]

Title: Rumble in the¬†Bronx
Text:
Keong comes from Hong Kong to visit New York for his uncle‚Äôs wedding. His uncle runs a market in the Bronx and Keong offers to help out while Uncle is on his honeymoon. During his stay in the Bronx, Keong befriends a neighbor kid and beats up some neighborhood thugs who cause problems at the market. One of those petty thugs in the local gang stumbles into a criminal situation way over his¬†head.
["Jackie Chan throws a baby and commandeers a hovercraft.
That's all you need to know.", "I really enjoy the blooper reels at the end of Jackie Chan's movies that show him wrecking his body while trying to perform incredibly dangerous stunts. It's funny! and works as a guilt trip so that if you didn't like the movie you feel bad for not enjoying something that someone risked their life for", '"Love your tits, Roxanne!" - graffiti on a wall
This was a major movie for me: the first Jackie Chan feature I saw (while working box office at Atlanta's United Artist Midtown 8, it was the first in a wave of domestically dubbed and re-scored Chan imports in the late 90s). That moment when Chan first unleashes on the wooden dummy, showing his speed and finesse was revelatory. 
This is a real Superman movie. Chan arrives from another place, endowed with superhuman abilities he attempts to keep secret from others, and he goes around doing good deeds and protecting the weak and innocent, only using his powers defensively. It's also a real comic-booky movie, with cartoonish gangs and villains that‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Mulan
Text:

Title: Hannah Gadsby:¬†Nanette
Text:
The Australian comedian Hannah Gadsby is taking an anti-comedy stance in her newest¬†special.
['tore apart and reinvented the art of stand-up comedy in 60 minutes? maybe so', "A powerful special that approaches jokes on a meta level for a greater purpose, before tearing it all down to embrace the most important and necessary parts of any comedy special‚Äì vulnerability in storytelling.
This is a special about tension, and about not letting you feel the release of a punchline, so you can come just a little bit closer to knowing how people like Hannah live. And it really is only a 
little bit
 closer. Because some of us will never truly know it firsthand. But for 60 minutes, Hannah makes damn sure that you're gonna sit with the feelings she's had to live with her entire life.", "Hannah Gadsby has sold out theatres with 
Nanette
.
The first time I saw her perform this show, I was front row at a trial run held before she took the show on tour. It was very small, very intimate. 
She talks about jokes on a basic level: 1) build up the tension 2) diffuse it with a punchline. She talks a lot about tension and you feel it because it's true. She talks about how she feels about men, not hating them but fearing them, and again you feel it because it is true. Just like that, the tension sits with you and you're craving for a punchline.
You don't get one because this isn't a comedy show on a‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Clearcut
Text:
A white lawyer finds his values shaken when he is paired with an angry Indigenous activist who insists on kidnapping the head of a logging company to teach him the price of his¬†destruction.
["This is listed as a horror film, and I can see why, but I genuinely think it's better posited as a supernatural-revenge flick. The villains (the exploitative white attorney and the logging mill owner) get off lightly, but the violence done to them is well deserved. It's perhaps disturbing to witness, but the film makes the point - and makes it well - that what these two men are experiencing is mild compared to what native people and the environment have experienced at the hands of them and people like them. While it verbally refers to white people, the two who experience the revenge are explicitly exploitative and violent, a parasitic lawyer and a petty capitalist. It doesn't outright state a class conscious view, but it lets it play out. That makes it extremely satisfying, even if the ending isn't a clearcut (sorry) victory for the native community - but as Wilf says, it's a long war.", 'strange, creepy, and beautiful movie that seems to oddly villainize the oppressed character, until it\'s about exposing whose side white liberals are really on deep down in their instincts, even though it\'s directed by a white man it\'s remarkable how brutally it makes the viewer interrogate themselves, a fake out journey where you\'re practically forced to think the word "savage" and then reckon with what kind of person that makes you', '‚ÄúWho do you feel sorry for? Us or yourself?‚Äù\nMan this is straight up one of the angriest movies I‚Äôve seen in some time. Contains a moment where a man, more or less representing an entire people‚Äôs frustration, points a rich racist capitalist towards the beautiful American wilderness he plans to destroy and asks him ‚Äúdo you see?‚Äù His bewildered response is, ‚Äúno.‚Äù Greene gives the performance of a lifetime.']

Title: Opening¬†Night
Text:
Actress Myrtle Gordon is a functioning alcoholic who is a few days from the opening night of her latest play, concerning a woman distraught about aging. One night a car kills one of Myrtle‚Äôs fans who is chasing her limousine in an attempt to get the star‚Äôs attention. Myrtle internalizes the accident and goes on a spiritual quest, but fails to finds the answers she is after. As opening night inches closer and closer, fragile Myrtle must find a way to make the show go¬†on. √ó
['cassavetes said after you watch gena rowlands have a mental breakdown for two hours you can have a three second peter falk cameo, as a treat', "the hybridization of written word and improvisation evokes the truest emotions. it's the antithesis of an algorithm. yes, you can predict that myrtle will drink a lot and freak out, but it's impossible to know what she'll say, how she'll behave. she's alienating and selfish and frustrating, and best of all, she's 
real.
 an empathetic, not sympathetic, portrait of an aging woman rebelling against the two roles actresses are allowed to play: sexy or matronly. it's a false dichotomy, and myrtle/gena rowlands is living proof. 
people often ask me which cassavetes movie to start with, and i think this one is easily his most accessible, thematic, and compelling. nothing makes me feel like that scene where john and gena are‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Birdman
 found dead in a ditch.']

Title: Death¬†Proof

Title: Them!
Text:
As a result of nuclear testing, gigantic, ferocious mutant ants appear in the American desert southwest, and a father-daughter team of entomologists join forces with the state police officer who first discovers their existence, an FBI agent and, eventually, the US Army to eradicate the menace, before it spreads across the continent ‚Äî and the¬†world.
['Who would\'ve thought a film about gigantic man-eating ants would be so good? Ever since I played the "Fallout 3" quest-line entitled "Those!" I\'ve been meaning to watch this film, and now that I finally have, I can say that I wasn\'t disappointed. The film takes place nine years after the first nuclear tests were conducted in the New Mexico desert. However, lingering radiation has caused the surrounding ants to mutate into nine-foot-tall monsters that go on a catastrophic rampage. It\'s then up to a couple of local police officers and two doctors to locate and fight back against the marauding ants. \n"Them!" is one of the most iconic big bug films ever made. Directed by Gordon Douglas, this film‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'Them‚Äôs some big ants!!', "of course you're a gigantic mutant insect and have pronouns üôÑ"]

Title: Clerks¬†III
Text:
After narrowly surviving a massive heart attack, Randal enlists his old friend Dante to help him make a movie immortalizing their youthful days at the little convenience store that started it¬†all.
['Some notes:
- The emotional high point of this movie for me came in its opening seconds, when Dante (Brian O‚ÄôHalloran) arrives to open the Quick Stop and Randal (Jeff Anderson) strolls out of the neighbouring cannabis store (formerly, of course, a video store). I loved Kevin Smith‚Äôs original 1994 
Clerks
 when I was a teenager and watched it many times. If you show me the guys from that movie looking older, I‚Äôm going to feel a little emotional.
- Kevin Smith‚Äôs early films were dominated by scenes in which actors arranged in simple visual compositions delivered reams of dialogue in long, static takes. In the process, he developed a reputation for being a careless and unimaginative visual stylist. The‚Ä¶ 
more', "Clerks III is not a perfect movie. Some running gags go on for way too long, the filmmaking is not a strong suit and they really make NFT references (ew).
But with that said, this is probably the most I've seen Kevin Smith just put his whole heart into a film. If anything, this film is just Smith fully putting his thesis from Clerks II to full use. It's Smith's love letter to the film and the characters that put him on the map. A showcase of how far Smith has come (for better or worse) and really does not hold back at points with how raw the emotion plays out. Jeff Anderson gets talked about a lot (and he's‚Ä¶ 
more", "We've done it. We've reached the end of the Kevin project and I can't think of a more troubling, confounding possible conclusion than this. One that despite hearing about its premise second-hand was somehow still shocking to actually witness. For those not aware this opens on the wrinkly cast recreating the original 
Clerks
 to My Chemical Romance's 
'The Black Parade'
, before having Randal suffer the same heart attack Kevin Smith actually did in real life and kickstarting the ugliest-looking metafictional mid-life crisis therapy movie ever made and ends with Dante dying from an identical heart attack right before our eyes while literally watching the original two films in some sort of ghostly movie theater afterlife. (Made all the more disturbing‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Shadows
Text:
The relationship between Lelia, a light-skinned black woman, and Tony, a white man is put in jeopardy when Tony meets Lelia‚Äôs darker-skinned jazz singer brother, Hugh, and discovers that her racial heritage is not what he thought it¬†was.
['breaking in my cassavetes boxset with his directorial debut, \nSHADOWS,\n a\xa0probe into the complications of interracial relationships in late 50s new york.\xa0the erratic jazz score is a definite highlight, brilliantly mirroring the improvisational nature of the dialogue ‚Äî makes sense that cassavetes and cast came up with the roots for the film in acting workshops, as some scenes do have the exploratory, push-pull dynamic of a drama school exercise. yeah, it‚Äôs a bit sloppy overall, but when you‚Äôre helping to pioneer the independent film movement, slack can be cut!', 'One thing I love about Shadows is how as a movie about the intersection between performance and expected modes of social interaction, it is all pitched at how comfortable it is inexperienced cast is at its many dramatic scenarios. The post sex scene remains one of the greatest in American movies and the bit Tony Ray comes back to apologize and makes clear he is a good enlightened guy one of the funniest (and a hilarious parody of nice guy twitter six decades before its time).', "Hard to critique something that's had such a heavy influence on some of my favorite films of all time and the film industry in general. First out of the five John Cassavetes films that I'm planning on watching over the course of this month."]

Title: Safety Not¬†Guaranteed
Text:
Three magazine employees head out on an assignment to interview a guy who placed a classified ad seeking a companion for time¬†travel.
["Part of Dastardly Difficult December: film nr.1
Have you ever completely fallen for a film? For no other reason than that it provided you with a perfect bubble of escapism wrapped in a blanket of charm and warmth?
This is what this film is to me and I hadn't expected it at all.
From the opening monologue I feared the worst. A twentysomething girl rattling existentialist quips at double speed while looking bored with life and the universe. I feared the dreaded 'indy quirk' that I just can't stand. And while this film is definitely quirky, it is not what it is about. It's about life, regret, the past, the future, love and, yes, time travel.
In this gem of‚Ä¶ 
more", 'There is a moment in 
Safety Not Guaranteed
 where Aubrey Plaza's quirky character asks Mark Duplass' even quirkier character, "Is that a guitar?" while sitting in front of a campfire after a romantic day of mutual quirkiness. Jaw agape, knowing exactly what was about to happen, I had to pause the movie and consider whether everything up to this point had been trying to make some kind of ironic statement about the romcom genre. Sadly, by the end, I realized it was meant as a genuine moment. 
Safety Not Guaranteed
 deserves the tiniest bit of credit for trying to shoehorn some superficially sci-fi elements into an otherwise mind-numbingly cookie-cutter romcom plot, and there were moments of promise in the subplot‚Ä¶ 
more', 'nooo aubrey plaza dont fall in love with a man wtf']

Title: Family¬†Pack
Text:
When an old card game comes to life, a family jumps back in time to a medieval village where they must unmask werewolves to secure their return¬†home.

Title: Searching for Sugar¬†Man
Text:
Two South Africans set out to discover what happened to their unlikely musical hero, the mysterious 1970s rock ‚Äôn‚Äô roller,¬†Rodriguez.
['Impoverished son of Mexican immigrants living in Michigan wrote some 70s sad boi working class solidarity tunes that helped end South African apartheid? We obviously stan.', '‚ÄúThanks for keeping me alive‚Äù', 'Christopher Nolan once wrote in Inception "It is the simplest version of the idea that sticks." I truly believe that the same thing applies to music as well. A simple soulful song can go a long way in touching a person\'s heart, changing him for good and infusing hope in him that better times would surface. Bob Dylan, Samuel Beam and Bob Marley come to my thought immediately as their songs find that immaculate and almost impossible connection with the artistically intellectual as well as with the common man. It is a bond which is incredibly difficult to achieve and something that only very few have managed to do.\nThis is the incredible true story of a person who played‚Ä¶ \nmore']

The school psychiatrist, Dr. Daniels, becomes aware that Rachel is insane, but Rachel is skilled at her dangerous game of death and identity¬†theft.

It was supposed to be a different project, and it was re-edited...‚Äù\namerican psycho II: mentions patrick bateman 24/7"]

Title: Red¬†Sparrow
Text:
Prima ballerina Dominika Egorova faces a bleak and uncertain future after she suffers an injury that ends her career. She soon turns to Sparrow School, a secret intelligence service that trains exceptional young people to use their minds and bodies as weapons. Dominika emerges as the most dangerous Sparrow after completing the sadistic training process. As she comes to terms with her new abilities, she meets a CIA agent who tries to convince her that he is the only person she can¬†trust. √ó
['cw: rape
One of the first things to happen is an act of intentional violence that destroys her dreams. Not long after, she is raped. Her rescuer (because she almost never operates fully of her own agency, but always propelled by men) saves her after the film has taken the time to linger on this act of despicable violence. Later, another man tries to sexually assault her, and she fights back. Her punishment is that the school she is in tries to force her to be raped in front of her class by the same man. She refuses, but not without opening her legs, not without pretending to allow it. Not without being forced into this circumstance. Not without having‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I was legit shocked at how good RED SPARROW is (where the shit has *this* Francis Lawrence been hiding?) a delectably slow, incredibly violent, and seedy as hell spy movie for the current Cold War. the sexual power dynamics are Verhoeven-esque. audiences are gonna haaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaate it.
in any event, I couldn‚Äôt possibly be more here for the ‚ÄúF- Cinemascore‚Äù portion of Jennifer Lawrence‚Äôs career.', "hey siri show me a straight teenage boy's jerkoff fantasy that's been directed like an over-budget Starz rip-off of The Americans where literally nothing that happens is important but they've made sure you get to see plenty of sideboob while its star is being tortured"]

Title: Bernie
Text:
In small-town Texas, affable and popular mortician Bernie Tiede strikes up a friendship with Marjorie Nugent, a wealthy widow well known for her sour attitude. When she becomes controlling and abusive, Bernie goes to great lengths to remove himself from her¬†grasp.
['LMFAO for some weird reason I always assumed this was that Jack Black and grandma in the bathtub movie Jim\xa0Pam and Andy were watching in that episode of The Office (i now know that was fake)', 'Obsessed with how terrible the poster is', "This was an absolute delight.
Linklater proves once again that he as the uncanny ability to get Jack Black to act. In the hands of another director I'm pretty sure this film would have lacked the lightness of touch, the whimsical observations and the beautifully blurred lines between fiction and fact.
Hidden beneath this darkly comic true story Linklater has found a subtle satirical thread running throughout the way it unfolds. Cast in the shape of a mockumentary, alternating between interviews with townsfolk (both the real people and actors) and scenes in which we get to see how the events around Bernie might have happened, the film says a lot about public perception and the way social structures operate in‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: La¬†luna
Text:
A young boy comes of age in the most peculiar of circumstances. Tonight is the very first time his Papa and Grandpa are taking him to work. In an old wooden boat they row far out to sea, and with no land in sight, they stop and wait. A big surprise awaits the boy as he discovers his family‚Äôs most unusual line of work. Should he follow the example of his Papa, or his Grandpa? Will he be able to find his own way in the midst of their conflicting opinions and timeworn¬†traditions? √ó
['i stopped turning my rubiks cube for a sec and watched intently cause i was scared he was gonna burn his little hands on the stars why am i a self proclaimed mother to all tiny animated characters', 'just stumbled upon this and it‚Äôs literally the perfect thing to watch before bed. so sweet and calming, thank u.', 'yes that‚Äôs me crying at another pixar short and what about it']

Title: Resident Evil:¬†Vendetta
Text:

['that breaking bad joke took 10 years off my life', 'The action in this movie is actually peak', 'This is Resident Evil, the real deal, but it is so Resident Evil that only fans will enjoy it.']

Title: R.M.N.
Text:
A few days before Christmas, having quit his job in Germany, Matthias returns to his Transylvanian village. He wishes to involve himself more in the education of his son, Rudi, left for too long in the care of his mother, Ana, and to rid him of the unresolved fears that have gripped him. He‚Äôs also eager to see his ex-lover Csilla and preoccupied about his old father, Otto. When a few new workers are hired at the small factory that Csilla manages, the peace of the community is disturbed, underlying fears grip the adults, and frustrations, conflicts and passions erupt through the thin sliver of apparent understanding and¬†calm. √ó
['Chekhov‚Äôs gun has seldom fallen into hands as steady and menacing hands as in Cristian Mungiu‚Äôs poorly titled, expertly staged ‚ÄúR.M.N.,‚Äù which finds the elite Romanian auteur extrapolating the personal tensions that gripped his previous work (e.g., ‚ÄúBeyond the Hills‚Äù and the Palme d‚ÄôOr-winning ‚Äú4 Months, 3 Weeks, and 2 Days‚Äù) across an entire Transylvanian village. The result is a socioeconomic crucible that carefully shifts its weight to the same foot that Mungiu always loves to rest on your throat; a slightly over-broad story of timeless xenophobia baked full of local flavor and set right on the cusp of a specific moment in the 21st century.
The film begins far away from the snowy hamlet where most of it takes‚Ä¶ 
more', "another wonderfully tactful panopticon of the (eastern) european society by Mungiu. the ocean of characters, words, sceneries let a topic hard to tackle with the means of cinema get to life, without falling out of subtlety.
parenthetically he creates one of the most horrific male protagonists I've seen in recent years, and has with Judith State and especially Macrina Barladeanu two mesmerising actresses by his side making this baby another sweet entry of the not-so-new-anymore Romanian wave.", 'R.M.N. is Cristian Mungiu‚Äôs patient & disturbing examination of rising tensions & anxieties in a xenophobic Transylvanian village. Bleak cinematography with many unforgettable shots including a 17 minute long unbroken scene at a town hall meeting where the film‚Äôs themes finally crystallize in a simmering combustion of anger, frustration, fear & hatred. It took a bit to get going and I‚Äôm not sure everything coalesces as Mungiu suspects between Matthias‚Äò journey and the journey of the community. Still, it has one of the best third acts of the year with a final shot that knocked me on my ass. Will probably be thinking about this one for quite some time.']

Title: White¬†Heat
Text:
A psychopathic criminal with a mother complex makes a daring break from prison and then leads his old gang in a chemical plant payroll heist. After the heist, events take a crazy¬†turn.
["James Cagney as a crazy gangsta who loves his Ma, tolerates his wife, and lives to rob and kill. Choo choo train. Dangerous thermos. Leap of faith. The way James Cagney holds a pistol. Kinda-hot water. Sexy snoring. The Invisible Man? Accidental discharge. Poco loco. Ma knows best. Whiskey cures everything. The way James Cagney establishes dominance. Doctor Death? The ABC game. Ma drives like Gos in Drive. Undercover Wild Freddie Sykes. Holy Fuck! The Raid 2 copied White Heat. Lip reader. A reindeer? Real motherfuckers don't need vaccination shots. Mirror communication. Close call. Crazy spell. Worst lawyer ever. Terrible news. Jailhouse meltdown. Dr. Lecter's straight jacket. Yucky soup. Escaping like a boss. Old school car phones are the shit.‚Ä¶ 
more", "89/100
Pure pleasure. Cagney's such a force of nature that I'd forgotten how much of the movie is told from the cops' perspective, and how much delectable suspense Walsh and the writers milk from the undercover scenario. Even our current Golden Age Of TV Drama, in which plotting has (thank christ) become respectable again, rarely offers bits as choice as Cagney opening the envelope containing the framed photo of O'Brien's fake wife and putting it out in the cell as a gag, to see what O'Brien does when he notices...
if
 he notices, we suddenly realize, 'cause O'Brien's never seen this woman in his life. There's even a lengthy tutorial on how to use three separate cars to trail somebody without‚Ä¶ 
more", 'There are very few films that are as prudent and as sustainedly controlled in their storytelling as Raoul Walsh‚Äôs 
White Heat
. Starring James Cagney in a powerhouse performance as Arthur "Cody" Jarrett, it delivers a volatile completion to Warner Brother's rotation of gangster movies which started in 1931 with 
Little Caesar
. It abides as possibly the pinnacle performance in Cagney‚Äôs lengthy and diverse career, as well as being the movie that contains the frequently misquoted "Made it, Ma! Top of the world!". It‚Äôs all riveted together beautifully by Walsh's vehement and polished direction and unhesitatingly stands as one of the most pre-eminent of all gangster epics.', 'Amazing
"Made it, Ma! Top of the world!"
Now that's how you end a fucking movie.', 'James Cagney in ‚ÄúWhite Heat‚Äù gives a resoundingly definitive performance as an unhinged, psychopathic criminal. The DNA of Cagney‚Äôs gangster Cody Jarrett is so powerful that it‚Äôs still propagating in great roles of today ‚Äî from Tommy DeVito in ‚ÄúGoodfellas‚Äù to the Joker in ‚ÄúDark Knight.‚Äù\xa0
Director Raul Walsh also deserves near equal kudos for his taught sensibility that essentially allows him to wrap a gangster flic, a heist film, and a prison break movie into a run time under two hours.\xa0
Cagney‚Äôs pure chaos matched against Walsh‚Äôs tight cohesiveness is a mix of fire and powder that explode into one of the most perfect movies ever made.', 'Great Cagney performance in a pretty gripping gangster movie.\xa0
Cagney returns to the gangster performances that he became known for in the 30s, and reunited with Raoul Walsh, who both seem to get each other perfectly. Cagney plays a charismatic gangster, who is electric and evil, and who you find yourself loving throughout despite his actions. The chase scenes in this also hold up.
You sort of wish this film had the freedom from the Hays code it deserves, where it could show a grittier prison and allow for more creative freedom, however given the time it‚Äôs quite intense.', 'pretty wild to discover that the first Michael Mann film came out in 1949, when he was six', '‚ÄúIt ain‚Äôt safe havin‚Äô a crackpot giving orders. About time somebody took over.‚Äù
Noirvember #5
Welcome back to the hellscape, everybody! Democracy is up in flames, so it‚Äôs the perfect time to watch a film about a man-child incapable of rational thought, a tyrant who‚Äôd rather destroy everyone and everything around him than ever back down from total power.
What can we say? asks my mother. In Yiddish: 
Der oylem iz a goylem.
 The mass is an ass.
The people here in New York voted to pass Prop 1 to ensure reproductive rights for women in our state, so, you know, at least that counts for something. Small favors.
Good luck to us all getting through the next four years in one piece, I hope.
‚ÄúMade it, Ma! Top of the world!‚Äù
The Films of Edmond O‚ÄôBrien: Ranked (So Far)', "raoul walsh is a such a genius because he's able to complicate the masculinity of the american gangster without making him into a pathetic caricature -- there's a reason to his madness, we empathize with him while never losing faith in his capacity for violence as a means of expressing that psychopathic turmoil. what separates a film like this from the earlier gangster pictures like 
scarface
 as well as the 'revisionist' ones like 
the godfather
 is that cagney isn't interested in anything but exploring his character to the furthest degree -- this is not a naive film or a decadent film, but a work of navigating external and internal landscapes, where there is a symmetrical relationship of the elements with‚Ä¶ 
more", '"We'd like to do Ma Barker and have the gangster with a mother complex and play it against Freudian implications that she's driving him to do these things, and he's driving himself to self-destruction. Play it like a Greek tragedy." They said, "Fellas ... ?" We said, "Believe us, it will work. And there's only one man who can play this and make the rafters rock."*
One of the keys to virtually every James Cagney performance is the warmth of his characters. Even when we dislike the men he plays, they have a charm and a dynamism to them that is undeniable, and very nearly impossible to resist. As Cody Jarrett in 
White Heat
, though, Cagney does something completely different,‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Compulsive with blowing away expendable men, set off by the most casual of backstabbers, the outlaw Cody Jarrett lets himself be quick to sudden rage. Betrayed by turncoats, betrayed by his two-timing wife, betrayed by the universe in general as brought on in the form of splitting headaches (‚Äú
it‚Äôs like having a red-hot buzzsaw inside my head
‚Äù), Cody‚Äôs only solace is Ma, whom heals with that mothering touch of hers and those devil whispers of barbarous encouragement in his ear. That beats anything his wife can give him, or anything money can supply to him. By the end of this classic unhinged film noir tale, Cody is up above chemical plant tanks lit on fire, and he‚Äôs such a screw-loose‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Just one of the greatest... ever. Amazing how this flick from 1949 has aged so, so, so incredibly well - just like The Treasure of the Sierra Made, released one year prior to White Heat. These just get better every single time you watch them.']

Title: Fantastic¬†Planet
Text:
On the planet Ygam, the Draags, extremely technologically and spiritually advanced blue humanoids, consider the tiny Oms, human beings descendants of Terra‚Äôs inhabitants, as ignorant animals. Those who live in slavery are treated as simple pets and used to entertain Draag children; those who live hidden in the hostile wilderness of the planet are periodically hunted and ruthlessly slaughtered as if they were¬†vermin.

Title: Sex and¬†Luc√≠a
Text:
Various lives converge on an isolated island, all connected by an author whose novel has become inextricably entwined with his own¬†life.

95/100", 'Momentazo el de Lucia llorando pk no le dejan comer paella en el chiringuito pk el m√≠nimo es de dos personas ‚ú®']

Title: Stella¬†Dallas
Text:
After divorcing a society man, a small-town woman tries to build a better life for their¬†daughter.
['Stanwyck is probably the best movie star who ever existed.', "Vidor is one of the most sensitive directors - it's wonderful to see a film which has no specific underlying message or theme, simply about people who are flawed and make mistakes and who often have the best interests of others at heart. And it maybe has the most beautiful parent-child relationship in cinema. There's no point to be made; all that matters are the people. And the ending is a moment of ironic sublimity that would not be out of place in a film by Dreyer.", 'I don‚Äôt think a mother-daughter drama has torn my heart out quite like this']

Title: Paul
Text:
For the past 60 years, a space-traveling smart-ass named Paul has been locked up in a top-secret military base, advising world leaders about his kind. But when he worries he‚Äôs outlived his usefulness and the dissection table is drawing uncomfortably close, Paul escapes on the first RV that passes by his compound in Area 51. Fortunately, it contains the two earthlings who are most likely to rescue and harbor an alien on the¬†run.

Title: Southern¬†Comfort
Text:
A squad of National Guards on an isolated weekend exercise in the Louisiana swamp must fight for their lives when they anger local Cajuns by stealing their canoes. Without live ammunition and in a strange country, their experience begins to mirror the Vietnam¬†experience.
["If I could submit one film segment as the greatest from the 80's, then I would cite the final 15 minutes of Walter Hill's underrated (although that's starting to change) 1981 masterwork. 
Throughout the whole film till that point, we've been blessed with an amazing soundtrack provided by Ry Cooder. But for the home stretch, Hill chose to drop it as the main characters arrive to where the last act will take place. In it's place is the genuine sounds and atmosphere (something the film is steeped in) of the locals gathering for a big ol' Cajun hog roast. The location, use of real locals as extras, and the strains of the resident band playing the dance all add to‚Ä¶ 
more", "73
What's integral about 
Southern Comfort
 is the initial expository scene, where all the soldiers gather together before heading into the Louisiana swamp. We learn that they don't take themselves or the job that seriously, and they care even less about the people who inhabit the forest. Of course, it immediately gets them into deep trouble, but Walter Hill explores how the masculine habits of these men are soon left vulnerable and lost without the structure of their occupation. The final 15 minutes are about as tense as can be.", "The cap of a loose triptych of films about the abasement of American imperial pride in its own backwaters. The first, John Boorman's 
Deliverance
, explicitly emasculated its macho adventurers in a brutal attack on personal and national self-identity. The second, 
First Blood
, found authoritarian confidence so rattled that domestic cops took out their own frustrated sense of control on a rattled, neglected veteran. 
Southern Comfort
 sends a National Guard on maneuvers in the Louisiana bayou where they immediately act like invaders, stealing boats from local Cajuns, then being enraged when those people dare to defend their property. 
Naturally, Vietnam comparisons abound, though Hill was right to dismiss them as he tackles a more deeply rooted issue of military self-perception; his‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: He‚Äôs All¬†That
Text:

"kurosawa and kubrick"

Title: The¬†Sadness
Text:
A young couple is pushed to the limits of sanity as they attempt to be reunited amid the chaos of a pandemic outbreak. The streets erupt into violence and depravity, as those infected are driven to enact the most cruel and ghastly things¬†imaginable.
['I can appreciate making a movie like this where the idea is to be such a viscerally nihilistic reaction to the pandemic and society‚Äôs response to it, but this is worthless edgelord fake-provocative garbage. I‚Äôm down with splatter movies and even sexual provocation intertwined with violence (I love HELLRAISER!) but this is the product of someone just seeing how ‚Äúfucked up‚Äù and ‚Äúdepraved‚Äù they can get with nothing to actually say about any of it. I left the Q&A after the director started talking about how he wasn‚Äôt interested in the politics of the film and was more focused on the ‚Äúfun and the gore‚Äù, a funny thing to say for a movie with so much grotesque sexual violence. Worst I‚Äôve seen at Fantastic Fest.', "Bloody, brutal, tasteless... fucking loved it obviously. THAT's what I call a pandemic film. THAT'S the way you close out a festival. Shades of Cat III gnarliness in all the glorious practical effects, lunatic grins and dismembered body parts. For anyone who thought 
Busan
 was good but too sentimental, this is your jam. First time director Rob Jabbaz, you hit it out the park my man. A proper horror film for proper horror fans.
And that brings FrightFest 2021 to a close. Had a blast! Saw some gems (and lot of shite of course, but that's par for the course), made some new friends (shout out to Eric and Andy!), survived the seventh circle that is Leicester Square and thoroughly enjoyed the first festival experience in the cinema since the world went to hell in a handbasket. Viva FrightFest, viva The Sadness! See you in October.", 'Ruthless, depraved and ultra-violent depiction of a pandemic but still not as scary as people hoarding toilet paper on supermarkets.']

Title: The¬†Misfits
Text:
While filing for a divorce, beautiful ex-stripper Roslyn Taber ends up meeting aging cowboy-turned-gambler Gay Langland and former World War II aviator Guido Racanelli. The two men instantly become infatuated with Roslyn and, on a whim, the three decide to move into Guido‚Äôs half-finished desert home together. When grizzled ex-rodeo rider Perce Howland arrives, the unlikely foursome strike up a business capturing wild¬†horses.
['"I just gotta find another way to be alive."
If there was ever a movie that truly broke my heart, it's this one. These broken characters, these actors who are running on their last breaths... how the line between cinema and reality gets blurrier and blurrier as the camera dances around them, trying to catch the last light of their souls. And how it succeeds because these people so desperately wanted to be seen. This isn't a movie, it's a poem in images, a prophecy and yet a memory. Everything makes sense, everything hurts, and everything shines on. The horses are running wild again, the tears are streaming down my face.', 'This film showed me that men are pigs and Marilyn Monroe is an angel. But we already knew that.', '‚ÄúThe Misfits‚Äù is a film so utterly despondent; it could only have been made by the truly lost at heart.\xa0
John Huston‚Äôs ‚ÄúMisfits‚Äù was long ago eclipsed in artistic merit by its widespread infamy. The final completed film of Marilyn Monroe and Clark Gable; Huston himself was also consistently drunk and/or gambling while on location, and costar Montgomery Clift would suffer an untimely early death within five years of the movie‚Äôs release.\xa0
It‚Äôs hard, then, to view ‚ÄúMisfits‚Äù for its original intent; a Valentine to Monroe from Arthur Miller. It‚Äôs unfortunate, because Miller‚Äôs script is among his best writings, and Monroe gave her greatest acting performance in the film... even while she was in and out of rehab, and her‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Bright¬†Star
Text:
In 1818, high-spirited young Fanny Brawne finds herself increasingly intrigued by the handsome but aloof poet John Keats, who lives next door to her family friends the Dilkes. After reading a book of his poetry, she finds herself even more drawn to the taciturn Keats. ['frail men are absolutely essential to The Female Gaze', 'bitch why didn‚Äôt u make him a coat if ur so good at it', "Who knew a man stroking a woman's hand could be so sexy? I've seen this movie seven or eight times now and it never fails to invade my soul and senses with its beauty and glorious sadness. It's the cinematic equivalent of smelling a lovely perfume, gazing at a field of lilac bushes or tasting a delicious wine...everything about it is full of sensuous texture and utter longing...longing to be touched, longing to be inspired, longing to love and create art. It leaves a mark on every part of your being and, like a person's first love, is incredibly difficult to forget about once it's over. You don't know until the end of the movie how tightly it wound itself around your heart."]

Title: The Legend of¬†Zorro
Text:
Despite trying to keep his swashbuckling to a minimum, a threat to California‚Äôs pending statehood causes the adventure-loving Don Alejandro de la Vega and his wife, Elena, to take¬†action.
["Leave it to Kurtzman and Orci to write a Zorro movie about a conspiracy involving foreign agents, private security, doomsday weapons, secret cabals, a rigged election, and a false-flag bombing. It's nice to see Zeta-Jones get a more active role in the Zorro-ing, but for all that plot this is mostly bereft of incident in favor of endless scenes of, you guessed it, characters explaining the plot to each other. And much more so than the first movie the fights here, shot mostly medium-close, are a bit mechanical and rehearsed and lacking in ferocity, as well as being generally dependent on gags about guys getting hit in the balls. There's also a train setpiece at the end that contains some truly dreadful digital compositing...I miss rear-projection.
More superheroes need to tag their enemies.", "Another universally despised sequel due to minor flaws.\xa0
The Legend Of Zorro
 may not be as smooth as it's predecessor, but this Antonio Banderas and Catherine Zeta-Jones reunion is bombastic when it has to be. First, the splendid child actor who played Joaquin (Elena and Alejandro's son) is adorable. The practical effects looked all too real especially during that painful looking jousting scene while the last arc is an exciting climax from our masked crusader. The set design and costumes felt authentic for its time as well.
Yes there‚Äôs flaws - from the forced humor, sagging opening arc, awkward dialogue and a runtime longer than it should be - but this is minute compared to the entertainment factor 
The Legend Of Zorro
 served.", "It's fine I guess; at least Catherine Zeta-Jones is still hot"]

Title: Exotica
Text:
In the upscale Toronto strip club Exotica, dancer Christina is visited nightly by the obsessive Francis, a depressed tax auditor. Her ex-boyfriend, the club‚Äôs MC, Eric, still jealously pines for her even as he introduces her onstage, but Eric is having his own relationship problems with the club‚Äôs female owner. Thomas, a mysterious pet-shop owner, is about to become unexpectedly involved in their¬†lives.
['100/100
Opens with the view through a one-way mirror, which turns out to reflect the film's very structure. As a young man I was enthralled by the way Egoyan withholds information, encouraging you to make assumptions that turn out to be significantly less twisted than what's actually going on; arguably no other movie has woven so many arresting, initially inexplicable strands into such a richly satisfying narrative tapestry. But that sort of gamesmanship, however brilliant, doesn't explain the full-body chill I still get from the final shot, 18 years and at least five viewings later. "You have to ask yourself: What brought the person to this place?" And while we eventually find out all about Francis, what gives 
Exotica

more', 'somebody on here dinged this as a "tv detective" story instead of i guess pure uncut glorious art-house cinema or whatever but i think the stuff that keeps it from being totally pretentious or oblique is what i love about it. thoughtful, delicate, kinda like a canadian almodovar, with as much to say about the transactional nature of relationships as fassbinder or eyes wide shut but with empathy & curiosity instead of nihilist resignation or camp horror. in a dumber movie bruce greenwood's character would become a bronson type vigilante instead of turning inward - its an emotional terrain i cant remember seeing a movie confront before. i know a couple other egoyans but tell me where to find more stuff like this!!', 'Leonard Cohen-themed strip club.']

Title: LA¬†92
Text:
Twenty-five years after the verdict in the Rodney King trial sparked several days of protests, violence and looting in Los Angeles, LA 92 immerses viewers in that tumultuous period through stunning and rarely seen archival¬†footage.
['85
A vital archival document. No talking heads. All images sourced from news footage and home camcorders. Begins with the Watts protests and continues with Rodney King, but the film is structured as a ceaseless stream of pain and anguish, rage and fury. The filmmakers know that systemic racism, the failure of the justice department, and the brutalization of the Black community by the police state will continue, and it has. We have seen this again and again, and the film asks us to be emotional spectators, to recognize the patterns in coded racist rhetoric by officers, presidents, judges, and government officials, and to observe the minimal changes, the little differences that only further emphasize how hardly anything has changed‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Figured that I wasn't riled up enough after watching Do The Right Thing.
The system is broken and I'm sick and fucking tired of trying to argue with people who look at cases like this and see nothing wrong with how the police handled shit.
People can throw around the "bad apples" narrative all they want, but you do know what they say about bad apples, right?', "When the film opened with the story of the Watts Riots, I was reminded of O.J.: Made in America. I thought the documentary was going to be thorough and cover some of the same subject matter and I thought it would be a little bit repetitive. But, not really.
Even though I was 10 when the L.A. riots happened, I remember watching it in horror on the television. People were looting and there were fires. And we lived about 2 hours away from L.A. So close, yet so far away. But being a child at the time, I didn't really know the full scope of what was going on.
The documentary was informative, but also extremely disturbing that police officers‚Ä¶ 
more"]

I was aware of some of his US titles because when I was renting props for Tangerine, I came across a small business located in Thai Town, Los Angeles called Cop Prop Shop. (They have a website) I walk in to the office and there are mini posters of Amir's films all over. I recognized the Hollywood Cop poster and asked what the deal was. They happened to be good friends and provided the guns, etc for Amir's films. I looked in to Shervan's filmography and found that his last film, Samurai Cop, was already gaining infamy. 
I just‚Ä¶ 
more", '"There's only one thing in this world I want. I want you to find that motherfuckin' Japanese gangster. I want you to kill him, and I want you to kill every one of his men. I want you to burn his house into a bloodbath. Don't leave anybody alive! And when they're all dead you come back to me, and all three of us'll turn our badges in, say goodbye to it. We'll be off this police force for good." -- actual dialogue', '"Why'd you go under?"
"'Cause I'm an undercover cop!"
There's no way of talking about a movie like this without discussing the nature of rating movies. I've seen 
The Room
 and 
Troll 2
 and countless features from The Asylum, and 
Samurai Cop
 is without contest the most poorly made film I've ever seen. To rate it accurately in terms of quality, my system has to be stretched to new levels to accommodate the incredible extent of its failure. It stands alone at its own individual level of ineptitude. But for me, putting it at the ¬Ω star it deserves and calling it a day ignores the potential entertainment value of such a unique catastrophe.

Title: Hellboy II: The Golden¬†Army
Text:
Hellboy, his pyrokinetic girlfriend, Liz, and aquatic empath, Abe Sapien, face their biggest battle when an underworld elven prince plans to reclaim Earth for his magical kindred. ['Now 
this
 is more like it.
The Golden Army
 improves on the first 
Hellboy
 in basically every way. The boring characters from the first movie have all been jettisoned (they even joke about the fact that Hellboy got the milquetoast perspective character transferred to Antarctica) and the villains are vastly more interesting this time around. (Also, given that their main motivation is ‚ÄúHumanity sucks,‚Äù they‚Äôre basically the tragic heroes.) The effects are sharper, the creature design is way more del Toro-ish, and all of the characters have higher stakes. (Even quirky fish dude Abe Sapien gets an arc! 
And
