I‚Äôm not sure why this franchise is quite so fixated on bad guys who love to do excessively flippy shit with pointy weapons, but other than that I have zero complaints ‚Äî\xa0except that del Toro never got to make his third 
Hellboy
.', 'this movie is singlehandedly responsible for my instant-cry reaction to ‚Äúcan‚Äôt smile without you‚Äù', 'they just don‚Äôt do creature design like this anymore!!!!!! gdt‚Äôs mind truly is the most wonderful place']

Title: King Arthur: Legend of the¬†Sword
Text:
When the child Arthur‚Äôs father is murdered, Vortigern, Arthur‚Äôs uncle, seizes the crown. Robbed of his birthright and with no idea who he truly is, Arthur comes up the hard way in the back alleys of the city. But once he pulls the sword Excalibur from the stone, his life is turned upside down and he is forced to acknowledge his true legacy‚Ä¶ whether he likes it or¬†not.
['i read a negative review of this that described it as "a movie for people who love charlie hunnam and leather pants" and i was like woah buddy quit pitching you've already made the sale', "I will never understand the mentality of modern filmgoers. They'll say they want something original and different, but when an original and different film comes out, they'll complain that it is weird, silly, and bonkers, even though the sequel or remake they just watched has the same elements and the love the living crap out of it (like Guardians 2, for instance). 
That's why I'm bummed that films like King Arthur: Legend of the Sword flopped, because in my eyes, it's a visually creative, utterly bonkers, stylishly filmed fantasy film that I hope becomes a cult classic at least. 
Directed by Guy Ritchie (a director I'm mixed towards because of how up-and-down the two Sherlock Holmes films were), King Arthur‚Ä¶ 
more", "Terrible but also Guy Ritchie's GODS OF EGYPT."]

Title: Johanne¬†Sacreblu
Text:
Mexico‚Äôs response to the French film Emilia P√©rez. The real life of French people in a musical made by people in Mexico. It tells the epic tale of baguettes, croissants, stinky cheese, and the difficulties of not taking daily¬†showers.
["Didn't understand a word of this but hell yea brother Emilia Perez found dead in a ditch", 'Johanne Sacrebleu es una pel√≠cula que brilla con su originalidad y estilo, transportando a la audiencia a un universo donde el misterio, la comedia y el drama se entrelazan de manera magistral. Dirigida por camila aurora, esta obra cinematogr√°fica nos presenta a Johanne, una protagonista enigm√°tica cuyo nombre no solo es inolvidable, sino que encapsula perfectamente su personalidad vibrante y compleja.
La trama sigue a Johanne en un viaje cargado de aventuras inesperadas, di√°logos inteligentes y situaciones que oscilan entre lo hilarante y lo profundamente emocional. Su mundo est√° lleno de personajes exc√©ntricos, cada uno con un prop√≥sito en la narrativa que a√±ade capas a la historia.
Visualmente, la pel√≠cula es un deleite: colores vibrantes, escenarios que evocan un aire‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Hasta me duele la pinche crepa nada m√°s de acordarme de t√≠. 
Francia le debe m√°s al mundo que el mundo a Francia. Esta va dedicada para Ignacio Zaragoza.', 'Como franc√©s, me siento profundamente ofendido por esta pel√≠cula. Cuando a la directora se le pregunt√≥ qu√© tanto tuvo que investigar sobre Francia para hacer esta pel√≠cula, dijo: ‚ÄúNada, lo que ten√≠a que saber ya lo sab√≠a‚Ä¶ Todo el mundo sabe que en Francia comen baguettes y croissants, y discriminan minor√≠as como deporte‚Äù. La actriz que interpreta a Johanne ha estado bloqueando y silenciando a todos los franceses que expresan su desagrado con la pel√≠cula en X, incluso lleg√≥ a llamarlos ‚Äúgatos‚Äù por atreverse a mencionar los puntos negativos que tiene el filme, adem√°s de haber dicho otra clase de comentarios denigrantes y xenof√≥bicos en contra de los franceses.
Francia es un pa√≠s que le ha dado tantas cosas al‚Ä¶ 
more', 'ES CINE. Yo fui el Hombre Basura (de cuerpo, no de canto) , aka Jacques Audiard. √âl est√° triste porque es una basura francesa cualquiera, no puede hacer una buena pel√≠cula. Est√° cubierto de basura y ratas t√≠picas de Francia, tambi√©n rodeado por la propaganda de buenos musicales y pel√≠culas francesas, pues √©l no puede crear nada similar para su naci√≥n y prefiere tomar historias de otros pa√≠ses sin importarle hacer apropiaci√≥n cultural.', 'La mejor pel√≠cula inspirada en Francia merece 13 nominaciones al Oscar... ¬°y deber√≠a llevarse todos los premios! Es una obra maestra que supera todas las expectativas, con una direcci√≥n magistral, actuaciones impresionantes y una cinematograf√≠a que te deja sin aliento. Definitivamente, es cine. üö¨', 'excelente retrato de los problemas de la sociedad francesa, como mexicana creo que es importante concientizar a la gente acerca de Francia, su gente y sus olores', '"Bienvenidos a la Francia" alone is a better song than any of the ones from Emilia P√©rez', 'Mucho mejor que emilia perez, viva Latinoamerica fuck Francia', 'Cuaso ü•ê', 'Como alguien que no se ha ba√±ado en 5 d√≠as y ha comido crepas, me parece una representaci√≥n digna de Francia que habla de problemas universales tan importantes. No necesito ir a Francia porque todo lo que debo saber ya lo tiene esta pel√≠cula üëèüèºüëèüèº', 'Cito a Jaques Audiard, pero voy a aplicar sus dichos a su idioma:
El franc√©s es un lenguaje de pa√≠ses soberbios, de pa√≠ses clasistas, de apropiadores culturales y de colonizadores üíã']

Title: Mortal¬†Engines
Text:
Many thousands of years in the future, Earth‚Äôs cities roam the globe on huge wheels, devouring each other in a struggle for ever diminishing resources. On one of these massive traction cities, the old London, Tom Natsworthy has an unexpected encounter with a mysterious young woman from the wastelands who will change the course of his life¬†forever.
["No one's gonna believe me but there were actual fucken Minions in this movie", "I'm into traction cities now", '‚ÄúMortal Engines‚Äù might not be a particularly good movie, but it‚Äôs a BIG one, and sometimes that can be even more important. Adapted (on steroids) from Philip Reeves‚Äô neo-Victorian steampunk fantasy of the same name, this $100 million holiday-season event starts off like a supersized remake of ‚ÄúFury Road,‚Äù as two mobile cities shoot massive harpoons at each other in a death race through the post-apocalyptic wastelands of Europe as Junkie XL‚Äôs bombastic score yowls in the background. Yes, mobile cities. One of them is London, and the other is a quaint mining colony that doesn‚Äôt have a name worth remembering; they travel on giant turrets, stretch a mile into the sky, and mulch each other for fuel.\nThis ‚Äî‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Purl
Text:
Purl, an earnest ball of yarn, gets a job at a fast-paced, male-centered startup company. Things start to unravel as Purl tries to fit in with this tight-knit group, but she must ask herself how far is she willing to go to get the acceptance she yearns for and if, in the end, it is worth¬†it.
['It oversimplifies the subject matter to the point where it doesn't say anything of substance. In the end, the solution it offers for balls of yarn (women) to be respected and included at work is just for them to "stick up for each other". The men are never actually challenged to take part in the change, and that's a problem.
This is particularly bad after 
the essay from last year
 that detailed the sexist workplace culture at Pixar‚Ä¶ if releasing this short was meant as some measure of damage control, they need to do way better.', 'purl you‚Äôre doing amazing sweetie!!!!!', 'we get it, women are unfunny and soft and men are aggressive and misogynistic :/']

Title: Operation¬†Avalanche
Text:
In 1967, four undercover CIA agents were sent to NASA posing as a documentary film crew. What they discovered led to one of the biggest conspiracies in American¬†history.
['There‚Äôs a scene in a car in here that is AS GOOD as THAT car scene in Children of Men. Like it‚Äôs a scene that‚Äôs waaay better than it has to be. But it‚Äôs so good. Great movie??', '72
First clever, then uproarious, and then, without a designated shift or tonal development, terrifying. Pushes its farce and satirical elements past the far side of the moon and into the great beyond, one of paranoia and mistrust. Also has an incredible car chase? Truly an original.', "1. i have a gross crush on matt johnson and i don't like it also owen looks like idubbbz in this movie
2. imagine making two movies so close in quality and both being so fantastic in such a short period of time matt johnson is a god

Title: Apur¬†Sansar
Text:
Apu, now a jobless ex-student dreaming vaguely of a future as a writer, is invited to join an old college friend on a trip up-country to a village¬†wedding.
['A stunning end to a beautiful trilogy about the human condition. We should all watch more foreign-language films!', 'I haven‚Äôt written a line since we were married.
Is that my fault?
It‚Äôs to your credit. You know how much my novel means to me. You mean much more.
The only thing more capable at building up, shifting and breaking down our dreams than love is the loss of it.', "If there's one word that would best describe Satyajit Ray's Apu Trilogy that would have to be universality. Which is all the more impressive when considering that the movies are so deeply rooted in Indian (and Bengali) culture and traditions. Everyone can identify with the characters in the movies, with the decisions they make, with the difficult moments they go through, with the emotions they feel, as they capture the human nature in a genuine and primal form. A true master when it comes to exploring the human condition, Satyajit Ray creates moments that feel very natural but moments that have layers upon layers of subtly different nuances. It doesn't matter if a scene shows a mundane activity or if‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Nimic
Text:
A professional cellist has an encounter with a stranger on the subway which has unexpected and far-reaching ramifications on his¬†life.
["that's what you get for trying to speak to someone on public transport", 'i bumped into yorgos lanthimos after uncut gems at london film festival and i wish i saw this sooner so i could have asked him, personally, what the fuck is wrong with you', 'Watching Lanthimos\' films feels like waking up in the middle of the night and there\'s this guy standing in front of your bed, telling you about his latest nightmare, and you\'re like "you seem to have issues and also what are you doing in my house."\nLocarno Film Festival']

Title: I‚Äôm Still¬†Here
Text:
A woman married to a former politician during the 1971 military dictatorship in Brazil is forced to reinvent herself and chart a new course for her family after a violent and arbitrary¬†act.
['de todas as dores que existem, penso que a do n√£o saber √© a pior. n√£o saber se vai voltar, n√£o saber pra onde foi, n√£o saber o que aconteceu e, por fim, n√£o saber que aquela seria a √∫ltima vez que o veriam. que ang√∫stia, que tristeza, que injusti√ßa. experimentei como se fosse comigo. o aperto no cora√ß√£o e na garganta.\xa0
Ditadura NUNCA mais.', 'what a fucking gut punch of a film. despite not knowing much about the military dictatorship in brazil ahead of time - if 
anything
 - i still immediately fell head over heels for this family and found myself instantly immersed in their tenderly depicted dynamic, so compassionately captured in that first (nearly) tension-free half hour. and it‚Äôs these first 30 minutes of unadulterated joy and frivolity that make the rest of the movie as mightily emotionally affecting as it ultimately is, because you too feel like a member of said family when its patriarch is so unexpectedly and aggressively disappeared and the whole world seems to lose its luster.
what more can be said about the towering fernanda torres? simply‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Truth
Text:
As Dominique Marceau is being tried for the murder of Gilbert Tellier, accounts by different witnesses paint a picture of the kind of relationship the two used to¬†share.
['you sit there dressed up ridiculous! you want to judge, but you‚Äôve never loved! you hate me, because you are all dead!
\xa0 \xa0‡ßé
‚ú¢ìè≤ i was never really into jury or court films, but after watching
 ‚Äòwitness for the prosecution‚Äô
 and
 ‚Äò12 angry men‚Äô 
i‚Äôve grown to like this genre. ‚Äî that‚Äôs why i decided to give this film a try ‚ô°
throughout the whole film, they try to portray 
dominique
 as promiscuous, careless and stupid, but to me, she was an icon ‚ô° that poor girl just wanted to be loved and enjoy her life. she was so raw & human, yet in the end, she was reduced to just another case to those people ‚Äî like what happened to‚Ä¶ 
more', "A remarkable and relatively hidden film by French master Clouzot, La V√©rit√© is a stack of lethal dominoes; love, lust, jealousy and infidelity, that begin to fall from its beginning and never cease with each highly charged scene that follows. Bardot as Dominique, brandishes her sensuality like a sharpened dagger, transforming from pouting, petulent temptress to an enraged and heartbroken soul in a performance that shows what she was capable of as an actor. The film has an incredible rhythm to it, an operatic feel that ties in with the conducting talents of Dominique's lover, Gilbert. Throughout the film I was struck by its anxiousness, through its direction, editing and performances and couldn't help but think of it as a rapidly beating heart, ready to explode. In an uncanny parallel to this noticeable vibe, I then read that Clouzot's wife in real life, died of a heart attack shortly after its release and his life and career never recovered.", 'the end with everyone in the court literally jumping over tables to get out of there, the blas√© way they discuss having to do it all again next week with a new case, the defense attorney patting the prosecutor on the back despite calling him heartless mere minutes before‚Ä¶just merciless. a movie about putting a raw and bleeding human heart on trial and ridiculing it for beating out of rhythm. I sat there staring at the screen speechless for five minutes after it was over.']

Title: Jackie
Text:
An account of the days of First Lady, Jacqueline Kennedy, in the immediate aftermath of John F. Kennedy‚Äôs assassination in¬†1963.
['end-credits have no music: a missed opportunity to play national anthem by lana del rey', 'jackie looking in the mirror, crying and wiping the blood off her face is one of the most heartbreaking, superbly acted and unforgettable scenes of 2016', "this is monumental. like Under the Skin and Marie Antoinette swirled together in a kaleidoscope of American history. such a dense tapestry of ideas and emotions, all of which fit into the scale of a single woman enduring the worst week of her life. so smart on the balance between life and legacy, between being and performance, between grief and guilt... not only the first Larra√≠n that i've loved, but the first time i ‚Äî an american jew for whom the kennedys have always felt like royalty from another country ‚Äî feel as though i've understand their myth in any real way. \nwhat a movie."]

Title: An Evening with Beverly Luff¬†Linn
Text:

Then Dan Aykroyd, that wonderful weirdo, writes this whole bible of mythology for their joke music personas and they make a blockbuster movie featuring Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles, and Carrie Fisher with a bazooka, and it‚Äôs both total nonsense and genuinely amazing. None of this makes sense. I love it.', 'carrie fisher trying to kill people; iconic', 'A moment of silence for the thousands of cars destroyed in this film.']

Title: Women in¬†Love

Title: Bo Burnham:¬†Inside
Text:
Stuck in COVID-19 lockdown, US comedian and musician Bo Burnham attempts to stay sane and happy by writing, shooting and performing a one-man comedy¬†special.
["now i'm horny AND i feel like shit", "there's something poisonous about being forcibly stuck inside as a person who views creative work as their life's goal; when there's nothing to do but create, your mind starts to eat itself and make you feel bad for not being able to create even more. there's nothing scarier than unrealized potential and the sands of that hourglass aren't going to stop just because the outside world has. even when that potential is realized, then you gotta be afraid that it isn't good enough and that the only thing worse than never having realized that potential, is realizing your potential isn't as good as you'd hoped it was. time is a curse, only made moreso by the meaningless benchmarks we make‚Äì‚Ä¶ \nmore", "bo is a very good guy who makes very good things that are very important to me and i'll just leave it at that"]

Title: The Forgotten¬†Battle
Text:
In WWII‚Äôs final years, a soldier in the German army, a British glider pilot, and a Dutch resistance fighter‚Äôs paths intertwine. Their choices shape destinies, impacting not only their freedom but also that of¬†others.
['Why would you cast Malfoy and not make him a nazi?!', 'There are brilliant elements to this film, but each is pieced together so incompetently that it fails to tell a coherent story. There are simply too many characters that we are asked to care for, and where I understand that the filmmakers were attempting to show the different perspectives of the giant clusterfuck that was World War II, the synthesis of the stories wasn‚Äôt great, and some did not land how they were clearly intended to. It‚Äôs never really sure if it wants to be brutally realistic or melodramatically sentimental, and this creates a jarring discrepancy in tone, emotion and ultimate impact.', 'But what happened to Henk????']

Title: Tinker Bell and the Pirate¬†Fairy
Text:
Zarina, a smart and ambitious dust-keeper fairy who‚Äôs captivated by Blue Pixie Dust and its endless possibilities, flees Pixie Hollow and joins forces with the scheming pirates of Skull Rock, who make her captain of their ship. Tinker Bell and her friends must embark on an epic adventure to find Zarina, and together they go sword-to-sword with the band of pirates led by a cabin boy named James, who‚Äôll soon be known as Captain Hook¬†himself.
['when all the fairies switched talents and outfits üíòüíòüíò', 'zarina is a woman in STEM', 'Every Tinkerbell movie:
"Don't do the thing!"
*does the thing*
*bad stuff happens*
"This is why we don't do the thing!"
*fixes the bad stuff by doing/using the thing*
"I guess the thing isn't so bad after all."
In this movie the thing is experimenting on pixie dust, and it also shoehorns in some origin that will eventually play in Peter Pan. If you've been a fan of these movies, then this is more of the same. Good voice work, decent animation, fun humor, and a rare instance of a good film for kids that centers on a group of females working together. Great film to watch if you have a young girl in your household, or a young boy. Any kid really.']

Title: Jules and¬†Jim
Text:
In the carefree days before World War I, introverted Austrian author Jules strikes up a friendship with the exuberant Frenchman Jim and both men fall for the impulsive and beautiful¬†Catherine.
['Sorry but neither of these guys would have survived World War I', "I think jules and jim should've dated", "I love how excited this movie is about how it works under its own rules. Truly unapologetic with it's style which is probably why it has that status of being one of the greatest to come out of the french new wave. Won't deny that it doesn't feel as though it sticks the landing. It also works at a very fast pace and trying to process all of the beautiful writing scattered throughout gets pretty overwhelming. That's more at the fault of my comprehension skills than the film. What I'm trying to say is that I am going to watch as many french new wave films as I can during quarantine because after dealing with the headache that is Avid Media Composer over the last 24 hours, losing yourself in this kind of filmmaking feels like a warm shower."]

Title: Love, Death & Robots: Ice¬†Age

['a t√°r is born', 'Hollywood so out of ideas they‚Äôre already making T√ÅR prequels.', 'I like the cinematography. I like the makeup. I like the acting. I really like the editing. I like that it starts with Comden and Green and ends with Tears for Fears. And yet ... I don‚Äôt really like 
Maestro
. My second viewing left me just as cold as the first. 
I don‚Äôt feel like I walk away having learned much about Bernstein. I don‚Äôt know what made him a great composer. I don‚Äôt know why he was such a special conductor. I don‚Äôt even feel like I really understand his marriage, despite that being the central element of Cooper‚Äôs film.

Title: Marvel One-Shot: All Hail the¬†King
Text:
A documentary filmmaker interviews the now-famous Trevor Slattery from behind¬†bars.
['justin hammer and his boyfriend will be the ones who defeat thanos', "A sweary prison-set epilogue to Iron Man 3 where we find Trevor Slattery enjoying his notoriety and being interviewed by a documentary film maker.\nI was pleasantly surprised by this. It worked well with a fun yet dark tone and a 1970's feel to it. It serves to tie up loose ends from the Iron Man trilogy, whilst also setting up a possible future film.\nThe twist in Iron Man 3 pleased some, angered some and surprised most. I was worried this short film would try to amend or ret-con the twist but it was handled very well. Although I suspect this story was not in place before the release of Iron Man 3 and was written to placate the 'fan boy' backlash, it is cleverly done in a way that should please everyone and also manages to be a sly commentary on the internet reaction. 8/10.", '#bringjustinhammerback']

Title: Hotel¬†Rwanda
Text:
Inspired by true events, this film takes place in Rwanda in the 1990s when more than a million Tutsis were killed in a genocide that went mostly unnoticed by the rest of the world. Hotel owner Paul Rusesabagina houses over a thousand refuges in his hotel in attempt to save their¬†lives.
['"NOT a date movie" - Dean Pelton (Community)', 'Hotel Rwanda might have a great score on Rotten Tomatoes but Yelp reviews are terrible.', 'The sentimental influence of Hollywood blunts the sharp blade of an African holocaust. 
Hotel Rwanda (2004) concerns the Rwandan genocide that had occurred a decade previous ‚Äì a mass slaughter of Tutsi people, on the grounds of ethnicity, that began within a few hours of reigning President Habyarimana‚Äôs assassination. Catalysed by the existing conflict from the Rwandan Civil War, and exacerbated by a prepared political elite known as akazu; what resulted was an eruption of terror and intense violence that snatched the lives of an estimated one million Rwandan souls in the period of around one hundred days.
This key historical drama is based on real life events that transpired only twenty years ago ‚Äì a modern day holocaust that‚Ä¶

Title: Lola¬†Mont√®s
Text:
Lola Montes, previously a great adventuress, is reduced to being the attraction of a circus after having been the lover of various important¬†men.
["The finest of Ophuls' films - the greatest and most profound film on the subject of spectacle. Spectacle turns life literally into a kaleidoscopic circus, furthermore womanhood into a false circus, all of life's memories into a grotesque parade and we see that spectacle by nature can only be a twisted commodified version of life. It's a relevant film...because Lola tries eventually to use her objectification to her advantage...even the seemingly most decent of men end up forcing her into their own codifications -so she turns herself into spectacle in revolt, only at the end to realize that spectacle is forever a cage. Lola is genuine, honest, forceful and willful - her revolt against the oppression cast upon the entire‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Director Max Oph√ºls‚Äô final completed work, ‚ÄúLola Mont√®s‚Äù is the closest that a camera has ever come to dancing itself into life.\xa0
Based on the life of ‚ÄòThe Most Scandalous Woman in the World,‚Äô \xa0Oph√ºls‚Äô film tells the story of the many, many loves of one of history‚Äôs most notorious courtesans - Lola Montez.\xa0
At a time when flashbacks were still a narrative trick most associated with ‚ÄúCitizen Kane,‚Äù Oph√ºls employs them with an eloquence still unequaled in ‚ÄúLola‚Äôs‚Äù unique structure. The story unfolds as its heroine takes part in a circus performance recreation of her biography ‚Äî pausing between acts as she reflects back on the actual events that inspired the garish spectacle.\xa0
It‚Äôs a visual that many will‚Ä¶

Title: WALL¬∑E
Text:
What if mankind had to leave Earth and somebody forgot to turn the last robot off? After hundreds of years doing what he was built for, WALL‚Ä¢E discovers a new purpose in life when he meets a sleek search robot named EVE. EVE comes to realize that WALL‚Ä¢E has inadvertently stumbled upon the key to the planet‚Äôs future, and races back to space to report to the humans. Meanwhile, WALL‚Ä¢E chases EVE across the galaxy and sets into motion one of the most imaginative adventures ever brought to the big¬†screen. √ó
['Bold of Disney to finance and release a movie about a megacorporation that destroys the Earth', 'WALL¬∑E is a creepy old man who stalks a young girl and takes her out on dates while she's unconscious.
EVE is a high-strung woman who destroys everything around her and won't even explain what her job is.
And it's the most adorable thing ever.
WALL¬∑E
 continues to convince me that part of Pixar's brilliance comes from their understanding of visual storytelling. They know that character doesn't come from having your actors read their characteristics to the audience, it comes from their actions. It comes from WALL¬∑E waking up groggy and trying to put his "shoes" on. It comes from the fact that he can't resist showing EVE all the cool stuff he's collected over the years. It comes from‚Ä¶

Title: A Good¬†Year
Text:
Failed London banker Max Skinner inherits his uncle‚Äôs vineyard in Provence, where he spent many childhood holidays. Upon his arrival, he meets a woman from California who tells Max she is his long-lost cousin and that the property is¬†hers.
['I get it Ridley. I too would like to inherit a vineyard in Provence, fall in love with restauranteur Marion Cotillard, and tell a bunch of City traders to fuck off', 'A romanticized vision of France, full of visual charm.
Cold London meets warm opposite and the joy of life it brings, and we have a story about what a "good" life truly is. Scott directs with a fairly steady hand, but in the end, it doesn‚Äôt really leave a lasting impression, as it doesn‚Äôt allow the characters to fully marinate in their own personalities.
Crowe plays a character named Max, who‚Äôs essentially...a wanker. Cotillard is the embodiment of independence and serves as a mirror to Max‚Äôs character. She‚Äôs not in the film as much as I initially expected, but her enigmatic gentleness and sharpness really work within the whole. I think I love herü§î
And then the story starts digging‚Ä¶ 
more', 'The romantic comedy hits all the predictable generically conventional buttons, yet stays enjoyable for its feel good appeal, charming cast, heartening soundtrack and the exotically beautiful countryside locations and lifestyle. A warm satisfying watch.']

Title: Hail¬†Satan?
Text:

completely captivated and fascinated by this, and it made me laugh harder and more genuinely than most anything i‚Äôve seen all year. y‚Äôall mind if i start hailing satan?', 'An unexpected and truly bizarre thought might ‚Äî no, will ‚Äî occur to most viewers at during Penny ‚ÄúHail Satan?,‚Äù though the lightning bolt of an idea is sure to strike different people at different points of Penny Lane‚Äôs provocative, hilarious, and latently enraging documentary about The Satanic Temple. Impishly protesting a bill that would allow for prayer in public schools, the group wears demonic masks and unfurls a massive banner that takes aim at the clear Evangelical Christian agenda underpinning then-Governor Rick Scott‚Äôs political agenda. It‚Ä¶

Title: The Gospel According to St.¬†Matthew
Text:
Along a rocky, barren coastline, Jesus begins teaching, primarily using parables. He attracts disciples; he‚Äôs stern, brusque, and demanding. His parables often take on the powers that be, so he and his teachings come to the attention of the Pharisees, the chief priests, and elders. They conspire to have him arrested, beaten, tried, and crucified, just as he prophesied to his¬†followers.
["The best thing to Pier Paolo Pasolini's 
The Gospel According to St. Matthew
 is the matter to which it handles the subject it depicts, it never succumbs to a specific bias. Many films about the life of Jesus Christ exist but there is a reason as to why Pier Paolo Pasolini's take happens to be the very best of the bunch. Years ago, this was my introduction to the films of Pasolini and it remains my favourite. It was interesting to see how Pier Paolo Pasolini of everyone would be taking on the task of directing a film telling the story of the life of Jesus Christ, especially when it is put into consideration that he was a homosexual, an‚Ä¶ 
more", "A supporter of Marxism, openly gay and a confessed atheist, Pier Paolo Pasolini, the Italian director who went on to direct 
Sal√≤, or the 120 Days of Sodom
, might not seem the most obvious choice to formulate an artistic retelling of the life of Christ from his birth through to his resurrection. Additionally, Enrique Irazoqui, the nineteen-year-old and virtually unknown actor who portrays Christ is not especially prepossessingly charismatic and initially looks like the most improbable person to represent him.
However, it's a heartfelt and honouring portrait and Pasolini is incredibly loyal to the scriptures with a priority bestowed on the words of Christ over and beyond his alleged miracles. It's a deliberately paced narrative which stimulates a contemplative quality‚Ä¶ 
more", '‚ÄúIf you want to be perfect, go, sell your possessions and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.‚Äù \xa0
Matthew 19:21
Jesus was a communist.']

Title: Life, and Nothing¬†More‚Ä¶
Text:
After the earthquake of Guilan, a film director and his son travel to the devastated area to search for the actors from the movie the director made there a few years previously. In their search, they see how people who have lost everything in the earthquake still have hope and try to live life to the¬†fullest.
["Obviously, And Life Goes On is a metatextual follow-up to Where Is The Friend's Home, before becoming what was only chapter two of what is now known as the Koker trilogy. But the establishing of the three films as a trilogy, while an obvious move, distracts from how each of Kiarostami's films are either a variation of the last or a synthesis of some sort - Where Is The Friend's Home is a fiction work set around a school day, Homework is a documentary on the education system. Close-Up is step 3: a synthesis between the formal and structural techniques of Where Is The Friend's Home and Homework - a fiction work on documentary. And Life Goes On is step‚Ä¶

Title: The Great¬†Hack
Text:
Data‚Äîarguably the world‚Äôs most valuable asset‚Äîis being weaponized to wage cultural and political wars. The dark world of data exploitation is uncovered through the unpredictable, personal journeys of players on different sides of the explosive Cambridge Analytica/Facebook data¬†story.
["If you want me to save you roughly two hours, data rights are important and we need to talk about how to categorize them and hold large data companies accountable. If you want to read what I thought of The Great Hack, read on. 
Under-specific, disjointed, overproduced, unreliably presented, overtly biased, and passively boring. There is an interesting overuse of the word Psychology and it's numerous suffixes, and an equally interesting complete lack of the word Sociology and it's suffixes in this picture. This leaves me with a feeling that the people speaking are not informed specialists on how to perceive individual behavior on a macroscopic scale.
If and when a Documentarian is entrenched not just physically but morally and‚Ä¶ 
more", 'So...political propaganda and manufacturing consent started with the 2016 election and Brexit? Could have fooled me. Guess they never heard of people like Edward Bernays and Henry Kissinger then. This doc is absurd in its presuppositions that private industry influence on national elections is some new phenomena, even the use of data (guess they missed Adam Curtis‚Äôs several docs on this subject over the last 20 years). No, it‚Äôs just more sophisticated now. The whole doc is a lot of bells and whistles but they never actually say anything of real merit expect Cambridge Analytica skirted the rules and frankly in making the story of 2016 election oversimplified of some failure of digital democracy the documentary is in fact the‚Ä¶ 
more', 'i demand that netflix give me back the 70,000 data points they gained from me watching this documentary']

Title: Two Distant¬†Strangers
Text:
A man trying to get home to his dog becomes stuck in a time loop that forces him to relive a deadly run-in with a¬†cop.
['This has some nice moments that had some strong untapped potential, but the rest of it can fuck off. Well intended, but hell no. Exploits the actual bodies on screen to make a point that was made very early on. The way people praise this is why we have not made any progress yet with this issue. There is nothing eye opening here. No new forms of micro aggressions or how black people each day navigate different forms of whitesplaining or white centric environments. This is disgusting and nothing more than black trauma used as a way for white people to say how power this was. Just another example of black trauma presented to be anti black.', "0.5/5.0 = Notably Terrible
Note: I only review short films if they're nominated for an Oscar. I don't like the idea of publishing criticism on other short films.
Joey Bada$$ police brutality drama TWO DISTANT STRANGERS is easily the worst short film nominated for the Academy award since 2017s SILENT NIGHTS. Honestly, it may be the worst short film I've ever seen, full stop. This is totally irresponsible, careless, stupid, juvenile, and tactless filmmaking. I'm not the first to say this and I sure won't be the last, but just because a film stands on the right side of an issue doesn't mean it's good. In fact, it's somewhat of an obligation (both on the part of the film industry‚Ä¶

Title: The Seventh¬†Victim
Text:
After young Mary Gibson discovers that her older sister Jacqueline has disappeared, she leaves her boarding school and heads to New York City to track down her sibling. But Mary gets drawn deeper into the¬†mystery.
["Pre-60s horror Tuesdays:
The main character Jacqueline (who still feels like the main character despite being onscreen very little and only showing up about a third of the way thru this) reveals a dangerous secret to her psychiatrist. Back then, gayness was a mental disorder called 'homesexuality' and (especially if you were female, but this assumption is purely based on the statistical likelihood of being considered the legal property of others more often than men were) you could be forcibly committed in an attempt to 'cure' you. Which could very well be considered synonymous with death (if not physical, then death of the self). 
Effectively for the plot of the movie, the secret is actually her participation in a satanic‚Ä¶ 
more", '‚ÄúDeath is good‚Äù is how producer Val Lewton summarized the message of his films, a credo that received its most explicit expression in this strikingly nihilistic shocker, the first film directed by regular Lewton editor Mark Robson. Kim Hunter makes her film debut as a young boarding-school student who, in search of her missing sister (proto-goth icon Jean Brooks), travels to New York‚Äôs bohemian Greenwich Village, where she uncovers a sinister shadow world of devil-worshippers and murder. And what about that mysterious room furnished with nothing but a chair and a hangman‚Äôs noose? With its daring treatment of depression and queerness, The Seventh Victim has haunted the margins of cinema for decades, its radical bleakness undiminished by time.
Our edition arrives on October 8, 2024. To learn more or pre-order, visit 
 Criterion.com.', '80
Nothing but bad vibes. A young woman learns to recognize when something is a fruitless cause, even if that cause is trying to find your sister. Might be the most influential RKO horror film? Its impression is clearly felt over the 20th century of ambiguous conspiracy horror. A scene with an impossibly dark hallway and uncertain shadows is so terrifying simply due to the power of imagination.']

With help from some unlikely allies, Abby embarks on a quest to save Gretchen. But is their friendship powerful enough to beat the¬†devil?

Title: Hoosiers
Text:
Failed college coach Norman Dale gets a chance at redemption when he is hired to coach a high school basketball team in a tiny Indiana town. After a teacher persuades star player Jimmy Chitwood to quit and focus on his long-neglected studies, Dale struggles to develop a winning team in the face of community criticism for his temper and his unconventional choice of assistant coach: Shooter, a notorious¬†alcoholic.
['I want to explain my potential personal bias towards this film before I start to review it. I was born, raised, and continue to live in Indiana. I am not quite old enough to directly recall the events of the movie, but I am old enough for the legend of those events to have haunted my entire primary education. The attitudes towards high school basketball in Indiana really only has one equivalent that I am aware of, and that is high school football in Texas. I currently work with people that sincerely believe that "dunking" a basketball and the three point shot ruined the game. They look at this film with a strange reverence, and and even stranger dismissal, because‚Ä¶ 
more', "One of those films that always comes up when discussing sports films, but one I never had the chance to watch. And with the passing of Hackman, I thought, what better time to finally see it?
And while it doesn‚Äôt reinvent the genre and sticks to a lot of the convention, the film is nonetheless quite fun and engaging. I had anticipated Hackman's Norman Dale to be more abrasive and confrontational, but I appreciated his balance of firmness, a no-nonsense approach, and a hint of inspiration. The game sequences are really well filmed and directed, not only allowing you to cheer for your team but also evoking a sense of excitement akin to a real-life game, a feeling I believe‚Ä¶ 
more", 'I had never seen this classic of Reagan-era nostalgia about a time when white people were good at sports. It was pretty good, Hackman and Hopper are great, but I never knew this was about a HS basketball team, I thought it was college hoops and as such cared significantly less about it. Also, the film introduces the fact that Coach Norm Dale lost his job coaching college ball for assaulting a player but sort of just leaves it there after Barbara Hershey decides that she likes Gene Hackman.']

Title: In the¬†Bedroom
Text:
Summertime on the coast of Maine, ‚ÄúIn the Bedroom‚Äù centers on the inner dynamics of a family in transition. Matt Fowler is a doctor practicing in his native Maine and is married to New York born Ruth Fowler, a music teacher. His son is involved in a love affair with a local single mother. As the beauty of Maine‚Äôs brief and fleeting summer comes to an end, these characters find themselves in the midst of unimaginable¬†tragedy.
['this movie has [smashes plate] EVERYTHING!!!!!', 'At one point Celia Weston explains what a Disneyworld Fastpass is to Sissy Spacek, automatic masterpiece.', 'Powerful and elegiac, ranking up there with "The Sweet Hereafter" and "The Ice Storm", "In the Bedroom" is a drama of a family marred by a horrific tragedy. Sissy Spacek, Tom Wilkenson and Marisa Tomei are equally devastating as a trio of loved ones who lost aspiring architect Nick Stahl. \nMy favorite scene: Wilkenson and Spacek are verbally duking it out with one another (Wilkenson whispers, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre bitter, Ruth,‚Äù reverberating quite loudly), only to be interrupted by a little girl selling chocolates. It is a priceless scene in a wrenching film.']

Title: Lilya¬†4-ever
Text:
In a struggling post-Soviet community, Lilya a teenage girl is abandoned when her mother moves to the United States with her boyfriend. Facing neglect and poverty, she meets Andrei, who offers her a job in Sweden, giving her hope for a better life ‚Äî and a journey that will change¬†everything.
["I'll never complain about anything ever again.", "This film should come with a health warning, it will put you in a state of depression and will probably make you want to kill yourself but it's a masterpiece and must be seen.", "I recently sent Lukas Moodysson a message to let him know that I loved and wrote a very positive review of what I believe is his most unfairly maligned film (A Hole in My Heart, which is sitting around a 4.6 on IMDb right now) and he actually took the time to message me back and thank me for the kind words. This is now the third or fourth time he's been nice enough to respond to one of my little appreciative e-mails, and I don't think he realizes how much his responses mean to me. His 2002 film, Lilja 4-Ever, is one of the few films that I can safely say actually changed my life. Sometimes you hear people‚Ä¶ \nmore"]

Title: He Got¬†Game
Text:
A basketball player‚Äôs father must try to convince him to go to a college so he can get a shorter prison¬†sentence.
['surprised this isn‚Äôt talked about more often as one of spike lee‚Äôs essentials. incredibly layered, his most expressionistic from what i‚Äôve seen, and a bit of a sampler platter for him as a filmmaker. thought ray allen was actually outstanding, thought the milla jovovich stuff was a total drag', 'Spike takes his complex relationship with a sport he obviously adores (all those lovingly photographed slow-motion montage/music videos of the game itself!) but also sees for the inherent industry exploitation of black men it is (also see: his brief appearance lecturing college hopefuls in 
Hoop Dreams
), and turns it into a stylish and colorful emotional melodrama about a father who uses his soon-to-be professional athlete son as a vessel for all his suffering, burdens and hopes he can live vicariously through. "It's biblical." "Yeah, no kidding." Denzel is unbelievable as always, and this has one of my favorite endings in a Spike joint.', '"all those lips all those hips all those honey dips." 
the *most* Spike Lee joint there is? and the quintessential Denzel Washington performance. 
that constant Copland score!
magical-realist touch certainly gives the impression that the bifurcated narrative comes together, but i get the impression that Spike was at war with his own cooked up abstractions... the director part of him wanted to let this story fly on its themes, but the writer part of him could never let that happen (hence, milla jovovich as one of the cinema's sweetest prostitutes). all the same, i cant' help but think that the ending works... the guard with the sniper rifle is a touch too far, and Ray Allen trying to command that long final shot is a bit of a laugh, but the shot counts even if it's off the rim.']

Title: Ender‚Äôs¬†Game
Text:
Based on the classic novel by Orson Scott Card, Ender‚Äôs Game is the story of the Earth‚Äôs most gifted children training to defend their homeplanet in the space wars of the¬†future.
["The reason I hate this film so much is because I love science fiction. Let me just start by saying that I haven't read the novel(s) this is based on, so my only reference to the world of Ender is this 'film'.
I struggle to call this a film. It has moving images and somewhere hidden among the CGI straight out of the eighties there are people. You could call them actors. You could call them bored people reading their lines. Both would fit.
Hold on a sec.
Can someone please turn down the soundtrack? Cheers.
Right. Back to the game. Film. Game. Whatever. It's a platformer. Ender goes from level 1 to level 2 to level 3 and so‚Ä¶ 
more", '"THIS IS NOT A GAME."
Bitch did you read the title?', "Ender's Game
 might just be the most unremarkable fascinating film I've seen. It is fascinating in that it goes into areas I wouldn't think a YA story would go. It is unremarkable in how it goes there.
There's a moment in the film where a reveal is made. In my head I was absolutely shocked the film had even suggested it would go there. I thought about how great a lesson it was for kids and how it really spoke to some very adult themes. Emotionally, however, I was unmoved. It's a strange feeling to be impressed and unmoved at the same time. 
I would direct most of the blame towards Gavin Hood. His direction of the film is completely‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Innocents
Text:
A young governess for two children becomes convinced that the house and grounds are haunted by ghosts and that the children are being¬†possessed.
["Every family should have a governess that teaches the children and loves them and makes sure they're safe from the slutty ghosts of old.", 'Part of 
Hoop-Tober
‚ÄúBut they haven‚Äôt been good, merely easy to live with.‚Äù
Beware the well-read virgin. So the saying goes. The imagination will be well lubricated by the endless tomes over which she has pored. She will know of the world, but will not be a part of it‚Äîwhat is worse, she will see this as a virtue rather than a liability. Hers will be a conviction that treats faith as the evidence of things unseen, an unseemly melding of hope and conclusion and fancy into an irrefutable approximation of truth. She will insist upon nothing but the best from people, and will assume nothing but the worst.
Miss Giddens (Deborah Kerr, in a tour de force performance) is‚Ä¶ 
more', 'This is peak ambiguity in cinematic form. Derived from Henry James‚Äô 
The Turn of the Screw
, 
The Innocents
 is a psychological horror film revolving around a governess slowly losing her mind as she thinks that the children she is taking care of are being possessed by the dead. The profound music score and the prepossessing cinematography transformed the 1898 novella into, dare I say, the most equivocal film to date, touching subjects like seclusion and sexual repression in a contentious yet terrifying manner. The lingering uncanny shots can drive someone‚Äôs claustrophobia to a maximum and the ending posed multiple symbolisms that was left for the audience to comprehend. Deborah Kerr‚Äôs performance was incredibly moving and phenomenal, rivaling her prodigious 
Black Narcissus
 act. The formidable phantasmal superimpositions can put anyone on the edge of their seat. An underrated must-watch if you‚Äôre into enigmatic psychological horror films.']

Title: Mountainhead
Text:
A group of billionaire friends get together against the backdrop of a rolling international¬†crisis.
['whole lotta mountain not a lotta head', 'Not remotely surprised that Jesse Armstrong decided to turn what was probably a Succession finale idea that got immediately shouted down in the writers\' room into a movie Adam McKay would blame you for not liking. I\'m as pissed as anyone that society somehow continues to reward these venal accelerationist tech pigs for deliberately dismantling civilization but it\'s somehow even worse to me that TV showrunners are endlessly allowed to get away with toothlessly "satirizing" the softest targets imaginable.', 'kinda impressively bad. jesse armstrong\'s sell for mountainhead, his first project since succession, has been that he decided to "run at it fast rather than stew on it for five years.‚Äù he would have been wise to wait because this is a turgid, boring nothing of a film and it‚Äôs clear armstrong has little clue what he‚Äôs actually trying to say. he obviously got the itch to write some elon fanfiction and HBO were more than happy to accommodate. yes, we live in unsubtle times but we deserve better art than this. armstrong\'s now overly familiar the-library-is-open zingers now come off quite sad and lame ("dark money gandalf" lol). so many lines are clearly unused roman roy quips he‚Äôs had‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Papillon
Text:
A man befriends a fellow criminal as the two of them begin serving their sentence on a dreadful prison island, which inspires the man to plot his¬†escape.
['In ‚ÄúPapillon,‚Äù existence itself becomes an act of rebellion upon the confines man has made for himself on earth.\xa0
Director Franklin J. Schaffner‚Äôs film about two men serving sentences on the French Guinea penal colony of ‚ÄúDevil‚Äôs Island,‚Äù was penned by Dalton Trumbo ‚Äî a man who knew something of suffering penance for injustice.\xa0
‚ÄúPapillon‚Äù is rife with a spirit of resilience.\xa0
Trumbo had come out on the other side of the Hollywood blacklist era, and star Steve McQueen - pretty boy that he was - still was sure to always insert a contract rider that sent classroom supplies back to California reform school where he grew up. These were men that were bent again and again by society ‚Äî‚Ä¶ 
more', "Might be a hot take considering how highly rated it is lol. The first half really dragged for me, I wouldn't say I'm impatient, yet it just felt way longer than it needed to be. I get that it was setting things up, but it didn't keep me engaged.
The last part was really well done tho, & the shots at sea were beautiful. It's a good film fs, just didn't hit me as hard as I expected.", "The art of the one-line review isn't writing one line but breaking down the words into five lines to honor Steve McQueen and his five steps of
endurance he made day by day in his solitary cell, so I'll do just that:
'hey
you
bastards 
I'm
still
here' 
I know it's six lines. But Papillon never lived by the rules, did he? He looked for freedom in his every waking moment. For him, freedom stood above everything. Nothing could stop him from achieving it, not even several years in solitary, not even the possibility of death as he glided from the cliff like a papillon. No. Because for him, freedom WAS everything. Thank you, Steve McQueen, for your transcendent performance. I'll never forget it."]

Title: Bait
Text:
Martin Ward is a cove fisherman, without a boat. His brother Steven has repurposed their father‚Äôs vessel as a tourist tripper, driving a wedge between the brothers. With their childhood home now a getaway for London money, Martin is displaced to the estate above the picturesque harbour. As his struggle to restore the family to their traditional place creates increasing friction with tourists and locals alike, a tragedy at the heart of the family changes his¬†world.
["I'm not sure what I was expecting - neo-realism or retro-styled kitchen sink drama perhaps - but Mark Jenkin's entrancing film is a labour of love that borders on anti-realism with its expressionistic editing, montage and post-synced sound. It's a defiantly experimental, subtly confrontational piece that stays true to his own Dogme-like Silent Landscape Dancing Grain 13 manifesto. It looks like a long lost artefact, rescued from oblivion, but has an unmistakably modern sensibility.
The way the sound is entirely dubbed in post gives the film a mesmerizing, hypnotic sense of unreality, as if the voices aren't fully anchored to the actors but hover close to them, like ghostly signifiers. It also allows Jenkin to take the ambient sound right‚Ä¶ 
more", '64/100
Here's the bait Mark Jenkin successfully used to hook me: b&w Academy-ratio 16mm, artfully distressed to look ancient √† la Maddin; Eisenstein-style montage, juxtaposing discrete close-ups of faces and objects to create mood via editing rhythms; post-synch sound (including all dialogue and effects) that's deliberately "off" without being jarring. 
Bait
 works as a deliberate throwback, but never quite crosses the line into outright pastiche, as Maddin always does‚Äîit's so sincere in its antiquation that it flirts with looking amateurish at times, employing shot choices (e.g. showing a stretch of dock for 20 frames or so before a coil of rope falls onto it) that one usually only sees in student work nowadays. Reminded me of 
œÄ
\xa0 (which I also‚Ä¶ 
more', "Those of you who are aware of Mark Jenkin's short films know what they look like, the man shoots pieces of art through almost lost and forgotten means of delivery, here it's an old Bolex which is then hand processed using 16mm film. Jenkin's desire to do everything by hand really allows him the most control over his film while also controlling the quality to the most minute detail. Bait is almost as if Ken Loach & Alfred Hitchcock decided to take a vacation down to the fishing villages in south-west England and while they were there decided to make a documentary about the inner power struggles between the local fishermen and the ever growing tourist industry that seems to plague‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Bird Box¬†Barcelona

After a mysterious force decimates the world‚Äôs population, Sebastian must navigate his own survival journey through the desolate streets of Barcelona. As he forms uneasy alliances with other survivors and they try to escape the city, an unexpected and even more sinister threat¬†grows.

Title: The¬†Outside
Text:
Longing to fit in at work, awkward Stacey begins to use a popular lotion that causes an alarming reaction, while an unnerving transformation takes¬†shape.
['Annihilotion', '"Men can be fat and hairy and ugly and impolite and old, and nobody cares."\nMen (derogatory) are going to rate this two stars or lower.', 'The week hasn‚Äôt given me time to write about every episode, but this one warrants a mention. While the first three were largely about malevolent fiends getting theirs in delightfully twisted ways, ‚ÄúThe Outside‚Äù is different, following an insecure woman‚Äôs obsessive quest for transformation in sad and stomach-turning fashion. It‚Äôs Micucci‚Äôs Black Swan, and it‚Äôs Amirpour‚Äôs ‚ÄúNosedive.‚Äù A hypnotic masterwork.']

Title: Lust,¬†Caution
Text:
During World War II, a secret agent must seduce and assassinate an official who works for the Japanese puppet government in¬†Shanghai.
['There was SO much lust and like, little to no caution', 'I watch a lot of movies that feel so messy and out of control I just think "who is this for? Does even the director understand what they\'re doing?" and it\'s refreshing to feel, from the very start, that you\'re in the hands of someone who truly knows what they\'re doing. Lust, Caution is exquisitely made; not just in terms of its lavish production values but in every sense. It\'s cinema that knows just the right balance between opulent movie magic and considered understatement, hitting all the right notes whether the mood demands high drama or subtle moodiness. It\'s tense from about five minutes in and (even as someone who generally doesn\'t enjoy long films) this doesn\'t let up until‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'tfw you‚Äôre carrying the entire group project']

Title: BlackBerry

Title: Leto
Text:
Leningrad, one summer in the early eighties. Smuggling LPs by Lou Reed and David Bowie, the underground rock scene is boiling ahead of the Perestroika. Mike and his beautiful wife Natasha meet with young Viktor Tso√Ø. Together with friends, they will change the destiny of rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll in the Soviet¬†Union.
['Tips on flirting from Natalia:
1) offer them a big tomato
2) ask them to bath your son', '"You don't like the sound. When the kids scream your songs in the hallways, that'll make a sound. Just think about it."
Listening to music and talking about bands are my second greatest passions. My greatest passion is cinema, that's why I'm here. What if there was a film that would offer us both in the same pot in a wonderful way? Yes, there is. I opened this film because the plot seemed interesting, and I knew from the first minutes that it would be one of my favorites. A musical genre born amidst controls and with pressures: musicians struggling to make rock in the Soviet Russia of the 1980s. A film that tells the story of Mike Naumenko and‚Ä¶ 
more', "This is my 
Challengers
.
Sometimes something happens. It doesn't leave your mind, it captures your thoughts, it settles in your heart. It's like looking in a mirror-similar to you but as distant as an old melody. This film did that to me. Another gem I found among underrated ones. My new comfort, me-core film.
Early eighties. Leningrad. Freedom is a language that has not been spoken for a long time. Repression, restriction, interference. The children of the revolution are now the greatest opponents of innovation. And rock'n roll: like a flower trying to grow on the sidewalk. It resisting those who can crush it at any moment. Underground rock bands: they don't even let their own winds flow in their‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of¬†Water
Text:
Burger Beard is a pirate who is in search of the final page of a magical book that makes any evil plan he writes in it come true, which happens to be the Krabby Patty secret formula. When the entire city of Bikini Bottom is put in danger, SpongeBob, Patrick, Mr. Krabs, Squidward, Sandy, and Plankton need to go on a quest that takes them to the surface. In order to get back the recipe and save their city, the gang must retrieve the book and transform themselves into¬†superheroes. √ó

The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water

Don't get me wrong, It's kinda sloppy at points, and the switch between traditional animation to live-action/CGI is pretty jarring, but the rest is just something else...
I really don't know how else to describe this work of absolute art, so I'm just going to‚Ä¶

Title: One False¬†Move
Text:
Following a series of drug deals and murders, three criminals ‚Äì Fantasia, Ray Malcolm and Pluto ‚Äì travel from Los Angeles to Houston, finally arriving in a small Arkansas town to go into hiding. Two detectives from the LAPD, who are already on the case, contact the town‚Äôs sheriff, Dale Dixon, to alert him of the fugitives‚Äô presence in the area. Underestimating Dixon, the criminals have no idea what they are about to¬†face.
["Noir-inflected Southern melodrama that slowly peels back its crime genre trappings until all that's left are the cyclical wounds of racism and violence. Franklin directs the shit out of this and Paxton and Williams both give layered performances that beautifully complicate each other when they eventually intersect. The ending is a bit much but still nearly ripped my heart out anyway. Really gotta respect something like this that will give you the pleasures of Paxton and Billy Bob swaggering around like dirtbags and having really nasty suspense sequences/shootouts but never takes the easy route with its characters, keeping them real and flawed and thorny til the bitter end.", "So lean and straight it's like a math problem; two trains (the cops and the killers, the ex-lovers, the father and his son, the Feds and the locals) leave their stations at such and such a speed, how long before the meet up? Nicely pulls at threads like race and power dynamics, but only as they criss-cross through the story, which never gets off track.
Discussed on Episode 59 of 
The Suspense is Killing Us
.", "Idolatry in all its forms shown at first with smiles and pleasantries before it pulls back the curtain and flashes its fangs. There's a particular sense of certain tragedy awaiting its characters on-the-move that initially registers as mechanical, run-of-the-mill even, before blooming into something both beautiful but dark at the end in which the outcome seems to be the only thing that possibly 
could
 happen. The title then carries with it a sense of foredestined fatalism in which one false move, many false moves, occurs constantly both obvious and not which steers its players towards a crossing of roads that arrives sooner than they expect. It is only in the finality of a dying clarity that the airs of idolatry are exposed and the truth of what it is that registers, too late, perhaps, but better than never. Not that it'll do much good for those who inherit those sins."]

Title: Four Nights of a¬†Dreamer
Text:
Jacques, a young man with artistic aspirations, spends four nights wandering Paris with a young woman, whom he rescued from¬†suicide.
['Lonely hearts search for love, but not real, true love; merely the idea of love. Their idealism is what drives them. Lost souls rendezvous, make gestures of longing and discuss their lives both past and present. And yet, when what they are both sure of is brought into question, then back into certainty, what are they left with? Musal inspiration for the artist and security for the pining lover.
Four Nights of a Dreamer
\xa0sees Bresson taking a stab at Dostoyevsky‚Äôs ‚ÄúWhite Nights‚Äù. Unlike in Visconti‚Äôs 
Le Notti Bianche‚Äî
another adaptation of the work‚ÄîBresson opts for more meditative ruminations on love, rather than the melodrama of Visconti‚Äôs take on the story. This is mostly done visually, as Bresson‚Äôs transcendental lens captures passing‚Ä¶ 
more', "Youth romanticism in a world that might have no future. The tension between the genuine mystery of fiction, the meeting of the young lovers promise, all those lovely night scenes, the near musical structure, those seductive surfaces, and Bresson's materialism is among the most fascinating of his career.", 'No credits whatsoever, 
the film starts right away.
By the side of a freeway entrance:
A young man hitchhiking, trying to leave the city. 
Finally, a car stops.
‚ÄúWhere are you going?‚Äù
The young man, instead of an answer,
just raises his arms, then shrugs his shoulders. ‚ÄúJust anywhere‚Äù, he seems to want to say.
‚ÄúGet in,‚Äù the driver says.
And off he goes...
We see nothing of the drive.
Instead, we see the young man enter the frame again.
He‚Äôs in nature, nothing but fields and green. (‚Ä¶)
Night. Back in the city.
The young man is back in Paris.
He walks into the night.
The image gets blurry and out of focus.
A guitar starts strumming, like the‚Ä¶

Title: A Short Film About¬†Killing
Text:
Jacek climbs into the taxi driven by Waldemar, tells him to drive to a remote location, then brutally strangles him, seemingly without¬†motive.
['In this film, Kieslowski is able to say more about human nature than most other directors could with a hundred films of their own.', 'Government be like: killing is bad, really really bad, and if you do it we‚Äôll kill you.
9.2 / 10', "I have previously noted that a film with palpable influence on the real world exceeds in my estimation any film whose most notable impact to the wider world is merely on the realm of film itself; there is a step further that should be noted, that when a film's influence can be proven to save lives, actually prevent killing itself, on not an individual but an institutional level, that film becomes more akin to something holy. I certainly did not have this expectation going in; Kieslowski has previously left me interested but not moved, intrigued but not scarred.
This moved me and scarred me. This seems to have saved lives.
Filters and bleach turn the world into a ragged, broken,‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Judas and the Black¬†Messiah
Text:
Bill O‚ÄôNeal infiltrates the Black Panthers on the orders of FBI Agent Mitchell and J. Edgar Hoover. As Black Panther Chairman Fred Hampton ascends‚Äîfalling for a fellow revolutionary en route‚Äîa battle wages for O‚ÄôNeal‚Äôs¬†soul.
['Just fantastic. Shaka King takes a crucial moment in history that could feel so cloying and unfocused in the hands of a less careful director, and gives us a smart, uncompromising tragedy about fear and power that properly portrays Bill O‚ÄôNeal‚Äôs story as both a slave rebellion and an act of war. Lakeith Stanfield and Daniel Kaluuya are exactly as great as you think they‚Äôre gonna be, if not better, but Shaka King‚Äôs name better reverberate through the halls of every studio after this.\nFred Hampton was 21 years old when he was murdered by the FBI. \nTwenty-one years old.', 'if your ensemble has lakeith stanfield in it, it‚Äôs gonna be a good film. devastating from beginning to end.', 'in my opinion we do not have a more entrancing, magnetic, fizzling, romantic, riveting, endlessly watchable actor in our ("our") generation than Daniel Kaluuya']

Title: Pieta

Title: The Man Who Knew¬†Infinity

When I see a movie about a subject I am deep into, it can be deeply rewarding to see it portrayed with care and spirit (which is why I love Whiplash so much). But at this point I just can\'t believe that math can be portrayed well in a film. Maybe if it\'s only barely related, like in "It\'s My Turn" where Jill Clayburgh delivers a totally accurate performance of someone explaining the Snake Lemma to her class but it\'s just a scene to introduce the fact that she\'s a math professor about to sex Michael Douglas.\nI was eager for this one though, because I know little about the particulars of the field‚Ä¶ \nmore']

Title: Innocence
Text:
At a peculiar all-girls academy, new arrivals, including Iris, are delivered in coffins. Guided by enigmatic teachers, the students dance through enchanted woods by day, while the night unveils sinister lessons that blur innocence and¬†awakening.
['(A quiet metaphorical piece about the ways in which young girls are trained to be exploited, in which innocence is glorified and misrepresented as obedience, in which a girl starts to die when she begins to be socialized, in which the emphasis on innocence in girlhood ill equips them to survive, in which the imagery of innocence itself is depicted as cruel. Clothed in whiteness, hung on thin frames, each child a model--this is the patriarchal ideal being challenged through representation.)
This reminded me strikingly of 
Haibane Renmei
.
52 project: 67/52', 'this film really had me scared that men were around the corner the entire time', 'A whole infinite universe of possible interpretations, perspectives, even personal feelings can circle around the concept of ‚Äúinnocence‚Äù, which we most often associate to purity, na√Øvet√© towards evil, ingenuousness towards sexuality, a lack of ability to measure personal acts, peaceful or violent. An Eden can come to mind, illustrated or not, real or theoretical. This place must be untouched by neoliberalism, industrialization, consumerism trends, or complex socioeconomic or political structures. Innocence entails a perception of safety, maybe even Nature in its least contaminated form. Now, can innocence be so pure that the possibility of it being destroyed by external forces opposite to its nature exists, or is purity a transcendent idea which ideological form shall prevail, allowing no extermination or‚Ä¶

Title: The¬†Swimmer
Text:
A man spends a summer day swimming home via all the pools in his quiet suburban¬†neighborhood.
['Me at the beginning of the film: Oh to be Burt Lancaster prancing through the woods in only a swim suit...\nMe by the end: Hey nevermind!', 'GOD Burt Lancaster plays a man who has had some kind of break with reality and decides to deal with his midcentury, suburban, masculine ennui by taking a dip in every one of his neighbor\'s swimming pools on the way home. \nBased on a story by John Cheever, this movie is one of the first mainstream depictions of the condition that would later become known as "Don Draper Syndrome." This ailment can affect any extremely handsome, wealthy, and successful middle-aged American man who constantly cheats on their wife and is also an advanced alcoholic. Despite being cool, victims of this disorder begin to feel like their life is a meaningless, empty fraud for some reason.', 'Lying on my roof with a sniper rifle and taking out Burt Lancaster as he tries to climb over my fence to swim in my pool']

Title: Dog Star¬†Man
Text:
Experimental film following a cycle of seasons as well as the stretch of a single day as a man and his dog slowly ascend a¬†mountain.
['Works insanely well when synced to The Money Store by Death Grips', "-Prelude-
One of the most spectacular things I have ever seen: the sole effect of being severely waterboarded by the forces of the Universe, from the origin of space and time to the crowded modernity. A tremendous juxtaposition of the visions of a man that has towards superior forces, towards transendence and towards our inherent spiritual perpetuity, contemplating the vastness of existence and the beginning of humankind and its continuation through procreation.
I must also highlight that this colossus predates Kubrick's odyssey by six years and there is an overwhelmingly substantial amount of traces that would be seen in Kubrick's more than legendary achievement. In the meantime, this is the transition between Dadaism and impressionism through a lens that experiments‚Ä¶ 
more", "I woke up today thinking to myself 'Jay, you've been much too kind to yourself recently. You've been logging mainstream TV shows; classic, critically acclaimed features; rewatching things you've already seen. When are you really going to challenge yourself?' So I replied to myself, '
Fuck you
, Jay. How about an eighty minute silent experimental film? How d'ya like 
THEM
 apples, fruitcake?'
It's very easy to get lost in the world of Brakhage. His passion for visuals, especially without auditory accompaniment give a new definition to the phrase 'challenging cinema'. It's less about the film challenging you, moreso you challenging yourself with the film. 
While trying to come up with my own interpretation for what I was seeing on screen, I‚Ä¶

Text:

Title: Relay
Text:
Tom, a world class ‚Äúfixer‚Äù, specializes in brokering lucrative payoffs between corrupt corporations and the individuals who threaten their ruin. But when a message arrives one day from potential client Sarah, needing Tom‚Äôs protection just to stay alive, the rules quickly start to¬†change.
['I definitely lack the typing speed required for a job at Relay.', 'Sharp, fun, and smartly entertaining from its first scene to its final twist, David Mackenzie‚Äôs ‚ÄúRelay‚Äù is an old-fashioned movie about an old-fashioned guy. The movie is a modern paranoid thriller that harkens back to the genre‚Äôs ‚Äô70s heyday (though the far more recent ‚ÄúMichael Clayton‚Äù might be its most obvious point of reference). The guy is an alcoholic Muslim named Ash (a sad and squirrely Riz Ahmed, fantastic throughout), who became a renegade deal broker after drinking away a more conventional life. \nHis stocks-in-trade are whistleblowers ‚Äî he works to keep them safe from the companies who want them dead. His methods are analogue ‚Äî Ash exclusively communicates with brave clients and evil conglomerates alike through a talk-to-text relay‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'Ending all my messages with go ahead from now on. Go ahead.']

['Watching this before watching the original (I just didn‚Äôt have the time) is gonna go down as one of the worst things I‚Äôve done. But hey, what a killer\xa0soundtrack brought to you by the Vampire Weekend Pandora station!!', 'Oh that‚Äôs not‚Ä¶

It follows the broad strokes of the novel, updating it with predictable but necessary tweaks so it fits the modern setting better. It has a great cast, with an excellent Julianne Moore.
And that's about all I can say about it without resorting to a fit of feet stomping and frowny facing.
The worst offence it commits is, bar the excellent opening, being completely bland. It dutifully and and mindlessly makes its way through the plot without any spark of creativity or originality. The first two acts are like tofu, there's no meat to them‚Ä¶

Title: Planet of the¬†Vampires
Text:
After landing on a mysterious planet, a team of astronauts begin to turn on each other, swayed by the uncertain influence of the planet and its strange¬†inhabitants.
['A revisit after putting the poster up on my wall. Love the production design of this film. And some of those smash zooms! Amazing how much Alien pulled from this film. 
Watched on Amazon Prime (very nice restoration).', "It's always been noted that Mario Bava's Planet of the Vampires (along with It! The Terror From Beyond Space) was an influence on Ridley Scott's Alien. 
I think now it seems that, intentionally or not, Planet of the Vampires might have been a bigger influence -- albeit a superficial one -- on Prometheus. Right down to the design of the space suits, the Alien ship with the giant skeletal remains, the invitation from a superior alien race, and the tuning fork technology! (Which immediately reminded me of the flute.)
Either way, I love both Prometheus AND Planet of the Vampires.", 'Pulpy B-movie fun from 
Mario Bava
. It is actually kind of dull, yet it is full of that colourful way of lighting that Bava does so extremely well. The sets reminded of something straight out of an episode of Star Trek: The Original Series, which I think is great. This was obviously highly influential on science fiction movies for decades to come (I am looking at you, 
Ridley Scott
.)']

Title: Police¬†Academy
Text:
New rules enforced by the Lady Mayoress mean that sex, weight, height and intelligence need no longer be a factor for joining the Police Force. This opens the floodgates for all and sundry to enter the Police Academy, much to the chagrin of the instructors. Not everyone is there through choice, though. Social misfit Mahoney has been forced to sign up as the only alternative to a jail sentence and it doesn‚Äôt take long before he falls foul of the boorish Lieutenant Harris. But before long, Mahoney realises that he is enjoying being a police cadet and decides he wants to stay‚Ä¶ while Harris decides he wants Mahoney¬†out! √ó
['The bad guy in the climactic scene is wearing a Vassar shirt and every time it cut back to him I laughed', 'I always wondered why they showed the sequels much more on TV than the original and now I know: The original, unlike the rest, was rated R, and so it had to be heavily edited for basic cable. And I mean 
heavily
 edited. Seeing it uncut for the first time some scenes were very surprising!\xa0
A lot of the humor has aged poorly, but some of it holds up surprisingly well. And I do love me The Goot.', 'Fuck the critics! Destroy the system! Burn the world!
There is a select band of films that are given an absolute ton of shit reviews when they are released but end up slowly changing the minds and opinions of the critics when they realise that they are adored by the public at large. Police Academy was one such film.
It was absolutely crapped on by almost everyone in the press when it was first released. Roger Ebert was especially harsh - "
It's really something. It's so bad, maybe you should pool your money and draw straws and send one of the guys off to rent it so that in the future, whenever you think you're sitting through a bad comedy,‚Ä¶
 
more']

Title: Agora
Text:
A historical drama set in Roman Egypt, concerning philosopher Hypatia of Alexandria and her relationship with her slave Davus, who is torn between his love for her and the possibility of gaining his freedom by joining the rising tide of¬†Christianity.
['when rachel weisz gave oscar isaac a sample of her period blood as an offering,,, i felt that', 'Alejandro Amen√°bar‚Äôs ambitious, big-budget biopic of philosopher Hypatia ‚Äì The Passion of the Christ for atheists ‚Äì struggled to find distributors around the world, was dumped into cinemas with barely any publicity, and was criticised by Catholic groups in Spain for defaming Christianity: the polar opposite of Mel Gibson‚Äôs berserk Passion Play. Who knows why audiences didn‚Äôt connect with this tragic epic: it has the requisite visual wow-factor, moves at a clip, and is easily accessible.\nPerhaps no one wants to be reminded of the ancient ‚Äî and modern ‚Äî punishment and subjugation of women by vicious misogynists whose pitiful moral shortcomings and weak-minded thuggery lead to acts of barbarous evil. Rachel Weisz‚Äôs towering performance breaks the heart, bringing to life a great thinker whose fate is decided for her by infantile monsters: a loss to the world more profound than the library she tries to save. It should be required viewing for anyone who supports reason over superstition.', 'the shit i watch for oscar isaac is truly ridiculous... when will i rule with my brain and not my vagina']

Title: Only the River¬†Flows
Text:
1990s, Banpo Town, rural China. A woman‚Äôs body is found by the river. Ma Zhe, Chief of the Criminal Police, heads up the murder investigation that leads to an obvious arrest. His superiors hurry to congratulate him, but several clues push Ma Zhe to delve deeper into the hidden behaviour of his fellow¬†citizens.
['He just walks around in a leather jacket smoking a cigarette for the entire runtime.', 'a sluttiest thing a man can do is to wear a leather jacket and be a detective', "Anti-noir...Anti-film?
More than once, the film claims that cinema is dead. Yet, Chinese mainland filmmaking really doesn't get any more realistic and stylish than this. Perhaps the film is director Wei Shujun's lament to single-handedly resurrect Chinese cinema. I will certainly be there to cheer him on.
With impeccable period-accurate production design and beautiful super 16mm cinematography, this film actually looks and feels like a product of the era that it represents. While the first 2/3 was beautiful to look at, one can't help but to compare it unfavourably to Memories of Murder. Luckily, the film goes on to evolve into something much more interesting. It stretched this sleep-deprived viewer's eyes wide open, buzzing with the enigma of a singular vision and the possibilities of cinema. Like a fever dream, infectious, and unexplainable. 
This is in no way a perfect film. But the way it spoke to me can only be represented with 5 stars."]

Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher‚Äôs¬†Stone
