Title: The Wind Will Carry¬†Us
Text:
Irreverent city engineer Behzad comes to a rural Kurdish village in Iran to keep vigil for a dying relative. In the meanwhile the film follows his efforts to fit in with the local community and how he changes his own attitudes as a¬†result.
['for me, watching abbas kiarostami‚Äôs films is like becoming wine drunk on humanity. he gently forces you to look at every character & feel their beating heart. in every interaction, there is humor, sorrow & joy. he is magically able to blend it all together. it‚Äôs as if his films echo what it means to be alive.', "Kiarostami again mesmerizes his audience with a tableau of simplicity, but upon closer examination, one will find vast richness in symbolism and metaphors. 
The Wind Will Carry Us
 takes the viewer on a journey through ancient Iran to a small, hidden village nestled in the mountains and surrounded by beautiful valleys. To be honest, with such an exotic and unforeseen locale, I almost have a hard time deciphering whether this is one of Kiarostami's most gorgeously photographed films or the immense visuals were just a product of the content filmed (this heavenly and simple mountain village). It also could be both, because I cannot deny Kiarostami's superb framing, especially when inside the village with the rooftops looking down (or up),‚Ä¶ 
more", 'redacted']

Title: The Matrix¬†Resurrections
Text:
Plagued by strange memories, Neo‚Äôs life takes an unexpected turn when he finds himself back inside the¬†Matrix.
['It‚Äôs fitting ‚Äî maybe even fate ‚Äî that ‚ÄúSpider-Man: No Way Home‚Äù should be the biggest and virtually only movie in the world on the week that ‚ÄúThe Matrix Resurrections‚Äù is released. Both are mega-budget, meta sequels that feed on our collective familiarity with their respective franchises. One is a poison, the other its antidote.
One is a safe plastic monument to the solipsism of today‚Äôs studio cinema; an orgiastic celebration of how studio filmmaking has created a feedback loop so powerful that it‚Äôs programmed audiences to reject anything that threatens its perfection (and to clap like seals for anything that reaffirms it, even if that means cheering for the ‚Äúunexpected‚Äù return of heroes and villains they were once eager‚Ä¶ 
more', "Nothing will ever approach the shock of the new the original gave us, but this is still a quintessential Wachowski huge swing, deeply idiosyncratic and defiant of expectation, cluttered but meticulously constructed and written to theme, and unabashedly dorky. Just like the last two sequels it'll probably be another decade before everyone realizes this is 
Actually Good
.", 'I never would‚Äôve guessed this was exactly what I wanted from a new Matrix movie in 2021 but wow I guess it is']

Title: Hereafter
Text:
Three people ‚Äî a blue-collar American, a French journalist and a London school boy ‚Äî are touched by death in different¬†ways.
['The crux of the plot is completely ludicrous, yet in a strange roundabout way it allows Eastwood to explore so many of his core interests, including death and grief as implied by the plot. I have very little to say about this one actually - what sticks with me the most is how much this film really consists of "little" moments - nothing really happens in this movie, but there are real moments of beauty throughout - like Damon (whose ability to underplay his parts makes him an ideal collaborator for Eastwood) and Bryce Dallas Howard meeting each other at cooking school, flirting and slowly getting to know each other. Moments like these are some of the hardest to get‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'what a sweetly sad thing? insane that it exists as a big-scale Hollywood project? Bacala plays a chef in this???', 'The most unlikely and underrated Clint Eastwood movie.']

Title: Junebug
Text:
On the way to meet with an independent artist in the South, newlywed art dealer Madeleine is convinced by her husband, George, that they should stop to meet his family in North Carolina. Madeleine‚Äôs affluent lifestyle clashes with the family, but she befriends George‚Äôs wide-eyed and pregnant sister-in-law, Ashley, who is nearing her due date. Through the family, Madeleine gains greater insight into George‚Äôs¬†character.

Text:

Title: AGGRO¬†DR1FT
Text:
In the seedy domain of Miami‚Äôs criminal underbelly, a seasoned hitman embarks on the relentless pursuit of his next target. The movie is shot entirely through thermal lens as he navigates a twisted world where violence and madness reign supreme. Tensions unravel, leading to a psychedelic journey that blurs the lines between predator and¬†prey.
['i see a lot of posts making fun of people who log a movie on letterboxd in a theater the second it‚Äôs over. i am perhaps the first person guilty of doing this at a strip club.
i am at the screening of this at LA strip club ‚Äúcrazy girls‚Äù. is it a great movie? hard to say. but it is the first example of truly pure cinema i‚Äôve seen from the 2020s that invoked the work of phil solomon and stan brakhage. also, a little bit of terrence malick.\xa0
there is a rare kind of artist that masters the medium so early on that they get bored of it and try to turn it into something different. this is not to say that they are the best at said medium but they certainly have the capability to be if they wished. harmony korine is one of those artists.', 'Demonic Synthwave GTA: Vice City Cutscenes To Study To. 
Feels weird to have a lukewarm reaction to this considering I watched it at the midnight premiere in Toronto with a packed, interactive crowd and 
Harmony Korine on stage in a demon mask
 declaring himself the "new Drake." But there's a reason the glowing reviews and hate-filled ones sound identical, and that's because Korine's only real instinct here is shallow genre incantation and BASED VIBES surface provocations that suit the name of his new production company, both of which have been smuggled into a movie mostly about how much of a Cool Dad he is. He plays video games and watches TikToks! 
Now he's smart enough to know what he's doing‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Pregamed this by eating a very special brownie, which felt great for a while, but 
definitely
 had me pretty drowsy by the end.
One thing that‚Äôs undeniable is that there are lots of colors to look at. The story, about a hit man who is also a family man, is a clear metaphor for Korine‚Äôs own concern about remaining cutting-edge at 50. Is this ‚Äúthe future of movies‚Äù or ‚Äúsomething beyond movies,‚Äù as Harmony himself has said? No. It‚Äôs an example of what‚Äôs called an ‚Äúexperimental film,‚Äù which is something they‚Äôve been making for a while. Check out 
Dog Star Man
.
Whatever the case was in Venice, this was warmly received by the Midnight Madness audience. If there were any walkouts, I didn‚Äôt see them.']

Title: Night Is Short, Walk On¬†Girl
Text:
As a group of university students go out for a night on the town, a sophomore known only as ‚ÄúThe Girl with Black Hair‚Äù experiences a series of surreal encounters with the local nightlife ‚Äì all the while unaware of the romantic longings of ‚ÄúSenpai‚Äù, a senior student who has been creating increasingly fantastic and contrived reasons to run into her in an effort to win her¬†heart.
['Perhaps the only film ever to include a pub crawl, a 10 minute musical number, a natural disaster sequence, an army of cowboys fighting a crowd of politicians, a slav squad, and still somehow be pretty coherent and unironically amazing.', "Y'ALL\ni had the shittiest of days and watching this movie cleared my mind and probably added 10 years to my life expectancy", "I want to live in Masaaki Yuasa's wacky incomprehensible gorgeous life-affirming world"]

Title: Times¬†Square
Text:
When a 13-year-old girl befriends a defiant antisocial child of the streets, the mismatched runaways set off to the Big Apple to find their own¬†adventure.
['‚ÄúEverything you do is poetry‚Äù ‚Ä¶. and I‚Äôm supposed to believe these two girls are just friends', 'With a spirit half made of misanthropy and half of punk rock; ‚ÄúTimes Square‚Äù is a scrawl of an anthem to the most proud of all feminist traditions: rebellion.\xa0
A favorite film entry of riot grrrl icons, not the least of which is Bikini Kill‚Äôs Kathleen Hanna, ‚ÄúTimes Square‚Äù captures the enthralling danger that pairs with entry into young teenage years.\xa0
The movie, like its young heroines, is engulfed in some sort of cycle of ending; one of which includes the inglorious peak scum era of its namesake locale. As leads Trini Alvaredo and Robin Johnson experience a self-made becoming by (in)virtue of running away from home to instead be parented by the place only some years before nicknamed ‚ÄòDanger‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Dear Daddy,
I am not kidnapped.
I am me-napped
I am soul-napped
I am Nicky-napped
I am happy-napped
Here‚Äôs a wonderful urban punk fairytale from 
Allan Moyle,
 the writer/director of 
Pump Up the Volume
 and 
Empire Records.
 It‚Äôs a sloppy, unfocused early film, but the vibe is a blast and you can totally see it as a template of what he would create a decade later.
Disturbed teens Nicky and Pammy come from opposite backgrounds, but their frustrations are the same, and the two of them team up together with the encouragement of rebel Disc Jockey 
Tim Curry 
to bring their music and rebellion to the streets.
Watching the two of them dancing along a New York sidewalk to the‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The Skeleton of Mrs.¬†Morales
Text:
A taxidermist decides to murder his wife after having to put up with her after twenty years of hellish¬†marriage.
['Esta fue y es una pel√≠cula inc√≥moda. Con El esqueleto de la se√±ora Morales, Rogelio A. Gonz√°lez ejerci√≥ en su tiempo un cine posbu√±ueliano donde hizo lo que no se hac√≠a en M√©xico: enfrentar al puritanismo cat√≥lico, celebrar el deseo sexual y darle un triunfo ‚Äîaunque un tanto p√≠rrico‚Äî al protagonista libertino. El problema que todav√≠a significa la pel√≠cula es la idea del feminicido como forma de liberaci√≥n. Al margen de su mentalidad cuestionable, la pel√≠cula resulta significativa por tomar algunas decisiones fascinantes, desde su mezcla de humor y crimen, inevitablemente ofensiva al conservadurismo mexicano, hasta el empleo de planos en contrapicada e iluminaci√≥n expresionista. Como la propia pel√≠cula lo muestra, no hay crimen perfecto, pero este no est√° mal.', 'Me encant√≥, no sab√≠a que M√©xico tiene pel√≠culas de comedia oscura con tan buen horror y menos de √©poca.
Am√© la trama sobre un hombre bueno atormentado por su propia esposa, ambos son personajazos. 
Adem√°s la fotograf√≠a noir y las actuaciones est√°n perfectas, sobre todo Arturo de C√≥rdova y Amparo Rivelles. (Hasta m√≠ abuelita los reconoci√≥ luego luego). 
Y ni mencionar ese gran final para el crimen perfecto ‚ò†Ô∏è', "A story about a man who hates his manipulative wife so much that he wants to kill her isn't exactly an original idea. I would also say that for some it may be a tough sell depending on the personal relationships they've had to deal with in their lives. There are so many ways that something like this can send the wrong message, especially if it comes across as a men vs women kind of thing. Luckily, that's not the case. 
The narrative has a pseudo Hitchcockian vibe, and the cinematography is rock solid with it's very smooth and deliberate framing. All of characters are well acted, which helps them feel authentic and believable‚Äîeven if it does feel a little‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Made in¬†Britain
Text:
After being sent to a detention centre, a teenage skinhead clashes with the social workers who want to conform him to the status¬†quo.
['The highlight of 
Made in Britain
 is a twenty-minute-long sequence set in the detention room of a juvenile assessment center. Trevor, the film‚Äôs embattled sixteen-year-old skinhead protagonist, has really gotten himself in trouble this time by first stealing cars while out looking for a job and then picking a fight with the center‚Äôs staff over lunch. A superintendent, who has probably performed this function far too often, walks in and meticulously lays out the future that is in store for Trevor if he does not mend his ways. It is as grave and absorbing a spectacle as anything found in Fred Wiseman‚Äôs 
Juvenile Court
 (1973). Even Trevor, who is generally never at a loss for words, looks stunned for a‚Ä¶ 
more', 'An institution that reduces human life to a mundane, pre-determined cycle of punishment and destitution so horrifyingly simple it can be written on a chalkboard is then shocked when someone opts to very angrily and very literally take the piss out of them.', 'There are only four walls and an entire system of institutionalization between a juvenile offender and a free life.
‚ÄúMade in Britain‚Äù continues the howling echo from its director Alan Clarke‚Äôs 1979 critique of the punishing national borstal system, ‚ÄúScum.‚Äù\xa0
By the time that ‚ÄúMade in‚Äù debuted, the borstal system had effectively dissolved in Britain. But while new youth detention centres aimed for rehabilitation instead of punishment, their inhabitants could hardly dissolve their own ingrained distrust of an abusive apparatus so simply as adopting an act of Parliament.\xa0
‚ÄúMade in‚Äù is the debut film role of Tim Roth; perhaps, one of the most seismic debuts to be expected of a young actor. As a teenage skinhead, he is the mocking‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger¬†Tides
Text:
Captain Jack Sparrow crosses paths with a woman from his past, and he‚Äôs not sure if it‚Äôs love ‚Äî or if she‚Äôs a ruthless con artist who‚Äôs using him to find the fabled Fountain of Youth. When she forces him aboard the Queen Anne‚Äôs Revenge, the ship of the formidable pirate Blackbeard, Jack finds himself on an unexpected adventure in which he doesn‚Äôt know who to fear more: Blackbeard or the woman from his¬†past.
['the lack of keira and orlando is sickening', 'The best thing to come out of this movie was "LEGO¬Æ Pirates of the Caribbean: The Video Game".', 'At least that mermaids scene still slaps.']

Title: Samsara
Text:
Filmed over nearly five years in twenty-five countries on five continents, and shot on seventy-millimetre film, Samsara transports us to the varied worlds of sacred grounds, disaster zones, industrial complexes, and natural¬†wonders.
['While undeniably beautiful, this film left a bad taste in my mouth. 
Samsara
 is a series of images, cut together in fairly rapid succession, taking the viewer on a ‚Äúglobal‚Äù tour of the ‚Äúcultures of the world‚Äù. Some images are meant to be purely aesthetically beautiful (which they are), some images are meant to be confrontational. But as these are just images, without context, and in the absence of any explicit narrative, the meaning comes from montage, and I did not care for that meaning.
Yes, there is confrontation, but there is also exploitation and exoticization. Unlike (from what I hear) 
Baraka
, 
Samsara
 concerns itself mainly with humans. The near absence of white people, except for a few shots from‚Ä¶ 
more', '‚ÄúRon, what do you want to make a movie about?‚Äù
‚ÄúShit, bro... Everything?‚Äù', 'the really astounding thing here is the amount of trust from these different cultures that it takes to make a film like this. and also the buddhist sand mandalas. in a thousand years i wouldn‚Äôt have the patience or fortitude to go through the process of making and destroying a sand mandala']

Title: The Road¬†Within
Text:
A young man with Tourette‚Äôs Syndrome embarks on a road trip with his recently-deceased mother‚Äôs¬†ashes.
['should‚Äôve been gay', 'unfortunately heterosexuality ruins everything', "I absolutely loved Dev Patel in this. He had the most development out of the three main characters and the moments that we saw the thoughts and emotions beneath his disorder were so heart-warming to me. \nPLUS THAT SCENE WHEN THEY'RE IN BED AND HE HOLDS HANDS WITH ROBERT SHEEHAN?! Too cute."]

Title: Onibaba
Text:
While her son, Kichi, is away at war, a woman and her daughter-in-law survive by killing samurai who stray into their swamp, then selling whatever valuables they find. Both are devastated when they learn that Kichi has died, but his wife soon begins an affair with a neighbor who survived the war, Hachi. The mother disapproves and, when she can‚Äôt steal Hachi for herself, tries to scare her daughter-in-law with a mysterious mask from a dead¬†samurai.
['one of the most haunting tellings of grief and\xa0the indirect effects of war. captivating as hell', 'The lesson here is to never, ever, under any circumstances, attempt to Scooby-Doo someone.', 'A movie in which the grass, the hole, and the mask are as important as the characters themselves.\nThis is a masterfully edited slow-burn directed by Kaneto Shindo. Particularly impressive are the movement in the frame and the modern twist on a traditional Japanese musical style.\nCurrently on HBO Max and the Criterion Channel, it will suck you in if you give it the chance']

Title: Wizards
Text:
After the death of his mother, the evil mutant wizard Blackwolf discovers some long-lost military technologies. Full of ego and ambition, Blackwolf claims his mother‚Äôs throne, assembles an army and sets out to brainwash and conquer Earth. Meanwhile, Blackwolf‚Äôs gentle twin brother, the bearded and sage Avatar, calls upon his own magical abilities to foil Blackwolf‚Äôs plans for world domination ‚Äì even if it means destroying his own flesh and¬†blood.
['I feel like my life can now be separated into two distinct eras: "pre-Wizards" and "post-Wizards"', 'When Avatar pulled out a gun and shot his brother I audibly went OH SHIT', 'This movie has one of the dumbest premises of all time. ‚ÄúWhat if there were nazis fighting Elves and Faeries and shit‚Äù fucking genius, pure vibe kino. More movies should use rotoscoping like this.']

Title: Animal

Title: SPY x FAMILY CODE:¬†White
Text:
While under the guise of taking his family on a weekend winter getaway, Loid‚Äôs attempt to make progress on his current mission Operation Strix proves difficult when Anya mistakenly gets involved and triggers events that threaten world¬†peace.
['I was going to say that Anya meeting the ‚ÄúGod Of Poop‚Äù was the most unhinged and glorious thing in the history of cinema.\nThat was before Yor obliterated Metal Man with the power of cosmetics.', 'Lmao talk about a shitpost in the best way imaginable. Cant believe the movie budget flexed its muscles for a poop joke. For that, respect.\xa0\nFinally, an anime movie that doesn‚Äôt require much lore or references to the mainline source that newcomers \xa0like me can get into and have a ball with. Hell, makes me wanna watch the show. I adore this hilarious ass family. This is everything I wanted from The Incredibles and Despicable Me franchises after they both ultimately become stale.', "Never in a million years would I have predicted that one of this movie's climactic plot points revolved around whether or not Anya would take a shit."]

Title: May
Text:
A socially awkward veterinary assistant with a lazy eye and obsession with perfection descends into depravity after developing a crush on a boy with perfect¬†hands.
['Adam: a yes ü§ëüò©babyü§§ im freaky as fuck üòàüëÖüî™ü©∏üí¶
May: *bites lip ü©∏*
Adam: notüò® that freakyüòêüòñ you lunatic üò±üò¨ü§Æüòí', "This movie understands loneliness a lot better than most. 
Whenever you've been alone for so long, you start to long for human touch. Some of you may have read about the scientific study at Yale that suggests that people who take frequent, long, warm showers or baths tend to be lonelier than folks who spend less time bathing and like cooler water. The scientists speculate that physical warmth, such as a shower or bath, is a form of self-therapy to restore social warmth when we're feeling isolated. I feel like the warmth from the water is ersatz for the warmth of human touch.
People who have experienced severe loneliness even start to see simple things like a handshake or a‚Ä¶ 
more", "Show and tell seems like a good activity to do at the blind children's daycare"]

Title: The Theory of¬†Everything
Text:
The Theory of Everything is the extraordinary story of one of the world‚Äôs greatest living minds, the renowned astrophysicist Stephen Hawking, who falls deeply in love with fellow Cambridge student Jane¬†Wilde.
["Undecided as to which is more offensive:
1. The implication that Hawking's work can only be understood, or even be relevant to us, an audience of normal dumb people, in how it validates or invalidates our concept of God.
2. The depiction of infidelity in which Jane's is fraught and melodramatic, to the point that mere knocking on another man's tent causes her husband to collapse into coma and never speak again (someone should do the math on this causality via montage) whereas Stephen's is seen as cute and inevitable (I mean, she's a nurse with red hair and boobs and she lets him read porn, why wouldn't he dissolve his marriage for her?)
Oh but it's oh so tasteful.", "So this is the film we give the greatest mind of our generation?
Wow.
Dull, overly sentimental, providing only soap opera insights and saying Nothing about Everything.
Performances aside, this is nothing more than manipulative, melodramatic piffle. 
And the most ironic thing is that to Jane, Stephen was more than his disease, to her it was always about the man. Too bad the film didn't follow suit.", 'What is this CBS in the morning \xa0ass bullshit?']

Title: Dog Day¬†Afternoon
Text:
Based on the true story of would-be Brooklyn bank robbers John Wojtowicz and Salvatore Naturile. Sonny and Sal attempt a bank heist which quickly turns sour and escalates into a hostage situation and stand-off with the police. As Sonny‚Äôs motives for the robbery are slowly revealed and things become more complicated, the heist turns into a media¬†circus.
['number 1 rule of bank robbery: have fun and be yourself', '70s al pacino could rob my bank any day and any night he wanted', 'the second my short king\xa0is climbing on chairs to spray paint over the cameras I knew we were golden']

Title: Maniac
Text:
Two strangers are drawn to a mysterious pharmaceutical trial that will, they‚Äôre assured, with no complications or side-effects whatsoever, solve all of their problems, permanently. Things do not go as¬†planned.
['i am trying to be more open about my mental health, something i‚Äôve spent the vast majority of my life feeling a prickly \xa0shame for. i have a panic disorder that makes my physical body think it‚Äôs 
GOING TO DIE!!!!!
 every time i‚Äôm even a little nervous, even though my brain rationally knows there‚Äôs no perceived threat. my throat closes up. i can‚Äôt breathe. i take a xanax with a trembling hand. i call my mom and she talks me down until it kicks in. i am painfully aware that i am a 23 year old woman sitting and shaking on a city curb, paralyzed by irrational fear, whimpering on the phone to her mother. i am so so so‚Ä¶ 
more', "tag yourself i'm james mantleray going temporarily blind after being kissed by dr fujita", 'they could just have emma stone sit there for the entire thing doing nothing and I‚Äôd give it the same rating']

Title: Sorcerer
Text:
Four men from different parts of the globe, all hiding from their pasts in the same remote South American town, agree to risk their lives transporting several cases of dynamite (which is so old that it is dripping unstable nitroglycerin) across dangerous jungle¬†terrain.
['Perfect movie if you want to reorient yourself on your couch and go "aaAAAaa jesus christ" every few minutes. Provokes such visceral reactions I'm aching to rewatch it with different people. (Several months apart, so my bones have time to settle between viewings.) Makes 
Uncut Gems
 look like a vacation slideshow.
While I'm here‚Äì William Friedkin's a psychopath, right? Drives me nuts that all the stories about his insane filmmaking antics genuinely result in masterpieces. Like yes, he shot a car chase in New York without a permit and fired guns on set, but out of that we got 
The French Connection
 and 
The Exorcist
. These movies should've sucked to teach us all a lesson. Real irresponsible failing on the universe's part. One (1) human belongs in a cage and it's William Friedkin.', 'jesus fucking christ', 'A cinema of madness. Pure physical detail. Damnation as a form of cinematic spectacle. Man with blood in their hands fulfilling their death wish. What for Clozout is social need, for Friedkin is self-punishment. First world crimes reimagined in a third world purgatory, an amusement park of unforgiven nature. The beauty is that everything is translated in pure action, everything a matter of another form of behavior. Among other things, this is Friedkin‚Äôs most compassionate movie, Francisco Rabal taciturn killer is the film‚Äôs heart and Bruno Kramer‚Äôs masochist banker it is clear-eyed soul.']

Title: Letters from Iwo¬†Jima
Text:
The story of the battle of Iwo Jima between the United States and Imperial Japan during World War II, as told from the perspective of the Japanese who fought¬†it.
['Clint took Spielberg‚Äôs money, tricked him and the audience into thinking he was making a Saving Private Ryan-esque No-man-left-behind O-say-can-you-see (literal) flag-waving propaganda piece, used 90% of it and made an anti-propaganda movie that criticizes all those things, and used the remaining 10% to make a personal, sorrowful, deeply moving character study on the Japanese "invaders" whom were simply young men forced to leave their families behind to die for people who believed they were doing what was right; just like us. All in the tender year of 2006.\xa0
Clint has a bigger set of balls than literally any director alive.', "one of the great war films precisely because it refuses to reduce its conflict to a couple of cheap action setpieces -- the battle for iwo jima was slow, grueling, protracted, and clint knows to spend that time on the human beings instead of the bullets -- i think it's really telling that this is among the few american WW2 pictures that portrays war crimes without narratively justifying them as 'necessary evils'. every death here is unnecessary, contingent, and lamentable -- regardless of nation or ideology, clint wants us to see all shades of the war, both the insanity and dignity.", "Letters from Iwo Jima
 begins in a state of solemn reflection. An examination of the brutality once exchanged at this iconic island. The remains of the battle are flipped through sombrely and in no time we are thrust back to their origins -- 1945, right in the thick of the coal-black soil. 
This particular battle has been explored before, but what makes 
Letters from Iwo Jima
 distinctive is its perspective and the films affiliation with it. The Japanese soldiers aren't relative, but absolute. They aren't hidden in the shadows like most war epics, but brought to light and sympathetically investigated in depth. From the coarse beaches of 1945 to the remains of present day, 
Letters from Iwo Jima
 remembers this‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Incredible But¬†True
Text:

["[Sorties France 2022 ‚Ä¢ Film #58 ‚Ä¢ 
Classement
]
Le film se passe en 2021 (G√©g√© le dit lui-m√™me), donc L√©a Drucker avait 49 ans.
√Ä la fin, elle en a 19 (selon les cr√©dits du film).
Elle a donc gagn√© 30 ans.
Sachant qu'en avan√ßant de 12 heures, elle gagne 3 jours, en passant dans le conduit sans s'arr√™ter, elle gagne 6 jours par tranches de 24 heures.
Sachant qu'elle vieillit quand m√™me d'une journ√©e dans le m√™me temps, elle en gagne en r√©alit√© 5.
En l'espace de 30 ans, il y a eu 7 ann√©es bissextiles (2000 n'en √©tait pas une). Il y a donc eu (23 x 365) + (7 x 366) = 10957 jours
10957 jours √† remonter, divis√©s donc par 5, cela nous donne 2191,4 journ√©es pour gagner 30 ans, soit quasiment six ans et donc (en arrondissant, on n'est pas √† √ßa pr√®s) = 4382 passages par le conduit.
Incroyable mais math√©matiquement vrai.", 'local man rejects absurdities of modern life, goes fishing', 'Tenet 2']

Title: A Special¬†Day
Text:

["I am speechless. 
A Special Day 
is beautiful. Marcello Mastroianni delivers his greatest performance. Sophia Loren is amazing. There's so much more to say, but I can't find the words.", "Marcello Mastroianni: I'm a queer! A pansy! A homosexual! .... A faggot!!!!

anyways he's so sexy I can't believe I didn't know he played a gay before", "Exceptional filmmaking to begin with! This is Scola at his most historically concerned and nationally impressionistic. After the historical footage, the magical flying camera introduces, through a gigantic uninterrupted sequence, a family life seemingly driven by routine which gets said routine broken by the landmark day of Benito Mussolini having an encounter with Adolf Hitler in Italian territory on the 3rd of March of 1938 (their second meeting after the 1934 encounter in Venice).
The film works extraordinarily at a large and at a small scale. Picture the macro war reconstruction conflict of Resnai's 
Hiroshima mon Amour
 (1959) with the controversial immorality of Malle's

Title: The Guns of¬†Navarone
Text:
A team of allied saboteurs are assigned an impossible mission: infiltrate an impregnable Nazi-held island and destroy the two enormous long-range field guns that prevent the rescue of 2,000 trapped British¬†soldiers.
['This used to play on TV a lot ‚Äî 
a lot ‚Äî 
and so I‚Äôve seen it in pan-and-scan, commercial interrupted, scraps and pieces. \xa0But this is the first time I‚Äôve ever sat and watched it start to finish (and on a pristine Sony 4K). \xa0Not in the top tier of this kind of film ‚Äî it‚Äôs no 
Great Escape
 or 
River Kwai
\xa0‚Äî but it‚Äôs still pretty good in fits and starts. \xa0Interestingly, the talky scenes between the action set pieces are perhaps the best thing about it, due largely to Mr. Peck and Mr. Quinn. \xa0David Niven is always a charming, welcome presence, and though he‚Äôs not at all bad, he‚Äôs really miscast here, easily ten years too old‚Ä¶ 
more', '‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in it now... Up to your neck.‚Äù
Adapted from Alistair MacLean‚Äôs novel and directed with seat-of-the-pants brinksmanship by J. Lee Thompson, this movie plods in places, rushes in others and delivers in spades where it counts - particularly in the film‚Äôs best (and best staged) scene. Here the ruthless and murky world of WWII special operations pushes past the film‚Äôs 1960‚Äôs mass-audience sensibilities and gets down to who handles the dirtiest job on a mission seemingly doomed from the outset.\xa0
Relationships are messy, tensions are high, the women are formidable and the Nazis seem to know everything.\xa0One of my all-time lazy Sunday afternoon standbys.', 'When Quentin Tarantino made 
Inglourious Basterds
, he did a lot more than just make another great film. He brought back the war adventure.
It had been a sub-genre that had laid more or less dormant for many years until he came along. Not only had he made a truly great tribute to such films, admittedly with more than just a soup√ßon of parody thrown in for good measure, but he had made a truly great example of them himself. It really did have all the elements that made the very best films of this type so enjoyable - except with a lot more violence and swearing, obviously.
I see a lot of Inglourious Basterds in The Guns Of Navarone and‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: When the Wind¬†Blows
Text:
With the help of government-issued pamphlets, an elderly British couple build a shelter and prepare for an impending nuclear attack, unaware that times and the nature of war have changed from their romantic memories of World War¬†II.
['COME BACK YOU STUPID BITCH AND GET IN THE SHELTER', "It's a flipping miracle the entire British population didn't off themselves after watching this, fucking hell.", "It's rare that I finish watching a film and have no desire to write about it or talk about it, but I'm honestly not sure what I'd say about this one that you couldn't get from simply watching it. It left me empty. It's a beautifully animated, heavily frustrating experience focused on two very cute characters that make you want to clench your fists and punch a wall due to their utterly baffling obliviousness, naivet√©, whatever you want to call it. And this is, of course, the intention of the director: to create a film that shows just how futile any preparation for a nuclear attack and fallout really is, that there's nothing one can do once the blast occurs. It's a hopeless, painful and endlessly terrifying film, but it does come highly recommended from me, so long as you're looking for a hollowing film rather than an uplifting one."]

Title: Zabriskie¬†Point
Text:
Anthropology student Daria, who‚Äôs helping a property developer build a village in the Los Angeles desert, and dropout Mark, who‚Äôs wanted by the authorities for allegedly killing a policeman during a student riot, accidentally encounter each other in Death Valley and soon begin an unrestrained¬†romance.
['To get a stronger grasp on this films ideas and intent one must first comprehend this piece of trivia: Michelangelo Antonioni's original ending was a shot of an airplane sky-writing the phrase "Fuck You, America" Venomous though it may be‚Äîand it doesn't need that last shot to drive its message home‚Äîit's a markedly seductive and inviting rendition of American socio-political structures through the lens of youthful/foreign cynicism, however patent. If the man's language is guns, you talk to him with a gun, so says a miscellaneous hippie. Antonioni's language isn't the type to end with lingering gun smoke, though watching credits roll by isn't far from it. "The audiences won't like it" MGM insisted, well, "That's the same old jive‚Ä¶ 
more', '92
""Kathy, I'm lost", I said, though I knew she was sleeping
I'm empty and aching and I don't know why
Counting the cars on the New Jersey Turnpike
They've all come to look for America"
 
Antonioni didn't like what he found, so he decided to blow it up. Not a dream, or even a nightmare, but a vastness, an emptiness of the heart and soul. A sultry, furious netherworld of countercultural ennui and institutional suppression. Two of the prettiest lead actors to ever grace a motion picture. Wasting away in the dust, making love in Death Valley, they are gorgeous and they are doomed. What a film. 
"What's your name?"
"Karl Marx."', 'With each viewing, its dramatic "weaknesses" recede and its pure cinematic beauty resonates more clearly.']

Title: Baby¬†Face
Text:

Barbara Stanwyck: I'm baby.

Use men to get the things you want!‚Äù) to go from abused speakeasy prostitute to millionaire banker mistress during the Great Depression from her real life; she even has her broke orphan character Lily Powers reference her real-life time spent as a burlesque chorus girl. There's so much subtle pain and depth to both the glee and rage she feels in overtly manipulating these men to extract the capital desires from them in increasingly humorous and ridiculous ways, and she's so‚Ä¶

Hokey ending but everything up to it is perfect. This film is to the Hays Code as that video of Limp Bizkit blowing up a boat at MTV Spring Break is to 9/11. They might not‚Äôve 
caused
 those reactions
\xa0
but in retrospect what other choice was there?', 'when i find myself in times of trouble, barbara stanwyck comes to me, speaking words of wisdom: USE MEN!!! USE THEM TO GET WHAT YOU WANT!!!']

Title: The¬†Grey
Text:
Following a grueling five-week shift at an Alaskan oil refinery, workers led by sharpshooter John Ottway are flying home for a much-needed vacation. But a brutal storm causes their plane to crash in the frozen wilderness, and only eight men, including Ottway, survive. As they trek southward toward civilization and safety, Ottway and his companions must battle mortal injuries, the icy elements, and a pack of hungry¬†wolves.
['All you need to know is that Liam Neeson calls a wolf a motherfucker and punches it repeatedly in the face.', "Revisited THE GREY with my oldest son. I don't know what it is about this movie that I find so haunting and affecting, but it remains one of my favorites. Joe Carnahan's film is BLEAK, and feels like a simple enough story about a group of plane crash survivors pursued by wolves, but there is something else at work here that I find very profound.
Perhaps the film's nihilism is masking something else; perhaps the survival story is more complicated than it seems. It is a meditation about the inevitability of death, and the different ways we choose to meet it - assuming there is any choice in the matter at all. Certain moments (such as a man sitting on‚Ä¶ 
more", "Damn, this one knocked the wind out of me. 
I expected to see a well-crafted action flick and I did. What I didn't expect was that it would be intelligent as well. The storyline isn't really original, but it's what is between the lines that makes this film extraordinary. This isn't merely a story about survival, it's also about what gives people their purpose in life. It asks questions about faith and doesn't provide any easy answers. 
At the centre of all this is Neeson's character. This is by far the best performance I have seen from Neeson. His character is burdened, on the brink of death and really doesn't have anything to live for (the reason for this only‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: The Blue¬†Angel
Text:
Prim professor Immanuel Rath finds some of his students ogling racy photos of cabaret performer Lola Lola and visits a local club, The Blue Angel, in an attempt to catch them there. Seeing Lola perform, the teacher is filled with lust, eventually resigning his position at the school to marry the young woman. However, his marriage to a coquette ‚Äì whose job is to entice men ‚Äì proves to be more difficult than Rath¬†imagined.
['i hate it when i lose my job at dipshit academy because of some good pussy', 'Deranged, mean-spirited and actually kind of hypocritical. Absolutely the work of a genius', "#Watched with
 Jack
Sternberg's dark morality play sees the juxtaposition of silent film veteran Emil Jannings and rising star Marlene Dietrich in a realistic tale of romantic obsession and its consequences. 
The Blue Angel
 traces the physical and moral downward arc of an aging, respected school professor who becomes infatuated with a lascivious dancer employed at a nightclub.
The film is shot in Sternberg's minimalist style ‚Äì to the greatest effect. It takes its time unfolding, but Sternberg knows exactly how to turn the slow buildup into the most riveting affair. His mastery behind the camera is unmatched among his contemporaries: he understands the dynamics of cinematic motion and stillness, and crafts each frame with his trademark detached, lingering takes.‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Liquid¬†Sky
Text:
An alien creature invades New York‚Äôs punk subculture in its search for an opiate released by the brain during an¬†orgasm.
['Punk cyberqueers who kill with their cunt to pokemon music', '"Come on, teach me. Are you afraid? You're right. Because they're all dead. All my teachers."
The awkward silence after Jimmy comes is a fantastic moment of cinema. This movie is a neon new wave fever dream where gender and sexuality are under assault. Outsiders and weirdos and freaks and faggots and addicts and predators converge and explode. Nothing is safe, not sex, not drugs, not fashion, not Connecticut, not fairytales, not the media industry, not the myth of New York City. Sleaze and frost, androgyny and sex, psychedelic alien sight, it's all a dirty, angsty poem inspired by a subculture that could never live up to this vision. It's about the hard lessons learned from being used and the power of vengeance through bodily empowerment/vaginal murder. Let's paint ourselves electric and embrace our orgasmic deaths.', "This film, and Dr. Caligari, are the two films that I felt the most supremely defined by in my formative years. They are the original 
'Neon Boogers'
. Liquid Sky remains one of the most visually interesting films I've ever seen and stands as a model by which I compare all movies. In this long overdue revisit I was lucky enough to see it in 35mm at Cinefamily. I noticed lots of little glowy details that may have been lost on my many vhs views. In the Q&A Production/Costume Designer Marina Levikova said that her wardrobe budget was only $500. I did the math and that's about $1200 now (that includes the cost of paying her assistants). She went around to‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: House of¬†Hummingbird
Text:
14-year-old Eun-hee moves through life like a hummingbird searching for a taste of sweetness wherever she may find it. Ignored by her parents and abused by her brother, she finds her escape by roaming the neighborhood with her best friend, going on adventures, and exploring young¬†love.
['You said you liked me.
That was last semester.
Being fourteen is full of moments and people which are transitory: The girl who once held your hand will ignore you when the new school year comes. Jumping on a trampoline in the sunlight. A death in the family. A fight with your best friend (but this won‚Äôt last forever). A mix tape, lovingly made but never gifted. Other moments will stick with you forever, like the scar behind the ear after a solo stay at the hospital. 
Set in 1994 in Seoul, against the backdrop of the Seongsu Bridge collapse, writer-director Bora Kim‚Äôs debut feature 
House of Hummingbird 
is a gorgeous, introspective coming-of-age film about the young Eunhee (an incredibly‚Ä¶ 
more', "if you don't face any existential crisis on eighth grade are you even an eighth grader", '"What's the right way to live? Some days I feel like I know, but I really don't know for sure. I just know that when bad things happen, good things happen too. And that we always meet someone and share something with them. The world is fascinating and beautiful."
how can something so beautiful make me feel so devastated??? kim bora is absolutely one to watch folks']

Title: A Lizard in a Woman‚Äôs¬†Skin
Text:
Carol Hammond, daughter of a politician, has vivid nightmares involving sex orgies and LSD. In a dream, she murders a neighbor she envies and wakes up to a real investigation into her neighbor‚Äôs¬†murder.
['Lucio Fulci‚Äôs trippy dippy giallo opens with a ravishingly colorful sex dream on surrealistic pillows before delving into a Cosmopolitan romp through psychosexual, drug-fueled hippie madness. Sleazy, surreal, and for my tastes‚Äîmost excellent.', '"What the modern movie lacks is beauty,‚Äù said D.W. Griffith, melancholy at the end of the a long career, ‚Äúthe beauty of the moving wind in the fur coat of a gorgeous woman right before she stabs her lesbian lover to death with a pen knife as two zonked out hippies watch from a balcony above.‚Äù [quote somewhat altered]
Fulci's anti-hippie, gay panic London town murder mystery is a psychedelic funhouse labyrinth of snap zooms, jump cuts, swish pans, split screens, split dogs, belfry bats and fashionable psychological mumbo jumbo. Fulci, like so many of his contemporaries, is alone a force to be reckoned with (at least when he's firing on all cylinders), but as he is here surrounded by‚Ä¶ 
more', 'Lucio Fulci Takes Acid, and Other Scary Stories to Tell at a Dark Sleazy Sex Party
Hedonistic elites run amuck, trippy sex dreams that fluctuate between drug-fueled fantasies, repressed memories, and imminent reality, and scaly lizard people that taunt you in your murderous psychedelic nightmares. This is the pinnacle of Fulci‚Äôs giallo catalogue, even if it is lighter on the gore and depravity than are his wackier outings (not lighter on 
sexual
\xa0depravity, mind you, there‚Äôs definitely no shortage of that). Instead, what sets it apart most (for me at least) is without a doubt the Alexandra Palace chase scene‚Äîthat‚Äôs some top tier giallo shit right there.
P.S. Shoutout to that bizarre giant evil goose that shows up for one brief moment and then disappears forever.
Best of: Classic Italian Horror']

Title: A Woman Is a¬†Woman
Text:
Longing for a baby, a stripper pursues another man in order to make her boyfriend¬†jealous.
['having a silent argument using book titles is something that can actually be so personal
also.. jean-paul belmondo in a turtleneck.. yeah', 'I really love the poster for this movie. the circles, the reds, the text all spaced out like that, the white background. MUAH!
The movie? Also really nice to look at. I want to know what PTA has to say about it because stylistically it is clear as day that Punch-Drunk Love was directly influenced by this. The lens flares, the wide shots, the blue suit and red dress.
It took me a while to calibrate my brain for this movie. The rhythm of any of Godard‚Äôs films is the equivalent to the song ‚Äúgecgecgec‚Äù by 100 gecs. This is the only place you‚Äôll find a 100 gecs reference in a Godard review. But my point is once things do start to click and you embrace that rhythm, everything makes a little bit more sense. I‚Äôll probably appreciate this more on a rewatch.', 'Anna Karina takes off and Belmondo turns to tell the audience, "There she goes."']

Title: Memories of¬†Matsuko
Text:
While combing through the belongings of his recently deceased aunt, Matsuko, nephew Sho pieces together the crucial events that sank Matsuko‚Äôs life into a despairing¬†tragedy.
['Greatest final 10 minutes in film history.', 'The colours shine bright, mystifying the sight. The music commands with fierceness, taking our hearing hostage. The vividly imagined set and characters, like a particularly imaginative dream, teleport us to a fairy tale. Except it is a fairy tale tragedy. The radiance of the colours and the catchy tunes try their best to act as a shield from the borderline phantasmagorical life of torment and misery that we are shown in 
Memories of Matsuko
.
Hers was a life of almost constantly undeserved pain. A string of wrongdoers and wrong decisions consistently led her down the stairs of abyss. Any hopes of positivity she experienced was often short-lived, disintegrating into dust; giving way to another quicksand of despair. She lived for‚Ä¶ 
more', '"A life isn't value by what one receives. But by what one gives."
I have been trying so hard to find a movie like 
Love Exposure
, which has been on my mind since the first day I watched it, and I finally found a movie as magical and amazing as it. Thanks to 
Mathew
 <3 You have my eternal gratitude for that Mister.
This is not just a movie, it is a journey through a woman's short and painful life and memories. In the first half hour, we enter the unique world of the film, or rather Matsuko, and we don't even notice how the rest of the time passes. Matsuko is a woman and a little girl. It actually‚Ä¶

There is no cool like Godard cool. It's in his blood. He oozes 350 coolness per second. Ask him how did he make it and he would probably blow cigarette smoke to your face.
Alphaville

Title: Berserk: The Golden Age Arc I ‚Äì The Egg of the¬†King
Text:
Guts, an immensely strong sword-for-hire, has little direction in his life, simply fighting one battle after the next. However, this all changes suddenly when he meets and is bested by Griffith, a beautiful and charismatic young man who leads the Band of the Hawk mercenary army. After Guts joins the Band and the relationship between the two men begins to blossom, Casca, the tough, lone swordswoman in the Band of the Hawk, struggles to accept Guts and the influence he has on the world around her. While the two men begin to fight together, Griffith continues to rise to power, all seemingly in order to reach his mysterious, prophesied goals. What lengths will Guts and Griffith go to in order to reach these goals, and where will fate take the two¬†men? √ó
['JUNIMATION III: REVENGE OF THE GOOFY GOOBERS
So this was another blind watch. I had no idea what it was about nor that it was actually based on a popular IP and honestly picked it up because of the solid ratings here and the cool poster.
And this was a pretty good time. Some people here say that this and the other two sequels are basically the anime crammed into three movies. What I saw narrative-wise was quite interesting. Not sure if it was enough to have me grip my seat, but I dug it. There were some lowkey 
Castlevania
 vibes that I liked. Wasn‚Äôt expecting this to be so bloody but I also liked that and how it was‚Ä¶ 
more', "My feelings on this film are practically the exact same as when I first saw it. It's enjoyable, it's fucking Berserk. But it's a lot worse than the series equivalent to it. You lose out on a ton of side character stuff, and most of the retelling of each event just arent as good as in the original.
The 2D animation is still gorgeous, but mixed in is some really bad 3D animation. In the subsequent sequels it gets much better, but in this one of just looks awful.
My favorite part was probably the duel between Griffith and Guts. It wasn't quite as good as in the original anime, but it was great to look at and a blast to watch. I also enjoy that the homoerotic undertones between Guts and Griffith is more nudging than originally. That was a good addition. Its an enjoyable film, but only if you have seen all of Berserk.", 'Anime Marches On 2023
You know, I really have a good feeling about this Griffith guy.
This is essentially a remake of the 97 series split over three films, just with a bigger budget and mediocre CGI.\xa0
How great would this have looked if they just ditched that clunky, ugly CGI and replaced it with the legitimately good 2d animation they use for half the film? Like anytime there‚Äôs not a battle happening this looks incredible! The animation pops with great backgrounds, gorgeous color, and fluid actions. But anytime a big fight starts the animation immediately dips and you‚Äôre left with something that looks like a cutscene from a PS3 game.
Now I don‚Äôt hate CGI in anime. I used‚Ä¶ 
more']

['Just so glad that Genndy is

Although I'm aware of Samurai Jack's existence and have seen the occasional clip, this is the first time I've seen anything more mature and violent from Tatakovsky, and needless to say, I'm looking forward to seeing more. The very specific style that exhibits the supremacy of 2D animation on many levels that must be seen to be appreciated, fits very well with the violence, giving it a very appealing aesthetic that feels familiar, but also rather unique. Title: So Long, My¬†Son
Text:
Two married couples adjust to the vast social and economic changes taking place in China from the 1980s to the¬†present.
["So Long, My Son
 is a film of frankness. It discusses complicated, personal topics without hesitation. Ultimately it becomes an indictment of China's one child policy, revealed subtly by showing how a lifetime of pain could have been avoided. This is a film about how life is filled with limited opportunities, with the one child policy being a metaphorical extension of that. Life is tough and endlessly tragic, silent tears are everywhere. People can carry a burden of guilt and you can waste your one life on that. In a country with a billion lives, how many are wasted? Like so many other films, 
So Long, My Son
 is about China's rapid change over the decades. In the foreground is‚Ä¶ 
more", 'Three perfect hours about how pain is inevitable and you will just have to keep on living.', 'Berlinale 2019
Di jiu tian chang (So Long, My Son)
 
"
Everything is fine
"
Despite being tired as hell in an uncomfortable cinema, three hours felt almost like nothing. If a miracle doesn't happen, this is the very defining film of the festival and one of the best pieces of the decade. Unlike two of its comrades, 
So Long, My Son
 escaped the wrath of the Chinese Chensorship and arrived safely to Berlinale; us kinophiles are truly blessed by that. Golden Bear's home must be here!
Cinematographer 
Kim Hyung-Seok
's stoic camera perfectly captures the turbulence of one Chinese lifetime and pain & survival of one Chinese community. Director 
Wang Xiaoshuai
 appears as a master of displaying repressed sorrow with a deeply emotional‚Ä¶ 
more']

ADDENDUM, 3/29/25: From here on out, If you wish to post something in the comment section, you must first go watch Webster Colcord's

Doctor Death

here
.", "Kung Fury, an 80's Miami cop who drives a Lamborghini, sports a pair of Converse Chuck Taylor sneaks, wears a bandana, travels in time, talks like Ken from Aqua's Barbie Girl song, looks like a cross between Johnny Depp from 21 Jump Street, Johnny Cage from Mortal Kombat, Ryu from Street Fighter, and Jimmy Lee from Double Dragon, has a talking dinosaur not named Barney for a partner, has in-depth conversations with King Cobra snakes, sells cordless phone systems on the side, and hits on Viking babes. So, do‚Ä¶ 
more", "And just like that, this synthy 80s movement has finally collapsed from its coked-out rejuvenation. Fun in spots but oddly insincere and fake in regards to its styling. The humor is hit or miss, the pacing is way out of wack, and the references are shockingly obvious and annoyingly prevalent. 
Danger 5

Title: Escape from the Planet of the¬†Apes
Text:
The world is shocked by the appearance of three talking chimpanzees, who arrived mysteriously in a spacecraft. Intrigued by their intelligence, humans use them for research - until the apes attempt to¬†escape.
["In order to escape one of the most hilarious franchise holes producers have ever written themselves into, screenwriter Paul Dehn came up with a clever reversal of the first film, where fan favorite talking pacifist chimps Dr. Zira and Cornelius escaped the nuclear destructive ending of the previous film via Heston's spacecraft at the last possible minute and somehow, due to some complex time travel nonsense involving shockwaves, arrive in our time (Earth 1972, where less money needs to be spent on production design and make-up) instead of us in theirs. \nWhich is at first a concept treated like a relatively goofy, occasionally sweet fish-out-of-water TV movie story about how humans react to ape astronauts who can talk and we‚Ä¶ \nmore", 'this movie with a close up of a baby chimpanzee being shot to death is rated G for General Audiences', 'Really good! Wisely spends most of the time letting us fall further in love with Zira & Cornelius which ultimately allows the ending to be surprisingly compelling. More in love with the way the movie depicts them as captives in a zoo‚Äî at times literally, but more often metaphorically.']

None of that is present here, they didn't even bother giving her a proper backstory.
She always struggled with whether her cousin was truly the Kal-El she remembered. Kara isn't some helpless damsel, she's a warrior, & a teenage girl willing to give everything for the one family member she has left. This turns her into a bystander in her own story, with no build up, no character growth, & no connection‚Ä¶

Title: Q
Text:

An out-of-work ex-con is the only person who knows the location of the monster‚Äôs nest and is determined to turn the knowledge to his advantage, but will his gamble pay off or will he end up as lizard¬†food?

This is one of my favorite monster movies AND one of my favorite casts from Carradine, Clark, and Roundtree right down to tony page and the dude who played the jerk rival to jim Carey in 
Ace Ventura:
 
Pet Detective

MICHAEL MORIARTY + LARRY COHEN = yes. All of the yes. I'm convinced Moriarty never reads a script and just makes up all of his lines as he goes along, there really is no one quite like him. Of all the grandiose pairings of directors and actors, Larry Cohen and Michael Moriarty are easily my most favorite pairing.", "There aren't enough movies about Quetzalcoatl, feathered serpent god of the Aztec pantheon, so trashmaster Larry Cohen's low budget creature feature is a welcome addition to the fold. Quetzalcoatl, or Q for short, since no-one in this movie can pronounce it, has been brought back to life in downtown NYC by cultists performing ritual sacrifices in its name. Hot on its trail are the city's finest in the form of Shepard - played with insouciant brilliance by David Carradine - and Powell; Richard Roundtree in typical take no prisoners mode. In a stroke of nonchalant detective brilliance and much to his boss's chagrin, Shephard puts two and two together, linking the recent spate of flayings with the appearance of the‚Ä¶

Title: The Turin¬†Horse
Text:
A monumental windstorm and an abused horse‚Äôs refusal to work or eat signal the beginning of the end for a poor farmer and his¬†daughter.
["This is a film of the elements. 
Between the constant wind, the need for water, the dirt and mud, and the light of small, flickering flames, this film is the sum total of reality. In the midst of all of these is the aether, the fifth element that controls movement and light. In this case, the aether is the camera, which moves fluidly about our sparse subjects and observes, yet also commands their fates in a metatextual way. The aether is Tarr's storytelling.
The wind is the uncontrollable power that sweeps away everything. It is the horse's refusal to work and the inevitability of the end. It is constant, grating, and brutal, and it drives those who attempt to move‚Ä¶ 
more", 'First Day
: Food and shelter
Second Day
: Touching, acquiring and therefore debasing
Third Day
: God watches all over you
Fourth Day
: Scarcity
Fifth Day
: Darkness and silence
Sixth Day
: Mortality
Predominant elements throughout the days
: A storm raging outside and moving everything that can be found in the air and on the ground, like trying to reach a destination, shadows, cotidianity occupying three alienated souls (two humans, one animal), a strong wind heard while outside, ghastly and scary wind sounds from the inside, repentance, mysteries unspoken, emotional detachment, water and potatoes.
Bonus feature
: Presented in the Second Day: A destructive critique to civilization throughout the centuries against authority and other godly figures attempting to establish their false omnipresence above everybody‚Ä¶ 
more', "More an experience than a film, B√©la Tarr's The Turin Horse is one of the bleakest and most depressing pieces of art I have ever encountered. And at the same time it is one of the most beautiful things I have ever seen.
Tarr's film builds on a thought, a musing (taken from the film's synopsis): 
1889. German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche witnessed the whipping of a horse while traveling in Turin, Italy. He tossed his arms around the horse's neck to protect it then collapsed to the ground. In less than one month, Nietzsche would be diagnosed with a serious mental illness that would make him bed-ridden and speechless for the next eleven years until his death. But whatever did‚Ä¶
 
more"]

Title: The¬†Raven
Text:
A magician who has been turned into a raven turns to a former sorcerer for¬†help.
['I thought I had seen this before but hadn‚Äôt. It was a amusing horror comedy directed by Roger Corman. Written by one of my favorite writers Richard Matheson ! Staring Vincent Price, Peter Lorre, Boris Karloff and Jack Nicholson shot back to back on the same set of The Terror. I loved the set design. Some might not like because it is very comical but I thought it was fun. If you haven‚Äôt seen it check it out!', "This movie is (apart from its cast) cheap and deeply silly, and it embraces both with such pride that the result is an unadulterated delight. It's so funny and so ridiculous that it's just utterly winning, and a complete pleasure to watch. It admittedly took me at least 50% longer to watch than it should have, but that wasn't because I was bored or distracted ‚Äî no no, I just had to rewind basically every Vincent Price scene, so that I could admire his line delivery and wonderful expressions all over again. 
(He's the greatest. Have I mentioned before that he's the greatest? Also, no movie has made me sadder that I just never got to just, like, hang out‚Ä¶ 
more", "People will accruately tell you that this tips that scale way too far to the silly parody vibes vs. the legitimate spooky ones of the best Corman/Price Poe adaptations (there are slide whistles, talking animals, and wizard costumes galore) but idk what to say to anyone that doesn't at least somewhat enjoy seeing Peter Lorre as an angry, treacherous little ball of revenge in a raven feather outfit trying to kill Boris Karloff as a washed up, wife-stealing sorcerer named Dr. Scarabus. Feels more like gothic horror for kids and I kinda loved hanging out with all my grandpas making funny faces at each other in their goofy outfits/elaborate castle sets. Anyone who's seen 
Targets
 will likely already be familiar,‚Ä¶ 
more"]

Title: Drug¬†War
Text:
A drug cartel boss is arrested in a raid and coerced into betraying his former accomplices as part of an undercover¬†operation.
["To's grace is replaced by a caustic bluntness more to-the-point than even the Category III films he ghost-directed for Patrick Yau in the '90s. But do not mistake this ostensible calming of form for acquiescing to Chinese censors; it instead gets one over them, mirroring the no-nonsense approach taken by police to drugs until it becomes a savage, uncompromising attack on that myopia. It's telling that, for all the planning and swift execution of the cops to put down a drug lord's operation, the generic upheaval of the final act comes out of nowhere to show how much they've missed.
And if the swooping crane shots and rapid leap of perspectives only make sporadic appearances here, what is left is‚Ä¶ 
more", 'From the beginning, it explains that this is not your typical heroic bloodshed Triad film, concerned more with codes of honor and brotherhood and the mirroring of good and evil than anything else. No, instead this is going to be a straight police procedural, with no metaphysical mumbo jumbo: "You're a drug dealer, I'm a cop. I didn't betray you, I busted you," explains Sun Honglei's Captain Zhang, and with that 25 years (at least) of Hong Kong genre convention, from John Woo's 
A Better Tomorrow
 and 
The Killer
 to To's own cop/Triad movies (
Breaking News
, 
PTU
, 
Mad Detective
, etc) is summarily dismissed.
More here
.', 'handcuffing your own corpse to a perp... metal']

Title: The Houses October¬†Built
Text:
Beneath the fake blood and cheap masks of countless haunted house attractions across the country, there are whispers of truly terrifying alternatives. Looking to find an authentic, blood-curdling good fright for Halloween, five friends set off on a road trip in an RV to track down these underground Haunts. Just when their search seems to reach a dead end, strange and disturbing things start happening and it becomes clear that the Haunt has come to¬†them‚Ä¶
['one thing about me is that i will always watch shitty horror movies instead of anything on my watchlist', 'Dig the concept, a bunch of the haunts and haunters, but the novelty of the first time I watched this (riding high after visiting several haunts) has indeed faded a bit. I am a found footage fan, and Houses October Built has a few charms (how this beat the late 2010‚Äôs craze of a haunt as a setting by a few years) to it besides the usual FF tropes that, at the time of its release, was a super saturated subgenre on its last legs.\xa0\nI still pop this in every other year, and although each time I find more about it I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôm fond of, there‚Äôs just enough here to satisfy my craving for a dumb ff‚Ä¶ \nmore', 'I would do that exact same thing to those pretentious ass white people just because they call a haunting house a "haunt".']

Title: An American¬†Crime
Text:

["First of all: Pardon my language, but I fucking hate this film. The fact that someone decided it was a good idea to make a bad movie out of one of the most heinous acts of abuse in American history, then trivialize it by not telling the story accurately; all while attempting to humanize her abusers as if they misunderstood their actions, is completely fucking offensive. Some jaded Hollywood studio executives exploited this poor girl's story to make money, or get notoriety, or whatever the fuck they thought they were doing here, and It makes me fucking sick to my stomach if I'm being completely honest. We all know there are stories like this that NEVER get told, so in‚Ä¶ 
more", 'they
1. tried to romanticize the boy who mutilated her
2. minimized events that irl were much more brutal
3. gave little depth to children who also brutally tortured her
I hate when true-crime movies do this. if you're going to make a true-crime movie, do it like "Der Goldene Handschuh" did, not like this one.
anyways, stan elliot page.', 'I need to start a list on Letterboxd called "Reasons to give up on living."']

Title: Demons
Text:
A group of people are trapped in a West Berlin movie theater infested with ravenous demons who proceed to kill and possess the humans one-by-one, thereby multiplying their¬†numbers.
["A moral lesson on why you should never ever ever accept free movie tickets from a fella dressed as a bootleg Phantom of the Opera.
So, what happens when a group of people including a duo of college class skipping ladies, a pair of yuppie yuppies, a young first love couple, a wise old blindman and his nymphomaniac companion, a gang of Class of 84 reject punks, and a mackdaddy pimp and his two ho's all get trapped in a movie theatre possessed by demons? Total fuckin' chaotic chaos, of course. What makes it even better? When they go from movie watchers, to demon green gooze ooze possessed. God bless, the Italians!
Lamberto Bava in the director's chair. Dario Argento‚Ä¶ 
more", "Takes place almost-entirely in a cinema and invokes the power of cinema narratively, because ultimately this is a movie that relies on being identified as cinema for cinema's sake. To be specific, nothing happens in this movie for any other reason than for the sake of being cool, cinematically. Metal masks that turns its wearers into pustulent ghouls? Demons erupting from the putrid flesh of the infected? A music video segment where a himbo and his gf ride on a motorcycle as he slashes through these hordes from hell with a... katana?? None of this shit makes sense, and thankfully it doesn't have to; it knows that as long as it invokes its tropes with sufficiently associative film-making, the content thusly explains itself to us. And just to make sure we understand, it lays its rules out to both us and the characters on-screen, within the screen. The ending is where cinema finally breaks free.", "just when you think this can't get any better mans got a motorbike and a samurai sword."]

Title: Save¬†Yourselves!

Title: Memories
Text:
In this anime anthology, a salvage ship crew happens upon a haunted vessel in ‚ÄúMagnetic Rose‚Äù; a cold tablet turns a lab worker into a biological weapon in ‚ÄúStink Bomb‚Äù; and an urban populace carries on an endless war with an unseen foe in ‚ÄúCannon¬†Fodder.‚Äù
['Magnetic Rose - *****
Stink Bomb - ***
Cannon Fodder - ****
End credits techno theme - **********', 'Magnetic Rose
Memory so powerful it overrides the limits of humanity and is conferred form posthumously, but only because these memories are dark and tainted and zealous and warped. They grow beyond the human they were meant for and become a simulacra; however, a simulacra of a human is just that and cannot itself be a human. It is stuck, without the capacity to move on, yet cursed to an endless existence. Time loses all meaning when one cannot either change, or die. And so it becomes a melancholic black hole, sucking in those it lures to its horizons to the same fate where memories can become so much more, yet paradoxically become nothing at all. It is only beautiful‚Ä¶ 
more', "A film comprised of 3 short, yet powerful, stories, all of which beautiful in their own right. The detailed aesthetic and animation add flavor to the mesmerizing world-building we are treated to, all backed by various toned gorgeous themes.
Magnetic Rose stands out among the rest as the most emotionally taxing story. It's as haunting as it is beautiful. An unnerving journey through the depths of space and the horrors and games memories can play on the mind. 
Stink Bomb is almost satirical in nature. What should've been one mans glory quickly turned into a failure of misconduct and a misunderstanding of ones intent with a new found power. It plays as a cautionary tale in the art of strength‚Ä¶

Title: The Last¬†Exorcism
Text:
After years of performing ‚Äúexorcisms‚Äù and taking believers‚Äô money, Reverend Marcus travels to rural Louisiana with a film crew so he can dispel what he believes is the myth of demonic possession. ['I lost it at "Blowing Job". ü§£‚õìÔ∏è‚úùÔ∏è
The Last Exorcism follows a disillusioned evangelical minister who agrees to take part in a documentary designed to expose exorcism as a fraud.
For me, this is more than just a movie about a minister debunking the practice of exorcism as it also focuses on the fact why conservative Christians would rather have a priest performing rituals than go to a medical professional for at least a second opinion. And this attitude prevails not just among Christians but among people of all religious backgrounds too with the highest concentration of the population being conservative or living in backward/rural areas with limited access to or knowledge of modern science and amenities. See whenever someone‚Ä¶ 
more', 'I THOUGHT I KNEW WHAT THIS MOVIE WAS AND THEN THE LAST TEN MINUTES HAPPENED WHAT THE FUCK', 'Wow, I mean, this movie has a lot of great reviews, many calling it one of the best found footage movies, and for my money, I have to pretty much agree. Personally, I think that the fact that the camera people were supposed to be shooting a documentary made the movie not have all the obnoxious shaky camera effects. While the camerawork isn't excellent in this movie, you can tell there was some thought put into it. I personally enjoyed many of the staging work and how many of the scenes were executed in a way that never reaches the level of sheer brilliance found in "The Conjuring", but it kind of does in a cheap way.
Also, the story‚Ä¶ 
more']

Title: The¬†Fits
Text:
While training at the gym, 11-year-old tomboy Toni becomes entranced with a dance troupe. As she struggles to fit in, she finds herself caught up in danger as the group begins to suffer from fainting spells and other violent¬†fits.
['When we are there when nothing else is.
When we are not there when everything else is.
When we are not, what is where we were? 
What stands or moves in, in its place?
The Fits, more than any other movie I think I have seen, knows what it is like to be alone or nearly alone in institutional spaces when no one else is there, when the building has been closed or is winding down its operations for the day or if parts of it have been abandoned recently or all human activity moved to another area. It knows that is a form of haunting, of what was immediately present now gone, having left artifacts scattered in its wake‚Ä¶ 
more', "Holy shit??? 
I could leave it at that and it'd honestly be a perfect summation of my thoughts on this but alas this film deserves better. What a great piece of filmmaking. Every aspect is demanding your attention leaving you hypnotized 15 minutes in, if not sooner. Now I could be alone on this, but you have absolutely no clue what's going on for most of the time. But thanks to the score, cinematography, and performance by Royalty Hightower (honestly one of the best performances I've seen in a long time) you never feel uninvested. 
Some of the pieces came together by the end, or at least it felt like they were. Despite what feels like a downward spiral that if anything moves further away from answers as time goes on, there's a feeling of liberation in the end. Do I know why? Still getting there. But I felt it and that's all that matters. I think?", 'me during every single shot: A SHOT']

Title: Lovesong
Text:
Neglected by her husband, Sarah embarks on an impromptu road trip with her young daughter and her best friend, Mindy. Along the way, the dynamic between the two friends intensifies before circumstances force them apart. Years later, Sarah attempts to rebuild their intimate connection in the days before Mindy‚Äôs¬†wedding.
["i'm really floored by how good this was... i wasn't expecting something this striking. so beautiful in the most simplistic ways. natural, and quiet. love shown in glances more often than actions (similar to movies like moonlight, and carol) the sting of heartbreak in the awkward spaces in between: casual conversations, group interactions. the tragedy of love when it exists, but isn't acknowledged. the stomach churning reality of it. pure longing. i don't usually write serious reviews but this truly deserved more than a one liner from me. my heart hurts", 'yes the rumors are true i love suffering', '"But you left."
"Sorry that I didn't stay."
I love this movie.
Mindy and Sarah have that type of relationship where they don't need words because they speak in a language made out of glances and touches. This movie is about the fear of ruining a meaningful friendship and losing an important person, about love that is so complicated that one might not even try because the outcome seems to be so obvious.
I find it fascinating how the two of them see marriage as an escape, as a way of avoiding and confronting their real feelings. I love how Mindy's mom seems to have known Sarah ever since she was a teenager and how her opinion on Mindy's fianc√©‚Ä¶ 
more']

review
, in which I decided not to address Zahler's alleged "garbage politics," as outlined
